I'm really torn on what to think of this book. On the one hand it's clearly been very diligently researched and is the result of a lifetime's worth of study. It may rely heavily on secondary literature, but it pulls from a wide range of books and tries to offers something that no other work has attempted. On the other hand it's full of unsupported assumptions and some highly misleading statements that diminish its value dramatically.Some of these false statements are the result of poorly worded sentences. The book feels like every paragraph's stuffed with as much detail as humanly possible and this can lead to confusion. This is especially true in the first chapters where it tries to deal with Roman warfare thematically but is frequently unclear about the era being discussed. We go from discussing procedures from the fourth century then back to the second and then to the sixth. These chapters are absolutely crammed with background material in a very confusing manner. For example, he will refer to an earlier point only with "See above" or a later one with "See below" without including page numbers or any easy way of locating the issue being discussed. If you're reading this book it's probably best to regard this as a reference section and just start the book with the main narrative.Not every questionable statement can be attributed to this overstuffing though. Many come from the author's unquestioning faith in any and all sources. He distrusts basic source criticism and his stated procedure is to believe every source implicitly, unless disproven by another source or archaeological study. The section on various barbarian groups is particularly prone to this, including details from the sixth century or later to describe events in the third and fourth centuries as if, unlike the Romans, barbarian groups were stable and unchanging in all aspects. At one point he actually uses sources from the 11th-14th centuries to describe Nubian kings in the 3rd century, even attributing their adoption of these customs to the exact year 298. I realize that part of the reason he relies on these sources is an absence of material from earlier periods, but that limited data means that you have to be extra careful and critical of every single piece of evidence you use. Instead he charges in as if there are no issues of reliability. If two sources say completely different things then he must find a way to keep both of them true. Only if he can't pull off this feat does he present both statements and argue for one. Occasionally he doesn't even do that.A big part of this problem comes from the choice of publisher. There's nothing wrong with Pen & Swords books, but they serve a different audience from academic literature. You can't stuff these books full of references or include in-depth discussion on historiographical concepts. For that reason, we have no way of knowing where he gets many of his statements from. There are a total of 382 footnotes in a 435 page book. That's less than a footnote a page. So if you want to know, for example, what primary sources he was relying on for those Nubian kings I mentioned earlier you're out of luck. His entire argument seems to be based around the fact that they used Greek names in their titles, which can obviously only be a compelling argument if those names come from non-Greek sources. The Byzantines would naturally be expected to translate foreign titles into their native Greek, and I suspect that's exactly what we're seeing due to the fact that the titles given are exactly correct and not Arabic or Ge'ez-inflected versions. The point is that I have no way of knowing. You just have to take his word on it, and as the book went on I found myself less and less willing to do that.And then there are the wildly unsupported assumptions. For example: "Persian rulers always learnt of a Roman invasion within twenty-four to forty-eight hours from the time the invasion occurred regardless of where they were in the vast empire" (p. 128); "Ardashir modelled most of his administration after the Achaemenid model"; "Muslim military organization was based on Hellenistic Greek practices" (p. 134); "Heruls were warrior berserks!" (p. 85); etc. These statements are common and extreme. I can't get over the Muslim one. How on earth does he propose this reliance on Hellenistic military organization was to have developed more than 650 years after the last such kingdom fell? And how can we know the Sassanians based their administration on the Achaemenid one when we can't even show that they knew of their existence not to mention their structure? For that matter, how would we even recognize it if they did given our extremely sparse data for the internal organization of both states? It's these sorts of comments that lost my tolerance of his other errors. When it states so definitively this many inaccurate or misleading facts a book becomes positively dangerous.By the time you get to the narrative (which is after all the core of the book) you're getting quite tired of these problems. As this is the author's area of focus you might expect these problems to diminish here. Unfortunately, only the overstuffed paragraphs go away. The other flaws are there in force. He relies heavily on the Historia Augusta for third century events (most notably arguing for the early existence of the limitanei and magister officiorum), despite more than a century's worth of studies showing that it's a late fourth century forgery (but that's source criticism, his hated bugbear). Worse still, he cites 12th century Byzantine sources as evidence for 3rd century army titles (specifically the obviously anachronistic tagmata), and uses John Lydus' (6th century) antiquarian musings as if they describe in perfect detail the army structure as it existed for a brief period under Gallienus. Why Gallienus? Because for any other period we have too much information showing that Lydus was being anachronistic (as he often was).Here more than anywhere we see his tendency to trust any and every source carried to its logical extreme. The numbers given in classical sources are questionable at the best of times, but he trusts even the least reliable ones. For example, he's quite certain that over 300,000 soldiers took part in the battle of Chrysopolis and gives similar numbers for Constantine's campaign against Maxentius. As to Germanic tribes he believes they were similar in scale. 150,000 for the Goths of the 4th century is a conservative(!) estimate, he suggests, based on Procopius' description of the later Ostrogothic kingdom of Italy.  In practice of course, he doesn't think they used armies larger than 70-100,000 men because Germanic armies didn't have a proper logistical network beyond having each soldier bring some supplies with him. I would really love to know how an army of 100,000 men could function in the field without a supply network and yet not starve to death in under a week. Living off the land is a lot harder for a large army than a small one.And then come the bizarre conclusions that are given no attribution or justification. For example, he claims that Ballista was sent with a  fleet by Gallienus to fight the Persians (p. 161); that Maximian was a notorious simpleton and most of the Germanic invasions under the tetrarchy were a result of his sexual depravity (p. 192); that Galerius' promotion was really a coup and Severus "undoubtedly" had orders to assassinate Maximian if he resisted (p.224); that Constantine recreated the tetrarchy (p. 293); that Julian was a literal psychopath who secretly murdered his wife and children (p. 381); and many other random ideas. These statements are positively damaging to anyone reading the book because unless they know better they'll assume he has some foundation for his statements. This isn't even a question of gullibly repeating sources verbatim, which at least provides information that's useful to know, it's inventing conclusions that don't match any facts. Here's where the footnoting problem really comes in. Footnotes keep you honest. Being able to do without them has sapped the value of what had the potential to be a truly amazing reference book by allowing unsupportable assertions to be thrown around without question. Could he have justified any of these wild assertions? Maybe not, but he could at least have shown us what he was basing his conclusions on.Is this book of value to anybody? Despite it's myriad flaws there is some use to it as a straight narrative history of the later Roman Empire from a specifically military point of view. An appropriately skeptical reader should be able to recognize most instances where the book strays from history into wild speculation. For example, when he starts proposing a historical basis for the Da Vinci Code you can probably tell the discussion need to be taken with an entire shaker of salt. If you're not planning to use this book as a source for anything it's probably safe enough. The maps are excellent and his diagrams and photos help with visualizing a sometimes inaccessible period. But on the other hand, the completely invented facts can throw someone really off if they're not already aware of events. If you're interested in history then don't these facts matter? And if you have to double check every fact then what's the point of it?A book like this that provides a detailed narrative of late Roman history for a wider audience is necessary and useful so I have to applaud the author for attempting it, even if it isn't what it could have been. No such book currently exists, although David Potter's The Roman Empire at Bay does a good job for this period and Peter Heather's The Fall of the Roman Empire covers the fifth century west well. I just wish that this book had lived up to the potential in its topic.

For those who don't know what these books are (ie. most people who aren't Russian) you're looking at the dry scholarly tomes of a mathematician who decided he didn't care for the minor role of Russia in ancient and early medieval history and decided that this meant all history must be all wrong. Now I'm not dissing the Russians here. These ideas were rightly dismissed by Russian experts decades ago and, except for the occasional eccentric mathematician and celebrity, they receive little attention now. That's why he's searching for a new audience: his books have sold just about as much as they ever will in Russia. Time to release them in English. Because if there's one thing an English audience loves reading it's Russian propaganda.These books are a statistician's attempt to combat established history using page after endless page of charts and diagrams in the hope that people won't actually check through all these figures. At twenty-two volumes in length it's a fairly safe bet, even though these books are extremely short (65 pages by my count, though he claims 350). But what's really amazing is how little digging it actually takes to find the repeated and obvious errors in his work. The man is so certain that he must be right that he sees no problem with forcibly altering the facts to fit his "theory" or accepting huge margins of error when seeking a parallelism.You don't even have to wait for the book to begin for the errors to creep in. The title alone presents a false dichotomy. Fiction or Science? As if those are the only two options. And I have no doubt that Fomenko does indeed see it that way given his haughty dismissal of anything even loosely connected to the Arts. History is too close to the Arts and must be purged of anything that isn't a string of exact, quantifiable numbers. All similar number strings must be combined into the same string, and any "facts" or "historical personages" attached to those numbers must be purged as well. Nice, clean math. But it's more disturbing than just that. These books are a vast horde of Russian nationalic propaganda. Apart from ridiculing any non-Scientists (AKA those unqualified to form proper conclusions) the main goal of these books is to establish that Russia ruled all the world from North America through Europe into China and the Middle East, and they did so for most of recorded history. So his two assumptions about the world are:1. All Non-Scientists are either liars or idiots.2. Everything in the world originated in Russia.One of these two assumptions is underlying every single one of his conclusions. He treats his random and unsupported speculations with just as much respect as ones that have been established through years of research backed by hard evidence. All Arts and Humanities subjects are regarded as worthless as sources of information and aren't even worth mentioning unless to state (not argue or prove) that they are wrong.And now the history of the world as outlined in this book: History begins when Andronicos Comnenos dies and becomes Jesus. History records him as an unsuccessful Greek emperor with no real successes who was beaten to death by the mob and not a poor prophet from Nazareth who was crucified but hey, what do they know. It's not like the crucifixion was an important part of the story or anything. Immediately all of Europe decides that they're Christian and march against the Muslims. It may sound confusing why they'd blame the Muslims for what was an internal coup but they were probably just confused because Mohammed wasn't born yet. At some point they changed their minds and decided to skip the first three crusades and jump straight onto the Fourth (except that they didn't. It was actually the same as the First. Obviously. Please try and keep up). They then sacked Constantinople which was also Rome which was Troy which was Jerusalem. At some point they get confused and occupied the Holy Land as well and then forget all about Constantinople and let it fall back to the Greeks since Jerusalem was now Constantinople which was Troy which was Rome. People back then had very short memories often forgetting why they did something before they even did it. This is probably due to their lack of statisticians. During the First Crusade the Greeks decide to avenge the kidnapping of their queen by... also sacking Constantinople. After sacking their own city they quietly vanish for a few years, probably in embarrassment. Some time later Erasmus wrote the New Testament confusing generations of scholars who wondered what they had been copying out for all that time. Having now written a New Testament it was decided that they needed an Old one. I'm sure the reasons for the reversed order are as obvious to everyone else as they are to Fomenko. Some time in the 15th Century David rose up, except that he was Turkish and ruled in Constantinople. Despite the many wars with the Turks Europe had never warred with the Turks and accepted all of these events as holy writ. After all, the Turks were really Russian in funny hats and the Russians ruled the world. The Byzantines were secretly ruling in England. After the death of Solomon (Suleimon) the Jews split off from Christianity because they were tired of not being persecuted because of something they didn't do and decided that being hunted by the Inquisition was more fun. In the confusion the Catholics and Orthodox Christians split apart as well because everyone else was doing it and it seemed a good idea at the time. They were to regret this later when the Catholics sacked their city but that had already happened so it was fine.It turns out that Russia has dominated the world since the earliest recorded history (what a shock!). The Mongols were not from Mongolia because the people there are nothing but worthless servants of the Russian Empire (it's ok. Fomenko assures us that the Mongols never knew of Genghis Khan until some pesky monks told them that they used to rule the world). Russia was actually the major Empire that the Romans were based off of and has existed since the dawn of civilization. Silly Georgians thinking they are anything but the personal property of Russia! Ha ha. They also controlled America, Europe and North Africa by 1300 so I guess that we should all submit to the Russian yoke as is our hereditary duty. Occasionally a czar would allow the governors of Europe (kings hah!) to wage war on each other if they pleased him. Presumably the English sucked up to him better than France which is why they did so well in the Hundred Years War but then lost his favor again which resulted in the French winning. Joan of Arc was probably the czar's sister or something. The czar could summon anyone to his court and they had to obey which is why Moscow is renowned the world over as being filled with better artwork and architecture than such dives as Paris and Rome (which isn't the REAL Rome after all). After Russia fell in the 1600s (through internal troubles. No one could EVER conquer Russians) the rest of the world immediately conspired to hide that they ever existed lest they should try to rule over them again. Thus they erased this empire from the history books and replaced it with such lies as Rome and the Holy Roman Empire (couldn't they even pick a new name? Obvious!). Thus the treacherous Romanovs rose to power (did I mention that he first published this under the Soviets?) and they too decided to forget there had ever been a Russian Empire of such a scale. Many "Roman" documents are simply Russian ones with a few name changes. Latin is merely a corrupted form of church Slavonic, despite bearing no similarity to that language. The Russians probably invented it to confuse future generations of schoolkids. They had after all had it engraved all over the southern part of their empire on specific styles of buildings which they immediately buried and built medieval cities on top of to confuse archaeologists. It never showed up in Russia itself. Perhaps they punished the provinces by making them write everything in Latin. Oh those cruel Russians. After the late 18th Century things begin to return to what is normally called history.As you can see it is far less confusing than the 'conventional' timeline. You might think I'm making this up but that is what you get when you put all his history together. Minus the sarcasm perhaps.Here we're up against an interesting change. Rather than rewriting European history Fomenko feels like taking on Chinese history, with amusing results. His conclusion? Those of you following along can probably guess this but: Russian. All Russian. Just like every other civilization on the face of the planet. How are people not more grateful to Mother Russia? No wonder Putin looks permanently angry. China was, like the rest of the world, ruled by Russia until the sixteenth century. At this point the great Russian Empire dissolved and East and West split off to form their own different governments and yet all agreed on a uniform policy of covering up their shared Russian past. Nope, no logical problems with that conclusion!So how are East and West to be united? Fomenko cites Morozov who made the ingenious observation that if Chinese names are but translated they lose their foreign flavor. It's an amazing revelation that changes everything we thought we knew about world history. It's almost enough to make one believe that a book translated out of, say, Russian could lose its obviously Russian appearance. But I dunno, that seems a little far-fetched. I'm pretty sure I could still tell based on the terrible spelling and grammatical errors. What this means in practice is that Fomenko is now able to translate more accurately original Chinese works despite not knowing any Chinese. That's how he knows that the phrase Chinese Empire is actually to be translated as Mediterranean Empire. His intuition is just that good. Once you recognize that the Chinese Empire is in fact the Mediterranean Empire you immediately realize that the three kings he mentions next must in fact be Diocletian and the tetrarchs. Of course, there were four of them and none of them were known as the Clear and Passionate, the Literary, or the Great, but that's obviously only a minor difficulty in this line of argument. This conclusively and forever proves that the Chinese in fact had no history of their own but simply copied and pasted it from Mediterranean history, just as the British did.I'm just going to summarize briefly Chinese/Roman history for people so that they can better understand it. That European history and Chinese history is identical is a fact often remarked upon. Actually, it's never been remarked upon, but let's not let that stop us. This identical history is because Chinese history is just European history given different names. The years match exactly with European ones. Roman history started when Sulla founded the Empire in "83 B.C.". Some people have in fact pointed out that nobody in the history of the world has ever claimed that, but according to Fomenko it's the accepted date and therefore he must be correct because he are being so clever. This is obviously a parallel for the foundation of the Han dynasty, only 57 years earlier according to Fomenko, which is of course essentially the same date. It's only two generations' worth of people after all. Practically the previous day. Certainly it's much closer than the 119 years that "conventional" history books would place between them. These two empires continue until the third century where they both fall to invaders from the north and internal problems. Sure, Rome doesn't actually fall during this time period, but that's a minor technicality. Now, both empires experienced a renewal in the 260s with Rome starting its Third Empire at this time and China entering the Jin dynasty. Nitpickers might point out that the division of the Roman Empire into three parts is something that Fomenko made up, or that no Roman Empire fell at this time, or that the recovery of the Empire is properly dated to Diocletian in 283, or that the Jin dynasty only ruled a part of China and was filled with constant wars, but these are obviously unimportant details. What matters is that they were identical in every way. Similarly, to point out that Eastern Jin was the continuation of the Western Jin empire while Eastern and Western Rome were two parts of the same is pedantic, just as it is to point out that this happened more than sixty years before the permanent division of Rome. And then of course, we have to go right to the fall of the Western Roman Empire in 476, which is obviously the same as the fall of Eastern Jin in 420, only 56 years off so the dates are getting closer all the time! And then China and Rome stayed collapsed forever, never to rise again. The End.I'd criticize this book more for its distortion of Chinese history, but more than with any other period it's clear that Fomenko has absolutely no understanding of this history to begin with. All we see of Chinese history is brief snippets excerpted from other authors' works and superficial comparisons like the one above. Chinese history is clearly wrong because Fomenko knows it's wrong, and doing the research to actually prove this would take valuable time away from explaining how amazing Russia was.

And I have no doubt that Fomenko does indeed see it that way given his haughty dismissal of anything even loosely connected to the Arts. History is too close to the Arts and must be purged of anything that isn't a string of exact, quantifiable numbers. All similar number strings must be combined into the same string, and any "facts" or "historical personages" attached to those numbers must be purged as well. Nice, clean math. But it's more disturbing than just that. These books are a vast horde of Russian nationalic propaganda. Apart from ridiculing any non-Scientists (AKA those unqualified to form proper conclusions) the main goal of these books is to establish that Russia ruled all the world from North America through Europe into China and the Middle East, and they did so for most of recorded history. So his two assumptions about the world are:1. All Non-Scientists are either liars or idiots.2. Everything in the world originated in Russia.One of these two assumptions is underlying every single one of his conclusions. He treats his random and unsupported speculations with just as much respect as ones that have been established through years of research backed by hard evidence. All Arts and Humanities subjects are regarded as worthless as sources of information and aren't even worth mentioning unless to state (not argue or prove) that they are wrong.And now the history of the world as outlined in this book: History begins when Andronicos Comnenos dies and becomes Jesus. History records him as an unsuccessful Greek emperor with no real successes who was beaten to death by the mob and not a poor prophet from Nazareth who was crucified but hey, what do they know. It's not like the crucifixion was an important part of the story or anything. Immediately all of Europe decides that they're Christian and march against the Muslims. It may sound confusing why they'd blame the Muslims for what was an internal coup but they were probably just confused because Mohammed wasn't born yet. At some point they changed their minds and decided to skip the first three crusades and jump straight onto the Fourth (except that they didn't. It was actually the same as the First. Obviously. Please try and keep up). They then sacked Constantinople which was also Rome which was Troy which was Jerusalem. At some point they get confused and occupied the Holy Land as well and then forget all about Constantinople and let it fall back to the Greeks since Jerusalem was now Constantinople which was Troy which was Rome. People back then had very short memories often forgetting why they did something before they even did it. This is probably due to their lack of statisticians. During the First Crusade the Greeks decide to avenge the kidnapping of their queen by... also sacking Constantinople. After sacking their own city they quietly vanish for a few years, probably in embarrassment. Some time later Erasmus wrote the New Testament confusing generations of scholars who wondered what they had been copying out for all that time. Having now written a New Testament it was decided that they needed an Old one. I'm sure the reasons for the reversed order are as obvious to everyone else as they are to Fomenko. Some time in the 15th Century David rose up, except that he was Turkish and ruled in Constantinople. Despite the many wars with the Turks Europe had never warred with the Turks and accepted all of these events as holy writ. After all, the Turks were really Russian in funny hats and the Russians ruled the world. The Byzantines were secretly ruling in England. After the death of Solomon (Suleimon) the Jews split off from Christianity because they were tired of not being persecuted because of something they didn't do and decided that being hunted by the Inquisition was more fun. In the confusion the Catholics and Orthodox Christians split apart as well because everyone else was doing it and it seemed a good idea at the time. They were to regret this later when the Catholics sacked their city but that had already happened so it was fine.It turns out that Russia has dominated the world since the earliest recorded history (what a shock!). The Mongols were not from Mongolia because the people there are nothing but worthless servants of the Russian Empire (it's ok. Fomenko assures us that the Mongols never knew of Genghis Khan until some pesky monks told them that they used to rule the world). Russia was actually the major Empire that the Romans were based off of and has existed since the dawn of civilization. Silly Georgians thinking they are anything but the personal property of Russia! Ha ha. They also controlled America, Europe and North Africa by 1300 so I guess that we should all submit to the Russian yoke as is our hereditary duty. Occasionally a czar would allow the governors of Europe (kings hah!) to wage war on each other if they pleased him. Presumably the English sucked up to him better than France which is why they did so well in the Hundred Years War but then lost his favor again which resulted in the French winning. Joan of Arc was probably the czar's sister or something. The czar could summon anyone to his court and they had to obey which is why Moscow is renowned the world over as being filled with better artwork and architecture than such dives as Paris and Rome (which isn't the REAL Rome after all). After Russia fell in the 1600s (through internal troubles. No one could EVER conquer Russians) the rest of the world immediately conspired to hide that they ever existed lest they should try to rule over them again. Thus they erased this empire from the history books and replaced it with such lies as Rome and the Holy Roman Empire (couldn't they even pick a new name? Obvious!). Thus the treacherous Romanovs rose to power (did I mention that he first published this under the Soviets?) and they too decided to forget there had ever been a Russian Empire of such a scale. Many "Roman" documents are simply Russian ones with a few name changes. Latin is merely a corrupted form of church Slavonic, despite bearing no similarity to that language. The Russians probably invented it to confuse future generations of schoolkids. They had after all had it engraved all over the southern part of their empire on specific styles of buildings which they immediately buried and built medieval cities on top of to confuse archaeologists. It never showed up in Russia itself. Perhaps they punished the provinces by making them write everything in Latin. Oh those cruel Russians. After the late 18th Century things begin to return to what is normally called history.As you can see it is far less confusing than the 'conventional' timeline. You might think I'm making this up but that is what you get when you put all his history together. Minus the sarcasm perhaps.Here Fomenko has to face the enormous problem that other forms of evidence pose to his "theories". He enjoys focusing on maps but coins are the real killer. Most of his supposedly nonexistent kings printed coinage in their own name which is both unique and localized to the region where they ruled. Fomenko mostly deals with this by, you guessed it, ignoring it. Even in the book that is supposed to be dedicated entirely to it. What he does instead is focus entirely on Russian coinage while ignoring other nation's coins and the fact that they are remarkably concentrated in the very areas that he claims constantly changed names. To the extent that he does confront this issue he focuses on side problems, like the fact that coin portraiture is generally similar or that they didn't generally provide dates until fairly recently. And he spends a surprising amount of time justifying his chronology's existence and making it look like the history of the subject isn't one of utter failure but in fact a growing consensus. And you can join in! Only $6.95 a shot! What a bargain!

For those who don't know what these books are (ie. most people who aren't Russian) you're looking at the dry scholarly tomes of a mathematician who decided he didn't care for the minor role of Russia in ancient and early medieval history and decided that this meant all history must be all wrong. Now I'm not dissing the Russians here. These ideas were rightly dismissed by Russian experts decades ago and, except for the occasional eccentric mathematician and celebrity, they receive little attention now. That's why he's searching for a new audience: his books have sold just about as much as they ever will in Russia. Time to release them in English. Because if there's one thing an English audience loves reading it's Russian propaganda.These books are a statistician's attempt to combat established history using page after endless page of charts and diagrams in the hope that people won't actually check through all these figures. At twenty-two volumes in length it's a fairly safe bet, even though these books are extremely short. The main argument in this book is that all Crusades, mass migrations, or great wars are the same eternal conflict. We can all see the absurdity of imagining that more than one world war could occur. Such a laughable thought! He also starts to do some construction work on his new chronology. For example, he's now decided that the Roman Empire dated from the 10th to 11th centuries and was located in Egypt before moving north to Constantinople (12th-13th centuries) and then north yet again to Moscow (14th-17th centuries). Ever closer to perfection in other words. The Romans buried their corpses in pyramids before moving them to the Valley of the Kings. This is why all the hieroglyphics refer to Roman events and use Roman names and are written in Latin. Can you imagine how crazy it'd look if that wasn't true? It'd be like he was making it all up! How can you even argue with such persistent madness? It's obvious that this doesn't make any sense, but facts just glance off his determined march towards a glorious Russia festooned with glory and world conquest.

You might think I'm making this up but that is what you get when you put all his history together. Minus the sarcasm perhaps.Ah, England. I knew he'd get here eventually. So, having seen how Fomenko likes to distort his facts we can legitimately wonder what method he'll use here to "obliterate" all the data we have. Will he invent dozens of insane theories and treat them as "legitimate possibilities" to cast doubt on the accepted version? Will he cite historians of doubtful value as if they are the accepted resources on the topic and then lie about being the first to see this? Or will we just get another string of lists? If you guessed all three: Congratulations! You win a free prize, which since all prizes look essentially the same to an impartial observer you've already received years ago but didn't realize it was actually a reflection of this one. Too bad.So, might as well do these in order. The first one is a bombardment as you might expect. He's trying to create as much confusion as he can so that when he finally does start laying out "facts" you're more prone to believe him. So a few of his claims: Armenia is Romania ie. Byzantium; Britain is actually in Albania (=Albion) which is in the Byzantine Empire and therefore Byzantium; Mt. Sinai is Vesuvius; Herculanium and Pompeii are Sodom and Gomorrah; New Troy=Old Troy=Byzantium=Rome=London; the English word island is actually Asia-land (because in the old days nobody had heard of vowels) and can therefore mean basically anything; Brutus was Julius Caesar; the Scots are Russian; the Britains were Prussians; the Welsh are Turks; the English are the Angeloi (a short-lived Byzantine dynasty that saw Constantinople sacked by the crusaders, except of course that the English are also the crusaders); the Irish language is actually Russian (because Irish without vowels is RSH which sounds like RSS, which is Russian without vowels); etc. I'm gonna just quote an example of how hard he works to connect everything together. "Today the name of the 'London river' is Thames. But because all these events are happened in the East, we need to remember that here some people read the text in opposite direction: from the right to the left (in Europe: from the left to the right). The word SOUND (= strait) without vowels is SND and after opposite reading is DNS. Because D and T were sometimes equivalent, and the same is valid to M and N, we see that the following conjecture (equivalence) is possible: DNS = TMS, i.e. 'sound' = 'Thames'." Why, that's not confusing at all is it? No siree, I'd sure be glad to see him finally step in and make sense of that!The second technique is also used amazingly here. He uses the normally reliable Anglo-Saxon Chronicle, but also Nennius and Geoffrey of Monmouth, who he calls Galfridus Monemutensis because Russian translators can't bother to translate names out of Latin (which was really corrupted church Slavonic anyway and not an actual language despite having its own vocab and sentence structure, so it doesn't matter). For those not in the know, these last two are accounts of King Arthur and are mostly fictitious. "Nennius" is called on occasionally (he's one of our only sources for Sub-Roman Britain, meaning the 5th and 6th centuries) but never relied on exclusively or even trusted. Geoffrey is just historical propaganda and English myth, written to please the new Norman overlords of Britain. Nobody cites him seriously except as an example of this. Despite that, Fomenko states that "In fact, these texts form a basis for modern concept of old and medieval English history." Where does he even consider medieval English history to end? Only one copy of the Anglo-Saxon Chronicle was updated after 1079. After this God knows what his sources were.Which brings us to his third method. So again we are confronted with a massive list of kings. Here we're confronted immediately with a problem: there was no king of England until the time of Edward the Elder in the 10th century. Fomenko deals with this the way he deals with all data that doesn't match his preconceptions: he ignores it. The chart starts with Cenwalh (king of Wessex) and Theodosius I. If you have to ask why you obviously haven't paid attention to his previous works. It's because he says so. And right away we have a non-match. Unbelievable. By his own math Theodosius I ruled for 16 years while Cenwalh ruled for 29. How can he consider this a match?!? That's almost twice as long! It ends with Justinian and Egbert, who are at least slightly similar, although bizarrely he cuts Justinian's reign in two because 553 was the highpoint of his reign. I think. Or as Fomenko puts it, he "became unique [ie. sole?] emperor in Roman-Byzantine empire. He ruled during his last 12 years without any corulers." A very odd comment to make because he ruled his first 26 years without any co-rulers too. In between these two figures are three kings unmatched by anyone on the Byzantine side, but he dismisses that because they had short reigns. Err, why should people making fake king lists add in short-reigned kings instead of just making up numbers? Oh right, because the charts don't work unless they did. And here again we see the most grievous problem Fomenko continually runs into: his numbers don't match. As in, in a chart of only eight matching kings only three of them match with less than a fifteen percent margin of error. That's according to his own numbers, which are frequently wrong (although closer here than in his Roman section). A match of less than a decade (or more if he feels like it) is considered definitive proof that kings are in fact the same people, this when the average reign of the monarchs listed here is 17.6 years.At this point his list falls apart even worse so he compensates by moving kings around. Oh yes, he can do that. Didn't you know? People in the past were so mindbogglingly unoriginal that they couldn't invent new numbers (though obviously they were experts at new names) and so simply mixed the dates around. The fact that this allows him to mess with the king lists as he wills is merely a happy coincidence. The best bit is that the kings being moved around are a father and his four sons. So two sons get to rule before their father and two after. As he sees it, this is obviously THEIR error as all the names look alike to him. It never ceases to amaze me how all these people are just interchangeable names and numbers. To repeat: two sons have been moved into position before their father to make Fomenko's job easier. At this point we see why Fomenko has messed with this list the way he has: it's so that Alfred the Great lines up with Heraclius. Two kings famous for driving back invaders threatening their kingdoms. Of course they must be identical! But I'm going to ignore here the fact that Alfred's campaigns against the Vikings led to the establishment of the first permanent pan-English kingdom that grew under his successors while all of Heraclius' achievements against the Persians were brought down when the Arabs took over most of his reconquered Empire. Instead I'm going to focus on his predecessors. The men ruling before him were his father and his brothers. His immediate predecessor was his brother Aethelred who died after being wounded in battle against the Vikings. This man is paired up with Phocas, one of the demons of Byzantine history, who murdered the emperor Maurice and started the decades-long Persian war that was to dismember the Roman Empire. Two more different figures could not be conceived, yet Fomenko would have you believe that they're the same person based solely on the fact that Phocas' reign was only two years longer than Aethelred's. Incredible. At least with earlier figures he at least TRIED to make their lives match. This sort of incongruity goes on for a while and then we jump forward 210 years in the Byzantine line while continuing on in the English one. At this point it's hardly even worth pointing out the silliness of all this. The last thing I will say is that he frequently gets the names wrong, especially the English ones. The most glaring example is that first king of the United Kingdom wasn't Jacob, it was James. So incredibly sloppy.And we're given a special little treat here as well. Fomenko treats us to more linguistic discussion. Yay! So, the dating of the Anglo-Saxon Chronicle was (following on from Bede) in A.D., or Anno Domini (in the year of our Lord). But not so, says Fomenko, for he knows this as the Year of Grace, apparently the Russian formulation of the term. And obviously the Russian term should supersede the Latin term being used, even when the text in question was written in Latin for a Latin-speaking audience (as Bede was). So why does this matter? Because obviously Year of Grace is still too precise! Why, what if it actually meant year of the Greeks instead? So to repeat, we are told that the Russian equivalent of a Latin term is in fact the correct one and that therefore the term used in the document itself in fact means what it means in Russian and not what it says it means in the language being used. We are then treated to a discussion of words that look similar to that Russian one and told that this means that in fact the imagined Russian Year of Greeks must be what was meant by In the Year of the Lord. I'm including an entire paragraph that follows on from this conclusion because I feel it demonstrates decisively how hard he's struggling to problematize what is in actuality a very simple concept:"Maybe the original (and forgotten today) meaning of a formula "Years of Grace" differs from one which is accepted today. Maybe it was "years in Greece", "Greek years" or something like this. It is possible also that there is a relation between terms Grace, Greece and Christ. Was the name of Christ associated in some sense with a name of country "Greece"? For example Christ religion = "Greece religion"? It might be because in medieval epoch Greece was a name of Byzantine empire, and another it's name was Romea, Rome. So Christian, "Roman" religion could be called also as "Greek religion"; but if so then there might be a confusion between "A.D.", "Christ" era and old "Greek", Byzantine era which was used sometimes, as well as "A.D.", with it's thousands omitted. It could be not obvious which era was actually used in an old documents which indicate "Years of Grace"." Yikes. It just goes to show that the only way his work can make any sense is if you assume that nobody before the 18th century actually knew how to count.The main conclusion he draws from all of this is that the English were actually the Byzantines. Ignore the fact that they wrote in Old English and had Germanic and occasionally Celtic names, they were Byzantine and wrote in Greek and had Greek names. There was in fact only one period of history covering all these times, the one known as 1040-1327 in England and 1143-1453 in Byzantium. The two other periods (640-830/830-1040 English, and 378-553/553-830 Byzantine) are simply reflections of this period. That's why the English kingdom fell twice, once in 830 at the height of Wessex's power and again in 1040. I guess William was a little slow to arrive. Ignore the fact that the few parallels he finds between English and Byzantine rulers in each individual period don't line up with the other periods. That is merely a distraction. It just shows that people have been altering the facts to make their past seem more distinguished. As he's clearly the expert on doing that I defer to his judgement here.

For those who don't know what these books are (ie. most people who aren't Russian) you're looking at the dry scholarly tomes of a mathematician who decided he didn't care for the minor role of Russia in ancient and early medieval history and decided that this meant all history must be all wrong. Now I'm not dissing the Russians here. These ideas were rightly dismissed by Russian experts decades ago and, except for the occasional eccentric mathematician and celebrity, they receive little attention now. That's why he's searching for a new audience: his books have sold just about as much as they ever will in Russia. Time to release them in English. Because if there's one thing an English audience loves reading it's Russian propaganda.These books are a statistician's attempt to combat established history using page after endless page of charts and diagrams in the hope that people won't actually check through all these figures. At twenty-two volumes in length it's a fairly safe bet, even though these books are extremely short (less than a hundred pages to this one by my calculations, though it claims it's 290. What good's pseudohistory unless it's ripping you off as well?). But what's really amazing is how little digging it actually takes to find the repeated and obvious errors in his work. The man is so certain that he must be right that he sees no problem with forcibly altering the facts to fit his "theory" or accepting huge margins of error when seeking a parallelism.You don't even have to wait for the book to begin for the errors to creep in. The title alone presents a false dichotomy. Fiction or Science? As if those are the only two options. And I have no doubt that Fomenko does indeed see it that way given his haughty dismissal of anything even loosely connected to the Arts. History is too close to the Arts and must be purged of anything that isn't a string of exact, quantifiable numbers. All similar number strings must be combined into the same string, and any "facts" or "historical personages" attached to those numbers must be purged as well. Nice, clean math. But it's more disturbing than just that. These books are a vast horde of Russian nationalic propaganda. Apart from ridiculing any non-Scientists (AKA those unqualified to form proper conclusions) the main goal of these books is to establish that Russia ruled all the world from North America through Europe into China and the Middle East, and they did so for most of recorded history. So his two assumptions about the world are:1. All Non-Scientists are either liars or idiots.2. Everything in the world originated in Russia.One of these two assumptions is underlying every single one of his conclusions. He treats his random and unsupported speculations with just as much respect as ones that have been established through years of research backed by hard evidence. All Arts and Humanities subjects are regarded as worthless as sources of information and aren't even worth mentioning unless to state (not argue or prove) that they are wrong.And now the history of the world as outlined in this book: History begins when Andronicos Comnenos dies and becomes Jesus. History records him as an unsuccessful Greek emperor with no real successes who was beaten to death by the mob and not a poor prophet from Nazareth who was crucified but hey, what do they know. It's not like the crucifixion was an important part of the story or anything. Immediately all of Europe decides that they're Christian and march against the Muslims. It may sound confusing why they'd blame the Muslims for what was an internal coup but they were probably just confused because Mohammed wasn't born yet. At some point they changed their minds and decided to skip the first three crusades and jump straight onto the Fourth (except that they didn't. It was actually the same as the First. Obviously. Please try and keep up). They then sacked Constantinople which was also Rome which was Troy which was Jerusalem. At some point they get confused and occupied the Holy Land as well and then forget all about Constantinople and let it fall back to the Greeks since Jerusalem was now Constantinople which was Troy which was Rome. People back then had very short memories often forgetting why they did something before they even did it. This is probably due to their lack of statisticians. During the First Crusade the Greeks decide to avenge the kidnapping of their queen by... also sacking Constantinople. After sacking their own city they quietly vanish for a few years, probably in embarrassment. Some time later Erasmus wrote the New Testament confusing generations of scholars who wondered what they had been copying out for all that time. Having now written a New Testament it was decided that they needed an Old one. I'm sure the reasons for the reversed order are as obvious to everyone else as they are to Fomenko. Some time in the 15th Century David rose up, except that he was Turkish and ruled in Constantinople. Despite the many wars with the Turks Europe had never warred with the Turks and accepted all of these events as holy writ. After all, the Turks were really Russian in funny hats and the Russians ruled the world. The Byzantines were secretly ruling in England. After the death of Solomon (Suleimon) the Jews split off from Christianity because they were tired of not being persecuted because of something they didn't do and decided that being hunted by the Inquisition was more fun. In the confusion the Catholics and Orthodox Christians split apart as well because everyone else was doing it and it seemed a good idea at the time. They were to regret this later when the Catholics sacked their city but that had already happened so it was fine.It turns out that Russia has dominated the world since the earliest recorded history (what a shock!). The Mongols were not from Mongolia because the people there are nothing but worthless servants of the Russian Empire (it's ok. Fomenko assures us that the Mongols never knew of Genghis Khan until some pesky monks told them that they used to rule the world). Russia was actually the major Empire that the Romans were based off of and has existed since the dawn of civilization. Silly Georgians thinking they are anything but the personal property of Russia! Ha ha. They also controlled America, Europe and North Africa by 1300 so I guess that we should all submit to the Russian yoke as is our hereditary duty. Occasionally a czar would allow the governors of Europe (kings hah!) to wage war on each other if they pleased him. Presumably the English sucked up to him better than France which is why they did so well in the Hundred Years War but then lost his favor again which resulted in the French winning. Joan of Arc was probably the czar's sister or something. The czar could summon anyone to his court and they had to obey which is why Moscow is renowned the world over as being filled with better artwork and architecture than such dives as Paris and Rome (which isn't the REAL Rome after all). After Russia fell in the 1600s (through internal troubles. No one could EVER conquer Russians) the rest of the world immediately conspired to hide that they ever existed lest they should try to rule over them again. Thus they erased this empire from the history books and replaced it with such lies as Rome and the Holy Roman Empire (couldn't they even pick a new name? Obvious!). Thus the treacherous Romanovs rose to power (did I mention that he first published this under the Soviets?) and they too decided to forget there had ever been a Russian Empire of such a scale. Many "Roman" documents are simply Russian ones with a few name changes. Latin is merely a corrupted form of church Slavonic, despite bearing no similarity to that language. The Russians probably invented it to confuse future generations of schoolkids. They had after all had it engraved all over the southern part of their empire on specific styles of buildings which they immediately buried and built medieval cities on top of to confuse archaeologists. It never showed up in Russia itself. Perhaps they punished the provinces by making them write everything in Latin. Oh those cruel Russians. After the late 18th Century things begin to return to what is normally called history.As you can see it is far less confusing than the 'conventional' timeline. You might think I'm making this up but that is what you get when you put all his history together. Minus the sarcasm perhaps.Here's where Red Dawn unexpectedly arrives. Yup, the good old USA was once a part of Russia. Didn't you know that? Apparently we were Russian until 1775 when the Russian wars between the Romanovs and Pougachevs split their empire (299). And Native Americans? Figments of our overactive imaginations. They never existed. The people who occupied America (or at least western America) were the Russians. And the proof of that is that the geography of the west was vague in the Encyclopedia Britannica of 1771. Were you expecting more proof? Well you don't get any. Apparently there is no other conceivable reason why the west would be unknown except that there was a great empire keeping people away. Nope, no other possible reason. I figure that this is part of his sinister agenda to give Russians the right to run casinos on American soil. After all, they're the REAL Native Americans yet we give privileges to all these phoneys.The rest of the book attempts to tie the American Revolution in to revolts in Russia. Despite generally accepting that post-17th century history is more or less accurate Fomenko decides that, well wait actually no it isn't because otherwise Russians can't claim to have controlled the US. So once again he throws history to the wind, complete with thoroughly dateable and identifiable documents, in favor of his own wild theories. Again, all of this is based on the fact that European maps of the west coast of America were rather spotty. I really want some of whatever he's smoking!

Minus the sarcasm perhaps.By the third book focusing exclusively on Russian history you may be starting to catch on to the idea that maybe making Russia look great is the purpose of this entire series. Congratulations: you can recognize patterns. Fomenko seems to think he's the only one capable of this. So this book continues to tell his story of Russian history. The Byzantines (Russians) collapsed unexpectedly from the fallout of that whole Jesus thing and each state immediately established its own version of history, which they nonetheless managed to keep separate and internally consistent. In Mongolia (Russia) the Horde (Russians) were disorganized and took years to recover from this. Although, as the center of all human civilization, they still managed to receive Byzantine empresses in marriage. Oh, and all European nobility is descended from Augustus. A random claim about a man whose entire line died out within a few generations but whatever.I'm not even going to bother going into too much depth here. Unless you know a lot of Russian history you won't know who I'm talking about anyway. Suffice it to say that every early Russian ruler was in fact one of the great Mongolian khans, starting with Georgi (Genghis). Tedious stuff for me, but maybe a Russian historian would find it more entertaining. This is actually as far as I'm going with the Russian ones. No fewer than seven of these books (almost a third) are detailing Russian history, and while that's fine and dandy for a Russian nationalist pseudohistorian it's pretty boring for someone outside Russia.

You might think I'm making this up but that is what you get when you put all his history together. Minus the sarcasm perhaps.To repeat what I said in my last review: Russian history is not my forte so I can't go as in-depth as I would like on the nonsense. Still, he has given plenty of examples to show us how he operates and we can see them all on display here. The most honest quote in this novel comes while introducing his hypotheses. Right up there at number one: "Russia has never been conquered by any foreign invaders." Why is that the preeminent conclusion? Because that's what he wants to believe and therefore what he shall believe. For that reason all foreign words or peoples are to be given a Russian etymology. Mongolia for example, is merely a derivative of the Russian word mnogo, or "many." The Greek word for great also comes from this term. The Mongolian word yurt (tent) comes from the Cossack words orda (horde) or rod (clan). How are they even similar to that word and why do they mean such different things? Moving on peoples! Czar's etymology is not explained (it actually comes from Caesar) but they are equated with the Khans. God, this ignorance is painful!But really, this is my favorite quote in the whole book: "The readers must become accustomed to the uncommon concept that geographical names would drift from place to place in the Middle Ages; this process had only stopped with the invention of the printing press and the mass production of uniform books and maps, which had naturally led to the 'solidification' of the names used for nations, cities, rivers and mountains." It is indeed an uncommon concept. And why must we accept it? Because without doing so the entire "theory" becomes mush! As they say, extraordinary claims require extraordinary proof, which is why the fact that he doesn't bother is just so laughable. There is no suggested method by which this extraordinary and constant shifting of names could take place, nor is there any reason to take his word for it when he offers no proof to the contrary! What a waste.

Russia was actually the major Empire that the Romans were based off of and has existed since the dawn of civilization. Silly Georgians thinking they are anything but the personal property of Russia! Ha ha. They also controlled America, Europe and North Africa by 1300 so I guess that we should all submit to the Russian yoke as is our hereditary duty. Occasionally a czar would allow the governors of Europe (kings hah!) to wage war on each other if they pleased him. Presumably the English sucked up to him better than France which is why they did so well in the Hundred Years War but then lost his favor again which resulted in the French winning. Joan of Arc was probably the czar's sister or something. The czar could summon anyone to his court and they had to obey which is why Moscow is renowned the world over as being filled with better artwork and architecture than such dives as Paris and Rome (which isn't the REAL Rome after all). After Russia fell in the 1600s (through internal troubles. No one could EVER conquer Russians) the rest of the world immediately conspired to hide that they ever existed lest they should try to rule over them again. Thus they erased this empire from the history books and replaced it with such lies as Rome and the Holy Roman Empire (couldn't they even pick a new name? Obvious!). Thus the treacherous Romanovs rose to power (did I mention that he first published this under the Soviets?) and they too decided to forget there had ever been a Russian Empire of such a scale. Many "Roman" documents are simply Russian ones with a few name changes. Latin is merely a corrupted form of church Slavonic, despite bearing no similarity to that language. The Russians probably invented it to confuse future generations of schoolkids. They had after all had it engraved all over the southern part of their empire on specific styles of buildings which they immediately buried and built medieval cities on top of to confuse archaeologists. It never showed up in Russia itself. Perhaps they punished the provinces by making them write everything in Latin. Oh those cruel Russians. After the late 18th Century things begin to return to what is normally called history.As you can see it is far less confusing than the 'conventional' timeline. You might think I'm making this up but that is what you get when you put all his history together. Minus the sarcasm perhaps.I have to admit, this era is not my specialty. I know very little about medieval Russian history once we get past the Rus Vikings. That said, by this point it doesn't even take much background knowledge to see his silly tricks at work. His two possible approaches are: 1. Take an already questioned fact and then "disprove" it, claiming that he was the first to do this and implicitly casting doubt on the intelligence of all before him. 2. Take an established fact and then propose a nonsensical alternate theory with no proof or justification and treat it as if the two theories are approximately equal in plausibility. For example, this quote on a Byzantine mosaic: "The word 'Mongolia' is written in Greek as 'Mugulion', or 'Megalion', which translates as 'The Great'. This confirms the hypothesis that the words 'Mongolia' and 'Megalion' are derived from the Russian word 'mnogo' ('many'), or 'mnogo' + 'vel' ('great')." The actual transcription is Mougoulion, or 'of the Mongols'. There is no Megalion in the mosaic, nor is that an actual Byzantine Greek word. The real word would be Megala, which this clearly isn't. Megalon would be the plural genitive. As for the rest of the etymology, do I even need to point out how ridiculous it is? Vowels aren't just interchangeable you know. Or the fact that the assumption is and remains that Russia was the progenitor of all things. Classic Fomenko.Once this has been done he can start throwing random speculation around as certain truths and claiming that any date, personality, or symbol is in fact identical to every other date, identity, or symbol. For example, did you know that the octagonal star is a uniquely Christian symbol? And that its presence on a Mongol authority tablet proves that they were in fact Russian Christians? By the same reasoning the Nazis must have been Indians since the swastica is an Indian and East Asian symbol of old standing. Again, I know little of Russian history, but I've seen enough of his unsupported allegations to know that this isn't the book to go to if you want to actually learn it.

For those who don't know what these books are (ie. most sensible non-Russian adults) you're looking at the dry scholarly tomes of a mathematician who decided he didn't care for the unimportance of Russia throughout ancient and early medieval history and decided that this meant all history must be all wrong. Now I'm not dissing the Russians here. These ideas were rightly dismissed by Russian experts decades ago and, except for the occasional eccentric mathematician and celebrity, they receive little attention. That's why he's searching for a new audience: his books have sold just about as much as they ever will in Russia.These books are a statistician's attempt to combat established history using page after endless page of charts and diagrams in the hope that people won't actually check through all these figures. At fifteen volumes in length it's a fairly safe bet, even though these books are extremely short (this one's only about 138 pages long, though it claims to be 418). But what's really amazing is how little digging it actually takes to find the repeated and obvious errors in his work. The man is so certain that he must be right that he sees no problem with forcibly altering the facts to fit his "theory" or accepting huge margins of error when seeking a parallelism.You don't even have to wait for the book to begin for the errors to creep in. The title alone presents a false dichotomy. Fiction or Science? As if those are the only two options. And I have no doubt that Fomenko does indeed see it that way given his haughty dismissal of anything even loosely connected to the Arts. History is too close to the Arts and must be purged of anything that isn't a string of exact, quantifiable numbers. All similar number strings must be combined into the same string, and any "facts" or "historical personages" attached to those numbers must be purged as well. Nice, clean math. But it's more disturbing than just that. These books are a vast horde of Russian nationalic propaganda. Apart from ridiculing any non-Scientists (AKA those unqualified to form proper conclusions) the main goal of these books is to establish that Russia ruled all the world from North America through Europe into China and the Middle East, and they did so for most of recorded history. So his two assumptions about the world are:1. All Non-Scientists are either liars or idiots.2. Everything in the world originated in Russia.One of these two assumptions is underlying every single one of his conclusions. He treats his random and unsupported speculations with just as much respect as ones that have been established through years of research backed by hard evidence. All Arts and Humanities subjects are regarded as worthless as sources of information and aren't even worth mentioning unless to state (not argue or prove) that they are wrong.And now the history of the world as outlined in this book: History begins when Andronicos Comnenos dies and becomes Jesus. History records him as an unsuccessful Greek emperor with no real successes who was beaten to death by the mob and not a poor prophet from Nazareth who was crucified but hey, what do they know. It's not like the crucifixion was an important part of the story or anything. Immediately all of Europe decides that they're Christian and march against the Muslims. It may sound confusing why they'd blame the Muslims for what was an internal coup but they were probably just confused because Mohammed wasn't born yet. At some point they changed their minds and decided to skip the first three crusades and jump straight onto the Fourth (except that they didn't. It was actually the same as the First. Obviously. Please try and keep up). They then sacked Constantinople which was also Rome which was Troy which was Jerusalem. At some point they get confused and occupied the Holy Land as well and then forget all about Constantinople and let it fall back to the Greeks since Jerusalem was now Constantinople which was Troy which was Rome. People back then had very short memories often forgetting why they did something before they even did it. This is probably due to their lack of statisticians. During the First Crusade the Greeks decide to avenge the kidnapping of their queen by... also sacking Constantinople. After sacking their own city they quietly vanish for a few years, probably in embarrassment. Some time later Erasmus wrote the New Testament confusing generations of scholars who wondered what they had been copying out for all that time. Having now written a New Testament it was decided that they needed an Old one. I'm sure the reasons for the reversed order are as obvious to everyone else as they are to Fomenko. Some time in the 15th Century David rose up, except that he was Turkish and ruled in Constantinople. Despite the many wars with the Turks Europe had never warred with the Turks and accepted all of these events as holy writ. After all, the Turks were really Russian in funny hats and the Russians ruled the world. The Byzantines were secretly ruling in England. After the death of Solomon (Suleimon) the Jews split off from Christianity because they were tired of not being persecuted because of something they didn't do and decided that being hunted by the Inquisition was more fun. In the confusion the Catholics and Orthodox Christians split apart as well because everyone else was doing it and it seemed a good idea at the time. They were to regret this later when the Catholics sacked their city but that had already happened so it was fine.It turns out that Russia has dominated the world since the earliest recorded history (what a shock!). The Mongols were not from Mongolia because the people there are nothing but worthless servants of the Russian Empire (it's ok. Fomenko assures us that the Mongols never knew of Genghis Khan until some pesky monks told them that they used to rule the world). Russia was actually the major Empire that the Romans were based off of and has existed since the dawn of civilization. Silly Georgians thinking they are anything but the personal property of Russia! Ha ha. They also controlled America, Europe and North Africa by 1300 so I guess that we should all submit to the Russian yoke as is our hereditary duty. Occasionally a czar would allow the governors of Europe (kings hah!) to wage war on each other if they pleased him. Presumably the English sucked up to him better than France which is why they did so well in the Hundred Years War but then lost his favor again which resulted in the French winning. Joan of Arc was probably the czar's sister or something. The czar could summon anyone to his court and they had to obey which is why Moscow is renowned the world over as being filled with better artwork and architecture than such dives as Paris and Rome (which isn't the REAL Rome after all). After Russia fell in the 1600s (through internal troubles. No one could EVER conquer Russians) the rest of the world immediately conspired to hide that they ever existed lest they should try to rule over them again. Thus they erased this empire from the history books and replaced it with such lies as Rome and the Holy Roman Empire (couldn't they even pick a new name? Obvious!). Thus the treacherous Romanovs rose to power (did I mention that he first published this under the Soviets?) and they too decided to forget there had ever been a Russian Empire of such a scale. Many "Roman" documents are simply Russian ones with a few name changes. Latin is merely a corrupted form of church Slavonic, despite bearing no similarity to that language. The Russians probably invented it to confuse future generations of schoolkids. They had after all had it engraved all over the southern part of their empire on specific styles of buildings which they immediately buried and built medieval cities on top of to confuse archaeologists. It never showed up in Russia itself. Perhaps they punished the provinces by making them write everything in Latin. Oh those cruel Russians. After the late 18th Century things begin to return to what is normally called history.As you can see it is far less confusing than the 'conventional' timeline. You might think I'm making this up but that is what you get when you put all his history together. Minus the sarcasm perhaps.This book is more of the same. Unsubstantiated assertions stated with complete confidence and any event that bears even a passing similarity gets combined with every other. Two Gulf Wars? How absurd. Clearly those and the war in Syria are all reflections of the same conflict. A proxy war between Russians and Americans? Must be the same one. Afghanistan, Syria, Korea, and Vietnam are surely the same thing. After all, they're all notoriously hot, with only a 25% margin of error.And for that reason we see the Gothic War against Theodoric and the war to overthrow Tarquinius Supurbus merged into one (A great claim here incidentally: Tarquin spelled backwards [phonetically] is Neukrat, which is probably connected to Novgorod. Of course, he's not using the Latin form of the name [Tarquinus, or Suniwkrat] and he provides no reason why anyone would write their name backwards or why the tyrant Tarquin would have the name of a city, but clearly that's incidental to his main point; which is that if he throws enough nonsense at you eventually some of it might stick). Both Servius Tullius and Theoderic were the last kings to die before their kingdom fell after all, and they were very similar. Except of course, that being the second to last king isn't a very strong connection. And actually Theoderic was in reality the first of about seven kings (depending on how you count them), not the second to last. And every successful king issues reforms if you really think about it. And Theoderic's reforms were wiped out when his kingdom was destroyed while Rome flourished in part because of Tullius' reforms. Actually, apart from the fact that they were both successful kings who had both at least been to the city of Rome (even if only once in Theoderic's case) I can't see many connections with them. But that's not the point, because they're otherwise so similar. Like in the way the Romans overthrew Tarquinius Supurbus. That's just like the way the Byzantines... conquered the Goths in a series of battles. Or the way the war continued for years and only ended when the invaders gave up all attempts to conquer the kingdom. Err, or when they took it over entirely and drove the Ostrogoths from Italy. Hmm. I'm starting to actually see more similarities with the Iraq War.Even odder, we see both these wars merged with the Nika revolt, which took place just before the Gothic War and therefore shouldn't even be open to parallelism according to his "theory" since they were both recorded by the same author, who surely wouldn't be copying himself. This is particularly odd when you consider that the Nike Revolt was exactly that: a revolt, while the other two were genuine wars.And then yet a third merger as all these conflicts are equated with the Trojan War. Because after all, a giant ten-year siege is exactly the same as a series of setpiece battles. Honestly, is it the word war? Is that what they all have in common (with a 25% margin of error)? Because that's the only similarity I can see here. But I'll just end this discussion with a direct quote from his brilliant novel: "Since both wars are but phantom reflections of one and the same real medieval war, they must resemble each other". I think that sums up pretty well his operating methods and basic principles.Honestly, there are far too many absurd claims and logical fallacies here to even list them. Every page is dripping with them. I'm simply repeating the best.
