This isn't a bad book. It's also not a good one. In fact, it seems aggressively mediocre, as if deathly afraid of doing something that might possibly mean something for any of the main characters. I say characters, but I just mean Luke. He's the only one who shows up here except for a brief appearance by Leia and, oddly, Ackbar. I can't say there's a single awful moment, but there aren't any really good ones either.In fact, the entire book reads like a series of side quests. The first third of the book is a sidequest unrelated to the main plot. The remaining two thirds is one brief adventure after another, none of which build on each other or have any real effect on future missions. In fact, the big dramatic escape at the end is resolved in one line that says that the main chase is over, instead of actually building on the drama of whether they made it or not. And again, even the main plot is generally unimportant on either a personal or galactic level.The big draw of this book is hearing an entire story told from Luke's perspective. It's less effective than you might think. Luke just doesn't have the sort of charming cynicism of someone like Han or even Leia. In fact, he doesn't have much of anything. Inasmuch as there is any cohesive character drama it's about Luke's daddy issues, which alternate between feeling really obvious and somewhat implausible. I could believe Luke being interested in what his father did, but his curiosity waxes and wanes depending on the author's mood. It would have been far better if the book had focused on Luke's insecurities (daddy issues being one among many) rather than just sort of half-heartedly acknowledging them. Some of the character dialogue is awfully stilted too. Can anyone really imagine Luke saying Thats an extraordinary feeling, if you dont mind me saying. How did you come to hold it?I can't really say I'd recommend this book to anybody who wasn't a diehard fan. It's not even of much use as a resource for finding out more about the new canon since, while it is new canon, it was already commissioned under old canon and hastily reworked. Of all the books released thus far this is by far the weakest. Still, it's fairly harmless and inoffensive as such books go. And if that's all you're in the mood for thenn it might work for you. Just don't go in expecting Shakespeare.

Tarkin is the second book in the new canon of Star Wars novels, and the first genuinely good one. A New Dawn, for all its various merits, failed repeatedly to live up to its potential as an adventure novel or a character piece. With Tarkin we can see a bit more of what the Lucasfilm Story Group has planned for this universe. That, for me, is one of the chief thrills of this book.James Luceno is an author who has been on my watchlist for years as one of the best Star Wars writers to never really have an unreservedly good novel. His books have to me seemed consistently better than their subject matter since his area of focus always seems to be periods of little interest. Who really wanted to see the background negotiation behind the trade regulation conflicts that lead up to the Phantom Menace? And the less said about the NJO the better. But despite the subject matter his books were always an easy read, and I've been waiting for the day when he found himself writing on a subject worthy of him. And finally he has in what is technically his first Star Wars novel in the new continuity.Tarkin is a book that's miles better than it should be. Wilhuff Tarkin is not a sympathetic man by any stretch of the imagination. To have an entire book devoted to him has seemed criminally wasteful to some. All the more so since this is not so much an adventure yarn as it is a genuine character study. At many points it feels almost like a biography of its subject, not a problem for me since I enjoy biographies.The main plot features a group of insurgents (not really rebels so much as terrorists) who are using advanced holonet hacking abilities/technology to sabotage and destroy Imperial outposts. The Emperor sends Vader and Tarkin to chase them down, and in so doing they form the beginning of the partnership we see in A New Hope. The secondary plot consists of Tarkin's musings on his past and the rise of the Empire. This section is focused on A LOT, and contains most of the truly interesting character moments along with a potted history of how the Empire is run and what exactly its inhabitants believe and value.The main plot's fairly weak to be honest. Or  I might better say that it's fairly simplistic and undeveloped. But that's because it really is only an excuse to allow the character study to unfold. And an excellent character study it is. Tarkin emerges from these pages as a fascinating figure who is understandable without being particularly sympathetic. While the book doesn't focus overmuch on his atrocities (apart from repeatedly demonstrating his indifference towards civilian casualties) it doesn't make the mistake of sugercoating them either. Tarkin is still that wonderfully privileged brute we saw in A New Hope, he's just provided with the background and beliefs to match it.It's not a perfect book by any means. The grand revelation about his past, saved until a conversation with Vader just before the book's climax, isn't nearly as big a deal as it's made out to be. But overall it provides a highly satisfying look at a man who doesn't generally receive a lot of attention. The look at the workings of the Empire is fascinating, as is the speculation sure to be raised about what sort of hints are being dropped about The Force Awakens. And Tarkin's personal history is truly interesting. Just don't go in expecting to see much in the way of sympathetic characters.

This is the best Final Fantasy game we've gotten in years (assuming we don't count Bravely Default). Sure, the game's already four years old but there's been nothing really good in the FF series since 2007. This breaks the losing streak. Type-0 is a brilliant game and captures the sense of wonder and awe that's been missing from recent Final Fantasies.I'm not one to gush over gameplay but this game has an excellent combat system. What's more, while I usually hate magic as a combat mechanism, the magic works really well here. There are four basic elements to combat. First is your attack. Playing as Ace (all the characters have playing card names. Don't ask) your main form of attack is to throw cards at people. It sounds lame, but it's actually really badass and effective. The second element is the shield system. You can summon shields that help protect an area from attack. This can be really useful in establishing temporary cover, although like most cover in this game the shields can be overpowered. The third element is the warping system. This is how dodging works and it's basically a really cool way of avoiding attacks and advancing quickly on your opponent. They've copied this system for FFXV and with good reason: it's really cool. The fourth element of combat is more typical: casting. You can cast spells and damage your enemies or help your allies. It's fairly standard, although the charge time is kinda cool.Type-0 is very unlike earlier games in the series for all it apes Crisis Core's combat system. The storyline is much darker and the issues it deals with more complicated. It's all very much military and mission-based and doesn't allow for the same type of roaming that other Final Fantasies offer. Actually, it reminds me more of Valkyria Chronicles in approach, particularly the documentary way the plot is advanced. But this works for the game rather than against it. The main series has been afraid to take risks of late (although FFXV seems set to change that) so a radical direction shift is a good idea. It brings this game to life and provides use with a reason to care about the storyline.The basic plot of the game is fairly familiar. Evil military dictator invades peace-loving nation intent on stealing their priceless crystal. Blah blah blah, bad things ensue. But it quickly becomes clear that this familiar situation is not going to be as familiar as we thought. The opening of the game is truly heartbreaking, following dying characters' efforts to reach their reinforcements. It's immediately apparent that this game is not going to shy away from looking at the darker side of war. To this end one of the main plot elements is that characters are forgotten as soon as they die, in line with the crystal's wishes. This has been done to avoid suffering among the survivors but it's incredibly tragic for everyone involved as they can't even remember their closest friends once they've been lost. It's kind of a crazy idea but it really works at emphasizing the loss and suffering. The game's different approach also appears in its setting. Instead of placing you as lone hero types you are merely military cadets training with the regular army. From this you get to experience life in the military rather than as the lone wolves you know you'll end up playing as in combat. It's a refreshing change and they handle it well.At some point we have to address the issue of the graphics. This is not a next gen game. It's a port of a PSP game, and a four year old one at that, so in many ways it's unfair to criticize it for its inevitable limitations. On the other hand, it's being very much billed as Type-0 HD, and that gives us cause to analyze how much that's accurate. While it is true that the graphics have been upgraded from the PSP version it is very clear that they remain very much inferior to the quality you would expect from a PS4 or even a PS2 game. I'd place it on about the FFX level, and not the remade version. The texture maps are quite obviously designed with a portable audience in mind as they appear blurred and 2D in HD resolution. Other aspects show the PSP's limitations as well. The camera controls have obviously been optimized for a system with no second analog stick, and while this does make combat easier it means that the camera controls are sudden and jerky and turn the world into a blur that makes it hard to keep track of.Does this really matter in the end? I'd argue that, for the most part, it doesn't. Type-0 isn't aiming for absolute realism but instead tries to create a vaguely Animeish world where everything is somewhat larger than life. And in that it succeeds. The game looked great on the PSP and for the most part it looks great here. The buildings are large and impressive and contain a surprising amount of detail for a PSP game. And of course, gameplay-wise graphics just don't matter unless they're so bad as to cause control difficulties. The only real problem from a graphical standpoint is that the game is inconsistent in quality. Apparently, they upped the quality of the leads by simply replacing the original models with the ones used in the the cinematics. While they are obviously not at next gen level they look acceptably detailed on the big screen for it to seem a design choice and not a flaw. For characters who never appear in cinematics they've stuck with the old models. This can be really obvious. In the opening scenes we get one soldier who never shows up in a cinematic holding hands with our lead. While Ace has smooth and articulated digits the side character's hands are just stubby rectangular blocks. Things like this make it harder to defend the 'artistic choice' argument. There's no denying that as ports go this one was lazy and superficial, particularly given the difficulties that should have been recognized in porting a portable game to a larger console, but it still works as a game.The level of detail put into all aspects of this world is pretty astounding. You can access the files in the library to find detailed descriptions of everything that's going on, from the history and background of the world to the characters inhabiting it. Unlike FFXIII this isn't essential to understanding any of the plot, but it is useful in case you forget anything or simply want more details than the main quest provides. The level designs are very impressive, even if they are quite linear. Here we run into the problem of the PSP again since levels are kept quick and are made up of many smaller areas rather than one large one that would tax the system too greatly. It's annoying but inevitable, and the load times are very good.There are two other things I adore about the game, one of which will please people and the other nobody but me will care about. First off, the music here is pretty amazing. I've been disappointed with the score of every game since X and even when they hit decent tracks it usually only shows up once or twice amid the generic ones. But this game has the best main action theme since VIII. A good action theme should make you feel like a badass even when you're facing off against minor mooks. While the rest of the music is less memorable the main theme is used in a lot of different variations throughout, all of them good. The other thing I love is that most of the names in here is Latin-based. As a latinophile I love seeing the Soldier Empire take on the Red Dominion (and their allies the Armour Alliance and the Harmony Kingdom) to prevent the time of ending. It's cool and should feel out of place in the Japanese-based world, but it really helps make the names seem foreign (to a Japanese audience as well as a Western one I imagine). And of course the music is filled with dramatic Latin chanting too. Awesome.On the whole I really loved this game. It has a great combat system and a powerful story that deals with some pretty dark issues for Final Fantasy. It feels creative and inspired and alive. If you can ignore the limitations imposed on it by the PSP system you'll find a spectacular game that really shows why Final Fantasy has been a force to be reckoned with.

This book is a brief but excellent biography of one of the most important figures of the early fifth century. Although primarily known (slanderously) as the man who invited the Vandals into North Africa Boniface was also an important figure in imperial politics, and a rare figure about whom we have contemporary evidence from his friends. This biography is probably overdue, but at the same time contains little that is astonishing or new. While we may have more information about Boniface than other figures of the time it still doesn't amount to much and the book is often forced to simply recount political events to which Boniface was only a minor participant. In so doing it always tries to show it from his viewpoint as well as can be known. The most interesting bits were the analysis of the letters Augustine sent to him. Augustine was his friend while he was a young man stationed in Africa, and while his opinion of Boniface sunk as the man meddled in power politics in later years he remained connected to him until his death during the siege of Hippo Regius. These letters provide insight into the man himself and suggest the course of his early career.If people like this book there's also a good biography of Aetius available.

I love the PS3. There, I've said it. It was very hard for me to get used to the idea of replacing it. Which is why although it offers improvements in several key areas I don't think the PS4 is quite as good as the PS3. In many ways the two systems are nearly identical. Controls, Settings, the PSN are all still here in only slightly different forms. The interface has been changed from a row of different options to two rows with one controlling settings/extra features and the other containing the games and apps. Instead of only displaying the game in the slot you now install everything like an app, which can make it confusing when you're not sure what disc is in the machine. This system makes it easier to find the most recently played game but gives fewer options for organization. I preferred the old system with its neat rows but this one is perfectly functional.On a technical level the PS4 is a marked improvement over the PS3. Games run much smoother and don't suffer from long loading times. The games that have come out so far seem to make good use of the system's capabilities and larger save files by, for example, keeping track of your character interactions and making the NPCs carry a grudge. It's an interesting and engrossing idea that really helps with immersion. A nice feature is that now the system can multitask. While playing your game you can pause it and go out to the main menu to check on downloads or settings and then go back to your game without losing your place.Some of the other changes are less interesting. The social gaming idea is something that Sony has worked very hard to incorporate into the basic design of the PS4 but apart from game reviewers I'm not sure how much use people will make of the ability to record gameplay. I've taken a few screencaps just for fun, but it's not a feature I'm likely to use very often.One change that is a step back is that they have removed video/audio file functionality. For those who are used to using their Playstation as a media centre in addition to a gaming system this will be a major disappointment. Now the only way to watch films or listen to music is to play it on DVD or pay for one of the streaming services. Since DVDs can be clumsy to carry around and streaming sites depend on reliable internet connections this simply isn't a reliable option for some people. Better keep that old PS3 around.I was more than a little skeptical about the new controller. Playstation has kept their controller design basically the same since the original in 1995, with the only major change being the dual analog sticks a couple years later and then a wireless version being used for the PS3. There's a reason for this, and it's not complacency. The design is quite simply the best yet offered for a video game system, and all of its competitors have imitated it to one degree or another at some point.Which is why I was more than a little surprised to discover that the new controller is an improvement. Not much of one mind you, but enough to make the change worthwhile. First off they've added a touchpad to the area between the screens.which allows slightly more choices to be made with maps and the like and also makes entering text easier. It's easier to hit accurately than the select button so this is a big improvement for games that rely on that. Another addition is a motion sensor. I doubt that it's as sensitive as the Wii, but the new feature allows it to select areas on the screen simply by pointing the controller at them. Which is cool. A speaker and microphone jack have been added which allows for some cool in-game effects.The rest of the buttons remain essentially the same (why improve on perfection?) except that start and select have now been replaced with share and options. I'm not that fussed about sharing gameplay footage but the select button does basically the same things as the start button so I'm not sure why they bothered to change the name. I'm less impressed with the new shape. It's been altered slightly so that the smaller handles now sit in your hand smoother but the steeper angle for the L and R buttons means you really need to hold the controller in a loose low-down grip to access both at once. They also have a glowing light on the back now which doesn't seem to do much except waste battery.In short, the new system is better than the PS3 in some areas, about the same in others, and actually worse in a few places. I'd still recommend getting it if there are any games you're interested in, but keep the old system around since they complement each other well. Honestly, there's no point in until a must-buy next gen game comes out anyway and that didn't happen until relatively recently for me. Most of the best PS4 games are also available for the PS3. Alien: Isolation, Assassin's Creed: Black Flag, Dragon Age: Inquisition, Metal Gear Solid V, Persona 5, Destiny, Final Fantasy XIV... all available on last gen systems. So why upgrade? But now they are finally coming out with next gen exclusives. Assassin's Creed: Unity was the first good one (glitches aside) and in the next year we get Final Fantasy Type-0, Star Wars: Battlefront, Kingdom Hearts III, and Final Fantasy XV. These are all available for the XBOX One of course, and there really isn't that much reason to prefer one next gen system over the other. Titanfall aside Microsoft doesn't have that many great exclusives either. However, later this year we get Bloodborne and Uncharted 4: A Thief's End, both exclusively for the PS4, and inFAMOUS: Second Son has already been released. Now there's finally a reason to buy a next gen system beyond the desire to simply have the latest platform.

In many ways Assassin's Creed: Unity represents a return to form after the largely disappointing American trilogy. Sure, Black Flag was a lot of fun, but the land stuff was almost an afterthought and it barely even feels like an Assassin's Creed game. But Unity is an Assassin's Creed game through and through, for better or worse. And it's about as good looking a one as they've produced thus far.First off, I think everyone has heard of the horrible glitches that this game had on release. I'm not going to deny that releasing a near unplayable game is an extremely bad thing, or that it deserves every sting of criticism it receives for that. However, by the time I bought a copy most of the bugs had been fixed by the giant patch it automatically downloads so I can't claim to have experienced these glitches as anything but hearsay. Sure there one or two minor glitches, but nothing that interfered with gameplay and nothing which I haven't seen in other games. For that reason this review will not discuss such problems and can focus on the game itself.First off, visually this game is a vast improvement over previous titles, which were usually very impressive on their own. The city of Paris is beautifully rendered here, with a nice alternating weather feature which really adds variety to the game and makes it feel as if time is passing. The ability to run through buildings is something I thought sounded cool but not particularly useful, but it's one of the key elements that aids in immersion. Going inside these houses just in passing makes them all feel like real and lived in to a degree I never thought possible. It also makes it ridiculously easy to lose guards. Another nice element is that they have given more life to the city than previous games could. Each NPC character seems to have his own life and we see numerous love affairs, robberies, mourning, etc. taking place throughout the city. Everyone has a reason to be where they are. The textures are more detailed and some of the faces look almost photo real, at least until they speak. Speaking of faces though, there is one feature that needs to be discussed.The hair. Oh God, the hair! Assassin's Creed and games in general have often had problems rendering hair believably, but I can't recall it ever looking this bad. They've abandoned creating the hair as a single block with a cool texture map and are now trying to create each hair individually. Except using about 1% of the actual hair. Which is why anyone who doesn't have their hair pulled back (or God forbid has a beard!) looks like some sort of monstrosity with a line of strings sticking out of their head at odd angles. I'm sure this is a logical step to developing truly natural-looking hair but the developers should have known it wasn't working and they should have known this pretty early on. Perhaps a part of it is how silly this looks on the new ultrarealistic faces but it would look bad on almost any figure.The gameplay is slightly different from previous games, but still similar enough to not cause a problem. Combat has been tweaked to be much harder. Gunshots hurt and are very difficult to dodge. Instead of health regenerating over time you buy disposable potions to heal yourself. These can get used up extremely quickly. Not so fond of these combat mods to be honest. What I do love are the stealth mods. They've really improved stealthing in this game. Now, when you're spotted as soon as you break their line of sight a transparent figure of you appears in the location where they last saw you.  The guards will run to the last place they saw you and look around that area, but if you're out of their line of sight they won't magically find you. You can use this to your advantage by being careful where your last known position was and then ambushing them.One element they're trying to push is the online multiplayer. Now many of the missions you come across around town are multiplayer co-op missions. If you're not interested in multiplayer this can be slightly annoying. The accents are slightly odd here. Previous games gave their characters accents to match their nationality, but now everyone speaks with an English accent except when they're speaking random French. It works fine but it's a little strange.The plot is basically more of the same and it's as tired as it felt in III. The Assassin/Templar conflict just isn't that interesting and has been played out already. The best drama in earlier games came from entirely non-Templar related elements. Ezio's family drama, Kenway's roguish greed, these were the bits that made us care. Listening to people jabbering about which apparently monolithic but vaguely-motivated group they belong to has become tedious. We learned everything we needed to know about this in the first game. Starting with Revelations the simple plots vanished and now we're given complicated political goings on that have nothing to do with the main conflict of the plot. I'm firmly convinced that tying these games around an existing war/social revolution is a massive mistake. How was aiding the American Revolution supposed to help the Templar cause? It was clearly about issues that had nothing to do with that, and forcing the two ideologies to merge made a muddled mess. This game has the same problem, although they play it more carefully. The revolution seems to be happening in the background and is almost irrelevant to the main plot, which is tied up with internal squabbles in the ranks, until the end where they at least give an understandable reason for why the Templars support the side they do. It doesn't make any sense because their plans are simultaneously too specific and too vague to be reasonable, but it is at least clear.Fortunately, this game learned from the best and gives Arno a love/family interest. She's a Templar which confuses things but it does actually give us a reason to care. Arno is an entertaining character too, being a bit cheeky and adventurous, at least until he joins the assassins for no real reason at which point he loses all personality. His personality comes back somewhat when the love  story picks up again, which makes the game worth playing through to the end. The love story works really well, as do the mystery elements sprinkled in towards the end (it'd be great if they could do more of this in London next year since that setting is full of mystery). The Templar/Assassin stuff is just perfunctory and done more from a sense of obligation than any real passion. They didn't even bother to give Arno a real motivation to join the assassins (he''s avenging his Templar foster-father? What?) and the fact that nobody among the assassins really questions his ties to the Templars feels so false it's confusing. We also get rather fewer historical personages here than I would have expected (and mostly in side quests), which is fine because shoehorning them in was a large part of the problem with III.If that sounds a bit confusing, well, it is. The plot is a mix of tired cliches and new ideas. Gameplay has been improved in ways I didn't think were possible. Paris is beautiful and immersive, with enough similarity to the real geography to be recognizable and with the same cheeky historical footnotes as previous games. Overall, I wouldn't say that this is the best Assassin's Creed by a long shot but it's a marked improvement from recent attempts. It's just that the series feels a little stale. Gameplay remains as fun as ever, but it would be nice if they could find a way to drift away from direct Assassin/Templar plots or at least find a way to expand their ideologies and plans into something intelligible or interesting.

This is an excellent case for the iPhone 6. It adds a little weight but provides a lot for that drawback. The battery in this case holds enough juice to charge the iPhone 1.5 times. Given the increased power demands required by the larger screen this is an important addition. Using it is easy too, since all you have to do is press the button on the back and it starts charging. It charges through the same port you use to charge the phone so there's no need for an extra charging session. Once the phone has finished charging the case starts charging too.With the case on it's about twice as thick and twice as heavy, but it's about the same width and smooth to the touch. The back of the phone is almost completely safe from breakage, although the camera is still exposed through a hole. The iPhone 6 camera is an ugly extrusion anyway, so this actually helps streamline the phone. The plastic lining the sides is transparent and not flush with the phone's body which means that dirt and grit begins to coat the inside and make it look really dirty. There's nothing you can do about this really, except keep the phone away from all dirt. The face of the phone is slightly recessed now which should help it in case of a fall. The buttons on the side still work, if slightly less well. The speakers seem to work about as well, though they may be quieter. The headphone jack is a lot worse though, being too deep for regular earphones and now requiring an extension wire. The charging port has replaced the Apple exclusive cable with a regular Micro USB. This works just as well as the Apple cable but is easier to replace.

Well. your iPhone certainly won't be damaged in here. This case basically covers the entire phone in rubber. The front screen is protected by a plastic cover that fits surprisingly well and about a 1/4 inch of rubber on the sides. While the phone may be protected the size increases exponentially. It's about three times thicker than the iPhone 6 and almost as heavy again. I found that the extra weight makes it very difficult to use the phone one-handed. The volume and on/off button aren't as sensitive as they are without the case. It can occasionally be hard to turn on. The Mute button (very important when in a crowded theater) is very hard to use without taking the phone out and fiddling with it for a minute. The Touch ID seems to work okay, though it's not as sensitive as it is without the cover. The screen protector fits well, but the thick rubber on the sides makes touching the edges of the screen difficult. Since this is the section you type on that can be a problem. For my part I found it so annoying I took it back out of the case and bought another brand.I can't really fault it for doing what it's supposed to do. If keeping your iPhone free from all danger is more important than some of the functionality then this will work fine. Otherwise, it's better to go with a slightly smaller case.

This is an excellent keyboard for the iPad. I spent a lot of time searching for a case for mine and this was by far the best that I found. All other cases on the market seemed to be designed to either work as a keyboard or a case, and not both. They may protect your iPad but when it comes time to use it you are required to have it sitting sideways propped up as if you're going to type. If you want to use it like a regular iPad without the keyboard you have to actually take it out of its case. With this case you can prop it up (it magnetically locks) and use it as a keyboard or you can fold it over and place it flat. In this position it protects the keys and lets you turn the iPad to face whichever way you want. It's a simple feature that was harder to find than I thought it would be.As to the keyboard itself, it works as well as any of the others I tested. The bluetooth link was easy to establish and caused no problems. It only turns on when the iPad is snapped in place to type so the battery isn't draining itself needlessly. The keys are closer together than on a regular computer, but this is going to be a problem with any keyboard you get for the iPad. The copy and paste functions are clearly labeled and easily accessed, along with all the other functions. The only real problem is that the numbers are shrunk down to about a third of the size of the other keys for some reason. The iPad sits at a convenient viewing angle when locked in and the area surrounding the keypad is not exactly cushioned but certainly fuzzy and comfortable to rest your hands on.When closed the case looks like a fancy notebook. It's quite impressive how easily it blends in with your other school materials. It should prevent the iPad from getting its screen cracked or scratched (and the heavier bit with the keypad on it is what's protecting the front) but if you really want tougher protection then you should probably go with one of the metal models. This one's good enough for me and, I suspect, most other people. Access to the iPad's regular buttons is slightly impeded, but it is not made impossible. The camera and microphone still function. The iPad is connected to the case in one of those mystical iPad ways that allows it to turn the iPad on when the case is opened and switches it off when it is closed. The only really annoying thing about the case is that every time you close it the iPad snaps in, which means that whenever you open it you have to force the bottom clip off. I don't know why it makes you do that.Overall I think this is the best case on the market. There are probably better keyboards out there, and I know there are better cases, but they aren't that much better and they don't do both as well as this one does.

This is one of the best Tales games out there. I fell in love with Symphonia and Abyss returned my affections, but some of the recent games in the series have left me feeling cold (*cough* Xillia). Vesperia has taken almost everything I loved about Symphonia and improved on it.Let me just get this out of the way now. The biggest flaw with Vesperia is its story. A lot of Tales games have confusing stories but Vesperia takes the cake for being the most confusing on an hourly basis. In other Tales games you know what you're trying to achieve more or less from the beginning. In Symphonia you're trying to save the world from decay. In Abyss you're trying to stop the miasma. In both games the situation takes numerous complicated plot turns that completely alter the manner in which you're expected to succeed in your task or even what that task means, but on the whole the initial quest leads directly to the end quest. In Vesperia you have no idea what's going on until you near the end. At 30 hours in I still didn't know what was happening and I had no indication that the world was in danger at all. After every major event Yuri asks Estelle whether she wants to continue on her current quest (which changes repeatedly) or investigate some new incident. The party is constantly struggling to find a reason to stay together. There's not really the sense of unity that the other games had. This is all tied into the game's theme of growing up and deciding your own path, but it's a really bad idea from a storytelling standpoint.Now if that sounds bad, well, it kinda is. But it's not as frustrating as it might seem. This is largely because of the characters. Vesperia has assembled one of the best cast of characters I've seen in a video game. Yuri Lowell is the lead and he's a ball of laughs. Unlike other Tales protagonists he's not quite as kiddish (he's 21, an old man by Anime standards). I was very impressed with what they can do when they have a more mature character like this. When the game goes for the stereotypical Tales character reveals (gosh, is that obvious princess really a princess? No...) Yuri reveals he's known the entire time and just hasn't bothered to tell anyone. You can feel his self-satisfied smirk at watching the others in shock. His friend and foil is Flynn (an NPC unfortunately). He's the second part of the duo and is essential to the question that drives the game: is it better to work from within a crooked system to try and change it from the inside, or to oppose it directly knowing that it means not much will get done. Yuri takes the latter approach, Flynn the former. As you might imagine this leads to some conflict but also some really interesting exploration of the issue.The other characters are good too. Estelle is totally not a princess. Honest. Raven's the untrustworthy scoundrel type who's always whining about his old age (he's somewhere in his 30s the poor man). Karol is a kid who wants to overcome his fear of, well, everything, in order to become a guild leader and respected person. Rita's very angry and likes hitting people. Judith is... odd. Let's leave it at that. Repede is a dog. With a  pipe. Yeah, I don't get it either. These characters are fun to watch and we still get the great Tales cutscenes that reveal background details and conversations to expand on the plot and characterization.The mechanics of the game are basically the same as earlier ones. We still get an open world and enemies you can see approaching and sometimes avoid. Fighting is done in a fighter game format and real time. Your companions are computer controlled, although you can determine the tactics they should follow or override their commands. The graphics are much better than in Symphonia, while continuing the same cell shaded style. Instead of the big headed wide-eyed spheres of that game we get more realistic Anime figures.I don't think this game quite beats Symphonia, although it definitely has areas where the improvement is massive. The plot is to blame for this defect, but it's never bad enough to make the game anything but fun. You want to find out what happens to these characters, even if you don't necessarily want to see it told in this way. The cities are charming, the gameplay first rate, and the plot (when it finally shows up) decent.

I have decidedly mixed feelings about this book. On the one hand, it is a useful examination of exactly what changed equipment-wise during the late 2nd and mid-3rd century. On the other, it does not have the in depth look that would have made it a truly great resource. There are not enough pictures or examples to serve as a resource on Roman arms and armor (at best it constitutes a thorough outline) and the narrative coverage of the third century crisis is broad enough that it doesn't really satisfy.The section of the book that deals with actual weapons and weaponry (the main topic after all) is small. Only 66 (pages 49-115) out of 142 pages actually cover it, with the rest of the pages devoted to a narrative of the period. These pages are the best in the book, but they do little more than whet your whistle. The illustrations in this section are sparser than they should be, leaving the author simply describing the objects through text in a somewhat unclear manner. His central argument about the reasons for the change are good, but again seem like they could use further bringing out. As an introduction to the topic it works well.The narrative section is fairly unimpressive. The author suffers from the common tendency of those covering specialist topics (here a historical recreationist) to suck in every piece of information and combine it, even when it doesn't make sense. That's why you get sections like the one on Valerian's Persian campaign where he combines a defeat in battle (Zonaras and Shapur) with plague (Zosimus, Syncellus, Peter the Patrician) and capture during negotiations (Zosimus) despite the descriptions in these sources not lining up on other details. A lot of the sources for the 3rd century are extremely poor and cannot be relied on, particularly the Historia Augusta (a late 4th century forgery posing as a late 3rd set of Lives) which is frequently used in the book. In general, there is nothing in the narrative section that couldn't be found in other better books.The best part of this book is the photographs. The author is a reenactor and has numerous pictures of himself in reconstructed 3rd century Roman armor. When he mentions that he has tried to make certain pieces of equipment shown in ancient sculptures/descriptions work practically you know that he means it. I honestly wish that the entire book had focused a bit more on this aspect since this is what the author is an expert in. If he could have shown photographs or drawings of the way in which his reconstructed equipment worked and how he arrived at his conclusions then it could have gone a lot more in depth and I wouldn't have as many source complaints.This book isn't the worst introduction you could have to the topic. I'm clearly not in the target audience in that way so maybe it's difficult for me to judge its quality. But to me I just feel there are better books out there that outline some of these ideas in as good or better detail. Roman Military Equipment from the Punic Wars to the Fall of Rome offers an excellent look at Roman arms and armor. It covers a much wider period and therefore goes into less detail but it has more pictures and discussion. The Late Roman Army is a good look at the army in general (again, over a somewhat wider period but this time only about 200 years) and features much information on archaeological issues such as arms, armor, and equipment. For general overviews of the period you can't do much better than The Roman Empire at Bay, which is both in depth and readable. Other good narratives include The Roman Empire from Severus to Constantine and Aurelian and the Third Century.

If I had to describe this film in one word it would be perfunctory. Each scene is brief and uninvolving and the audience only endures them in hopes that the scenes being set up will prove better. Unfortunately that turns out not to be the case. This film isn't trying very hard and it has no real point to make or issues it wants to deal with. There's nothing unique here. The film has taken elements from the legend and earlier screen depictions and reformatted them without adding anything new. There is one exception: God. The God of Exodus is presented as a small and petulant boy. It's an intriguing idea, and one that would have potential if this was a completely different film. Making God a brat only works if you're taking a much harsher approach than this film is. If God is just a callous child then he should be crueler and more indifferent. Impulsive even, especially towards his chosen prophet. But that would require a different film. One that challenged the idea that God is just or that obedience to his command is righteous. In short, a film with passion.If I was permitted to use a second word it would be indifferent. This is nowhere more apparent than in the performances. It is in fact Ramses' entire character. He seems bored with everything and nothing really interests him at all. At first I thought this to be intentional, that Ramses was an uncharismatic and disinterested ruler who would eventually need to change to respond to challenges he could not anticipate, resulting in an unbending air of autocracy resulting from his inner weaknesses. But this soon proved not to be the case. While he does care for his son and displays some other such humanizing traits he can never quite shake the air of apathy. Even when charging at Moses beneath the crest of a fearsome tsunami he displays little emotion. It's a stunning indictment of Joel Edgerton's acting abilities. Not that Christian Bale does much better. His Moses manages to creak above indifference to become merely passionless. He clearly has some principles, but we're rarely allowed to see them and he rarely offers any justification or explanation. Other characters do display some emotion but to say that they're minor roles is an understatement. Only Moses (and to a much lesser extend Ramses) gets all the attention. Secondary characters, even those played by such wonderful actors as Ben Kingsley and Sigourney Weaver, get only one or two lines in the entire film.My third choice of words would be anachronistic. And every aspect of this film is tainted with this to one degree or another. Where to even begin? For a start, Egyptians weren't white. Neither were Jews. When called on this Ridley Scott actually said that he didn't even try casting ethnic actors because the studios would never finance a film starring "Mohammad So-and-So From Such-And-Such". I think that sums up his approach right there. He's probably right about the need for name brand recognition (though I could point out several Arabic or at least Arab-looking actors who have carried films in the past, or the fact that biblical epics rely mainly on a religious audience who don't care so much about the actors and thus often have unknown casts) but that doesn't just sweep the problem under the rug. It's not just a question of using white actors in Middle Eastern roles, it's a question of where those actors are used. The upper classes of Egypt are the palest of the bunch while servants and social inferiors provide the touch of color. The worst example of this is in the battle of Kadesh at the very beginning. The Egyptian army (mainly white) faces off against the Hittites (varying shades of brown, with shaggy beards and primitive costumes). The Hittites came from Asia Minor and would have looked about the same as modern Turks do (ie. a mix of European and Middle Eastern features). Their army even included people from as far away as Greece, or at least the Greek colonies on the shores of western Asia Minor. In other words, the Hittites are us, or as close to us as anyone gets in this film. And yet they are portrayed as primitive native tribesmen, reinforcing the negative stereotype of superior white men versus barbaric brown peoples that has been entirely artificially placed in this film for no discernible reason.There are many other elements of inauthenticity as well. Egypt has never looked less Egyptian than it does here. Honestly, where did all those mountains come from? Egypt is mainly flat and only inhabitable along the Nile or the coast. The costumes are forced as well, looking more like modern garments with Egyptian touches than anything from the time. The inhabitants of these costumes speak in pseudo-modernese with no obvious effort made to match the time period. To hear Ramses speak lines like "From an economic standpoint, what you suggest is problematic to say the least," feels painfully false, and equally so is the way they handle all aspects of life in the capital where every element of modern government seems present from military briefings (complete with maps) to near universal literacy and the concept of universal human equality. Non-ahistorical scenes feel forced as well. The reveal of Moses' parentage is unlikely and confusing at best, certainly not the life-changing moment it should be. Ramses' reasons for banishing Moses (or anything else he does really) seem utterly unmotivated. And why on earth would the two of them charge at each other when a tsunami is about to hit them? But worse than this is the fact that it never FEELS authentic. In fact it feels completely artificial. Unlike Gladiator or Kingdom of Heaven (or even Robin Hood, which suffered from the same problem) this isn't a lived in world. It's a stage for people to play on. And the fact that such an unrealistic world is being treated so mundanely really crushes it. A movie can get away with a lot of factual errors, but not when it doesn't feel like it's coming from a real place.If forced to pick another word I would choose pretty. See? If you keep picking words to describe a generally crummy film eventually you hit on a good element. Almost all films have something to recommend them. Even this isn't that much however. I could have chosen beautiful, and it's never that. But some of the shots were very well chosen and the effects well incorporated. Some of the plagues in particular are wonderfully realized. If it weren't for Scott going a little overboard on the color palette these scenes would be stunning. The CGI is impressive and manages to provide us with some quite cool moments indeed from a boat crew devoured by angry crocodiles to an army caught in an avalanche to the final tsunami, these moments all work impressively well. The ability to do pretty is even carried out so well it can be a detriment to the film. The final scenes of Moses and Ramses charging under the tsunami look gorgeous, but make no sense at all since they would certainly die. The fact that they do not lessens the entire point of the scene (that the tsunami is wiping out Ramses' army) and turns it from cool into a massive and worthless gimmick. Scott still has a flair for the dramatic, but without the material to back it up none of it can take root.If I had to chose a final word to wrap up this film it would be tired. Scott must have felt some passion for the project at one point (unless he simply wanted to cross biblical epic off his list of genres), but whatever he may have felt at one point was gone by the time it came to filming. There is no love here. No passion. There was undoubtedly effort, but all the effort in the world can't make up for a lack of inspiration.Another word: Recommendations. Since I'm complaining so much about this one it seems like I should provide some sort of reference to the films that succeed better. There are a lot of good biblical epics out there, most of which leave this one in the dust. The most recent and interesting one is Noah. Now there's a film that did exactly what this one tried to do: present a semi-rationalized look at Biblical events which treats religion as reality instead of stage drama and God's will as a questionable motivator. The Moses story is a more popular one among biblical epics and it has been told many times. The most famous one is The Ten Commandments, where we're treated to a cast of thousands and all the self-righteous posturing you could want. It's pretty good and pretty much the benchmark for Biblical epics. Moses is a miniseries starring Ben Kingsley (also in this film) and is really quite good for a more limited budget. The Prince of Egypt is a wonderful cartoon that captures this story in a slightly less serious (and more musical) manner. It's really a lot better than it has a right to be. I attribute this to the fact that the story is just so darn good and open for embellishment. It's rather hard to screw it up this bad.

Popular histories are often looked down on by professional scholars. Which is unfair really. Popular histories may lack the vetting of the peer review process but many of them provide a perfectly reliable view of events. Good popular histories offer accommodating prose and a cushioning of major debates in order to draw in new readers.This is not one of those books.Uncountable inaccuracies spring up from the very beginning. The account of the battle of Megiddo matches up with the real battle in only the broadest strokes, and is filled with tedious rhetoric. The book is clearly intended to be read like a novel and follows that path clearly, even to the extent of including imaginary dialogue between participants. That's right, he makes up entire speeches. And the worst part is he isn't even explicit about when he's doing so.The bronze age clearly bores him since we quickly move on to Greek and Roman times. In under fifty pages we've covered a thousand years. Why even bother covering Megiddo, honestly?  He's clearly more interested in the classical era. It's much better documented and more familiar to most of his audience. Which is why it's surprising to see him continue to get everything wrong. From describing the Spartan warriors as bearing 13 foot Macedonian sarissas at Thermopylae to describing legions as composing 5,000 hoplites, 4,000 velites, and 800 cavalry, there seems to be no fact so basic he cannot screw it up.His understanding of the battles themselves is no better as they are heavy on hyperbole and "character" and weak on facts. Interpretations are taken from better authors and rewritten. Those interpretations he creates himself are wrong. For example, did you know that Hannibal won his battles by inventing the commando unit? Or that the Persians could have defeated the Greek navy at Salamis if only they had lured them out to sea where their triremes would have been destroyed by the high winds?The most painful part for me is his depiction of late Rome, one of my favorite periods. Many authors get this time wrong but his is genuinely the worst I've ever read. According to him Rome was still the center of the Empire, barbarian auxilaries replaced Roman legions, Rome was run by barbarian soldiers (whose compatriots invaded and destroyed Rome anyway), millions of Visigoths invaded Rome, the size of the army shrank, Constantine had all the citizens of Rome baptized, Valentinian was killed by the Goths, Valens was captured alive, Stilicho was killed at Honorius' banquet, and Alaric burned Rome to the ground as part of a carefully orchestrated Gothic policy. It's just awful gibberish.So much of his material is confusingly wrong. I can understand an incompetent researcher using Shakespeare as a historical source (which he does), but some of this is truly confounding. Why does he think the Emperor Titus was murdered? Nobody says that. Or that Frankish soldiers "liberating" Gaul were treated as saviors? Or that Augustus' death resulted in civil war (confusingly called the war of the diadochi, which as he notes was fought for control of ALEXANDER's empire). Or that the Jews invaded Asia Minor? Or that legions were usually encamped without their generals for security reasons? Or that Philip of Macedon was not an empire builder? Or that helot was the word for Greek light infantry? Or that Greek triremes typically charged into battles using sail power? Or, most absurdly of all, that Asoka ruled from 293 to 36 BC? That last one is presumably a typo, but the fact that it was just left in there is a depressingly accurate sign of how little effort went into this book.The welcoming prose isn't that great either. Just to include a random sample:"Most of the augusti were possessed of an empty idea of self-worth. All were spoiled by wealth and power, posturing as emperors, but once confronted with reality their faade collapsed and they saw no way to stop the headlong descent into disaster. Then they fell on their knees to beg, 'Help me!' And those being addressed would look at them ironically, and then do nothing, whether for the Emperor or his empire." This is neither the best nor the worst prose in the book and is depressingly typical.This is one of those books where reading it will actually make you know less than you did at the outset. Not only will you not learn anything of value but you'll have to actively unlearn all the mistruths presented here. A real waste of a book.Having thoroughly blasted this book it seems like I ought to mention some general histories that cover a similar period in a more reliable way. I found The Birth of Classical Europe: A History from Troy to Augustine a generally reliable guide. Classical World: An Epic History from Homer to Hadrian was also good.

I'm not going to say the Tales series is necessarily predictable, but when you put one of these games in you know pretty much what you're getting. The characters will be variations on classic Anime tropes as you navigate your teenage protagonist through a series of battles based on a combination of button mashing and tactics. In terms of design and style they all follow a pretty tight formula. The main variations come from the plots, which (while they always share features like multiple worlds and a powerful church) are all unique and clever with a lot of enjoyable world-building.Since the elements that make up a Tales game are so standard there are really only two major questions that need to be answered about this game: how good is the story and how well does the game adapt itself to the portable system? As to the latter the answer is pretty well. The graphics on the Vita are very good and the game doesn't look substantially worse than Tales of Xilia on the PS3. The fact that this was ported from a DS game makes it even more impressive since there is little evidence of the compromises that must have been made for that system apart from slightly smaller level designs than normal.As to the story, without giving too much away it's a decent one. You play a teenage boy (of course) called Kor Meteor who has accidentally scattered the emotions of a girl (the eponymous Kohaku Hearts) while trying to save her from an evil witch. Kor is fun in his innocent easily pushed around way, while Kohaku gets to slowly recover her personality. To help repair your mistake you travel with her and her comically overprotective brother as you hunt for the pieces of her soul. As you might expect complications ensue. The characters are entertaining and the plot diverting. Like all Tales games there are short character skits that appear occasionally where you get to see the characters interact with each other outside of the normal exposition moments. These are often funny or character building so they help flesh out the story a lot.Gameplay is basically identical to other Tales games. The levels consist of a series of towns and paths which you access by traversing a world map. It's nice to see the world map back again after its absence in Xilia. It really does make the world feel larger. Leveling up is done via your Soma, a wrist device kind that works kind of like EX Gems. This process is refreshingly simple and effective. In battle the gameplay switches to a combat mode based off fighting games more than your average JRPG where you have to attack your enemies manually while your party follows the guidelines you set. Sometimes it's complicated, usually it's simple. One unfortunate change in this game is that you can no longer see the enemies approaching. Instead we get a random battle situation similar to Final Fantasy.If you enjoyed this game you might also want to check out Tales of the Abyss, the other portable Tales game. That one is a direct port from a PS2 title so it didn't need to make any of the compromises that this game did. On bigger consoles there's always Tales of Symphonia (the best of the bunch) and the newer titles Tales of Graces and Tales of Xillia. All of these games are pretty good, although it wouldn't kill them to put a bit more variety into character designs and gameplay elements.

To begin with I'd just like to say that the LOTR score is one of my favorite soundtracks of all time. The Hobbit series has generally been of similar quality, even if it doesn't always have the thematic richness of the first trilogy. That latter reason is why this album could never top ROTK, though it could certainly have wrapped up the Hobbit trilogy the same LOTR was. It doesn't quite achieve that for reasons that will be obvious as the review continues.The album starts off on a triumphant note. Fire and Water is a strong track continuing on directly from where the last film left off. Some might point out how that just shows how unnecessary a cliffhanger the ending of the last film was but that's an issue for the filmmakers and not the composer. As a track this captures the mood perfectly, although I'm slightly surprised at both how short and channeled the track is. I expected to feel the fiery terror swooping in from the sky, like I did with My Dear Frodo in An Unexpected Journey. This is more of a swan song to the glory that was Smaug's theme with elements of the heroic Bard theme thrown in. Bard's theme is actually fully on display here in a way that it hasn't been before and it sounds great. It isn't one of those grand display pieces like the Fellowship theme, but it has a certain quiet heroism that pops out along with a very angelic chorus at what I can only assume is the moment of Smaug's demise.From this point on it's like listening to a different album. Smaug is dead. His theme is no more. And just as in the previous album, without Smaug the soundtrack has no real focus. The next couple tracks are nice if unmemorable, dealing with the aftermath of Smaug. The score seems a bit more focused with Guardians of the Three where we hear the Rivendell theme appear in a somewhat heroic way that it wasn't designed for (but I really like) and then the Ruins of Dale where we get to hear Bard's theme again and bits of the Shire theme appearing in a subdued fashion. We also see hints of a new theme here, a harsh and militaristic one. Unfortunately the theme never really gets developed to any great extent and it remains its clearest here. The Gathering of the Clouds is more of the same, a little more heroic but still quite subdued except when it's being ominous.The final non-war track for a long while is Mithril. This is a very nice exploration and variation of what I guess is the mithril armor theme (I always associated it more with Bilbo when it showed up in FOTR). This is followed up by a very fitting version of the gold theme with hints of Smaug. It's harsh and unpleasant and absolutely perfect. One of my problems with the previous album was the absence of any unifying Company theme like they had in Misty Mountains Cold. Upon listening to this album I realized that the aggressively rousing theme at the end of DoS was actually the Company's theme. It works well here (especially when juxtaposed with Bard's theme) although I still prefer Misty Mountains for its sense of adventure.As far as heroic themes go I really like Bard's theme and wish that we could hear it belted out triumphantly in all its glory more. As the score continues his somewhat lighthearted and cheerful theme transitions into an organized military beat. This theme is the only one that really seems to get the development it deserves. When I thought about this album I assumed that the battle would feature a lot of previous themes blending together in clever ways. Instead, they play one right after the other in a slightly jarring fashion, and even these appearances aren't that common. It's odd, we have five armies here, and five established leitmotifs. You'd think we'd hear more of them apart from the moment of their character/people's introduction.And here we get to the battle music. It's nothing that great I'm afraid. Just generic action music. Actually, all the middle tracks are fairly bleh as far as I'm concerned. They're designed to not intrude on the story. There is one exception and it's probably my favorite track on the album. Sons of Durin is a really great track that brings the Company's theme in for a triumphant entrance. It's extremely aggressive and played on drums with lots of chanting. Wonderful. But then we're back to generic music again until we come to To the Death, where Shore tries something different. He's been giving brief hints in previous tracks of a theme that sounds like a sort of drumming heartbeat but it really comes out strong here. This is presumably the big tear-jerking finale so he pulls out all the stops. It hits its climax with a nice rendition of the theme they use for the Ents and certain other creatures which should play nicely with the battle's ending.After this the album calms down again and we get some nice quiet reflective pieces. The Return Journey has little new or exciting about it but it is fittingly sedate and feels like it's tidying up after the big battle. It's too late to be introducing new themes anyway so that's fine. There and Back Again is similar although it has a surprisingly dark variation of the heroic theme included for reasons I'll likely be more clear on once I've seen the movie. It ends us on a nostalgic note as we get the Hobbit theme and the Shire theme and the Ring theme all jumbled together to remind us what's coming up next for those carefree hobbitses.Unlike the, lets call it ill-fitting, I See Fire at the end of DoS, The Last Goodbye is a perfectly matching piece that is well suited to conclude this trilogy. Sung by Billy Boyd (Pippen from LOTR) as a sort of mournful lament it manages to end the series on a reflective and nostalgic note. Not nearly as depressing as "Into the West" it feels both sufficiently sorrowful and suitably like it's promising a well-deserved rest. This song works exceptionally well as either a wrap up to the entire series or a bridge between the Hobbit and LOTR. One of the things I really like about the songs in these movies is that the LOTR endings were all sung by female artists, thus catching a more atmospheric and thoughtful tone, while the Hobbit films are all masculine, capturing the more guys' own adventure that they're undertaking. It works very well indeed.I think this is the first time I've been genuinely disappointed in one of Howard Shore's Middle-Earth compositions. It's not a bad album by any means but it provides little that is new either. It's largely a rehash of earlier themes dominated by a massive battle that seems to rely surprisingly little on the score for establishing the mood. Part of this is going to be the nature of the film. A film score has to do what's best for the movie, even if that comes at the expense of the music itself. This one was always going to be dominated by battles, but apart from what sounds like the introduction of the major players the music is surprisingly unforceful. Maybe Jackson was afraid that the constant trumpeting of war music would wear out the audience. Maybe he was right. But either way it leaves us with a somewhat neutered score. Certainly it's not the triumphant finale it could have been.

DoS was rather disappointing in that regard so it was nice to see that these tracks have more in common with AUJ's wonderful themes. Apart from the rather boring Thrain (taken from the extended version of DoS anyway) these are all excellent. Ironfoot is a great piece performed on bagpipes for Dain Ironfoot. It reminds me of Erebor, possibly my favorite track from the first Hobbit film. Dragon-Sickness is next and it is a nice rendition of the gold theme with a final reprise of Bard's theme.I think this is the first time I've been genuinely disappointed in one of Howard Shore's Middle-Earth compositions. This game is not a regular Persona game for the 3DS. That has to be put out there before continuing. There is no social gaming, no year-long adventure, no exploring outside the dungeons (labyrinth), no nothing. It's a very bare bones experience. Instead, what you do have is a whole lot of dungeon crawling and fan service (err, not that kind). This isn't lethal to the whole experience and if you go in with your expectations tempered in advance then you'll find yourself having a fun time re-entering the world of Persona 3 & Persona 4 and enjoying the character interactions that were the best thing about those games.The gameplay in this game owes little to Persona and everything to Etrian Odyssey. Those games feature a similar dungeon system, the same basic controls, and the same lack of options. They're also by Atlus, so it's not that surprising that they would copy their own system for this game. The way the dungeons work is this: you walk around in first person mode moving one square at a time using the directional button. The analog stick only allows you to look from side to side. After a certain amount of moving you will be attacked (you generally have warning when this is about to happen) and the game switches to a combat system not that dissimilar to the regular Persona one except that you have to manage which players are in the back row and which are in the front.There are also big monsters (F.O.E.s, short for the atrociously ungrammatical fusis oikein eidolon, or creature to live in ghost. Yikes) who you  should really avoid wandering around. These show up on your screen. They only move when you do and they follow set patterns that you can figure out pretty easily, so avoiding them is usually not that tough. The really unique feature of this system is that you are not provided with a map but have to create your own as you go along. This does increase the difficulty of your exploration but it also provides you with a certain satisfaction from actually completing it. Outside of combat there's little to do. The main screen in Yasogami High only has a text menu of options for things like buying new items, healing, or saving the game. The majority of your time will be spent in the labyrinth.Is this system a perfect fit for Persona? No. I don't think they'd have lost anything by giving you the option to run around your school outside of combat and interact with the various zombies outside. It would have given the world a slightly less limited feeling while not requiring a large amount of storage room or effort. But in general I think the gameplay works well for what it's trying to do. At the least it isn't jarringly distracting.The big thrill here of course is playing with these characters again, and that's where the real fun in Persona Q comes in. The characters are back and they're as well done as ever. All the voice actors have returned and bring their customary liveliness to the roles. Sure, you can't talk to them in private like you could in the main games, but they do have frequent conversations throughout your adventure. They have also been given a design overhaul to better match Etrian Odyssey, which doesn't take long to get used to but can feel a little weird. They look a bit chibi. Plot and characterization has not been the strength of the Etrian Odyssey series. Until the last one (Millennium Girl) they didn't even bother with them. That's why I never had much time for them. But the addition works really well here and makes the game feel more like Persona.The really impressive thing here is how they've managed to incorporate two separate stories in the same game. At the beginning of the game you chose whether to follow the Persona 3 story or the Persona 4 one. Whichever one you chose, the cast from that game are the ones you'll be travelling with. Sure, you'll meet up with the other crew eventually, but for the most part (especially in the beginning) you are on independent quests. It's a lot of fun to play the game from both sides since, while they cover the same ground, the way they get there is often completely different. For example, since the game takes place in pseudo-Yasugami High from Persona 4 the arrival of the Persona 3 crowd is rather disorienting and you're thrust into the adventure rapidly and against your will. With the Persona 4 crowd the transition is more subtle and mysterious and involves a mysterious clock tower appearing in the courtyard. Neither storyline suffers from a feeling of being an afterthought, so you can essentially enjoy two games for the price of one!So should you buy this game? If you're a fan of Persona strictly for the social gaming then no. There's nothing like that here. And it's not as in-depth a game as Persona 3 & 4. But if you really loved those characters and just want to see them in an adventure again (and together this time!) then this game will probably be perfect for you. The difficulty curve can be a little steep, but aside from that the game is a lot of fun. I'm getting a little sick of the spin-offs from the main series. Sooner or later it will run out of steam and make both those games feel tired and stale. But that moment hasn't come yet. It may be waiting for Persona 4: Dancing All Night, but Q isn't the disaster people might have expected. If they're still bringing this level of quality to their spin-offs I say bring on Persona 5!
