Am I the only one who gets ticked reading a story only to find out it ends on a to-be-continued note?The price listed might warrant better editing but at a little over 300 pages, reasonable for a good story.  It reminded me a little of the Gallagher Girls series by Ally Carter.

This is the first book in the Duke of Brimstone series.  It sets up the mythogical land of CHALYS, a Monaco type place where modern technological is not allowed and there's a forbidden area shielded by dark woods where things that go bump in the night live and no human has survived to tell tales.The author certainly knows how to set an intriguing scene and this story is no exception.  This forbidden area is ruled by Brimstone and his friends include werewolves, vampires and other paranormals.  It's got a dark brooding Hero and a feisty heroine like others in this genre but the author knows her way around dialogue and writes a compelling story.  So why not 5 stars?  Maybe Marian Tee set too high a bar (I've read several of her books, PARK and VIOLET and SUIT and FANGS were amazing) or maybe too much time is spent setting up this new world when it's around 150 pages but either way, it still works.The writing is witty and hot and worth the price and time to read it. I will be looking for the next book in this series.

My first 1.5 inch curling iron was a bust so I went for the more expensive one (TIGI) and this one works great!  I love the easy on and off button and the adjustable heat dial.  It heats up quick and stays hot for a good length of time.  I have long hair and I can use it all in one shot with just one 30 second wait for the iron to maintain the highest setting.This curling iron is more expensive but it's worth the price with it's work horse and uniform performance in every day use.

This product does NOT work as a hairspray but it does provide plenty of glitter....everywhere.  The glitter effect is pretty cool but when using, be sure to cover your face and clothes since it sprays all over.  It also pushes out a strong burst of air when pressed so if your hair is carefully styled, it will end up ruined.  It works with a looser and tousled look with plenty of shimmering glitter.I would recommend this for young women looking to stand out in a crowd.  It provides lots of glitter but not any hairspray holding power.

Right now this is listed as free which makes it a recommend.  It's worth a try as a freebie but when it's listed for just under a buck, how can the author expect us to pay for 29 pages?!  This very short intro to her upcoming series "Sons of Mayhem" and should always be free.The characters and storyline hint at potential but how do you provide a review for something so short and inconclusive?  Yeah, the series might turn into something good but it's hard to tell based on this brief intro and the price seems high for a teaser.My advice, wait until this series is released in a collection or longer format before you pay.

I am not sure how I ended up with this book in my "To Read" pile but I'm very happy about it.  I only wish this author had more available.This book is a mix of mystery and romance with the heroine (Katie) narrating the story with a very funny and unique voice.  She is snarky without being too much and entertaining as heck.  Her relationships define her in the best way.  I love Katie's interaction with the Hero and her best friend from Kindergarten.  All of the characters have their own distinct voice and felt like real people.It ends way before I wanted it to and I hope this is the beginning of a series.  I would love to read about further adventures of Katie, Dirk, and their best friends.  I am adding this book to my library and the author to my "Must Read" list.

This inspirational love story would rate higher if it was edited better.  There are too many mistakes and it makes reading the story difficult as you need to figure out correct or missing words.  I understand eBooks usually contain some editing issues but for the price listed, I expect better.I also had a minor issue with the relationship.  The Hero and heroine grew up together but spending 5 years apart has changed the Hero's view since the heroine now appeals to him physically.  Men.  Understanding why the heroine's view changed is unclear and made too quickly for this reader.I cannot recommend this book as written but might if it was editied further.

Not just 1000 stickers, but activity pages too. Some decent sized stickers, many more smaller ones. A decent sized book that my 3 year old is still working through. And the speed 3 years old blow through stickers - that's saying something.

The Good: The introduction of Georgina's long-time friend Bastien brings equal parts fun and aggravation. He's part of her past, when she wasn't always playing good-girl succubus. He's just like her, yet without the moral qualms. He can me less likable at times, but he's a good time. Between helping Bastien with a super interesting project/mission and trying to figure out the key to Doug's  new fame, Georgina is busy. The story moves very quickly and is almost always interesting and awesome.The Bad: The one not awesome point: Georgina's flirtation with Seth worked in the first book , but as a relationship in this book it turns annoying. They can't be together physically. She needs to have sex with other men. He accepts that? To be with her? Why? Is this all a lead up until she can't take it any more and ends up breaking and just feeding on him? But . . . ugh. It makes me think less of both characters to remain in this situation.

The Good: Another painful book for Merry. Another book where she proves she's strong enough to handle all that is thrown at here, even when she doesn't always believe in herself. A huge amount of action in a relatively short period of time means the book is extremely fast paced. Now down time, no opportunity to emotionally deal with all that's being thrown at us. Hamilton is on a role with consistent plot progression in the last few books and Swallowing Darkness takes us into some very unexpected places. Choices are made. Serious choices. Choices that readers will love and hate at the same time. The main question after this book is - where do we go from here? Merry's future is completely turned upside down, again, and while I don't know if that's a good or bad thing, I do know that it'll be a hell of a ride.The Bad: Not a thing.

My daughter loves it, but the zipper sticks a lot. This is a plastic coated backpack that is good in weather, but not great for wear. If your child has a habit of dragging their backpacks, I'd avoid this one.

The Good: Taranis has been discussed at length many times in the previous books, but we finally get to see him as a major character in A Lick of Frost. Everything mentioned before pales in comparison to the reality of what Taranis is capable of. Things get dark and gritty quickly and Hamilton is the queen of dark and gritty. Some very powerful, emotional, devastating stuff goes on here with Taranis and beyond. Merry experiences bitter joy and deep loss, all in the confines of needed plot progression. Frost's backstory was an important inclusion here, really explaining who he is and why he's different than the other sidhe.The Bad: This is another shorter book and I sincerely believe it should have been combined with Mistral's Kiss to make one larger novel that would fit better with the flow of the series.

The Good: This book was simply amazing. I felt wonderful things, horrible things, painful things and joyous things. A complete roller coaster of emotions. While the focus was on saving Hank, these really was so much more to it. Hank's situation fueled the progression, but things soon surpassed his survival and resolved plot issues that has existed since the very beginning. Another book is forthcoming, someday, but I would have been fully satisfied had this been the last. That's not to say I don't want another - I do and I'm pretty excited about it - but that I'm completely happy with the answers to my questions and where the story has brought us thus far.The Bad: Not a thing.

The Good: I am really enjoying this series of graphic novels. Cycles features a fully detailed story, as well as moving the overall plot along. More questions are raised than answers are given, but the journey has only just begun for Yorick. The characters and premise continue to appeal and I have high hopes for satisfying resolution given what I've read so far. This series debuted well before the current dystopia boom and the originality shines through.The Bad: Not a thing.

This apron is perfect for all sizes. It has one long tie, so you can adjust how high or low you want it to cover your chest. The tie is so long that I can wrap it easily around to the front to tie and I'm well over 200 pounds.When it arrived, the material was very stiff. I machine washed it with other clothing in hot water and it softened up quite a bit. It is cotton and wrinkles very easily so make sure to immediately hang or fold it after it comes out of the dryer.

The Good: I really enjoyed the entirely of Rose questioning her own sanity. The way it was effecting her ability to perform up to her usual standards put her on the same playing field as some of the other students. It also made her more relatable. She's no longer only tough, rule breaking, does what she want girl. She's growing to consider others, and not just Lissa. She's finally getting some real answers with Dimitri and honestly, that's a huge part of my love for this book. We so needed progress in that area.The Bad: The ending left me annoyed. Yes, it does it's job of making me need to know what will happen. But it just felt wrong. Out of left field, and not in a wow what a shock type of way. Also, this book was really long. Much longer than it needed to be. We rehashed the past over and over when a vague bit and here and there would have done fine.

The Good: Puck is amazing and Ash isn't bad at all either. The love triangle works because both of the guys in Meghan's life are so different, but equally as good for her. It would make sense for her to be with either one of them. There is a good amount of action in this book, some twists and a major surprise or two. The pace is extreme and it was extremely hard to put down once I started.The Bad: Meghan makes some strides in growing up, accepting the world around her and not whining all the damned time. Now she only whines about 50% of the time and is annoying, yet tolerable. While I love her story, her personality grates.

The Good: The Cat and Bones dynamic is super sexy. They're very close, but at the same time, they're starting all over again after having been apart for so long. They're still learning about each other and what has transpired in their time apart. Some decent revelations here, mostly unexpected. The mystery didn't feel like a traditional mystery in that we were searching for answers as much as we were seeing how the characters were dealing with the problem. We were waiting to see how everything turned out for them.The Bad: I had to keep reminding myself that this wasn't the first book in the series and that I had actually read the previous book. While Cat was a familiar character, her situation was much different that the previous book. The world building has been established, but there was a huge amount of government job specific building that really made it feel like we were starting over. Normally, that would be fine, but being only the second book in the series, I would have wanted to get more character centric progress as opposed to having to rework a lot of what we had experienced in the first book.

The Good: V's backstory was completely laid out, surprising and totally emotion pulling. We learn what he's been through to make him as troubled as he is now. As with all the previous books in the series, no matter what you think of the main brother of the story going in, you can't help becoming very attached to him as the story goes on. His future destiny is equally as unfair as his past and seeing him struggle with it - vying between destiny/duty and love kept me completely glued to the page. No huge battles with the lessers here, which I was quite thankful for as they are the worst part of the series for me. We get to see the other brothers stories continue to unfold in bits and pieces we didn't know we were missing.The Bad: Jane wasn't a great fit for V. Yeah, she's willing, eventually, but she feels too available to his wants. Or something. It's hard to describe, just a gut feeling I had the entire time I was reading their time together that they just felt wrong. And I would have liked it if V hadn't found it necessary to hold back so much every time things got a little frisky. I get being scared, but if you have to hide this much of your need, maybe she isn't the girl for you.

The Good: I think this is where the TV show veers sharply away from the books. This book has a ridiculous amount of surprises, even for the avid show fan. You go in expecting one thing, or if you watch the you are expecting something different, what you get is something completely off the wall unexpected - and that's sort of amazing. Huge, HUGE, shocking revelations in this book just blew my mind. Sansa and Jaime really shine here, their stories fleshing out and growing their characters. The book slowed down a lot on the action and replaced it with political intrigue and setup for future events. The pace was slow but completely engaging.The Bad: I hadn't noticed while reading, which probably says something, but this book only covers half of the characters. The last section of the book mentions that this installation in the series focuses on those close to King's Landing and that the next book will focus on those farther away like Stannis, Daenerys, Jon and Tyrion. So, while very long, the book only covers half of the current story. The next book is supposed to cover the same exact time period, which really should have been covered here. I would have rather had half the time covered, but all the characters - all the story lines playing out at once.

The Good: I postponed reading this book for years. The cover screamed cheap romance and the title made it seem like it was selling the raunchy aspect over plot of any kind. Needless to say, I went into this book with a very closed mind and expected a large amount of eye rolling during my read through. I found myself pleasantly surprised. Yes, this is paranormal romance. Yes, there are sexy times. I usually enjoy both, by the way. But nothing here was cheap and easy and the book was chock full of exciting story elements. The psychic race was done uniquely, creating a whole unexpected set of obstacles.The Bad: The world building slowed the pace significantly,  but it had to be done. Sascha was internally repetitive at times, making me want to slap her silly for harping on her "brokenness."

The Good: I love how this series slowly unfolds the whole paranormal side of things. As the third book, the faerie stuff is coming into the forefront. We still get a ton of answers regarding the ongoing mystery of Olivia's parents crimes, but we also get a lot of the why and how of the town of Cainsville itself. There is a love triangle building up steam, but it's weird. Olivia is sort of stuck between Ricky and Gabriel, but Gabriel has more issues than any character in any book EVER, so romance isn't a possibility for him. The love triangle thing is a predestined deal of sorts, so it's going to play out regardless of its realistic possibilities, which will likely lead to some very interesting events in the future.The Bad: Not a thing.

The Good: Lots of sexy times, a little more hardcore than we've seen before in the series. Variety is good in a series with this much mating going on. Significant increases in power move the story along and give the reader some interesting possibilities for the future. Merry remains awesome, as she masters diplomatic issues and the hardness that is necessary in the world of faerie.The Bad: Mistral's Kiss is significantly shorter than the earlier books in this series. Normally, not a huge deal - but here it's extremely noticeable in the lack of single book mystery. The entire book pushes forward the series but lacks anything that would make it stand out in the series as important on its own.

The Good: Merry and her men continue to be awesome, navigating the deadly political situation they've been thrust into. A murder mystery in the Slithen mixes the world of magic and faerie with the human forensics. I love how everything Merry says or does changes the whole of faerie. Her every action seems to push the plot into a new direction. You never know what the magic may do.The Bad: The book moves at a quick pace the entire time, except when things get sexy. Those scenes seem to go on at a snails pace. Which makes very little sense since Merry is usually in the middle of a time-sensitive perilous situation when the clothes start coming off. All of this is important to the overall plot of the series, but it would be nice if the pace was balanced throughout.

The Good: This series is comparable to the Once Upon a Time TV show, except it's a little more messed up. It pushes the envelope more, taking the well known characters into darker places. And that's pretty awesome. Some very good twists in this edition. Definitely plan on continuing on with Fables.The Bad: Animal Farm wasn't quite as good as the first volume, but that's probably tied pretty closely to my dislike of the George Orwell book of the same name. This volume loosely follows the happenings in that book and that particular plot line never works for me.Also: If you enjoy these graphic novels, you have to check out the video game, The Wolf Among Us. It's phenomenal.

The Good: I continue to read this series in utter disbelief. Jaw hanging open, more often than not. I struggled reading A Storm of Swords - reading as fast as possible to find out what was going to happen next, while trying to slow myself down enough so I didn't miss anything. It's hard to explain my addiction to this series. The characters are so good. So well developed. So complex, that we keep uncovering things we never expected. I am constantly surprised at every plot twist, yet I know I should expect the unexpected at every turn. Nothing is ever as it seems, even when it couldn't possibly be other. If that makes sense. The writing in these books gets under your skin. Martin making you question your initial opinions. Making you love the characters you should be hating. Making you root for things that make you a very bad person. It sort of makes you crazy in the best possible way.The Bad: Not a thing.

The Good: The characters in this series continue to amaze me. They are so wonderful. Or horrible, depending. So many secrets, lies, hidden pasts waiting to be uncovered. I never know what was going to be revealed next. The political intrigue plays out in often scandalous fashion. The more I read these books, the more I see the series as primarily historical fiction with a hint of magic thrown in now and again rather than straight high fantasy and that really works for me. A little easier to put down than the last one, but still a very quick read considering the length of the book. Can't stop, have to keep going, have to know what happens next.The Bad: Thing dragged a little more here than in the first book. There seemed to be a decent amount of unnecessary filler and not as much plot progression as I would have liked for a book of this size.

The Good: I'm not a fan of Nora Robert's romance novels, so I dragged my heels in getting around to read her pseudonymous In Death science fiction series. I should not have done that and now have over 40 books I'm excited to catch up on. The mystery is really fantastic and edgy - doing well to illustrate the world Robb is building here. Roarke is a fascinating character, much of his life and history is hidden and rumored, making me want to know it all the more.The Bad: Eve is strong and smart. She's also super annoying when it comes to men. Her budding relation with Roarke is the basis of half the series so I can see why the author would push the issue, but her choices in relation to him are career suicide. Her risk taking based on lust makes her character hard to root for.

The Good: Diana and Matthew's journey has been epic, through time and space. The ending of their story is just what you'd expect - magnificent. These books are written beautifully, detailed without dragging and realistically emotional. I would have never expected a love story between a witch and a vampire to feel like such a serious, important book. I love how intelligently this series was written, educational, yet entertaining with the academic details. The ending was all I could have ever hoped for and more. All my questions were answered and I am at peace with the characters and their world.The Bad: Not a thing.

The Good: I'm always wary of middle of a trilogy books. I've been let down more often than not. Totally not the case here with Independent Study. Joelle Charbonneau blows this installment right out of the park. Big things happen in Independent Study. This book has action, really emotional events, important plot progression, everything that makes a sequel essential. Cia is sort of annoying at times, but it's realistic given everything that's going on around her. We got a bunch of answers to questions, but even more questions have arisen, making me super excited for the next book.The Bad: Not a thing.

The Good: I loved this book, and that was a huge surprise. I was vaguely intrigued way back when I heard about this book pre-release, but once I got my hands on it I continually put it off. I love the 80s, but 80s gaming isn't my specialty. I got sucked into the book immediately and read it for hours after I had planned on going to sleep. I picked it up the next day and didn't put it down until I finished it. I was completely enthralled, loving the 80s movie and music mentions, even if the gaming went a bit over my head at times. I often found myself thinking that this was the coolest book every written. The stakes were high, always, and the world was so creative - virtual and real world. I'm currently counting the days until the movie is released, some 2 years for now - it's a long count.The Bad: Not a thing.

The Good: People rave about this series. I just didn't get the appeal. From what I had heard, it seemed like every other generic fantasy epic saga. But I sort of wanted to finally check out the TV series (5 seasons behind everyone else) and I have a need to read the books before seeing the movies and shows based on them. So I went into A Game of Thrones expecting to be bored quickly and often. I was absolutely shocked at how quickly I got sucked into the story. I read this book for 3 days straight, did not put it down. Read it walking from one room to another. Read it and woke up with it on my face after my 3 hours of sleep, only to continue reading it immediately. I had to know what was going to happen next. I came to care about the characters in a painful way. Painful, because even those who don't read the series and watch the show know of GRRM's need to kill everyone all the damned time. The book was long. It was very detailed. It is also one of the very few books that carries its length well. This wasn't a case of a lazy editor - oh no, GRRM just packs a ton of wonderful into every single page.The Bad: Not a thing.

The Good: I never buy short stories, but since I've loved everything written by Mira Grant, I decided to give this one a shot. It was much shorter than I expected, but the story was totally worth the purchase. This story was utterly captivating. Good premise, huge tension, abrupt on-point ending, every element of the story perfectly executed. This is how you do a short story.The Bad: Not a thing.

The Good: Shades of Earth was the absolute perfect ending to this series. So much action. So many unexpected twists. So much emotion I could barely contain myself. Every single question I had was answered fully. I could not have asked for a better book to finish out this amazing world. Everyone experiencing life on land for the first time. The wildness and unknown. An entire hidden past that changes everything. This is how you end a trilogy.The Bad: Not a thing.

The Good: I love everything Jonathan Maberry writes and Flesh & Bone was no exception. Benny and the gang face yet another evil, in addition to the ever-present zombies, and it's the craziest one yet. I was on the edge of my seat, so to speak, the entire time I was reading this book. I couldn't put it down. This series is very much like a young adult version of The Walking Dead. Same horror, same creeptastic situations, same level of danger and excitement - just with teenagers as the main characters. I felt like we got to know the characters a lot deeper in this book, especially Chong and Lilah. The book ends smack dab in the middle of some plot progression - a total "To Be Continued" moment that makes me desperate to continue on to the next book in the series.The Bad: Not a thing.

The Good: This series is super fast paced and full of action. Nothing drags the story. I just can't put them down once I start one. Magic Strikes is when the Kate/Curran tension gets ramped up like crazy. Sexy as hell. Waiting for Kate to get out of her own damn way, because Curran - just wow. The whole Midnight Games situation was really interesting. Well, more than interesting - I got very into it - but Kate/Curran just kind of eclipsed everything else.The Bad: Not a thing.

The Good: The chalice appears and boosts the series into overdrive. The power the chalice can give or return to a Sidhe significantly raises the stakes for Merry and is the stat of a long-running subplot in the series. Seduced by Moonlight is when things change in the series, when the pace of the books increases greatly. Now, not only does Merry have to get pregnant to gain the throne and protect herself from Cel, she also has to act as the vessel of the goddess to bring all of faerie back into their rightful power. As more and more danger is thrown in Merry's path, the sexy times ramp up to secure her rise to power. These books are almost impossible to put down.The Bad: Not a thing.

The Good: This was an extremely thrilling mystery. I loved being stumped the entire time I read the book. I loved Eva, her outlook and her friendship/romance/whatever with Nate. It was great how the visions Eva had changed as soon as the people involved in the visions changed their minds. The book was legitimately scary at times. More of a creepy, unsafe feeling. That was very awesome, having a book effect me like that.The Bad: There was no real satisfying explanation to Eva's visions. Yes, it was resolved and finalized and all that jazz, but I never really got the feeling that the we knew for sure why she was having the visions that were so directly connected to the killer.

Using this is the same as not using anything at all. I've used many serums and hair protectants over the years, some good and some very bad. This product isn't bad. It doesn't weigh down hair or make it greasy. It just isn't good, as it doesn't seem to do anything at all. After using this product, my hair was the same as it is without product. Same amount of frizz, same texture, same everything. I would expect more obvious results from an "EXTRA STRENGTH PROFESSIONAL" product.

My 5 and 6 year old daughters love this playhouse and I totally understand why. It's got lots of pieces and plays fun music. My 2 year old is completely indifferent to it though. Which works out well, as the rocket ship garage refuses to stay attached if moved even slightly and my older kids get annoyed when the baby plays rough with it.This is an attractive set, but the music is loud and doesn't have a volume control. The pieces feel are sturdy enough to withstand most play, as long as they aren't stepped on my adults. Overall, a decent toy for a the higher end of the suggested age group set.

I can't even begin to explain the freedom a cordless vacuum brings. There was this small corner I just couldn't reach, in almost every room in my home. They're all finally clean.This thing is light. Perfect for going up and down the stairs. It has a low profile swivel head, allowing for easy access into even the toughest to reach areas. They're is no place in my home I can't reach with this vacuum.The batteries last 25 minutes each, more than enough time to vacuum my 4 bedroom 2 story top to bottom with an extra battery to spare almost every time.Unfortunately, the hose is short. Like, wow short. It connects to the removable handle to reach further, but this makes it less than flexible and still doesn't give as much reach as any of my previous vacuums. All in all, it's an acceptable trade for all this vacuum can do well.

I have bad luck with coffee presses. I've gone through 3 in the past year so far. I seem to have an issue with knocking the glass carafe into things when it's hot. Seems that shatters even the supposed "shatter-proof" carafes.That said, the Kona french press is still standing and functional. A small miracle, really. Or, more likely, it's the plastic carafe holder. While not as glamorous as the metal holders, the plastic seems to absorb the bumps and keeps the glass intact.My only complaint is the filter design. Coffee grounds get trapped in between the lip of the filter and the plunger. The entire thing needs to be taken apart to get them all out. I hadn't had this issue with other coffee presses.

The Good: The best Charley Davidson book yet! Charley's off even more than usual due to lack of sleep, but that doesn't make her even a tiny bit less entertaining. Fun and unexpected twists as well as totally unforeseeable mystery. Reyes is unbelievably mad, but that doesn't cool down the super hot fun times. How could things get any better than this?The Bad: Not a thing.

The Good: This is how you end a trilogy. Exciting and action packed scenes, one right after the other. Always on the the edge of your seat. A completely wrapped up storyline, with an unexpected conclusion. Complete closer with the characters we've come to know and love and/or hate. I absolutely loved every single thing about this book. It absolutely made the series.The Bad: Not a thing. It was perfect.

The Good: Panic was an exciting read. It made sense in a way that I think will connect with a lot of people. Kids living in a small, go-nowhere town pool money and compete in a dangerous contest for a chance to get out and have a different life. The characters were really interesting and I had a hard time putting the book down. I just had to know what was coming next and how everything was going to work out.The Bad: I love a good epilogue and the last chapter is pretty much that. Two months or so in the future, we see how the characters are doing. What lost me was the extremely heavy-handed moral of the story blatantly written out in the last few paragraphs. If the book had ended two pages sooner, it would have been perfect. That last bit completely rubbed me the wrong way.

The Good: This was a fun, fluffy series to read and I was pretty pleased with the where the characters ended up. Not everyone grew or changed, but that's what makes the entire situation realistic. Some people are going to end up on the same path they started on. I loved that we get pretty definite answers to the few remaining questions lingering from the earlier books and that we knew where everyone is off to, for the most part, now that high school is over.The Bad: This book didn't flow nearly as well as the earlier novels in the series. It seemed as though the author got sidetracked cramming in everything readers wanted to know that the book ended up weirdly fast paced.

The Good: Great interwoven mysteries I didn't see coming. Yuki is getting more interesting and it's about time. Maybe she just needed some male interaction. I especially loved Lindsay in this book, and her having to come to terms with being part of a married couple as opposed to just an individual who only consider herself.The Bad: I would have loved to have seen a ton about Lindsay's wedding, since we've been leading up to it since almost the start of the series. It was glossed over so completely I thought I may have missed a book between the last one and this one. Also, in certain instances, main characters should die. Patterson has done it earlier in the series, so it's confusing as to why he's letting everyone live pretty much happily ever after.

Bought these because I do some living history costuming and they have a bit of a look like some that people wore back in the (way) old days.  Went 1/2 size up as people recommended - thank you!  Although, the pair I got had a full 3/4 inch difference around the top between the left and right boot.  Returned for a different pair, fingers crossed.  The ONE complaint I really have is that there isn't very much padding in the footbed.  I have very high arches and can't walk for long without some shock absorption.  These aren't horrible - I did order another pair - but I would think twice about these if I planned to walk miles or wear them on a long trip or something.  That said, they're pretty cute and the price is fair for the quality.
Not awesome print quality of these maps, for the price.  Expected it to be larger and with higher resolution.  The text is informative.
Super cute! Plan to wear this on the 4th every year!

Clips with a curved jaw mean you can clamp your towel to your beach umbrella, or hang things off the top of your chair.  In a pinch you can also use these for chip clips at lunch, or put one in your hair!  I started with six and came back to buy more - Can think of many productive uses for these.  Love!

LOVE these shoes.  Luckily I bought two colors!  The soles are really soft like a yoga mat - yet there's plenty of arch support.  The seller is located in Germany, but I've bought from them three or four times now - the shoes usually arrive within a week.  I might need yet another color!

These are cute as can be but have a high sort of 'rim' around the front - which didn't accommodate my larger big toe.  Also, the 'keepers' for the straps are thin straps of leather which I would anticipate would break easily - and would be hard to replace, which would make the straps stick out and look odd.Too bad, because I love the color and these are obviously otherwise well made.

For several years EVA Arizonas were hard to find.  I ordered a pair from Germany and have literally worn them out - holes in the soles - so was thrilled to see I could finally get an easy, affordable replacement.I absolutely live in these things in the summer.  I have super high arches and am a supinator, so have to have a lot of cushioning underfoot.  I also do a lot of yard work so need something waterproof.  I can wear Crocs, but the wide width makes my foot slip around so they don't quite fit right.  Like the story about Goldilocks and the bears, these are just right.  The material underfoot is squishy like a yoga mat - plus they weigh almost nothing.  I've also ventured into the Madrid and the EVA Gizeh's and have nothing but good news to report.I think I'll hoard a few pairs of these in case they again become hard to find.  For the price, how can you go wrong.

LOVE!  I have another pair of Madrids in the two-strap style and I have literally worn them out - holes in the bottom.  I ordered another pair and when they arrived the footsole was a lot harder, more like molded plastic than soft rubber.  So, I ordered these from Amazon knowing I could easily return them in case of a problem.Not to worry.  They are FABULOUS.  I have super high arches and am a supinator so I have to have a lot of soft cushioning.  These are NOT hard, they're cushy and comfy, and I'm already living in them.  I bought the pink color in a 39 (fits my US 9 foot fine) - think I'll try the red ones next.  (Edit: the red ones are similarly awesome.  Now for black and whatever color they make ;))I tried on some white ones in a store and the footbed did feel a little harder.  If you get white and they're too firm, try one of the other colors.I was afraid they'd be too loose and I'd kick them off.  I have a somewhat narrow foot but they fit just fine.  What am I saying - these are AWESOME.  I may even buy another of the pink color in case they quit making them.

I'm a big fan of Case Logic for various reasons - the price point is pretty reasonable, and the products seem to hold up well for the price.  This little case is no exception.Honestly, I ordered the case with nothing in particular in mind - it seems like I've always got something that will fit in one of these little jobs.  It could be a small camera, maybe a slew of charger bricks, or similar.  What I like about these is, the size is pretty reasonable, which makes the weight not a problem if I choose to purchase several of these to transport items in a suitcase.  They're even fairly well water resistant, with a liner which will keep your stuff from getting soaking wet if you're stuck in a shower.  Caveat: I wouldn't hold one under a faucet or leave it out in the rain, but for a short hike or a little sprinkle you should be OK.The only criticism I might have is that this is black - if you put it inside a suitcase with a black lining you might inadvertently over look it.  If it came in alternative, brighter colors I might have been tempted to go for that instead.  Also, don't forget to put a small luggage tag on your case - the handle makes that easy to do - so it can find its way home should you misplace it.

Bought plain Arial text on a black tag and it looks great.  I needed something a little more professional looking than the crummy tag that came with  my briefcase.  These arrived really quickly, are very sturdy, and a great price.  Only issue is, now I'm going to have to order some more as gifts - everyone asks where I got them!

I agree with others in that this book is beautifully written, but I ordered it mostly because my ancestors hail from this part of the world and I was looking for a little detail about it.  The book is more of a day to day, diary format without very much information the background of the area.Honestly, the writing is fabulous and it deserves more than the three stars I'd have given it for what I view as a slightly misleading product description - but I don't want to ding this great author, so four stars it is.

Just in time for my beloved Nashville Predators to arrive in the Stanley Cup Playoffs! It's a little expensive, but in my opinion worth it - quality materials, plus the adjustable beard makes it more comfortable. I am going to sew an enormous team logo onto the front of the hat. Thanks Beard Head!

I finally sprung for my own copy of this book, which in my view is irreplaceable as a resource for any study of early Nashville.  Yes, it's expensive, but it's worth it.  For months now I've been faithfully traveling to the state Archives to view their copy - but the details here are such that it may save me the time and expense of a trip to North Carolina or Virginia while trying to run down an ancestral line, so it's time for me to get my own copy for off-hours study.The actual book is large and richly detailed, so you can actually read the maps within without much trouble.  It's based on primary source material, not guesswork and speculation like some, so you can take what it says to the bank.  I'll start saving my pennies for the other volumes soon.

Get ready to start drooling to go to Scotland!  have been contemplating such a trip myself for ages and honestly I'm not sure how much longer I can hold out - I understand the pound sterling is finally at a reasonable exchange rate vs. the American dollar.This tourbook is laid out pretty well as one might expect, with the various things to do in different locations.  Where it really stands out I think is the practical advice - what times of year are good for certain things and little need-to-know items like what gear to bring or what to wear.  Readers are also advised with local faux-pas to avoid, down to which sports teams are favored in certain areas.  I also like the historical perspective, which is important when visiting a place with such a past.  The book includes a full fold-out map of Edinburgh and many other helpful layouts of various cities.  Maybe I'm just easily amused, but I always get a kick out of the rulers LP print in the inside of their book jackets ;)If I were to make one criticism it might be something like additions for specialty shops or restaurants.  Although the book is packed absolutely full of detail and generally is first-rate.  I also like that it's not enormous so I can actually carry it with me in a daypack as opposed to leaving it at the hotel for nighttime reference only.

My husband and I recently got onto the GoPro wagon as I am a scuba diver and he's a fiddler about the house one of our favorite uses for our cameras is strapping them to the birdfeeder to watch our little critters dine.  We have rapidly accumulated cases, chargers, etc. so it's getting to be time to think about organizing it all.I guess I hadn't realized this case was quite so big.  That's both good and bad - good in the sense it's going to be harder for me to mislay than I might otherwise.  If it had come in a color other than black I might select that, since I tend to mislay black items in black suitcase interiors more often.  Of course it will however take up more room in your luggage.One thing I really like is how lightweight it is.  For years I've been using Pelican brand plastic cases to protect my camera gear but those really weigh a lot, particularly once you get them loaded with metal camera lenses.  With suitcases ever more expensive to check, a less-heavy solution is really a boon.  I get the sense the closed cell foam in this case will do a good job protecting my gear without all the added weight.I've owned Thule brand cases and protectors before, so can say that these are really well made - the zipper is sturdy and obviously won't come apart too soon with wear.  I'm not 100% crazy about the foam being pre-formed (some foam-filled cases are what's called 'pick and pluck' so you can size them to preference.)  That said I think it'll work well enough since it's got a couple of big squarish holes where I can cram in my miscellany. ;)  I also like that it's got the carrying handle on the corner so I can attach it to something with a carabiner.I suspect my spouse will be getting one of these for his birthday soon!

I just noticed the five-star rating here on Amazon means "I love it," but in this case it means: THEY love it!  I have my five cats tricked into thinking brands of food they don't normally get are treats, as opposed to the more-expensive actual treats.  Long story short, if it's something they really like they'll dance on their hind legs and beg, or wait till my back is turned and try to chew into the bag.This one is a big hit.  I'm getting lots of begging and sorrowful lookspleeeeeeeze Mom so far we've gone through about half the bag in three days!  The pieces are big and seem to have quite a bit of flavor, to judge from their reactions.  Of course with only one bag I have no idea what it would do for their health over time, but I've been feeding them Friskies canned food for years one of them is 19 years old and going strong, so Friskies must be doing something right.

Completely fabulous mix for the little critters.  Trouble is, like other Lyric products, it goes so fast you'll need to buy a lot of it.  Luckily it's not terribly expensive.  I just went and put some out for my resident birds - which I think of as my pets - because the weather is scheduled to get really bitter here over the next few days.  You'll also draw cardinals, titmice and nuthatches with this mix, in my experience.  Shipped in no time flat - they really love it.

This came just at the right time as our area was hit with an unchararacteristically cold snap.  Long story short:  it drew red-winged blackbirds.  Hordes of them!  Beautiful!  The woodpeckers love it, too.  The only problem you're going to have with this mix is that it vanishes instantly, like Chex Mix at a party.  I think our critters (I put out some for the squirrels) went through it inside a couple of hours.If you're new at feeding birds and are looking for something that will bring them in droves, give this a try.  It's not terribly expensive for what it is, either.

I do a lot of genealogy research, which means spending time in libraries Xeroxing piles of documents.  In a nutshell this item is a godsend - while I can always use binder clips or rubber bands to hold my copies, I find that sheets often slip out using those holders.  Often the materials I'm copying are handwritten notes or other ephemera that are without page numbers.  It's great to have a stapler that can handle pretty much whatever I throw at it without binding up or leaving the last couple of pages to fall out and get lost.  The ONE downside is that I'm going to have to remember to buy the special staples for this magnificent item - but given that Amazon delivers things so quickly that likely won't be too big of a problem.I have disproportionately small hands, so was sort of worried about the strength that would be required to fire metal through 40 sheets of paper.  Luckily that really hasn't been an issue, since the construction of the stapler is such that leverage does the work rather than your knuckles.  I even was able to staple together some material that had a bit of a hard plastic coating on it without too much trouble.  For the price you really can't beat this item.

Just another plus size woman who LOVES this suit.  One detail, though that I didn't notice in other reviews:  I wear a size 18W in most street clothes, but had to order up THREE sizes (to a 24W) to get the correct size in this bathing suit.  Luckily I read the sizing chart on the seller's website before I ordered.  That being said, there is nothing not to love about this suit - it's fully lined and perfect for my purpose (scuba diving).  Really had to look long and hard to find one that didn't send the wrong message with too much flesh exposed - I am just not interested in appearing to be trying to 'pick up' the married men in my scuba group!  Think I'll order a couple more of these suits just in case they stop making them.  I also ordered some of the swim shorts and the coverup shorts for this suit, all of which appear to run at least two or three sizes too small but are well made and fabulous otherwise.

I have extremely high arches and am a supinator so have to wear shoes with a lot of cushioning.  These are so awesome I can hardly believe it.  I'd buy another pair if I hadn't already bought the Neevah, which is basically this shoe in a short boot.  Oh, and the Kaleen, too.  :)I have some other Ugg short boots I have worn absolutely to death for the past six years, which is why I won't ever buy the off brands - real Uggs last forever.  My experience is that the wool will eventually pack down, which is why it feels so tight at first.  These will feel too tight for the first several weeks or even a couple of months, but eventually they'll be heavenly.They're also going to be a little bit waterproof.  Not sure I'd wear these out in a flood, but they're going to be better than the suede boots that do sometimes show water stains.  I expected them to be really warm - and they are somewhat casual looking - but I didn't expect them to be fabulously comfortable.  Really really love these.  I may buy another of the exact same pair in case they stop making them.

In a nutshell (tee hee), my critters went bananas over this.  I often joke that the definition of happiness is a blue jay with a peanut, and the four that visit my yard regularly were some joyous birds this week.Honestly, the mixture in this feed seems human-food grade.  I saved it to start putting it out on a very cold day and the three or so cups I put out that first day were gone inside an hour.  That's actually the one downside - it's surely not going to last very long.I placed some down on the sidewalk under the birdfeeder and the chipmunks and squirrels loved it as well as the hairy woodpeckers, white breasted nuthatch and cardinals that visit my feeder.  If I can get this for a good price I will definitely keep some on hand for the animals I almost think of as pets, that live outside.

Really nice little cross.  I bought this for an early-1800s historical costume - they wouldn't have worn big flashy jewelry at that time - it will fill the bill perfectly!It isn't super huge or noticeable, but it's shiny and lovely.

I needed a collar for a living-history costume from the early 1800s, so I removed the rhinestone brooch and added a cameo pin.  It looks more authentic than you would imagine.Be aware, though, that it contains real rabbit fur, not faux - I might not have purchased it had I realized that (and might have returned it had I not been in a time crunch for my costume.)  I got it quickly and it's just as described, though.

I have an older edition of this cookbook I've used to rags and am pleased to say this new one is awesome.  IMO, a key to weight loss is learning to achieve great-tasting food without overuse of needlessly caloric ingredients.  As a pescetarian, it's also important to me that some of the recipes are vegetable-heavy.This fills the bill nicely.  Really tasty entrees are included and there's even a 'vegetarian entree' section.  One of my favorites so far is the North African Chickpea and Vegetable Tagine.  Speaking of sections, the cookbook is organized helpfully - categories include "small plates," "seafood entrees," "slow cooked favorites" - there's even a small "fruit and frozen dessert" section.On the downside, this isn't the hugest cookbook I've ever seen.  It's nowhere near as large as Moosewood or even Joy of Cooking.  But it's well-curated, IMO.The book itself is pretty interesting, also.  It's actually a small three ring binder, so it's easy to move favorites up to the front or take out pages if you need to carry them to the store.I find these books are my favorites more due to the quality of the recipes than anything.  None of the recipes require ingredients that are extra hard to find or contain overly complicated directions.  I would imagine my household will be using this new edition to pieces for years.

The image itself is of a person very important to my family's history, but it's obviously a photograph of a print - not a printed copy itself.I guess I'm glad to have it, but would have preferred a clearer copy.

This is an optical character recognition (OCR) edition - the formatting makes it nearly unreadable, with pages of gibberish and lots of nonsense characters interspersed with text.  (OCR saves publishers the trouble of re-typesetting old books, since a computer "reads" the words and reprints them on the page.)  I'd have avoided this edition if I'd known this in advance.The book itself is full of interesting information, but you may want to choose a different edition if you want to read it without going to a great deal of trouble trying to interpret what it actually says.

For whatever reason my particular metabolism runs through calcium more quickly than some people.  If I don't get enough my hair starts to fall out and I get horrendous insomnia and a host of other health problems.  Pill-type supplements do a little bit of good, but in order to avoid all the problems I really need the mega-protein (and calcium) dietary additives.Pure Protein doesn't have as much calcium as some supplements, but it's also got fewer calories.  It costs lots less than the powder from the vitamin store, too.  I like the flavors - this one goes well with both milk and a kind of powdered peanut butter I sometimes use to make a 'banana split' smoothie.  You can buy PP in a much larger container but those take up a lot of room in the cabinet - really would prefer to buy it in these smaller jars even if the cost is a little bit more.

Hadn't thought I would like this, since it's noticeably thinner than other duct tapes.  As it turns out I like it a lot, since mostly I use duct tape for packing up things I plan to return to manufacturers or send to friends.  It's much stronger than regular packing tape but thin enough that it isn't a pain to tear, plus you get more on the roll so you don't run through it so quickly.Downside: it doesn't come in cute colors like other brands, but who cares if you're just using it to seal boxes.  I'm not sure I'd rely on this for actual duct work, though.

I admit I was initially very skeptical.  Have had problems with similar mixers having not nearly enough 'torque' to the point they wouldn't effectively crush ice, which IMO you really have to have for a smoothie.Not the case here.  This is almost shockingly strong.  It will vaporize a glass of ice into orange juice and fruit within about fifteen seconds.  And it has two containers, since you'll be using it a lot.  The best part is the rubber 'feet' that stick it to the counter so it doesn't jog all over the place or make a mess.This is going to be fantastic.  I was getting pretty tired of using my king-sized blender to make smoothies, since it's an older model I can't put in the dishwasher.  Just too cool to able to easily wash this and not have the huge blender carafe from my other model sitting around in the sink, yucky all the time.  No issues with getting the blade off and back on.  I like this so much I think I'll buy a couple more for Christmas gifts or in case they stop making it.  I got the red color, which is just too cute.

Have been buying Wahl brand clippers for years and have some that are probably 15 years old.  Agree with others on the smooth, easy operation.  What's important to me is that the clippers don't seem to injure the skin of my shaggy Maine Coon mix cat, who sometimes gets gunk stuck in his fur that needs to be removed.  Had gotten used to some rechargeable clippers I bought a couple of years ago for my boy, but they never seem to have a charge when I need them.  I have to plug them in and wait a while for them to charge up, which means kitty is uncomfortable until they're ready.  It's nice to have the corded model again, especially one that's long enough to reach across the room if needed (we live in an old house without a ton of outlets).I've been casting around trying to figure out what blades fit this clipper and which smaller blades will work for my less densely-coated cats.  Will update the review once I try a couple of options on that.These are certainly more expensive than some other options, but believe me when I tell you they're an investment and you'll have them for years.  Beats going through several pairs of clippers that are cheaper but add up over time.

**Edited, about three months later: Whatever was making my fan squeak and knock eventually worked itself out.  It's now pretty silent and I sit in front of it constantly while watching TV. Have upgraded my review to five starts, b/c I've been using the heck out of this thing!**Reminder: This fan DOES NOT OSCILLATE.  It's fixed, and the idea is that it moves the air around in the room.  You can set it upright or horizontally.  Either works great - it moves a lot of air and is really comfy if it's a hot day and you're sitting in front of it.One problem:  It makes annoying noises.  When it's on its side, it squeaks.  Upright, a knocking noise.  I think it's just something to do with the air-moving mechanism.  Hopefully it won't stop working.  I probably just got a bad one, since others don't mention these issues.I have a similar Lasko brand upright tabletop fan and I really kind of miss the oscillating action, tell you the truth.  The Vornado probably moves as much air, though, and if I weren't sitting right next to it the noise probably wouldn't be so bothersome.  The styling of it is pretty nice; it's snappy-looking, as opposed to the industrial-looking airmovers you sometimes see.The fixed nature of it really makes me feel like it should include an air filter.  It would do a great job probably, considering the volume of air it moves.  I'd probably buy this again.

Hey everyone, just noticed that the headline for this item reads 'messenger bag', which usually is a sort of large floppy bag you can fit a laptop and some notebooks into.  Please note that this DSLR case is in fact mostly just a DSLR case - I have no idea why they're calling it a 'messenger bag.'That said, it's pretty nice!  It's definitely big enough to fit your DSLR into along with a couple of lenses, or a higher-end point and shoot with some accessories.  It's got the kind of styling that I personally really like - with a detachable lens on, it can be organized so the camera faces down and rests on some padding - then the weight of the camera isn't on the end of the lens.  That said, the dividers inside are completely removeable, so you can arrange this however you like.  (There are two of them and they're fuzzy with velcro on both ends - they 'grip' to the soft inside of the bag, and the hold is what I would describe as 'very firm.')The bag does have a small outside pocket and two 'grab straps' so you can pick it up from the front or the top.  The description advertises 'water bottle pockets' on both sides and I'm personally not sure what I think about that - a SMALL water bottle, sure, but anything larger than that like a Camelbak bottle certainly isn't going to fit.  You likely could fit a small fixed lens or a packet of filters.  The pockets are deep and the top is elasticized, so your stuff shouldn't fall out with normal use.It's nice and thickly padded.  The strap has a nice rubberized shoulder grip pad; the drop is about 24" from the top of the bag.  The back of the bag is mesh padding, NOT a pocket, which will be a pro or con depending on what you're looking for.The real selling point of this bag, though is the semi-concealed pocket at the bottom of the bag that holds a weatherproof cover.  HOW many times have I wished for this when caught outside in a sudden shower while taking pictures?!  Many many scenes of panic while trying to cram a camera bag under my coat come to mind.  These bags are fairly well water resistant but they are NOT waterproof, which means your stuff will get damp.  Thrilled to find they have finally tuned into that fact and included a cover.  BE AWARE the cover is folded and the case comes with it stowed into a dedicated bottom pocket - I turned the house upside down looking for mine, sure it had been left out of the package, until the truth slowly dawned (and now I'm embarrassed!  :))In my mind you just can't have too many of these bags.  I inherit another DSLR every time my semi-pro photographer spouse upgrades, and it's nice to have everything packed into its own bag so I can 'grab and go' depending on what I need to shoot.  Downside: Smaller than other similar bags in this price range.  Upside: The smaller size means less unnecessary bulk and weight if you don't have a lot to carry.  If what you want is a bag to house a DSLR or a higher-end point and shoot with an extended lens, this will probably suit your needs beautifully.

Put my 18 year old black cat on this and, he's back to jumping and running.  It's really amazing to see.  He's clearly feeling a lot better.  I actually give him two of the tablets per day - it costs a little bit of money, but he's been my good boy for a long time and deserves to be taken good care of.  He really doesn't seem to mind the taste, I put it in right on top of the wet food I give him because his teeth have gotten bad.Have had good luck with this supplier, got the pills right on time and in good order.

I have one of these that I keep in my car and I use constantly for everything.  Recent great story: was at a home and garden show at a local fairgrounds.  I have no idea why it didn't occur to the organizers to account for the fact that people would be buying big, bulky plants, but I saw people make several trips to the car.  They were carrying big ferns and palms spilling dirt everywhere, while I made ONE trip using my fabulous wagon!  Everyone kept asking me where I got it.  Honestly someone should sell these at the home and garden show!It carries absolutely a ton of weight - over 100 pounds (though I probably wouldn't try 200).  It's easy to collapse and to get out.  I love mine so much that I recently saw another one on sale and bought it just to have a backup in case they quit making them.  I paid around $100 for my first one, it's nice to see the price has dropped.People are mentioning local retailers and honestly I have seen them at K mart, but if you live in a rural area or away from a big box store I'd say it's well worth paying the shipping to get one of these awesome carts.  They're made really well - the stitching is well done and doesn't come out, the bottom is thick and padded, and the wheels are sturdy.  It's not the most lightweight thing ever but considering how much it holds it's amazing.Just have really been enjoying mine so thought I'd share the good news ;)

This stuff really lives up to the claims.  It seals odors an order of magnitude better than competitors, and I tried with a big box used by five cats!  It also has superior clumping ability as advertised and I like the smell - much less like chlorophyll than competitors.The only downside is it's really expensive for how much you get.  A 10" square box that's 3" deep is at least eight or nine dollars everywhere I've checked - and since you'll be fishing big clumps out of it I wouldn't even really expect it to last that long.In a nutshell, if you have only a couple of cats, you'll probably be really happy with this litter.  Personally, I plan to buy it if I can find it on sale.  It's great to find it on Amazon, though, since it's also fairly heavy and the online delivery will allow you to avoid hauling heavy boxes home from the store.

One thing I like about these is, they're only open on the top - some protectors are open on the top and one side so it can be a little harder to get your documents to stay in.  They're nice and heavy, as advertised, and the hole punches seem like they're not going to tear out so your pages come loose.Mostly I use these for recipes - I like to cut them out of the newspaper and just paste them to a page and throw the whole thing in a notebook.  It's better than having scraps of paper floating all over our house that I can't ever find when I need them.  Since I'm going to be using them a lot I also like having a nice heavier protector.  These are a little more expensive but worth it, IMO.  I also really like that they're acid-free and I haven't had any problems with newsprint lifting on to them.

We have a five-cat household and typically we buy traditional litter due to the higher expense of the scooping stuff.  However, got a box of this to review so here's my 2 cents.It's good litter!  Basically the claims as to the smell seem to be correct.  After a few days of heavy use by our brood, the box wasn't exactly a flower garden but noticeably better than other litters.  The smell of the product itself is fairly pleasant - a little more perfume-y and less like chlorophyll.  It was nice to smell this on our long-haired part-Maine Coon rescue kitty, whose fur really traps odors, as opposed to what he sometimes smells like.It also clumps pretty well, in line with the claims on the box.  I wasn't just overwhelmed, but again it was noticeably better than some competing brands.  There was one wet area that came up mostly in one piece as opposed to my having to go through the box repeatedly.The only downside?  This stuff costs plenty.  The box I got is about 10 inches by 10 by 3.5 or so, so it's not a whole lot of litter, despite weighing 14 pounds.  If you have one small cat and a box will last you a while, then go ahead and buy - but if you have a whole horde of cats, it's probably going to take you the full box and to my mind this isn't a super-terrific financial decision.  That said, I'll be keeping an eye out and buying some on sale where I can find it.

I used this backup to power my iPad for a few hours during a power outage during a strange time of year - didn't expect it, so I didn't have my tablets charged.  The batteries only lasted about three hours, but hey, it's AA batteries - I always have fistfuls on hand so it's no big deal to chew through a bunch of them when you need them.  They're lots cheaper than D batteries to be sure.Think I'll buy another one of these.  Like that it has a detachable cable so I can use either the older iPad cable for my old tablet or the new Lightning connector.

EDIT JUNE 8, 2014: The headline of this review was: WOW!  Intuitive user interface, improved functionality over other optionsHowever, I can't get the program to sync with my online family tree - at all.  Meaning, not one time have I had a successful sync.  The program constantly says I've unlinked my tree from the program - which isn't correct.  I've tried linking and unlinking my tree, downloading my online tree to start from scratch with a new GEDCOM, letting the program run for several days with 'media processing' in the background.  To no avail.One reason I wanted this program is that I have a lot of incorrectly entered place names - various abbreviations and such, that I need to clean up.  It would be so awesome if I could do that locally, then upload my work, but the lack of sync prevents that.  Apparently this is a long-running, known issue with FTM, which is too bad.I cannot recommend this product at this time.  A couple of stars b/c it does at least keep a tree you import from a GEDCOM in decent shape and will allow you to run and print reports from it.  You can also sort your tree by place name, which is more difficult functionality to find than you'd think.*Old review as follows*:Long story short, I'm migrating from Reunion 10 - a genealogy software package for Mac I've been using for a long time.  There's a lot to like about Reunion, so I'm not interested in trashing it as much as in mentioning the (better, IMO) user interface and utility offered by FTM3.I'm an 'advanced beginner' when it comes to genealogical work.  A few members of my family migrated from England to Virginia in the 1600s (to be followed by others) then traveled west to Kentucky and Tennessee, which were the Western frontier of the 1800s.  In my opinion it's a fascinating story and one I can't really get enough of, so I spend quite a bit of my free time trying to dig up details on these relatives.  Friends, I have found tales that sound as though I'm making them up!  In my case it's been absolutely true that you don't know what you'll necessarily find when you start digging into your own family history.Not having had much luck joining genealogical societies, when I first got started I did some research to see what program for the Mac I could use as a repository for these stories and details.  Enter Reunion by Leister Software - it's good enough, will save your people into a database and will allow you to perform the usual searches by tree, overview, pedigree, whatever you like.  Their customer service is terrific.  However, its default data entry screen is somewhat clumsy - media is entered in a different area, there are only a couple of customizable screens you can look at when viewing an entry, and the 'Find' function is somewhat difficult to use, having two search windows - I know, this makes no sense to me either.I know opinions differ on Ancestry.com as a research source.  Admittedly, Ancestry's user-submitted family trees are often riddled with errors - children born after their parents' deaths and similar.  However, using it to fact-check good information can be highly useful.  Since my family roots in the USA go back so far, I often have to sort through information dated before counties or even states were formed, and that means I have to get creative.In one example, I found traces of my 5th great grandfather in Kentucky in 1797, just before Logan became a county, and found a few notes about him in a local library in the Military records section.  1797?  Too late for the Revolution - thanks to Ancestry I now know he was a veteran of one of the Indian wars, and their copy of the paperwork saved me a trip to the National Archives in Washington.  I have many many other similar stories.  It's even possible to get in touch with your distant cousins using Ancestry's messaging system to compare notes with them.  So, for me it's highly useful to own a copy of software that will download and sync with my online Ancestry family trees without my having to download separate copies of my databases and media sources and enter each, plus its description, by hand.Another GREAT fact about Ancestry: You're allowed to download and keep your own records on your family whenever you want - no EULA contracts to sign or Digital Millennium Act threats claiming these records to be the property of someone else.  That's really refreshing considering how many companies try to "monetize" your personal information as a profit center these days.Since I've been working on my database for five or six years now, it's gotten huge - over 1400 entries, with many of them dating to the mid-1600s (and even the Middle Ages) in Scotland and England.  Like many people I find the same place entries in my research over and over, and am contemplating a trip to the UK to visit some of these spots.  Was thrilled to discover upon installing FTM3 that I can now map places!  There really isn't another easy to use solution I've been able to find - websites that used to offer that service have been discontinued.  It's wonderful to see at a glance which relatives are assigned to each place name and to easily see on a map exactly where it is!  Especially when you're dealing with small villages in another country you've never visited, and you have no idea even in what general part of the nation they're located.  You can also see the migration pattern for each person in your tree, interesting in my case as generations traveled west.Just can't say enough about the superior user interface.  The media for each person is saved WITH the person's name and relevant dates and you can see it right there - no having to remember complicated steps to find each piece and to see what sources have been used generally for your tree.Another thing I like: LOTS more options for printing reports, which is useful in my case b/c members of my family often want to know how they're related to someone else.  You can see what the reports on your pedigree or descendants look like and can easily customize which people are included.  No having to remember highly technical terms and run each report four times to get it to include what you want.In a nutshell the functionality of this program is vastly superior to Reunion.  I feel a little guilty saying that since Reunion is stable, reliable and has kept my records in apple pie order for a long time.  However, the developers of FTM3 have clearly learned from users' feedback on the Ancestry.com site.FTM3 comes with an easy to follow, clearly written manual that reads like it was written by a native speaker of English, not a person from another country, so I'm sure I'll be picking up additional tips as the next few weeks roll by.  I'll update my review as I discover new options in the program.  The only reason I'm stopping short of five stars is that I had a little trouble syncing my Ancestry tree the first time I tried, but this may be a problem with my network - will update and add the fifth star if that turns out to be the case.  (Just a reminder:  back up your tree as a GEDCOM before you use this or any other program to mess with it.  You don't want to corrupt the data you've spent months or years compiling!)  EDIT: In contrast to other reviewers I only had a little trouble downloading my tree - it didn't work the first time I tried, but I rebooted the machine and tried again and there were all five of my trees in FTM3, ready for download.  I only downloaded one of the smaller ones to start, will report back after I've tried all of them.In a nutshell I think this would be a great program for a beginner to genealogical research.  You get a free 3-month subscription to basic Ancestry.com to sort of get a feel for the website and how it works - yes, this is likely a 'hook' to get you to sign up for a longer period, but in my case it's been absolutely worth it.  It's fascinating to learn about not only my own family's journey, but about the settlement and evolution of American history, in a context that means a lot to me personally.  I don't think you'll regret it if you purchase this program.

I bought this to prevent my five pet cats from devouring my Rex begonias, since they have dead reckoning ability for anything green and can decimate it in seconds.  Was unsure if the product would wilt the plants or fail to work, but happily neither is the case.  Admission:  I tasted it myself, and yuck!  Keep the cats away for sure, and has had really no noticeable effect on the plants at all, other than appearing to make them stand a little more straight as though they'd been watered.  Will be back for more!

I'm an average size female, I'd guess, and this eyeshade is simply too large for my head.  It slides up, down and all around, and I'm awakened at daybreak by the sunlight streaming in around the edges of this thing.  I'd surely return it if I could.  That said, if you're a larger person looking for a bigger size, this should fill the bill - the materials and workmanship are excellent.  If it only weren't enormous.  Sigh.

Drank a couple of cups of this "decaf" late at night and spent the next seven hours lying in bed staring at the ceiling.  I'm more sensitive to caffeine than most, admittedly, but it's really an inconvenience to unexpectedly be utterly unable to sleep and consequently unable to fulfill your responsibilities the next day.I'm giving it two stars b/c the taste is pretty great, but not at all happy to discover that for me at least, the product has some serious truth-in-advertising issues.

Bought these for this year's Halloween costume.  Thanks to other reviews I learned they run a little small, so I ordered an 11 to fit my size-9 foot and a pair of thickish socks.  They fit fine.However, like someone else I had a problem with the laces being too short.  (My calves are fairly muscular from all the hill climbing I do here in bumpy Nashville.)  The shoe fit, width-wise, but I needed about 16" more lace.  Shocking, I know - the laces that come with these a a full 10 feet long!Trouble is, laces are expensive!!  I looked at one of those custom-order websites and they wanted $18 for a longer lace.  I see someone else tried clothesline cord - I ordered a bunch of grosgrain ribbon in a cute zebra print pattern and am going to try that.  You can use heat-shrink tubing to fix the end of a ribbon like a shoelace: Anytime SHRINK TUBING SLEEVES ASSORTEDAnyway, I'd buy these again.  They do have a zipper up the side, which I somehow overlooked when I ordered them and was pleased to see.  Had been thinking I might trim the tops a bit and I can't do that because zipper, but it looks like I can roll them down fairly easily.

I needed a bigger wallet to carry the billion store cards it seems I'm being required to carry these days (loyalty cards you must present to receive a discount, I mean.)  I'm a small business owner so I also always have tons of receipts & stuff.  This had the most credit card slots of any wallet I could find.I know this is advertised as a travel wallet, but I've been using it day to day and it's excellent.  Pacsafe items are crazy well made - some sort of ballistic fabric - so the cost is worth it.I do wish this were some more flashy color so I wouldn't lose it in the bottom of my bag.  Guess I could put stickers all over it.Hopefully Pacsafe won't discontinue this, because I will eventually wear it out.  I also bought the matching travel-document wallet for more of those pesky receipts.

Get comments on them wherever I go.  I liked my first pair so much I bought two more in different colors.Basically the top part of the shoe stretches out for your foot to go in.  I'm a little worried it may eventually stretch out too much, but it seems pretty sturdy and Crocs are crazy well made, so not *that* worried.The footbed is super-comfortable, which is one reason I like these.  I have very high insteps and require a lot of cushioning, these fit the bill.Another great aspect is that they weigh next to nothing.  I'm always looking for decent-appearing shoes to pack in a suitcase for a trip.  Of course, they're also totally waterproof, which makes them great for a beach vacation.These are fairly unbeatable.  I'll probably buy yet still another pair if Crocs is still making these next year.

Love this new trend of crazy-colored sneakers.  I have high arches and a tendency to walk on the outsides of my feet.  Love the look of these and the cushioning - I can wear them for hours and they feel great.  May buy them in another set of colors, come to think of it...

I'm a larger gal, wear a size 16 in most brands.  I just figured that, even in an XL, these would be too tight and miserable like some others I tried but figured it was worth a shot.  They fit great!  And are soooo cute.  I'm definitely considering a second pair or another one like this in a different pattern.  I'll wear the heck out of these at USA soccer team watch parties.  The best part:  MADE IN USA!!  I will go out of my way to purchase clothing from this manufacturer now that I know how great these are.

I realize the price was low but it got here and it's just so obviously a poor-quality bag manufactured in Asia.  It'd be nice to be able to find something like this made in America for once... I'm going to return this and make my own bag, since I'm a crafty type.

Bought this to carry to outside Preds rallies and such and it's great!  Nice and big, and there's no missing your Preds fandom carrying this thing.  Plenty of room to have guys sign it in Sharpie on the yellow panels, if you're so inclined.  Pretty great product for the price, I'd buy it again like a shot.

Nice drink holder. Stays semi level in the turns. Would like to see the base to drop lower to provide better leveling of top heavy drink cups.I ended up using a 16 ounce Tervis cup in it with a straw. I get insulation and condensation control at the same time.
A little smaller than I was expecting, but it works perfectly for Shrimp Boils.  Fits perfectly in my MasterBuilt Fryer.

These are the quickest and easiest quick releases to use on the market.  Have used them for years, and as long as you insert the tab in straight, you will have zero problems with this setup.  The trouble comes when you don't insert the locking tab in straight.  The device will not unlock in this position. You must fully seat the clip, and then press to release. Wish they could solve that issue after 10 years, but other than that.  This is a good locking clip.
I used a quarter of a bag for a shimp boil with 12 pounds of shrimp. Everyone loved the flavor of this mix. I only added some old bay to have that flavor in the mix as well. Great job!!
