After experimenting with airflow I found that 2 small external fans providing more input air was a 20C answer. These were perfect INTERNAL solution: 2 holes nibbled in the case cover, and voila! The 7100 case is pretty tight ... these squeezed in perfectly  And with an external USB power supply, a system shutdown won't cause heat soak  I'm also a "fan" of the larger, single version, which now exhausts heat from behind the case. The system runs 24/7, generally at 85%+, and nothing inside tops 50C. So ... coo-uhl!;-)

This is a VERY small card ... which is why I needed it. Long story short: old card in PCIe1, 2-bay graphics in PCI16, covering PCIe2, leaving PCI open. So, this went into the PCI, and it doesn't block the GPU fan intake ... opening up PCIE1 for a USB 3.0 card.That was my main reason. Turns out this installed easily,  was compatible with everything else, and has excellent, straightforward controls and panels. 4 speakers + woofer, no problems.I deducted a star because it doesn't have Soundblaster punch, but that wasn't a priority. The space on an older mobo was.If you need to squeeze adequate sound (depending on how hungry your speakers are) into a PCI slot, this is about as tiny as it gets.

This went over Big-Time! What's not to like (unless you like skinny lead)? this comes with enough spare lead and erasers to last a looooooooong time. It's satisfyingly chunky in the hand, with a subtly-textured surface. Very cool! Especially if you love retro 51!

The hand fit on this is nice, and I like the easy-access to the battery compartment (magnetic cover).The adjustable resolution is good, but a bit awkward. You have to push both primary buttons and the wheel button simultaneously, and the LED inside the wheel flashes to inform you of the setting. Which seems funky to me, since your finger will be on the button when it flashes. Why not the side buttons? Who knows? Oh, well ...So far the one thing that REALLY ANNOYS me is the range. If the dongle isn't within two feet  of the mouse, the mouse hops, skips, jumps, freezes, and does just about everything you DON'T want a mouse to do. So, if you're planning on using this on a desktop (as I am), plan on getting a USB extension cable, too. The odd thing about the range (and i've experienced this with other mice, too) is that this mouse is a bit large for netbook/laptop portability. It is a full-size (but not "orthopedic-ergonomic-monster-size) mouse. So to me, the size-to-signal range is a little odd.The programming features are pretty basic (no app-specific macros, etc.) which might turn some folks off. I settle for the wheel button to autoscroll/open new browser tabs (a must-have), left-side/page-down, right-side/page-up. There are a number of other off-the-rack options, as well. If you're looking for a Robo-Gaming MegaSword-Hand --- forget this one.This will do, for now. It's an OK mouse. You can find others that cost less and have more going on, but I got tired of looking and settled for it.

Well, it got here, finally. Pretty sure it drifted.The packaging was ... bizarre. The heli and parts got one partial wrap of bubble, then tossed ... I mean tossed ... into a flimsy cardboard box. A few bent parts and a replaced rotor later, and it actually ran!Fun little thing, neat having it scoot sideways.Would I order from these folks again?Hahahahaha ...

This stuff is amazing. Low tack enough to maneuver, position and remove it, high tack on pressure to itself only. A snip here and there, and it conforms and stays put. Easy to make access hatches for parts that need ocassional access. Tough as heck, and great coloring, too. The more "patchy" your job is, the more effective it looks.I was able to completely mummify a P-rod, scope, stock, and all, with one roll. Small leftover strips used on turrets, QD levers, and trigger guard. Get two, just in case.This material has a grippy surface - great for most things, possibly a problem for others. Used on a buttstock it can hang coming into position. On the other hand, it stays put very well. I wouldn't use it on any surface that has to slide easily or quickly.I can "see" my Mini-14 "disappearing" already!

Neat, clean embroidery, crisply done. Lots of Velcro hooks kn the entire back, sticks to a lot of surfaces.My wife thought it was hysterical.Only wish: I'd prefer it if they'd made it circular, with the commentary around the edge.Still prett nice.

$6 or $7 bucks, lasts for four months or so. We have a HUGE number of indoor plants, especially in the winter ... so, a little extra mold floating around. We use a tiny dash of the anti-mold/bacteria solution ... and we try to run them dry every few fills. Wish we could dry them all the time, but keeping about 40% (35-40 grains) all winter means running these a lot. We have two of these units, plus an excellent auto-controlled Holmes (of course discontinued).We also run HEPA units, which helps.

It is small.It does a couple of tricks. Ssssssslllloooowwwwwllllyyyyy.It has a tiny little battery.It can't be used as an external power source.It only accepts microSD cards.IT decides when it's connected ... and when it isn't ... and when it won't ... and when it can't ...IT decides where and how you will move and handle files.BUT ... it is small. And you can poke it directly into USB.On the other hand, I got the 32GB for $20, which is sort of what the micrSD is worth. So I'll keep it. Not worth returning.If TINY isn't your priority, and true functionality is, check out the RavPower. Multiple slots, leave a 64 or 128 in one, plug whatever you want in the other. USB it with a cable, use it as a 3000mAh backup battery. It streams. AND, you can use ES (or whatever) and use it like an actual file device ... not ... this. It's 3x the size, I'll deal with it. Costs $10 LESS than the regular price for this thing.At least I have another 32, now. Nice idea, but ... unless I'm missing something that isn't in the manuals ... fail.EDIT"Try moving it further away. Or closer. Or to the left ..." This is not worth my time or effort.The RavPower is a bit more intensive to set up ... but you wind up being able to use actual directory-tree file handlers, however you like. It also connects the first time, every time, and stays connected. Etc. ...As a side note: You might notice the "subtle" fact that "0" of however many people found ANY of the reviews down here at the bottom helpful. To help things along, I've deducted another star. So, I'll try to be as bluntly helpful as I can: Do Not Buy This.

A dose of 395nM UV, followed by a dose of 254nM (sorry, didn't time it, but it wasn't long) ... and presto! Goop-to-tough-acrylic!Worth downloading the data sheet. Temperature, light intensity, distance all make a difference.Careful with the eyes and nose!

Edit 11/1/2015:For what it's worth, I was able to fix the timer by taking it apart and repairing a solder joint on one of the relays inside.  So if you're electronically inclined and your timer has failed, you might want to check for that issue.Edit 10/2015:I'm downgrading my review from 4 stars to one because this thing just died at the "ripe old age" of 2-1/2 years!I didn't misuse it... it was used exactly for its intended purpose, controlling a water heater.  But this morning we had no hot water, I did some electrical troubleshooting, and one of the switch contacts of the timer is open.  So I'll be buying a new timer... but not one from Intermatic.Original review 4/2013:The instructions were clear (for someone like me with some wiring experience), the unit was easy to install (likewise), and it works well.  I bought it because unlike most mechanical timers, I can have a different program on the weekends vs. weekdays, to match the times at which we have low electric rates.

My dentist tells me flossers like these aren't as good as dental floss used "the old-fashioned way".  But if you're as uncoordinated as I am, and you're able to floss better and more frequently with these (like I do), you may come out ahead.

Some other reviews of this product I read indicated the magnets were weak and it tended to fall off.  I've experienced no such trouble.  The magnets can slide in and out, and if you don't press them into contact with the metal register, they indeed hold very weakly.  But when in contact, they seem quite strong - I've had the deflector in use for several months now and it's shown no tendency to move.

Obviously this is a specialty item and if you need it you need it, otherwise you don't.  There's not really much to say about features and performance, but as far as I can tell this is genuine made-in-Germany Bosch product, priced lower than almost anyone else.Okay I can say one thing about performance: my Saab 9000 has had idle problems forever.  I'd taken the idle valve out several times and cleaned it, with so-so results.  Installing this new one made it idle perfectly... well worth the expense in my opinion.

I just received these sprinkler heads, and what was notably missing from the package was extra nozzles.  Sometimes when you buy sprinkler heads they come with nozzles in a variety of sizes... these don't.  Thanks to Amazon's lousy product descriptions, it's hard to tell this before buying.If the 3.0 GPM nozzle it comes with (green color) happens to be the right size for you, you're set.  If not, you're gonna have to shell out another 7 bucks for a nozzle set... making these pretty expensive.EDIT: I took this from two stars to one when I did some research and discovered how poor Amazon's descriptions really are.  Orbit sells this item under two part numbers: the 55069 is this one and does not include the extra nozzles.  The 55059, also sold by Amazon for about A DOLLAR MORE, does include the nozzles.  However neither product description mentions nozzles or the absence of same.  So now I've got to spend $28.00 to buy nozzles for the 4 heads I just bought.

Update 11/2013: this effin' thing quit working completely!  If you read my essay below I thought I'd fixed the serious reliability problems it had when I first got it.  But a few days ago I noticed the lamp connected to it had stopped lighting on schedule.  I pressed the manual override button and... nothing.  When I looked at the timer, it appeared to have lost all its programming... again.There's nothing wrong with the lamp - when I plugged it directly into the outlet, it lit up.So this thing's going in the trash... I'm done with it.Previous review---------------Well... it seems many people like this thing, I have to say I do not!First: it's incredibly sensitive to the battery's connection.  Light finger pressure on the battery cover, or even vibration in the house from a truck going by, is enough to interrupt power from the battery.  When that happens, the timer instantly "reboots", and loses the time setting.  Apparently the actual programming settings are saved, but until you manually set the date+time the unit will not function.  This alone for me makes the unit essentially useless.Luckily I solved the above problem by opening up the unit and installing an electronic component called a capacitor across the battery - Leviton could have done this for an additional cost of about 50 cents but didn't.  The capacitor has fixed the above-mentioned problem but installing it certainly is not something the average person could do.Another significant gripe is its inability to handle certain programs that include both sunup/sundown and fixed times.  Example: in the winter, I want my lamp to come on at 5:30 AM and go off at sunup which might be around 8:00 AM.  As long as it's winter this works just fine.  But then this thing called "summer" comes along, and now the sun is coming up at 5:00.  You'd hope the unit would be smart enough to deal with that situation by just not turning on in the morning but no!  It turns on at 5:30 AM, then apparently wants to stay on until sunup at 5:00 AM... the next day!  In other words the lamp is on all day, negating the point of having a timer.  As far as I can tell, the only way to get around this issue would be to program the "on" time to be earlier than the sun could possibly come up... pretty lame.Lastly a less important issue.  The instructions helpfully tell you that you can enable "permanent override" to keep the output on or off by holding down the "override" or tethered remote button for a few seconds.  Okay, cool.  But the instructions unhelpfully do NOT tell you how to cancel that override!  I had to ask on Leviton's user forums and wait over a week for someone to respond and tell me that all you have to do is press the button again.  I might have figured that out for myself if I was able to see the display on the unit which has graphics to indicate what mode it's in.  But the unit is buried behind a table and not visible at all... that's why I bought a timer with a remote!

This is a pretty specialized item, but if you need a set of vise-grips with wide flat blades (for sheet metal work or whatever) it really does the trick.  And the price is closer to what I expected for a Chinese knock-off, not a real Irwin tool.

I really can't say anything bad about this!  It's reasonably well built, works well, is comfortable, and the price is fair.  It was extremely valuable in diagnosing a bad driveshaft bearing on my Audi.
This brush does a great job, and in spite of its seemingly odd design, is very easy to hold and comfortable.  The little "clip" goes around your finger and makes the brush much easier to hang on to.

My wife stopped at the local auto parts store and bought some Trico blades for her '12 Chevy Volt.  They left a large area unwiped on the passenger's side.  I looked and they have this little "airfoil" part built-in that interfered with the wiper arm on that side, causing the blade to be unable to pivot as it should.So I got on Amazon and bought these Valeo blades.  They fit perfectly, and clean the windshield better than the Trico blades did at their best.

Okay, it's a shower curtain liner so it probably doesn't merit getting all that excited.  But as far as such things go, this one's pretty nice.  It's stronger than the cheap ones, and has a nice texture to it.  For whatever reason, it seems to resist getting dirty better than most I've owned.  And the best thing - it's not made of vinyl and does not have the stink that most vinyl ones do when new!Highly recommended.

Well I guess I'm going to be the minority opinion here... I'm reasonably happy with this TV but not jumping with joy.Just a little context: this is our 2nd plasma.  The first was an HP 42" set manufactured by Panasonic.  I have no complaints about that one at all, it worked pretty much perfectly.A few months ago we decided we'd like to go a little larger and 1080p, and based on experience with the other set I pretty much limited my searching to Panasonic.  I quickly found the TC-P50ST30 here on Amazon, the price was good and the reviews were wonderful.  So we bought it.The first thing we noticed upon installation was the sound - it's lousy.  About a 3 on a 1-10 scale of all TVs I've ever heard (just counting internal speakers here) and the other Panny was a 10.  Literally the next day we ordered a cheap surround receiver so we could hook up real speakers.  That solved that problem.But my other 2 complaints about this set persist.  First is brightness fluctuations.  I've read a lot about those in the comments here and I don't think my problem is the same as others have reported.  My issue is whenever a bright scene comes up, the picture slowly grows dimmer over about 10 seconds.  Likewise, when the scene switches from bright to dark, the picture grows slowly lighter over a similar period.  It's like it's trying to make all scenes the same brightness.  I should mention this is with an HDMI connection from a FIOS box and it's possible it's the FIOS box and not the TV.  But we've got the old TV up in the bedroom connected to another FIOS box and it doesn't have the problem.  I should mention I've got all the various "automatic" features (like room lighting compensation and color correction) turned off.The other problem though I do think is definitely the set.  The picture flickers!  It's exactly the same as what's called the "rainbow effect" with DLP projectors - you see multicolored fringes around bright areas of the picture.  You can kind of learn to ignore it, but the old plasma did NOT do this at all.Other than the above, we're pretty happy with the set.  Color rendition is good, the larger screen and higher resolution are great.  3D we haven't tried yet but I'm sure eventually we'll give in to temptation!  The online functions, especally Amazon VOD are great.

This tortilla keeper seems well enough built, but there's no marking on it about what kind of plastic it's made of (usually plastic items have symbols showing the type of plastic for recycling purposes).  This concerns me a little, considering it's coming into contact with food...

These corn holders seem very well-built but you should beware of one thing: they're large!  If you're like me and had a small corner of your silverware tray reserved for corn holders, you're going to have to find a bigger space.

This grille is priced pretty well and decently made, but is small in diameter.  When I tried to install it on my 8" Boston Acoustics car subwoofer, the raised center area wasn't large enough to accomodate the speaker's surround.  Needless to say, that makes the grill pretty useless since if I had installed it the surround would hit the grille.Also is made of aluminum not steel like other similar products which is okay but it's clearly not as strong.  This would not be an issue in some situations but in a car trunk where something could hit it you want good strength.

I bought this to use on Intex's smallest pool, the 8-foot easy-set.Basically with my setup, the thing just doesn't work.  The blue top ring that's supposed to float and control the skimming action floats too high, no water goes over its edge and it doesn't collect anything.  I'm using a pump that's above the stated minimum size for the skimmer (1500GPH pump, skimmer instructions state 1200GPH minimum), but I think because of the loose tolerances with which this thing is made, the water just goes through the underwater gap around the floating part, rather than over its top.Contributing to this I think, is the fact that while the instructions make a point of saying the skimmer has to sit level, there's no way to make it sit level in an easy-set pool, which has sloping sides!  It would probably be better in a framed pool.

This book is wonderful!  I use it every time I need to repair my Titanic. :^)Seriously, there are a thousand books out there about the Titanic but most focus on the "story" / social / cultural angles of the event.  This book is more technically-oriented with a lot of great info for us geeky types who are curious about the technology of the day.

I was impressed by the fact this comes packaged in a Ziploc-type bag so if you don't use the whole thing the leftover part doesn't get stale.  :^)Seriously, the valve seems well-constructed, has a smooth action, and it's priced right!

Another reviewer said it's hard to read (which is true) but they didn't say *why*.*Why* is because the scale on the crazy thing goes from -20 to 120 degrees F!  The temperature marks are very close together because there are so many of them.  I don't know about anyone else but I typically don't go swimming when the water is minus 20 degrees.  Basically it looks like rather than bother to find a thermometer with a suitable temperature range, they just took an outdoor one and stuck it in a tube (with a cute little shark thingy on top).Still, I give it 3 stars because it does work and it's cheap.

Good chocolate and a lot of it, and quite a unique item.  If you're a chocolate lover and need a huge fix, or want a great gift for a loved one, this is what you want!Highly recommended for anyone who's not on a diet... :^)
...you put it on your car and it makes stuff rotate! :^)Seriously, Gates belts have a good reputation and this one seems well made.  Amazon's price is good, and Prime shipping makes it even better!

If you think getting a perfect roast every time is worth $18.00 then buy this product!  I've been using this and its identical predecessor for about 7 years and have no complaints at all.  The only consideration is you have to take good care of the sensor - don't expose it to too-high temperatures or get water in it, as explained in the instructions.

Been using this for a few months now - don't be fooled by the wording in the description that implies this has nonstick properties.  It may be a tiny bit better than untreated metal but not much.  On the other hand, there are no chemicals from a nonstick coating to be concerned about.Also seems a little pricey for what it is - a *very* small baking sheet.

I'll second what another reviewer wrote - although the photo on the product page appears to show something made of metal, the body of these things is PLASTIC.Having said that, they're decently made and cheap.  So if you're not looking for something really heavy-duty, probably a good choice - they've worked well for me in hobby use.  But I'm very careful not to tighten them too much!

I bought this because its claimed range is 100' - more than many competing units.  When I installed it in the fall, it never worked at anywhere near that distance - would work maybe 50% of the time standing inside the house next to a window that's about 50' from where the receiver is located (outside in the yard).But here's the worse part: as the weather got colder, the range decreased - a lot!  When it's 20 degrees F outside, it won't work from more than about 10 feet away.  Completely useless for my application (trying to control outdoor lights from inside the house).I'm an electrical engineer and understand the considerations with designing electronics to work over varying temperatures.  Clearly the designers of this thing put in little or no effort in that area.  For indoor use that might not be an issue, but outdoors = bad news.
This battery fit my Dell D410 perfectly, made a night-and-day difference in runtime compared to the old tired battery, and is priced well.  Me = happy!

I really like this unit!  It's not the cheapest bath fan out there, but if you want "quiet" this is the one you want.Seems very well-built, and was easy to install with one exception and this is my only complaint: the straight part of the inlet/outlet fittings is very short - doesn't give you much to attach hose/pipe to.  I think it would be better if they could be lengthened about 1/2".

This item is only of "okay" quality - as other reviewers have mentioned, the setups for adjusting the slice thickness and wire tension don't work too well.But... the thing is only 10 bucks (currently on sale for 5) and at that price I think it's a good value.  If I'd paid the "list price" of $75.00, I would not be a happy camper!

** This review has been edited **  I now give the product 5 stars (stupidly, Amazon doesn't allow changing the rating when editing).Originally I wrote a bad review indicating the unit eats batteries.  We didn't use it frequently and every time we did, the batteries were dead.About a day after I submitted the review, Bill from EatSmart Products emailed me indicating he had seen the review and short battery life is not typical of the product (he stated they should last ~1 year).  With no prompting from me, he sent out a new scale along with some batteries to replace the ones the original scale consumed.  Although it hasn't been very long, so far the batteries in the new unit are holding up well.So as I stated above, I now give this scale a 5-star rating due not only to its good performance, but the great customer service from the manufacturer!
This is a good solidly-built product that's a whole lot cheaper than most similar items.  Good assortment of hardware included.
I love these pencils! They are smooth and the colors are vivid and blend well. I definitely would buy again.

I love me some Moogs!! I have several sets of glitter pens and the Moogs are now my favorite. I use them in my adult coloring books. They are smooth and have some awesome glitter. I have a suspicion I'll be buying more of them. They would fit so well in a Christmas stocking, wouldn't they?

I returned this book. The cover with the gold accent looked great but unfortunately that's the only thing that impressed me about the book as far as art is concerned. The "gold" accents inside the book are more like a tan-ish/yellow color and the pictures themselves are less than impressive. They are rather boring. I did like the quality of the paper however and I wish the art work had been better. As it is, I could only give it 2 stars.
I love this little coloring book with its whimsical pets in adorable scenes. My only wish is that the paper would have been a little heavier.
I love these pens! They have bright colors and are wonderful to color in tiny areas. Great buy!

A few months ago I received a free sample of HB-101 after filling out a request on-line. I have been using this on my house plants ever since then and I love the results. My plants love it too! My peace lily has never had this many blooms and it's about 12 years old, so that should tell you something. I have used other fertilizers before and I was always concerned that I would mix it too strong and burn the leafs but with HB-101 I've had zero mishaps.  Good stuff :)

Finally! I found a pencil sharpener that actually works. I absolutely love the way it produces a sharp point in no time at all and I have much less waste then any of the other sharpeners I have tried. Wish they sold these in bulk, lol. I'd stock up. I would definitely recommend.

Received my book today and had a chance to look through it. I do like the Tiki theme which is something I haven't seen yet in adult coloring books. The pages are one-sided and an extra sheet between them will be needed if using gel pens because it might bleed through. There are about 8 pictures I really like. Others are a bit simplistic for me and a couple of the drawings seem to have pieces of clip art-type pictures randomly put together without any obvious cohesiveness.  I wasn't sure if I liked the picture of the canoeist at all until I looked at it long enough and decided that yeah, I can work with that, I will have to use my coloring prowess to bring to the forefront what needs to stand out from the rest of it but I've always liked a challenge. All in all, I give this book an "OK".

So yummy!! I Besides just eating them plain, try using them in puddings and you'll see they taste divine. Make home made chocolate or vanilla pudding and put them on the bottom while the pudding is still warm and you won't want to share. Yes, it is that good.

I love these pencils! It takes a lot of the frustration out of trying to shade and blend with regular coloring pencils. It's great to watch your coloring come to life after using these. Thank you Tritone! :)

This is the first USB MIDI controller I've used, but I've used soundboards and mixers in the past so it wasn't completely foreign to me. And while none of the faders, buttons or keys felt luxurious, mechanized or very finely weighted and crafted... they didn't feel nearly as cheap as they should for this price. The controller is attractive and does not seem like it will break easily. Getting it installed and going did take some unnecessary time. You need to register your keyboard, download some very large apps/packages, register for and download Abelton Light (for free), and go through the installation steps. It can take an hour or more to set up depending on your connection speeds. Once I got the drivers and Abelton installed I thought I'd just be able to start playing around... not quite. I could control some things, but the keyboard and other options wouldn't work. There is an important step after installing, which is in the manual but I missed it at first, that has you set the correct MIDI ins and outs for Abelton. But once you do that, there's no mapping necessary. Which is a huge time saver and more than makes up for the lengthy downloads. It took a little bit of poking around to get used to Abelton, but after a couple of nights I was able to make some fun little jams. It's going to take some time before I can make anything good, but this is just the controller to get me there.On a side note, I also used it to control my photos in Lightroom using a program call MIDI2LR. It was fun to be able to use real sliders to control the virtual ones, and each button could issue a command like ratings, navigating photos, and changing modes. This controller (the 49key) is a little bit too big to use like this all the time, but I may just pick up a smaller or keyboardless unit for that purpose in the future.Overall, it's a really nice entry level controller that's easy to get going and will grow with you.

These come as six individual packs. So it's quite possible that your 6 may be different that someone else's, but like most others I got Boba Fett's Slave I instead of the Star Destroyer, and the X-Wing was with open wings. And while it's true that these are not solid metal, they are a lot better quality that the Micro Machine line, with better heft and details. I started buying these before, so this set did cause me to have some duplicates. If you're just starting out though it's a good way to go.The roughly 3+" models come with a stand that also allows you to put your finger into, so that you can "fly" the ships around. This is a great idea, and works well with all of them except Slave I. Since it connects upwards to back of ship, Slave I is always in the landed position rather than a flying position. My six year old son loves them, and I've even decorated my own desk with some of the duplicates. Highly recommended as great Star Wars item that's well worth the price.

Coming from the previous model Jabra Sport Plus, I found this to have several big improvements, however they made a few missteps in my opinion.Still the same as my previous set is Jabra's fantastic un-boxing experience, the magnetic box opens up fluidly and easily. Jabra still has one of the best pairing systems, and syncing it with my phone was very easy. The headphones still seem as durable as before, my previous set have been dropped, sweated on, rained on, forgotten, and generally abused but they always worked assuming it had batteries.The biggest improvement is the on cord controls. I hated having to fiddle with my ears to control volume, power and tracks, now the controls are on the cord, which is a huge improvement (although I wish the pace/status button was also on the cord). Next biggest improvement is the battery life, it has an extra hour and weighs less than my previous pair, plus the Jabra app will tell you an exact amount of life left. In the event that you do drain the battery, it charges a lot faster and 10-15 minutes will have it ready for most workouts. Also, the sound is also louder and clearer thanks to the noise isolating earbuds.Of little consequence to me is the Jabra Sport app. I tried it out, and it seem solid enough but since it doesn't sync up with any other service, so you'd pretty much have to start you training diaries from scratch with it, and I'm not ready to do that. It does fully support the pace button (Strava on Android did not), it also has a basic Cooper Fitness test and various running/walking/cycling modes including intervals.But with all these improvements and solid carryovers there are a couple of things I didn't like. Mostly it's my own preference against in ear buds... But I found between songs and when off I find the noise from them rubbing in my ear while running slightly annoying. Also they block out more noise than the previous on ear buds, which I find a little more dangerous with traffic. Also, the pace button on my Android phone just triggers the Jabra Sport app to open (maybe it works with other fitness apps?), this makes it less than useful to me, but since that button is on the ear piece I wouldn't want to press it anyways.Overall, I prefer these for time when I want to block out more noise, like work or the gym, but when I go running outside I usually stick with the older set.

I'm very impressed by this toy model that lives up to the "toy" qualifier better than most regular toys. The size is ideal, it big enough to have gravitas but can be held with a single hand to simulate epic dogfights. There's a button on the back that activates the thruster lights (a transparent piece of plastic in front of two leds) in a brilliant blue, as well as one of 3 sounds (engine roar, slow cannon fire, and rapid cannon fire) in sequential order. As for the "model" side, it is a beginner set, it easier to put together than it is to unpackage most modern toys that are strapped inside their boxes for in store presentation. There are 19 pieces and almost every step has a twin (top and bottom cannons, left and right window, left and right locking pegs, etc), so it's ideal for building with a young child since you can show how it's done and then let them do the other half.Overall, I like it a lot, especially since my 6 year old son is obsessed with Star Wars Legos, but also likes to play with his models. With the Legos it usually involves me spending countless hours finishing models he has tired of building, only to have them come back for regular repairs. With this we get both the joy of engineering our toys without the drudgery or risk of obliteration with regular play. Sure it's a lot less modular, but it's the Millennium Falcon, you don't mess with perfection.

It didn't work with either my 5S or iPad Mini 2 while they were in their case. The cases are the bulkier OtterBox style cases so I half expected that, but even a modest case would have trouble working in this. It would be nice if they provided adjustment that would allow for different case types (for example, it the side supports could be depressed so that a cased unit could make firm contact with the plug, and extra space at the bottom for port covers).Overall, my review of 3 stars is not because this doesn't work well, because it does without a case... It's because its design failed to plan for even the most typical of cases.

For the price this all in one printer checks all the right marks. A scanner with an automatic document feeder, good quality color prints, and fully wireless between PCs and mobile devices.To set it up you simply take it out of the box, remove about 10 pieces of tape and plug it into the wall. Oh, and it's just a cord... there are NO bulky adapters... SWEET! Once powered on you need to download the app to your phone, it was fast and easy and the app found the printer quickly and asked which network to connect to. Once done the printer walks you through installing the ink and loading the paper. It then prints a calibration page and asks you to scan it. I wish it came with a few blank sheets, but you do have to have some of your own to get started. Printing from the phone is easy with the app, and there's another app for android devices that lets you print from more apps as well. To get it working with the PC I tried following the recommended online instructions, but it required an account setup... and turns out I already had an account... to SnapFish which HP acquired. Of course I didn't know the password to the account and had to ask for reset. The resets all errored on me and cause a lot of frustration to an otherwise smooth experience. I finally caved and just used the CD... which went much better. I wish the online method didn't need an account to complete, but it did and I couldn't try it. After all the setup the actual printing is very easy as is the scanning. The touchscreen was very responsive although it was in simple black and white.PROS:+ No adapter or wall wart on the power cord.+ Small footprint+ Simple mobile setup+ Scan from the printer to your phone/pc JPG or PDF+ Scan from your phone to you printer with auto straighten and enhance+ CD in box for much simpler PC installs+ Paper catch automatically swings out when printing and tucks away to save space+ Auto document feeder make scanning multipage PDFs a breeze+ Responsive touchscreenCONS:- Website for PC setup wouldn't let me sign up since I once had a SnapFish account, I tried to reset it but it always errored out.- No starter paper included and you need at least a couple sheets to finish setup.NEUTRAL OBSERVATIONS:* Touchscreen is black and white, but that doesn't matter* No memory card slots, but does support printer over wifiUnboxing and mobile setup: 5+ StarsWebsite for PC installs: 0 Stars for me (If you never had an account it might be much higher)CD for PC installs: 5 StarsValue: 5 StarsOverall: 4.5 Stars

One of the better glass shields at one of the lowest prices. It's the 3rd one I've had on my Nexus 5 and it's free of dimples and has gone the longest so far without signs of chips or cracks. Even though I change these out more often than the plastic ones, they provide a lot better drop protection and are much more pleasant to the touch.

If you are looking for a low cost Windows machine to surf the web and run the occasional PC app, but don't plan on using it to store photos or play games (including sophisticated online games) then this isn't too bad of a deal. You get a reasonably nice touch screen computer in a lightweight package, that's much more capable than net-books of the past.But if you are storing photos of videos, you will quickly find the 32GB (of which only about 13GB is available) will fill up way too quickly. You can get around this by adding something like this: SanDisk Ultra Fit 128GB USB 3.0 Flash Drive (SDCZ43-128G-G46) which will give you more than enough storage, but you'll need to manage it as a separate drive and be careful not to lose it.As for streaming Amazon Prime video it worked pretty well and as long as you look at it mostly straight on the colors are rich and image sharp.  It can also be used in tent formation, but there are no sensors to detect it so the image will be upside down unless you flip the video. The way to flip the video is with the shortcut CTRL+ALT+Down Arrow [Up Arrow to return it back]. But watching video on this is best suited for small groups, since the picture is small, the sound is modest and once you move more than 45 degrees off center the colors begin to shift dramatically.The webcam, while low res actually has really good image quality for video chatting. The touchpad, screen, and keyboard are also as good, if not better than you would expect at this price, and the fully convertible screen does let this act like a tablet. But if you are looking mostly for a tablet, then you should probably get a dedicated one instead. The windows marketplace isn't nearly as robust as Apple, Amazon, or Google's and the slowish processor and limited memory are so busy running the heavy Windows OS that apps tend to run a little on the sluggish/slow responsive side.BEST FOR:+ Web use: Facebook, Shopping, Photo Browsing+ The one Windows app you absolutely need to run+ Your accessories (Printer, Camera, Etc) need a Windows PCGOOD FOR:+ Watching streaming video by yourself or with a friend or twoPASSABLE WITH:- Web games, mildly complex web games like Club Penguin load, but slowly- Photos, if you get additional storageBAD FOR:- Anything that requires a lot of memory, storage, or processor (e.g. Photoshop, Videos, PC games)

These are a reasonable alternative to giant slim jims. They don't taste phenomenal, but they aren't too bad either. A little on the salt and pepper sidem but well within the normal range of meat snacks. They are a lot less greasy than the "giant" 1 oz slim jims which may account for the significantly fewer calories. These 1.5oz sticks have only 90 calories, while the smaller 1oz slim jims have 140. I also prefer the firmness of the casing on these over other snack sticks (probably due to the much lower fat content). So if I was in a gas station with a choice between these and a slim jim I'd probably go with these, especially if I wanted to limit my calories.But I personally preferred the Old Wisconsin "Honey Brown Sugar Turkey" flavor better. Its added sweetness makes the flavor more balanced, although it does bump up the calories to a still reasonable 120. The turkey also has a collagen casing which improves the outside texture even more.

The packaging is reasonable, it shows the miniatures though a window and as soon as you open the box they all come out easily without a bunch of tie downs and tape. So far so good. The star destroyer looks great too when closed.But after this, there's a lot of frustration. First, getting the pieces to move harmoniously from closed to open takes practice so that you don't hold back pieces that are supposed to move and to not move pieces that should stay put. Plastic parts just seem to want to snap off at every turn. Getting it to stay in the locked opened position is also a challenge until it gets worked in. The back section (behind the thrusters) is poorly illustrated in the guide and difficult to open unless you know the undocumented secret. There's a little stop pin on the lower left side and if you squeeze your grip to open it, you only tighten it more. So a a light touch is required (or pry the shell away from the lock). There are also a ton of stickers that you have to put on, in some fairly tight spaces. I tired quickly of this and let me kids try, so now the whole ship looks sloppy. So the question is... Why do I still think it deserves 3 stars. Well because my kids still love it, and it's Star Wars. And despite the ship collapsing and snapping apart and looking like a scrap heap, they still have epic dog fights and light saber battles. So I guess Star Wars is still powerful enough to save a haphazardly crafted toy.

This is a tasty snack bar that does a good job at balancing the fruit, nut and chocolate flavors. My wife says that they're addictive like crack, I on the other hand can enjoy one for a quick breakfast or a snack, but the hint of Acai berry keeps me loving these as much. The texture isn't quite as crunchy as a KIND style nut bar, but the combination of chew and crunch is very satisfying.If you enjoy nuts and fruit coated with chocolate, but would like to have them in a nice portion controlled and portable package, it'd be very hard to go wrong with these. I would only ding this half star since I think it would've been so much better with something like pomegranate instead of acai.

I have really enjoyed using this pan. I've bought very large skillets before, but once the pan hangs over the burner you get uneven cooking, or burn marks on the stove. This one fits perfectly across my large burner and have generous 3" walls, so that I can easily cook 2+ pounds of meat plus something else (mac & cheese, pasta, veggies, stir fry) so that I can feed the entire family without dirtying a lot of pans.  In reality if you need more surface area than this pan, you're better off with a griddle. My only concern was that mine is not a perfect circle due to the delivery guys. It doesn't effect the performance, but the looks are slightly compromised. So be sure to inspect it upon delivery and don't treat it too roughly. Other than that it's a treat to use.PROS:+ Perfect fit on the large burner with high walls making lots of space for large single pan meals.+ Very effective non stick surface+ Attractive finish, looks clean when it actually is+ Heats up quickly+ Textured surface aids in browningCONS:- Mine was dented during shipping, possibly indicating fragility, but couldn't hand straighten.- Aluminum pans don't hold heat very long once removed from the source.

Overall, this speaker has solid sound and build quality, it also has a few novelty features like usb charging and stereo pairing, but for the most part they're more gimmicky than useful. Also, while it's a simple speaker, you still need to start with the instructions, which is a shame since it wouldn't take much to improve it's usability.Sound Quality: 5 StarsIt filled the living room clear vocals and booming bass, the size of this unit is fully maximized for sound quality.Build Quality: 4.5 StarsThis thing is solid and fairly large. It looks as though it may be made of aluminum, but alas it's only a high quality plastic. Very sturdy, but different materials would make it more elegantUsability: 4 StarsYou turn it on by holding the power down, you pair by holding the play button down until you hear the pairing sound. There are no icons to indicate that this is the procedure for pairing. You have to already know, look it up, or guess (and since many other bluetooth speakers pair through the button button or a dedicated pairing button it's not certain you will). Once you get this down it works like any other bluetooth device and it remembers the last 8 paired devices. One nice thing is that it does come with an Audio-in jack with an Aux cable, which is a nice fallback that will keep it usable even if technology changes.Power Bank: 3 StarsThe power bank aspect is very limited. It's great for keeping the speaker portable and cordless, but as a charger it has the following flaws: 1) It only charges if the speaker is on, even if it's plugged in. This means if you don't want to use it as a speaker, you can't charge. 2) The unit automatically powers down after 90 minutes of Bluetooth inactivity, so charging will end too. 3) The unit is heavy, so you aren't likely going to carry this out into the remote wilderness or anytime you're walking with it. So chances are you'll have other, less complicated power sources for your phone. 4) Once it runs out of battery, you have to use it's proprietary charging plug, so if you left it behind and used up the battery to charge your tablet... then you're out of business until you get home. On the plus side, if you travel internationally, they provide adapters for nearly everywhere in the world.Stereo Speaker: 3.5 StarsI love the idea of this, and can only imagine that two of these working left and right channels would make any room or outdoor setting an aural sensation. But based on the instructions in the manual, it seems intimidating, non-intuitive, and prone to problems. First you need to make sure nothing is connected to either unit via Bluetooth, then you hold down the battery buttons on both speakers for 8 seconds. In another 30 seconds you will get another confirmation beep. You can then pair/connect to either speaker. You can turn off both speakers by powering off either one. However, if you want to skip the stereo pairing the next time, you must turn them both on within 5 seconds of each other... and then wait another 15 seconds for confirmation. None of these instructions on the unit either as instructions or with iconography. There are also warnings that other bluetooth devices trying to connect to the speakers will cause them to distort.

When I first turned this vacuum on my cats didn't scatter in every direction. That was my first clue that this vacuum was something special. On the low setting you could probably get away with vacuuming while someone was talking on the phone or sleeping in the same room. But is it quiet because it's weak? Far from it, when you lift it off the ground while running you can hear the loud acoustics of the engine that did startle the cats, but as soon as it's returned to ground it hums along sucking up dirt and debris with quiet ease. There isn't a hose to use, so cleaning crevices and stairs with small steps isn't this unit's specialty, but it's light enough that it's easy to carry up stairs and would do fine with larger stair landings. The cord is like that of a power tool, with a short lead that plugs into a long extension cord (included), at first this seemed odd but this makes a lot of sense if you need more (or less) length, need to fix cord damage, or just a simpler way to untangle. This is bag unit, which is nice in that there's no filters to clean out by hand, but most bag units fill up too fast and it can be hard to know when to change the bags out. This unit solves both of these with a HUGE bag (it's fills the entire upright compartment), that is easy to remove and seals automatically. Plus there's a light on the top that indicates when the bag is full. With 2 kids and 6 cats it tough on any vacuum to keep up, but this one is up to the job and does it without disturbing the peace. Highly recommended for home, pet, or commercial use.PROS:+ SUPER QUITE+ Very light+ Direct feed from vacuum to bag+ Huge bag+ Works well as floor sweep, fantastic on carpet+ All controls and indicators right at your handCONS:- No hose or attachments for hard to reach places- Bags are a little pricey, but are reasonable for their size and even better when bought in bulk

Between all the kids, cats and rabbits we've had over the years we've gone through a lot of deep/steam/power/spot cleaners. For the most part we've relied on the Hoover SteamVac line, even when they broke we replaced them due to their simplicity. But even the simplest upright SteamVac is a chore to setup, and then prep vacuum, steam cleaning an entire room, and finally cleaning out all the gunk. It means that stains which aren't in high visibility areas or that are hard to get to (like in the car), they often go untreated for ages. I tried a spot cleaner before, but between the cord and warm up time, it too became too much of a hassle to bring out.This unit on the other hand is super simple, very portable and a joy to use. The biggest caveat is that you need to charge it first and it does take about 4 hours to go from empty to a full battery. Because the lithium batteries are very good about holding a charge, this should only be an issue the first time you get out of the box. I took this unit through it's paces, from old juice, food, cat, and car stains and it did all of them really well. After turning it on, you pull the trigger to spray the solution over the area to be cleaned. You then have to work the solution in by hand with the brush instead of powered brushes that full size units have, but I found the spots came up quick enough that I didn't get fatigued. Finally, you angle the brush down so that you get a good vacuum seal to suck up the dirty water. Of the half dozen spot cleans I did, only one set-in juice spots are still slightly visible after drying out. I could, and probably will, go over it again, but most people would only see it now if they were looking for it (see photo with several small dark spots for a before/after). The separate clean and dirty tanks are also very easy to fill and empty.PROS:+ Goes anywhere cord free+ Every took has home on the unit+ Gunk/Hair catch on the handle is very easy to clean+ Unit is easy to fill and clean+ Battery lasts long enough to clean a household of small stains on a single chargeCONS:- Needs up to a 4 hour charge to use- The spray width is generous, great for large stains, but may over spray- The lack of powered brushes means some hand scrubbing is neededTIPS:* Plug it in after each use, the next morning it's okay to store away* For small stains or where over spray may be a problem hold it very close to the stain and use shorter pulls on the spray triggerOverall, the ability to clean difficult spots in the car alone make this a compelling tool. And while you're not going to clean the entire carpet with this thing, it is does make it very easy to get great results anywhere in or even outside the house without a lot of effort.

This is actually a pretty cool toy. It's a miniaturized version of those marble machines you see in museums and my kids love playing with it. From cranking the marbles up the shaft (3 marbles are included, but we added a dozen more to make it more interesting) to watching them wind, plop and spin back to start. They even imagined the marbles to be the "memories" featured in the recent movie Inside Out. The building time was about 50 minutes (slightly faster than the estimated 1-2 hours on the box) and I enjoy the building before play aspect of toys like this and Legos.So why am I dinging it so hard in my reviews? Because I feel it doesn't live up to its potential. This is a precision contraption, if something isn't in the right place or the lifting apparatus in the auger gets pulled apart and then misaligned (this happened to me), or the pieces of similar but different heights are in the wrong place, then the entire thing doesn't work right. It would have been better if the back wall was a solid piece with peg holes for the various attachments like slides and gears. That way you could enjoy the physics without the time consuming assembling, and reassembling with every found error. The parts are slightly difficult to put together and even harder to diagnose errors and reassemble, I wouldn't recommend solo construction of this toy for children under 12. The other problem is that it falls out of alignment as you use it. So the crank stops engaging the auger as it is slowly lifted up from your hand's cranking motion. I've since instructed my kids to just spin the primary gear and that works well enough. In the end, I just wish they had either made it stronger and less modular or gone the other way and devised a way to make it a lot more modular and stable. As it is, you can't go too off book since the pieces have measured connection points and the beams are too many different sizes without extras.Overall, if you have a kid who loves the marble machines, or a physics loving teen then this is a nice gift, just be prepared to deal with a little bit of frustration for a lot of fun.

These are comfortable and slightly larger feeling than my other compression gear (110% and Camden), but they still squeeze nicely on the muscles to help prevent fatigue while running and improve recovery afterwards. If you find your current calf sleeve feels like it's tugging at your leg hairs then give these a try in the same size. I like that the back of the sleeve, where the calf muscle goes, has a printed design that helps ensure putting them on the right way and that they didn't get twisted once they are on. They don't have pockets for icing like my 110%'s, but on the other hand they are  a lot more breathable because of it.Overall, they're a nice quality sleeve that hits the sweet spot of price/quality, at about half the price of the big brands and a little less than double the cheapest brands.

PROS:This slide has a soft-ish air pillow to takeoff on and the blue side has a sprinkler system. The spinkler continues to a little pool with a sprinkler that my kids were most happy hanging out in after the fun of sliding wore off. It comes with attachments for both male and female hose attachments (although the instructions don't tell you how to attach the male hose) and a tear repair kit (although the most like tear is not really repairable). The price is quite reasonable even with what will typically be a single weekend of fun, so keep that in mind when purchasing it.CONS:The instructions are HORRIBLE, they don't refer to this slide in particular. They don't explain the difference between weight, drain, fill, or air valves and pockets. Nor do they tell you how to attach a male hose attachment or tell you where or how to fasten the stakes. The slide isn't very long and is very thin and hard on the body. Since the sprinkler is only on one slide, it doesn't work well for races, it's just a wide single slide in my opinion. Also, it says on the slide that the limit is something like 12 years, 5' and 110lbs (although it seems like a safety issue since it did take a couple of larger sliders, albeit with some pain). Finally the sprinklers on the end are too tempting for kids to put there fingers into which will cause tears that will only become exacerbated if you drain it improperly.WHAT YOU NEED TO KNOW:After meeting with a committee of adults, playing  here is what you need to know. None of this is properly covered in the instructions.1) The launch pillow fills up with air at the small air valve (similar to a beach ball). It is a very large area to fill, using a pump is the only practical way to go.2) On the sides of the billow are two drain valves, these are separate weight pockets. They each need to be filled with water and closed.3) At the end are additional drain valves. These just need to be closed for use. As the sprinkler system fills up the water will collect at the end of the slide. You simply open these valves when ready to drain and store the slide (If you don't the water will be forced through the small sprinkler holes are create serious tears).4) Finally you attach the hose by using one of the two adapters into (the attachment for female hoses pushes into the hole with the treads pointing up) or around (this donut looking adapter is pushed over the filling hole to create an internal thread which the hose screws into) the filling hole.OVERALL:It got the kids out there, but the 6 year olds were really too big for double sliding and the 8 year old was giant. There was fun to be had, we used some tear free soap to make it a little slicker and had a few successful runs and some wallowing in the pool at the end. It would have been nice if our ground was softer or the mat was padded. Once we tried to put it away however it did self destruct since I didn't know the importance of the drainage plugs yet.

KNIFE BLOCK - 5 StarsThe first decision when picking this KithenAid set over another is most likely a brand/design one. Let me assure you the zinc wedge block looks and feels spectacular. It would go perfectly in a home with similar KitchenAid appliances, and will still draw complements without them. It is important to note that the 7 piece and 11 piece sets come with the same block, so you will want to finish off the set eventually if you start there or it will look like something is always missing. It comes with following slots (also note that the medium slots will hold small knives too):1 - Sharpening Steel Holder1 - Kitchen Shear Holder2 - Large Slots (1 open, 1 holding the Chef Knife)3 - Medium Slots (2 open, 1 holding the Bread Knife)3 - Small Slots (1 open, 2 holding the Utility and Paring Knives)* In case you're keeping score, that's 10 slots, the block itself counts as a piece of the set.KNIFE QUALITY - 4.5 StarsThese all feature a nice thick German steel blades. The tang of the larger knives are about 1/8" thick. And once you hold it in your hand you can tell it's a quality tool. Compared to my last set of J.A. Henckels, which I was happy with they feel night and day sturdier and more confident. The sharpening steel is also very heavy duty, although I feel it's useless for the serrated utility knife and not ideal for the bread knife, but for the other two knives and shears it will do the job admirably. My only real con is that I would like the kitchen sheers to separate for better cleaning, other than that it's near perfect set, once you finish it. For me I think adding a large santuko and 3 more utility knives (for a total of 4 utility knives which will allow them to serve as exceptional steak knives for small dinner parties).OVERALL - 4.75 StarsOverall, the design impresses and the knives don't disappoint. My only caveat would be, make sure you plan on finishing the set or the 7 piece set will look spartan although if you're a serious knife person you might prefer the flexibility of picking and choosing the last pieces.

These balloons use a floating dis-solvable capsule that locks into the neck of the balloon to form a temporary water tight seal. The biggest problem with them is that they don't last long enough to prep them in advance. The package said that it would last 20 or 30 minutes, but from our hose during an early Florida summer they wouldn't last more than 5 minutes. Which basically means it will only work if you can fill and throw at the same time. This brings me to the second problem, the filler nozzle doesn't have a valve control. So if you don't have one on your spigot then it's near impossible to fill these up since you need the water to be off the put the balloons on the filler nozzle. Once you have filled the balloon the snap and seal usually works, and it is fairly ingenious, but the failure rate is higher than balloon bursts from tying errors. Overall, I'd only consider this if both sides had their own filling station and the water was reasonably cool.I personally settled on the Kaos tie-not system. It's a bit of plastic attachment that makes tying a balloon a simple and rhythmic 3 step process (flip, slip and pull) and doesn't require any fine finger dexterity. You can get them to fit a hose or in a portable pump. We (3 people with three tie-nots) were able to fill up 500 balloons in under a half hour the night before, and they pretty much all survived for an epic battle the next afternoon. This would have been impossible had we used the Zorbz which we originally bought.

This is a great basic BR player with Smart TV features. I've tried a few BR brands in past and like many others have settled on Panasonic BR players (mine current unit was the DMP-BDT220), which have served me very well and only recently had the YouTube channel been decommissioned by Google since it wasn't using the HTML 5 version of the client. So I was eager to see how they improved on an already solid machine. The first thing I noticed was the speed improvement. Movies loaded faster, same with the Netflix app (which used to take forever) and the other Internet features. The YouTube app is back and with a new interface. It's actually harder to use with the remote than the old one, but they have an easy way to pair it with your phone's YouTube app so you can easily cast your videos to the TV from the app. I also love that they reduced the size of the player, it makes it fit in a lot better with my other set top boxes.On the other hand there I still have a few complaints, they aren't deal breakers but I wish they would fix them before I get my next Panasonic BR player. Firstly is the remote control. The directional keys are shaped well and very useful, however they put shortcut keys with the same shape right above them, so it is way to easy to exit your app and jump to another part of the system instead of navigating as planned. A universal remote or the phone app mostly fixes this, but it's the number one cause of pain when I use the remote. The next two items aren't expected at this price point, but it would be nice to have an audio out of some sort (other than the one that goes through the HDMI) and secondly I'd like the ability to navigate and start the movie from the set top box itself, but there are not enough buttons to do this. It also supports Miracast which is great, but I don't have any devices that use it. I would really like it if they supported other casting platforms like chromecast or airplay in the future (ideally in a firmware update).PROS:+ Great form factor+ Much faster than previous models+ Good NetFlix, YouTube, Amazon, Vudu, and Pandora support+ One button shortcut to NetFlixCONS:- Remote makes it too easy to jump out of an app/feature when operating by feel.- No audio out (SPDIF or Coax)- No directional/select controls on unit

This is a great loveseat with some really good bones. You can feel the structure and quality of the construction as soon as you sit on it. Even a group of heavy sitters didn't cause any creaking of sagging. The quality doesn't end with the frame either, the throw pillows are filled with real feathers that fluff up really well and are very big and comfortable. While the fabric looks and feels almost exactly like leather, I actually prefer the more humanitarian material that doesn't get sticky on bare skin. Overall the feel is very nice, with a medium/soft firmness and the arms are definitely comfortable enough to rest on. The only slightly negative comment I've received from any of my guests was that the seat wasn't as deep as my other couches. This is likely due to the fluffy, yet non-detachable back cushions. I don't think this will bother most people, but if you like very deep seats you may want to be aware of it. The bottom cushions are removable and reversible, which should extend the life of the seat if you get a stubborn stain.For me the delivery was quick and easy with the freight company dropping off the huge box directly into the garage. I did still have to unpack it and move it into the house myself (with a helper too). The feet are not screwed in for shipping, so it was fairly easy to put it on its end and twist it through the door. Once in, the big wooden feet twisted onto the bottom by hand. Much easier that other furniture that I've had delivered, but you should be aware that it's not full service delivery and you'll need a place to drop it until you can get someone to help you bring it in.

First setting up the serger was intense. It's not hard, but there are a lot of steps and ways to mess up, but with the help of the DVD with frequent pausing and rewinding I was able to get it threaded and running a poorly lit room in about half an hour. Now that I know how to set it up I'm sure I could thread the machine from scratch in about 10 minutes, maybe a little less if I take the short cut of tying the old threads to the new ones and much less with practice. The automated needle threading was very simple and with the exception of the tight quarters to pull the the thread through it was easier than any other machine I've used.Once the machine is set up the sewing was very easy to do and makes a nice finished edge or blind stitch with automatic trimming. With the other included accessories and configurations you can do sleeves, un trimmed stitches, fabric bunching and a lot more. I'm very excited to see what I can produce with it, but with just the starting configuration it already very useful for making sturdy sewn crafts quickly that look a lot more finished and professional. It worked with the standard spools of thread that I had laying around as long as you put the thread catch downward, but it looks as through it can easily handle larger cones which may work out better in the long run. It has lot of adjustments for a variety of fabric and stitch options. The nicest thing about the serger in my opinion is how thoughtful the accessories are for actual storage. The extended table stores all the feet, tools, pedal, DVD and instructions (although the later has to be folded to fit). There are no loose pieces to float around and get lost.Right now, I feel that it definitely worth the investment in time and money to get going. I'll have to use it a bit more to see if there's any gotchas that I'm missing, but so far it feels like a winner.

The one ounce spray bottle is ideal for travel. It's compact, TSA friendly and seems relatively strong and spill resistant. As for the scent it a pleasing mild yet manly scent that would be great for a night out without drawing too much attention to yourself. The only thing I didn't like about the overall scent was that there was a lingering sweetness to the smell. Most of the time this doesn't bother me, but if I'm feeling nauseous or under the weather then sweet smells can do me in.Overall this bottle is great for travel and the scent is a winner if you don't mind the lingering sweet smell.

The GoodThis pizza oven really is very well suited for cooking thinner pizzas a little faster and more golden than other options. The 600+ degrees is hotter than most ovens and gets you closer to a pizzeria style finish. The marketing on the box mostly talks about frozen pizzas, but honestly I don't think I would spend this much money to cook a marginal pizza a minute or two faster. I think a better target audience would be for amateur foodies who want to make pizzas and could use it as a poor mans salamander broiler. It does a great job at cooking thin things very fast and crispy, as long as you're careful not to burn your food.The BadThe curved top keeps you from using the top as extra counter space. I know it's expected to get hot, but even it could have had a cooling rack top for you to cool down/keep semi-warm your finished pizza. The handle for the pizza tray attaches to the side, but the customer affixed plastic bolts don't seem that secure. The pizza tray isn't completely flat, which means you need to transfer your pizza before you can cut it.The UglyThe 5 settings are utterly ridiculous. They're labeled for the finished product (Bake, Frozen Snacks, Fresh/Frozen Pizza, Rising Crust Pizza, and Deep Dish)... In reality they are basically two setting 375 degrees and 600+ degrees (the Rising Crust setting claims to be of a lower intensity 600+). If you lose the little pamphlet you will not know what the temperature settings are. These "dumb" labels also don't have timing guide on them so you will likely have to keep a constant eye on it. Which is true even if you do know the appropriate time since the timer is not precise enough to rely on.In UseIt cooked a regular frozen pizza very well. Fast and golden, just as if it was made for this machine. For the rising crust pizza it cooked it to a golden burn the roof of you mouth done-ness, but to me it seem the crust wasn't given quite enough time to fully rise in the accelerated cooking time. For other frozen snacks, it worked okay if you kept your eye on them, but often times that wasn't enough. For example, the potato skins need to come out since they were getting carbonized, but the middle of the potato was still pretty cool and mostly ruined the experience. So overall this machine doesn't work so well in traditional baking, but it does excel for high heat applications, but it's a little pricey if your only application is frozen pizzas.

A word of warning, this book is written in Pig (it is a Pig's diary after all). If you are not fluent in Pig, and only speak Farmer or perhaps another dialects of Human, you should still be able to read it, but the grammar will seem off and you might find some words don't translate as well. You will also find that the plot is absurd and story points unrealistic.BUT, if you enjoy a good story with likable yet flawed characters, that moves in at a reasonable pace, and has both intrigue and adventure then this is the book for you. It's perfect for the early chapter book reader since it isn't too flowery with prose and the words are all easily decode-able (even when they are intentionally misspelled). Each character's name is written in a different font so it's easy to identify them as you go along (similar to pictographs). My 2nd grade daughter read it easily and found the story amusing, and I finished it in 2 or 3 sittings and enjoyed the story. It's not really educational, between the loose grammar and non plausible story points, but it is fun and easy to read. And that makes this book very easy to recommend.

This exfoliating soap is very close to perfect. The off white appearance with little bits of natural scrubby husks is very appealing to the eye. In the hand, the over-sized bar starts off a little too large for its sharp corners, but after a shower or two the bars fits well in your hand and feels great for longer than other soaps. The soap doesn't leave any funky residue and the exfoliating texture feels good. The only thing that I wish was different was the scent. It's unmistakably based off of the original Irish Spring scent, which smells clean, spicy and sporty. This isn't bad, but it doesn't match the look of the bar and makes it smell a little less "mature". I think I would have preferred a more neutral (like Lever 2000 or Ivory) or an earthy natural scent like Shea butter or sandalwood, but you get used to the scent pretty quickly and it's not so strong that it sticks to you. So overall a very nice soap, and if you already love the Irish Spring scent, then I think you may have found the perfect bar.

The chocolate cream filling is very similar to what you'd find in Pirouline or Pirouette rolled wafers, while the outer shell is much more like a Pocky sticks or other short bread style biscuits. Overall, I found them to be very satisfying, with the box being much more portable that the tins that rolled wafers come in. If you were to binge on an entire box without sharing you'd still be under 300 calories, well within normal "candy bar" limits. But the box is easy to share and should make for a fun responsible snack. Like others, I did have some broken pieces, but that's pretty much par for the course with any fragile filled snack shipped via UPS. For the most part however, I had a lot more full sticks than broken one and the broken pieces didn't take away from the experience since unlike traditional Pocky's there aren't any "handles" since they're filled end to end with delicious chocolate.In short, they're a nice snack and I'll be getting these again.

This flat iron heats up a lot faster and maintained its temperature much better than her old one.  The cord is about 5' long and was workable from either sink plugged into our counter level outlets. She found it to be comfortable to use and didn't cause any noticeable frustrations. I could only ooh and ahh over the results which made her hair much smoother and shiner to the appearance. She credits that it being able to tame the heretofore unmanageable frizzy split ends. Whatever it was, I liked the results.

SHORT REVIEW: I received a review set and loved them (clean light, low power and good presentation) so much I bought more.LONG REVIEW:It's been a long road getting decent light in my loft. The room has multiple recessed outlets, but not enough power to supply all those 65 watt bulbs, a computer, TV, plus the surge from a vacuum cleaner all at once. To fix this I moved over to CFLs, but the colors were awful, some took time to warm up and when they did... they were often too bright, and worst of all they didn't last nearly as long as they should. I'm pretty sure their short life was due to mild power drops that wore on their circuitry, so even though I don't have dimmers in that room, I am happy that these are dimmable so that they are prepared to handle partial power drops. I'll try to remember to update this review when they do fail, but according to the estimates that may be in over 20 years ;). I found that these turn on very quickly, very near instantaneous, other LED bulbs I have take a tenth of a second till they illuminate, which is fast enough, but occasionally it make my second guess itself. There's no noticeable change in brightness once they're on either, very consistent. The power draw is now a fraction of a single bulb now and power is no longer a concern in that room. The odd shaped body is not noticeable once it's installed and the finished look is very nice and I think as good ,if not better than, the old incandescent flood lights. I'm sure if you were to put it somewhere else you would be an eyesore, but any other style of light would equally look odd in my ceiling.Overall, I highly recommend them for it's purpose in recessed lighting.PROS:+ Fast on+ Low power+ Finished look+ Consistent light+ Dimmable (which hopefully means long life with power irregularities)+ Reasonable price (especially when compared to other LEDs)CONS:- None (other that it might not look good for purposes other than it was designed for)

So the cable I got was more paler yellow than the cable shown in the photo. Which could be a bit of a bummer if you were expected a bright yellow cable. It's more of a pale yellow. This minor cosmetic issue is the only reason I dinged it a star.On the other hand, it's been serving it's purpose well. I use it to charge a phone plugged into a high amp USB wall adapter that is near the floor. The 6' length is ideal for this use. I also wanted my charging cable to stand out from all the other black USB cables on my desk, since they are plugged into data usb ports that don't charge as fast. I did plug it into a PC to make sure data transfer worked and everything seemed in order, although I will only use it as a charging cable because of it's standout (if not accurate) color.

Fully extended the cable is roughly the length of my arm. This length does limit the usefulness of it to car use, laptops and table top plugs. It is not really long enough to plug into a wall outlet that's a few feet from the nearest surface. But this is obviously best suited for travel, given that it's retractable which prevents tangles and reduces it's overall size, so it's plenty long enough most of the time.The cable performed well, it charged the phone in the same time as the Apple cable did plugged into the same adapter. The rubber shielding on the wire feels very robust and I'm not too worried about wear and tear breakage, but only time will tell. Finally the price is pretty good for lightning cable from a name brand. I've been bitten too many times from off brand cables that stop working with an new iOS update. With any luck that shouldn't happen from a cable from Amazon.

From the synopsis I was really looking forward to it. It sounded like a cross between "The art of manliness", infographics, quick start guides to life's many joys and hobbies that may push you toward travel, but not necessarily. And while there are a few pages that get close to this promise or nods in it's general direction, the bulk of the book is a top 5 location list for X type of experience. Not that there's anything wrong with that, it's just generally not very useful. Sure the suggestion that you should splurge on a meal well beyond your means just for the experience is intriguing, but a list of 5 restaurants throughout the entire world is both limited and mostly unhelpful. I'd much rather have a quick guide to the types of dining experiences there are and how one is to conduct themselves. There are other things like types of entertainment, food, drink, learning, and life experiences that are perhaps worth pursuing, but again it almost never pushes you to how, but always to the where. And since there are so many "wheres" (about 5 per page spread), it is almost always just a small caption and not a travel guide, just a small travel tip at best.Now that doesn't mean it isn't a good gift book. It would make an ideal graduation gift for someone relatively under experienced in life, but has wanderlust in them. It makes a good impression in that it weights nearly 4 pounds and is gorgeously illustrated with photos on nearly every other page (making my argument of more fluff and less substance). Overall it does have a lot of ideas in it and a lot of places to visit which could stoke the imagination of someone who is just starting out and has the freedom (and hopefully the means) to travel. I just wish it was more informative and lived up to it lofty yet admirable premise.

I love this car mount in theory, but it doesn't quite work well for me. Here's why. When the metal mounting plate/sticker is in the center of my phone (A Nexus 5) my NFC connectivity is seriously diminished, and when I add my case it's non-existent. I can mount the metal plate off center, but then the phone doesn't stay steady for the whole drive and can not me rotated. My car dash is excessively curved and textured, so I can't mount the suction cup anywhere on it, even with the smooth disk. On the windshield however it mounts fantastically, and even though I think the twist is a little difficult, it works really well. But once mounted I can only tilt in one direction (typically up and down).
