I've gotten compliments on it.  And as a water-delivery-device, it works about as well as you'd expect it to...So not as good as my Camelbak, but still, for someone looking for a glass water bottle, I can't complain.

I guess I have to put out the disclaimer of buyer-beware.  Reviews seem to be all over the map on this one.  I can only write my own personal experiences with it.  When I was offered to test this out, I almost passed on it.  I like to stick with whatever company my product belongs to (in this case Apple) instead of going for an "off-brand."  Even though Belkin is a known company and I've purchased things developed by them, I still tend to be leery.  But I ran into a problem.  A common problem, it seems.  I have an iPhone 5 and the new iPad, and I've been relying on one charging cord for about three months because the cord that came with my iPhone 5 eventually stopped working.  It started fraying around the area where the cord meets the lightning connector.  At first, it was pinched and I had to move the cord around just right to continue charging.  Then it just started falling apart.  With the new iPhone just around the corner (hopefully) I didn't want to drop a huge amount of money on a new charging cable since I'd be presumably getting one when I upgrade.So I took the chance on this one.  A lot of the reviews are negative, suggesting some of the same problems I noted above.  Well, those are problems I had with the Apple-created charging cable.  So, you win or you lose.  For what it's worth, I don't have any of those non-compatibility errors and it charged my iPad really nicely.  Also, the cord seems a bit thicker than the Apple one, so I hope that means I won't run into any of the stripping problems that caused it to fail last time.

This scale is fantastic for a variety of reasons.  It's priced competitively, but it also offers a multitude of options and functions that I'm not used to in a scale.  For the longest time I've used the EatSmart Precision Digital Bathroom Scale and have liked that one, for its no-frills use and modern style sensibilities.  So there's the standard things you'd expect; the scale is very accurate, within .2 lbs.  If you're looking for a scale to be more accurate than that you....might have a problem.  It will work up to 350 lbs, which is less than my previous scale but a non-issue for me.The scale also measures BMI, which is something I have started looking at once I joined a kickboxing fitness gym here.  The BMI calculator on the scale is more of a wag, honestly.  It's not as accurate as the machines devoted to BMI tracking; nor was it as accurate as the BMI scale at my gym.  But it will give you a ball park figure.  One of the nice features is that it has the ability to set 8 different profiles, so it will track 8 individual weights and progress.  You tell it your height, age, activity level and how much weight you want to lose and it will track it for you.  It'll also give you a calorie range you need to eat to maintain your current weight.There's a lot of information right within your grasp and presented easily and helpfully.  I've gotten a lot of use out of my previous scale but switching to this one seems a no-brainer.  I'd definitely recommend it.

Sometimes the stars align and you receive the perfect product at the perfect time.  About four years ago, when I moved into my new place, I purchased the Margaritaville DM1000 to celebrate with friends.  That was a fantastic purchase that made the most consistent and tasty margaritas this side of going to a professional place.  I have since gotten a lot of use out of that one.  So when I was given the opportunity to test out the new DM3500, I immediately jumped on it.  This was a case of perfect timing because a friend was having her annual end-of-summer party and, while I was afraid the machine would come after it, the DM3500 was delivered the day before.  Serendipity.  Small story aside, needless to say the new Margaritaville machine got put through its paces all day/night Saturday.  With so many working parts here, I was a little leery of diving right in but I have to say that the DM3500 is the best Margaritaville machine I've ever used...and my friends at the party want one, too.It's very large and intimidating, but setup is a breeze.  The basic function of the machine remains the same as previous models.  The ice container on the top perfectly shaves (or crushes...but more on that later) the ice, while the blender mixes up the ingredients and combines the two.  This model differs from the other models in a couple areas.  The first is that it has four settings: daiquiri, margarita, pia colada and smoothie.  The guide explains what should go into each setting.  Because the margarita setting is supposed to be more liquid products (i.e., not fruit) we stuck with the daiquiri setting for making our margaritas which expressly said it included fruit.  We ended up "testing" the daiquiri setting and the pia colada setting most of the day.  There was a difference in the ice levels and the ice consistency between the two settings.  The daiquiri setting is most reminiscent of the Margaritaville machines I've used in the past, with a nice shaved ice and has the consistency of slushies.  The pia colada setting, though, actually crushed the ice it seemed and it wasn't as smooth.  But it worked for what most people know of pia coladas.  It also changes how much ice is in it.  The guides come with sample recipes, too, and we basically followed them for perfect-tasting drinks.The second change is that this machine does the best job actually mixing the ice and ingredients together.  My previous model sometimes required me stirring the drink together because sometimes the ice on the top didn't get mixed in perfectly.  The DM3500 does it in sections.  It blends, shaves the ice, blends some more, shaves more ice, blends some more.  The setting determines how much ice gets pumped into it (with the pia coladas using pretty much the entire ice reserve for a full container) and each time it was perfectly mixed.  The third big change is that this model has a spout that guests simply place their glass against and the machine whirls to life, blending/mixing up the drinking and pushing it up the pipe (that also mixes it as it goes) and through the spout. One guest said, "well I guess I can't sneak a drink with this machine...".My friend was right.  If there's one complaint about this blender, it's that it isn't quiet.  It's very loud.  That said, the blender is about as loud as you would expect a blender to be and the ice shaver is tossing ice cubes around so it's not exactly a subtle device.  It's about as loud as previous Margaritaville machines I've used.  But that's about the only negative thing I can say about this device.  The pitcher holds 60 ounces, so it holds a lot more than my previous model which means there's less time spent preparing drinks and more time actually enjoying them.  It blends the drinks more perfectly than any other machine I've used and is the most automated of the devices I've seen.  When I saw the price tag, I blanched; but for the individual who constantly entertains and wants a nice machine, this is, hands-down, the best margarita-maker I have ever used.My recipe for the strawberry margarita:7 oz tequila4 oz triple sec1 container (about 12.5 oz) frozen strawberries with sauce (aka sweetened)Few scoops of frozen limeade (~1/4 of the frozen tube, give or take based on personal taste)Use this with the full pitcher setting and you got yourself a party.

Assassin's Creed is one of those series that is constantly disappointing me.  I start playing them, get enthralled in the historical context and parkouring around all over the place.  Then, I invariably get bored.  The systems in place never seemed to hold my attention.  The most I've played an Assassin's Creed game was probably the second one, but even that game I never finished.  Never even came close.  Because boredom.  With my new Xbox One, with its kind of depressing slate of exclusive games, I wanted to make sure that I had a game that I knew wasn't a rushed launch title.  So I sighed and picked up Black Flag, expecting to play it a little bit and then go back to playing XCOM on my PC.  I was shocked to find that I didn't hate Black Flag.Actually, I absolutely love it.The biggest problems with these franchises (see: Call of Duty, Assassin's Creed, Elder Scrolls) is that each game is released as iterations, in that the core game is remarkably similar to the first game, but each time they iterate it, refine it.  They change the story but you are doing pretty much the same thing you've done in Assassin's Creed or Call of Duty.  The story and settings might be different.  They might have given you a dog (or a Dragon Shout).  But you're still playing the same game.  In that regard, Black Flag follows suit.  You're still assassinating Templars.  You're still free-running across buildings.  You're still performing absolutely annoying eavesdropping missions or sometimes frustrating sneaking missions.  You're still caught up in some metaphysical story.  You're still being interrupted with annoying modern day Abstergo interludes.  But this iteration has a boat, something somewhat introduced in AC3, and it makes you a pirate.  And that has changed absolutely everything, for me, at least..  There's just more to this iteration that makes me want to play than any time before.Examples. Naval fortresses.  These are heavily fortified areas that turn into a mini-boss battle of sorts, between your ship, the Jackdaw, and the fortress's armaments.  Once you've destroyed the armaments, it immediately segues into sieging the fortress on foot.  It culminates in an assassination and the keep becomes yours and sheds light on the map of the area surrounding it.  These, so far, have been eminently thrilling for me.Sea battles.  The first time I fought a ship in a stormy sea, with rogue waves crashing into us, high seas causing eye-sight issues and complications for firing cannons, and water spouts spawning around us, I was entranced.  The epic scale, the graphics, everything was just so exciting.  And then when the ship was dead in the water and I could board it, swinging from my ship to the burning wreckage of my foe, before jamming my sword into an unaware British soldier was everything I imagined as a kid, growing up on pirate films.  It was exciting.  It was thrilling.  It was different.Hunting/fishing.  Yes, hunting is back.  Yes, it's still kind of annoying.  But it's tied to your growth (health upgrades, pistol upgrades, storage upgrades, etc.) and presented a lot easier.  Each island or area has a certain type of animal, marked on the map.  And it doesn't take a lot of skins to create new items.  But the game also introduced fishing and these little moments can be thrilling.  When you go harpooning, you're in a small boat and it's just you and a very large fish/whale.  There's a good variety between the whales (humpback, killer, even the mythical white whale) and sharks (Bull Sharks, Hammerheads and, of course, a Great White), and they add little wrinkles to the combat, depending on the animal.Later on, as these games do with breadcrumbs, Black Flag introduced the diving bell.  This device allows you to investigate shipwrecks on the bottom of the ocean.  These are both thrilling and terror-inducing, reducing you to a weaponless man in an often shark-infested area.  The first time a shark lunged at me from behind, spawning a QTE minigame, I almost leaped out of my chair.  It was so intense.  I had to yell "Xbox record that" to share the moment.  These shipwrecks are all different, with their own sets of obstacles and threats.  Some include sharks and rely on racing from wreckage to areas with heavy seaweed to hide in.  Some involve underwater cave systems, requiring you to be quick before you run out of air.  All of them are thrilling and add just a bit more to the game.The rest of the game is pretty much the same Assassin's Creed game you've been playing since the beginning, just refined and iterated.  You can upgrade your ship, the Jackdaw, by adding different cannons, increasing the durability, etc.  You can also purchase items to customize the appearance of the ship.  And of course, there's a home base that you can start sinking your money into, to upgrade it.  I just feel more attached to this part than I have in previous games, mostly because of the pirate motif.I don't really have much else to say on other aspects of the game.  I don't really care about the stories in these games; they are more of a means to an end, for me.  The graphics are awesome, but that's to be expected.  I don't know how this version compares to the PS4 (other than the PS4 version is rendered in native 1080p) or the previous generation, but I honestly don't care because it looks beautiful, particularly the open sea.  It is engulfing in its majesty and I haven't seen water effects look this realistic (though the boat sometimes seems to be floating through it, when you're in travel mode).  I will say that the on-land portion is mostly just okay, for me, but for fans of previous Assassin's Creed games, you'll probably find the same stuff to love.  What makes this game and what I wanted to focus on was how much different it feels because of the pirate theme.  Black Flag is the most fun when I'm on the open sea, destroying ships, fighting epic battles, tackling legendary ships and exploring the massive world.  I really hope that they will stick with this motif a little bit because this is the first time I've truly enjoyed an Assassin's Creed game and will be the first Assassin's Creed game I've completed.  Very much recommended.

Over the years, I have gone through so many routers through upgrades, review offers and replacements that I've tried most of the major brands like D-Link, Linksys/Cisco and Netgear.  In fact, in the last year I've tried the newer options provided by all three major brands and I was surprised the most with the Linksys EA4500, which offered blistering speeds with nary a connection issue.  But, over the years, I have been the biggest fan of D-Link for reliability, ease-of-use and speed.  When I was offered this new router, which looks very cool (and reminds me of the newly redesigned Mac Pro from Apple) I quickly jumped at the opportunity because historically D-Link has been the best brand of routers for me and was always super reliable.I was prepared to write a simple review, espousing how this router that has something called "StreamBoost" technology that supposed rack and stacks the devices currently using your router and pushes more bandwidth and speed to the ones that it and you deem more important.  In theory, this is awesome.  But It didn't work for me and in fact, having it on caused my streaming videos--which I have never had a problem with since the very early 2000s--to pause.  Not once or twice.  But it had to buffer every 30 seconds or so.Turns out this was the least of my problems.  My Playstation 3 just would not work with it.  It attached to it and it streamed to my PS3 enough so that it recognized it was online.  But when it tested connections, it would only tell me it failed.  Watching a video on Amazon or Hulu Plus downgraded the picture to the quality I remember when Netflix first dipped into online streaming...AND it buffered every 20-30 seconds.  It was bad.  Impossible to watch.  I also noticed that when I tried to do two devices at once (streaming on my Roku box and miscellaneous web surfing on my iPhone), my phone would not pull data from the router.  I ended up downgrading my security connection to WEP and it helped a bit on my Roku but my PS3 just wouldn't connect at all.Setup was surprisingly easy and I'm sure even those not tech-savvy could get through it with little to know problems.  My PC, which is connected through Ethernet, ran blisteringly fast for my service (SpeakEasy clocked it at just under 50 MB/sec), but everything else was slow as hell.  My iPhone, when it could connect, was speed testing at less than 1 MB/sec.  This device, which is marketed as a Gaming Router that is supposed to "traffic shape" your connection to give you the fastest speeds where needed did none of this.  It's really unfortunate because I have been a D-Link fan for years.  I ultimately plugged back in my Linksys EA4500.

Stealth games are kind of like puzzles.  The developers give you all sorts of tools and places you in areas where your main goal is usually to not be seen.  You have to use whatever tools you have available to you, as well as skill and, let's be honest, sometimes luck to maneuver your way to your objective.  When games get it right, the player feels empowered.  When games get it wrong...well, you get games like Splinter Cell: Conviction, a game I tried to play and like but ultimately never finished.  So, I approached Blacklist with some hesitation.  For me the sweet spot of Splinter Cell: Chaos Theory, a game I gave 5 stars to here on Amazon.Blacklist looks to invoke the earlier games, including Chaos Theory, while at the same time making the game less punishing as the earlier games were.  In essence, it's a combination of what made the earlier games so revelatory and the parts that didn't stink in Conviction.  Missions score you based on three play styles: Ghost for non-lethal stealth, Panther for lethal stealth and Assault for throwing caution to the wind.  Instead of earlier games that blatantly punished you for not being 100% stealthy or for games like Conviction where it was all out warfare, it felt, this game tries to please everyone at once and offer more options for how to tackle missions.  And unlike most games that try to be everything to everyone (*cough* Resident Evil 6), it doesn't fail.  It actually is fun.This must be the era of changing well-known and liked leads.  We have Kojima telling fans that David Hayter is no more and we have Ubisoft replacing Michael Ironside with Eric Johnson for the voice of Fisher.  The story, meanwhile, is serviceable but I'm having a hard time remembering much about it.  The gameplay is what drew me in and is what kept me playing.  Once you're done with the single player, there's the extensive multiplayer.  Finally a return of Spies Vs. Mercs, which was my favorite from the earlier games.  Here, refined and expanded; it's the reason I will keep coming back to the game.Overall, fans of the previous entries will find lots to love here; and people who, like me, were turned off by Conviction will have a reason to come back.

I have always enjoyed using Sony receivers.  My very first foray into receiver land was with a Sony 5.1 receiver back in the early 2000s, when I didn't know what an optical cable was or that I was supposed to use that for getting surround sound.  Back then, I just knew it said 5.1 and continued to use the red/white/yellow cables (not even knowing the name, RCA).  Since then, technology changed and my knowledge of technology changed.  With the introduction of HDMI, my old receiver was no longer useful.  And with the change, tons of new names and formats (TrueHD, LPCM, dts-HD, etc. all came to the forefront, confusing everyone.  At that time, I went with an Onkyo 5.1 system that had 3D passthrough, supported the new sound codecs and I have enjoyed it immensely, even when some of its terminology required tons of googling to understand the ambiguous sound settings.I've been looking at upgrading to a 7 speaker system for awhile, simply out of curiosity.  So when offered a chance to review the Sony DN840, I had to jump on the chance of going not only forward in speaker and options, but also to see how Sony has faired in the receiver department since my first purchase in 2000.My Onkyo was a pretty no-frills device (at the time it was around the $250-300 ballpark) and so didn't have some of the newer features like Wi-Fi or Bluetooth and completely forget AirPlay.  I mostly wanted it because it had good reviews, HDMI ports and had 3D passthrough so that it was "future proof" with 3D.  Now of course the new fangled word is 4K, in terms of video clarity.Which brings me to the Sony DN840.  This receiver has a lot of the frills I was missing.  I enjoy that it has Wi-Fi built in and can utilize AirPlay from my computer or my iPhone, for streaming music.  It's a nice feature.  I know it's asking for too much, but if it had the video feature for AirPlay, that would have been amazing.  As it is, being able to stream Spotify to this receiver is great for parties.  It has 4K pass-through which probably means nothing to most people.  It's a good feature to look for in a receiver, though, if you're looking to buy one receiver and (probably...hopefully) not have to worry about future content.  It's good for right now, with the 3D pass-through, and when 4K TVs drop from their absurd prices and become as plentiful as 1080p TVs are now, it'll be a good feature to have.  6 HDMI inputs is great, since the number of devices requiring them have gone up (PS3, Xbox, Wii U, DVR took up all of my inputs on my Onkyo receiver).Now how about the sound quality?  I'm really impressed with this receiver.  I had to go out and purchase two new speakers to get the most of it and plan on eventually replacing all of my cheap speakers I got when I purchased my first Sony Receiver packaged system.  But even with my cheap speakers, I can already tell a difference.  The 7 speaker system does do a better job of completely surrounding you in the movie/game you're playing.  It's important to note that you won't get the full 7 channel experience with a lot of online content.  Most (if not all) online video services like Amazon and Netflix only recently moved towards 5.1 surround sound.  So the biggest reason for a 7 surround sound system is for watching movies on Blu Ray, where they are specifically engineered for that type of sound.  Oh, if you're confused why it's 7.2 vice 7.1, that .2 just means you can plug in a second sub woofer.  My one subwoofer is quite enough bass, but if you were creating a home theatre setup, I could see how using another sub woofer might be worth it.Oh, and if you are upgrading from an older model like I did with my Onkyo, be prepared to purchase Banana Plugs.  I had no idea these existed when I upgraded to my Onkyo and was in for a surprise when I opened the box (I didn't look closely enough at the speaker connections).  So I would recommend picking some up.  I have had good luck with the Sewell Direct SW-29863-12 Deadbolt Banana Plugs, 12-Pair and would recommend them.  They were easy to use and worked perfectly.Overall, I came away impressed with the Sony system.  It has a ton of frills and is, as of right now, pretty future proof with the 3D and 4K pass-through.  It outputs 150 watts, which is a decent output and the sound quality is just as good as the other hallowed sound receivers I've experienced.  For the money, I'd say it's a great value.

This is one of those devices that you look at, think, "well duh" and then buy one.  The idea of having a system of inter-connecting crock pots for a brunch or a party is pretty novel.  I never really thought about it, using individual crockpots to heat/keep food farm during parties.  The problem with that is when you have huge crock pots for something really small (i.e., dip) and that's all you have.This connectable "Entertaining System" actually came at a great time for me to try, since I was throwing a end of summer bash.  It worked perfectly.  As other reviews have noted, the cooker does get a bit hot.  Unlike some reviewers, mine wasn't a danger issue, but it did get pretty warm.  If it is a concern, obviously a potholder pad should be used and is just good safety, anyway.  The system is built so that you can (of course) but more crock pots to connect into them, creating a sort of buffet line.What I love about the system is the idea of using one plug for a series of crock pots.  Before this, all of my plugins would be used for crockpots and they'd be all over the place.  What I also like is the size.  These are one quart a piece (for a total of two quarts), which is a perfect size for dips, over the 3-5 quart crock pots I currently own.  The ability to mix and match this system is also perfect, for those who host on a recurring basis.Which brings me to my final point.  The system is, in my opinion, expensive.  For this total of 2 quarts you're paying as much, or even more, than you would buying a decent 5 quart crock pot.  You're paying for the convenience (and color options).  I would pretty much only recommend this system for those who cater or throw parties/brunches on a recurring basis.  Otherwise, I have a feeling this expensive unit will collect dust next to your Margaritaville Drink Mixer machine.

Blackfish mostly follows the story of Tilikum, an orca captured in the 80s when he was a mere pup, and his rise to fame and infamy within Sealand of the Pacific and, eventually, SeaWorld.  Known to be involved in the deaths of three trainers, Tilikum's story is tragic both for the whale and also for the trainers, some of whom did not truly know the dangers of working with him.  Thrown into this mix are some anecdotal stories about other killer whales, the number of "accidents" involving killer whales and trainers and, for some random reason, a whale's sexual organ on display.  I know Blackfish has received a lot of positive press and reviews, but honestly it left me feeling pretty nonchalant.  Not about the travesty that happens to these whales or the tragedy befalling the trainers.  That obviously hit home.  But the documentary seemed all over the place and wasn't really put together very well to make a cohesive whole.  Random parts of the film seem pulled directly from YouTube, and just when it seems like it's making a point, it veers off into randomness; for example, for no real reason we go from the tragedies happening to seeing a pod of whales in the ocean attacking a sea lion.  I didn't really see how this added much to the main thrust of the story, other than to pad the already slim running time.  Additionally, while they tried to make a point of showing how the aggressive Tilikum is used to breed for most of the whales in captivity, I don't see why they had to focus on his, er, erupting member.  I now know that it looks like a tentacle.  So, you know.  I learned something.My biggest problem with the documentary is that I left not really knowing more than when I went in (erupting member, aside).  The other problem is that it feels cloyingly attached to appeal to our emotions.  How anyone could watch the footage of a whale calling out to her young that's been ripped from her and not feel pathos is beyond me.  And that's exactly what the documentarians are counting on.  It sometimes feels manipulative.  But I say this not as someone who's on the side of SeaWorld, but as someone who definitely agrees that these beautiful creatures should be able to roam free and not be forced to do ridiculous tricks.  I just don't like to feel like I'm being manipulated.At one point, the documentary tells the viewer that SeaWorld was asked repeatedly for interviews for Blackfish, but they were (here's a shocker) turned down.  Obviously, SeaWorld knows that the documentary is about lambasting them, so why would they submit to it?  Yet, it's played off as if the directors are trying to be fair and balanced; Fox News follows a similar tactic.  Look, Blackfish is a one-sided documentary, telling its viewers things they probably already know: animals in captivity = bad; animals in captivity + interacting with humans = worse.  Worse for the humans interacting with an animal that can't really be domesticated and worse for the animals who have been robbed their freedom.  The best thing the documentary does is show real human emotion for these majestic creatures, often showing how social and family-focused they are.  It's just so jittery in its narrative focus, bouncing all over the place, that in the end it doesn't really make a concrete point, other than one that we can probably reach on our own.  I enjoyed it and I think it's worth watching, but I don't think it's constructed as well as it could have been.

I love my Philips Sonicare toothbrush.  In the past, I've used one of their cheaper ones and recently I upgraded to the HX6972.  It's probably one of the best toothbrushes I've owned, so when given the option to try the Intercare brushes, I had to jump on it.  My biggest complaint about these brush heads is the fact that they are smaller than the ones that come with the toothbrush or other replacement heads I've seen.  They are contoured, supposedly to get between the teeth and do a better job of cleaning.  I've been using them for over a month and I have noticed that they've improved my gum health more and it does feel like the plaque between my teeth is significantly less than with a standard brush.  I probably won't know the extent until I go in for my next dental visit, but I really like these replacement heads.  The only complaint I can levy against them is that they were smaller than I was expecting.  Overall, very good for interdental cleaning.

I remember picking up David Gordon's The Serialist on a lark.  That novel gripped me from the first page until the last.  So I was curious to see how his follow-up novel would fare and I'm happy to say that it's just as good, but not as humorous or meta, as The Serialist.  Much like the character in The Serialist, Sam Kornberg is a failed novelist whose marriage to Lala is failing.  Lala walks out on him and he tries to win her back by finding a job.  He ends up taking a job as an assistant detective to a Solar Lonsky, a morbidly obese man who wants Sam to follow The Mystery Girl.  Of course, Sam discovers on his path through LA that showcases geekery of assorted nature, doppelgangers and awesome characters that you don't normally see in a mainstream novel, that the case isn't what it's cracked up to be.David Gordon proved in The Serialist that he knows the detective novel inside and out and was able to both take jabs while simultaneously mimicking the same structure.  The Mystery Girl isn't as meta as The Serialist and I didn't find it as funny.  That said, Gordon's ruminations on life and the way he turns a phrase had me bending pages of the novel to go back to later.  The Mystery Girl is dark, darkly comedic and full-on noir, oftentimes at the same time.  Fans of The Serialist will find lots to love here.

In some ways, the concept behind The Shining Girls is reminiscent of Looper, in that killing people across time is a great way of not getting caught.  It posits this house, this kind of supernatural house that allows a decidedly creepy man named Harper Curtis to travel across time.  A Depression-era drift, Curtis must travel time and kill these "Shining Girls," girls who have something that makes them special.  One of his victims is Kirby Mazrachi who ends up surviving and makes it her life's mission to catch the killer.It'd be hard to not mention The Time Traveler's Wife, either, because of the way The Shining Girls is written.  It's written out of order, flipping between time periods so that the reader fills in the pieces.  I had a hard time getting into The Shining Girls but once it started and got into its rhythm I found it difficult to put down.  Definitely recommended.

Is there a show on television as depressing and nasty as The Killing?  I'd be hard-pressed to find one.  If I were to boil down the first two seasons of The Killing into one unifying theme, it's how shoddy police work can destroy everyone it touches.  Whether that's the family of the slain girl, Rosie Larson, the black teacher who gets kicked to a bloody pulp because of racism and racial profiling, the idealistic politician who gets paralyzed...and that's all within the first season.  By the end of Season Two, how many more lives will be destroyed by our intrepid heroes?I'm being a bit glib, but that's mostly because there's nothing glib or even humorous about this next season.  The Killing is dark, dreary, dismal and depressing.  I love alliteration.  You might need to double up on Zoloft by the time you're done with it, especially if you binge on the episodes.  I know that when I finished the stomach-churning final episode, I immediately had to dive back into the cartoon-hilarity of Weeds to cleanse my palate.But I'm getting a bit ahead of myself.  Fans were outraged when Rosie Larson's killer was falsely identified last season, leaving another full season of twists and turns to discover just who killed this poor young girl.  When the second season starts, politician Darren Richmond is heading into surgery because of the gunshot from last season's finale, Sarah Linden is on her way (finally) to move to California (spoilers: that doesn't work out), Holder is dealing with the fallout of the Richmond arrest and the Larson family is pretty much falling deeper into depression the likes of which they'll probably never be able to fully escape.  Linden discovers that the photo of Richmond pinpointing him near the scene of the crime was faked.  But faked by whom?  Obviously, this pulls her back into the quagmire of the Rosie Larson case.The truth is, Season Two starts off quickly and spirals into conspiracy theories and worries of mental illness.  The beginning episodes have an intensity befitting the best paranoid thriller.  Linden doesn't trust anyone and starts to believe that everyone around her, including her partner, is in on some grand plot.  Unfortunately for her, as we begin to learn of her past, everyone thinks she's just crazy.  The first half of this season is excellent and the pacing is a bit quicker and more intense that anything the first season had to offer.  It's also a lot more focused, tying up the stories a lot better than the way the first season simply discarded plot threads after utilizing them as red herrings.  It's only the last half of the season where I started to feel like the show was dragging out the ultimate epiphany.Once the truth of Rosie Larson's murder is in the open, I felt pretty ambivalent.  It wasn't until the last half of the last episode where I felt gut punched by some realizations about the characters that I left with a bad taste in my mouth.  The Killing can be a nasty, nasty show, filled with broken characters and broken dreams.  And no one gets a happy ending.

I have been a fan of Logitech keyboards for years.  They seem to offer the most features for the buck and, even though I've seen tons of reviews slamming their build quality, I've never had any issues with any of them.  I've pretty much used all of the recent models, to include the original G19, the mechanical G710+ and the more sparse G510s.  This particular keyboard is a refresh of the G19 model from 2009 and honestly it's one of the weaker refreshes I've seen from Logitech.  On the surface, the only noticeable difference is the color, which is now a metallic blue as opposed to being pure black.  Apparently, the LCD screen is of better quality and doesn't break.  I didn't realize this was a problem on the G19 since mine is still working today (I got it when it first came out in 2009).Who really needs a $200 keyboard? I mean, seriously, unless it offers something truly magnificent, games have been gaming for years with crappy come-with-the-PC keyboards for years. So what exactly is Logitech bringing to the table with their premium priced keyboard?The G19s is nicely laid out, with all of the obvious/normal keys a regular-sized keyboard should have. Of course, it comes with all the little fangled things you'd expect, like back-lit keys. You can change the colors to your liking. The keys all have a nice, springy feel to them. There's also a switch that turns the keyboard to "game mode" so that you don't accidently press a button that throws you out of the game. The biggest features, though, are the ones that will mostly benefit MMO-players. For starters, you have twelve "G" keys, fully mappable keys that, with the push of a button, can change to another completely different set of twelve keys. There's three "M" settings, meaning that those twelve keys technically can have 36 different customizable uses. Another nicety is that you can assign those buttons to specific games (the keyboard software comes loaded with quite a huge variety of games, both new and old) so that when a game loads, it instinctively loads the button combination for that particular game.The software is the same that comes with the Logitech G13 Advanced Gameboard. The software, as I've mentioned in my review of the G13, can be both terrific and terrible. It will automatically scan your computer and load up games that it finds and has a loadout for. In my experience, however, it doesn't always work as intended. I'd say that it only located about a fourth of the games that were actually on my computer and completely ignored any of my Steam games. If it doesn't locate your games, it adds a few steps to getting them set up and it took me awhile to figure out exactly what I could and couldn't do with the software. What's nice, though, is that if you have both the G19 and G13 plugged in, the software automatically detects them and shares a single loadout.The G19s comes with a full color LCD screen that has a variety of apps. So you can watch your PC's performance, queue up the media display to see what songs you're listening to, have a clock so you can keep track of the time, etc. It also has a movie viewer, which you can load up anything on your hard drive and watch...on a very, very tiny screen. I guess for someone who wants to watch a program while waiting for a raid to get going, this is very useful, but the small screen (for me at least) isn't conducive to movie/TV-watching.  This screen was lacking useful apps back in 2009 and I don't really see much difference in this new model.  The most useful aspect of it is for MMOs, where stats (e.g., health etc in Guild Wars 2) can be displayed.  What I usually rely on, though, is the Ventrilo app that shows who's speaking and has some useful Ventrilo information so you don't have to Alt-Tab out of the game.Honestly, I don't really see much differentiating this from the cheaper, original model.  The color is different and apparently the LCD works better.  But those looking to upgrade or those looking at spending the money, just know that while I still love this keyboard and haven't had any problems with it, the original model is still cheaper.

It's impossible to discuss A Haunted House without acknowledging the Scary Movie franchise because not only did Marlon Wayans co-create Scary Movie, but the latest in that franchise just came out recently and parodies some of the same films.  Before Scary Movie was neutered and smashed into the ground into some ridiculous teen parody film, it actually was pretty entertaining.  The first film, in particular, was actually a decent parody and pretty strictly followed the original Scream's story with dialogue taken directly from the script and, most of the time, warped into comedic sensibilities.  While it catered to the lowest common denominator and was filled to the brim with juvenile humor, it also showcased a team that had comedic timing and knew the rules of the genre it was aping (slasher).  It also wasn't just unfunny vignettes with no real over-arching plot tying it together.So now we have A Haunted House, with Marlon Wayans back in the writing and starring role.  And while it's a step up from what's become of the Scary Movie franchise, it still not as good as the movie that started it all.  A lot of the jokes feel "been there, done that...only better before."  The only reason the movie succeeds at all is based on the comedic timing and chemistry between Marlon Wayans and Essence Atkins.  When A Haunted House begins, Malcolm Johnson (Wayans) is expecting his girlfriend Kisha (Atkins) to move in and he, as is required of a found footage film, wants to film everything.  The opening is actually quite smile-inducing because Wayans plays on the found footage genre and throws in a couple funny homages (e.g., quick-panning to the house keeper to startle the viewers, girl arriving and accidentally killing the dog, etc.).  The dialogue is quick, often-times funny, if not laugh-out-loud, and surprisingly subtle.  When a knife is found on the floor and Kisha goes crazy, saying that the house is haunted, I couldn't help but smile because of how quickly they were willing to jump to the paranormal.  The first half is funny and follows Paranormal Activity pretty well.Then things start to go downhill, as they introduce the go-to-actors to play their stereotypical parts.  Here we have Nick Swardson playing Chip the Psychic, bringing up gay jokes and making Malcolm uncomfortable.  Racism gets addressed as David Koechner shows up, playing the role he always does as the racist Security Man.  Here, the humor relies on very similar (if not the same) jokes Marlon Wayans has mined in the first two Scary Movies (there's even a ghostly sex session...scratch that, two ghostly sex sessions...that is nowhere near as chuckle-inducing as it was with Tori Spelling).  As the movie continued, it felt like it was dragging much longer than the short 86ish minute running time.The only thing that kept me going was the comedic timing of Essence Atkins specifically and the chemistry between her and Wayans.  They manage to elevate, however small, the score.  I was kind of hoping a return to the original Scary Movie and, to some degree, I got just that.  Just not in a good way.

Ever since I got into gaming, I have been a headset junkie. When you spent most of your PC gaming time playing co-operative games that require VOIP, it just seemed to work better for me than to rely on speakers and a standalone mic. As such, I've gone through more headsets than I could probably describe. Some have been awesome, others not so much. Since I've used and reviews plenty headsets in my time, I've kind of come up with a guideline for reviewing. When I use a headset, I grade it by four things: comfort, sound quality, mic quality and durability. I'm not really used to using headsets with my consoles (except for the mic/headset for my Xbox 360 when playing multiplayer games).  I didn't know how I would like using a console headset when I have 5.1 surround in my room already.  But let's get into the specifics.In terms of comfort, this was easily the most comfortable headset I've used in awhile. I have a large head and a lot of times headsets can give me a headache when first using them because they scrunch my skull.  That's not the case with this headset.  It fits comfortably and will be even more comfortable as time goes by.The sound quality is fantastic. The psuedo surround sound sounds good, though it can't compete to my receiver.  But it does a great job of balancing talking with game sounds, so that I'm never constantly changing settings (of which there are 8 presets).  It's very nice and sounds great.Durability is another area that's important, especially when you're spending over $200 on a headset. The XP400 is very durable. I like the way the mic works and bends.  It's also detachable.Mic quality is also very important to me because I use it to communicate constantly with my friends who are spread out across the nation. Mic quality is also something very hard to review. No one complains when I talk and it pairs well with my cellphone and no one complains with that sound either.Pairing the headset with everything worked really well.  It has about 15 hours of battery life.  If you're looking to spend in the neighborhood of $200, then this is a great choice in headset.  But I would recommend the XP510 if you're looking to spend this kind of money.  It works even better.

This printer is by far the best and easiest to use of any printer I've used at home.  Getting it set up on my network was as easy and putting the included CD in my PC and letting it set itself up.  It took minutes and was done.  I love being able to store my printer in another room and simply print to it.It prints really quickly (15 B&W/minute, 8 in color) and it has two trays that can hold 250 sheets.  I like that each color can be replaced individually, but of course it's annoying when you are trying to print and it's missing one color.  Overall, it's a great printer and has a lot of options for everything from printing, faxing and scanning/copying.  I've never had any issues with printing jams as some have and one of the neat features I appreciate is the ability to AirPrint from my phone/iPad.The biggest difference between this model and its sibling, the 7520, is that this one doesn't hold 500 sheets in two different sizes.  But that's not a huge issue.  Otherwise, it works just as well as its more expensive brother.One caveat: it's very large and heavy.  But it's fantastic and works really easily.

This printer is by far the best and easiest to use of any printer I've used at home.  Getting it set up on my network was as easy and putting the included CD in my PC and letting it set itself up.  It took minutes and was done.  I love being able to store my printer in another room and simply print to it.It prints really quickly (15 B&W/minute, 8 in color) and it has two trays that can hold a combined 500 sheets, in one of two different sizes.  I like that each color can be replaced individually, but of course it's annoying when you are trying to print and it's missing one color.  Overall, it's a great printer and has a lot of options for everything from printing, faxing and scanning/copying.  I've never had any issues with printing jams as some have and one of the neat features I appreciate is the ability to AirPrint from my phone/iPad.One caveat: it's very large and heavy.  But it's fantastic and works really easily.

I fell in love with the Dyson vaccuum back in 2006, when I purchased my first one.  It, to this day, works just as great as it did the day I brought it up.  I was curious how this LG Kompressor vacuum would stand up to my Dyson, since it's a competitively priced alternative.Right away one of the features I appreciated was the button to switch the vaccuum from carpet to hard floors.  My older Dyson does not have this ability and was pretty useless in my kitchen/bathroom/litterbox area.  It works great on hard floors (I have linoleum).  When I used it on my carpets, I quickly fell in love, as well.  It works just as well, if not better than my Dyson.  The carpet looks immaculate and you can tell it's been vacuumed.  It has a smaller dirt container than my Dyson and at first I thought this would be a huge complaint for me, but honestly it's better for two reasons: 1) it is easier to clean and 2) it has a little wand that compresses the dirt.  This makes it less dirty/messy when I have to clean it and it also compresses the dirt so honestly it holds about as much as the bigger Dyson.The biggest thing I was looking forward to was trying the vacuum on pet hair.  I have a maine coon cat and another cat which is like a furball bomb.  She goes "POOF!" and her short hair goes everywhere.  I swear, she shreds more than my maine coon cat.  So I have tons of hair on one hand and very thick heavy fur on the other.  This machine vacuumed it up and left my floor looking great.  The wand attachment works great and I appreciate the length and ease of use.  It does a great job on my couches, sucking up cat fur.I have two complaints.  The first is that it makes a clicking sound when I lean the vacuum back and I don't know how to fix it.  It sounds like plastic rubbing against plastic.  The other is a lack of places on the vacuum to store the wand attachments...there's like none.  And coming from my Dyson, where everything had a place and it was easy to keep everything together, this one has no visible place to store things.Overall, it's a great alternative to Dyson and does a fantastic job both in cleaning up cat fur and also working on hard floors.  Very highly recommended.

I have a maine coon cat.  She has incredibly thick, thick hair.  And lots of it.  Consequently, she has hair in bad places that can cause a mess when she needs to take care of her business.  I decided something needed to be done but I don't want to bring my cat to be groomed constantly.  I bought the Oster A5 pet clipper which worked pretty well.  My poor cat had a few very tight knots near her skin and it had a tough, tough time getting rid of those.  So when I was offered the A6 to review, I jumped at the chance.  Overall, the A6 works great.  It's surprisingly quieter than my A5, which is a plus with a skittish cat.  It doesn't get as hot as the A5, even though it seems to be more powerful.  It's also slimmer and definitely more usable than the A5.  The biggest issue is that my roommate took the blade attachment off because he thought it was a replaceable blade and now I can't figure out how to get it back on.  Just don't do that.  Otherwise, it's a fantastic, thinner, more powerful grooming tool and one that I can readily recommend for thick cat fur.

I have been a D-Link fan ever since I had to upgrade from my old, old (remember the blue wireless with bunny ears?) Linskys router and never looked back.  I've recently used the D-Links most expensive, "gaming-centric" model which has been working well until recently.  First I started noticing that my cell phones kept saying they were attached but were still not receiving data.  Then other portable devices started having issues.  When offered this Linksys router, I jumped at the chance because of the problems I'd been having with the D-Link one (that I spent about $150 on, for comparison).  I have to say that this router is the easiest to use/set-up router and also the fastest.Right now, there are three people in my house who are constant users of streaming options.  At any one time, I probably have two Roku boxes and a wireless TV streaming at the same time.  As well as cell phones/tablets.  So there's a lot of streaming going on.  Whereas my D-Link router seemed to be having issues with all of them going at once, this new router has kept up and there's never been a dip in quality from the HD programming.  It simply handles it.Speaking of simply handling it, while I'm not tech-newbie, I appreciate devices that easily set up and don't require a lot of tinkering.  The N900 definitely goes this route with a CD starter that actually is useful.  It's simple plug and play when you insert the disk, which sets up the name, password and immediately creates a security level (which you can tinker with later) and you're up and running.  It literally took less than five minutes and all of the devices immediately synched up with the new router, as if it had never changed.  For individuals who want to tinker more with the settings, it still offers up the usual tech options but this router seems made to make you not have to/want to do it.  I honestly didn't have to do any tinkering for mine.It also has an app you can download to your phone, which is handy in some ways.  I haven't dug around too much into it, but one neat thing is that you can see what devices are connected to your router and it might come as a surprise to realize just how much your house is connected.  I looked at it and went "no way is there twelve devices connected to my router!" but yeah, there was.  Anyway, my little detour aside, this router is sleek and sexy-looking and operates just as reliably and easily as I hoped.  Linksys has surprised me.

This floor lamp is very, very nice, especially given the price.  It stands just under 6' tall, was incredibly easy to set up and offers both a nice room-enhancing light and a smaller reading light.  The rotary switch offers options for both or only one of the lights on.  The only complaints I can levy at this is that my other lamps have two rotary switches, one for each lamp, and that the larger light (100 watt) would be a tri-setting lamp to get different lighting options or that it was a higher/brighter wattage.  Otherwise, for the price, it's a beautiful-looking floor lamp.

Belkin is obviously going for the Apple look with this particular product.  It reminds me of the bumper cover Apple offers.  The biggest difference with this is that it has an actual plastic see-through back cover.  Otherwise, it's very reminiscent of the bumper cover.  The biggest complaint I have with this is that it feels a bit bulkier than the bumpers; but it's also cheaper and works just as well.  Recommended.

You wake up in a small room, with a young woman sitting in the corner.  You don't know where you are or how you got here.  The woman calls herself Phi and seems to know you.  But she either can't--or won't--tell you how.  Once you figure out how to exit the room, you meet seven other individuals, most of whom seem to have a connection to at least one other person in the room.  None of them know why they are there, where they are or what lies in store.  Before you can really gather your bearings, a rabbit puppet of sorts appears on a screen in the warehouse room you are standing in and, much like the Saw movies, the rabbit wants to play a game.  And, also much like Saw, it doesn't seem like the game is stacked in your favor.Welcome to the rabbit hole that is Zero Escape: Virtue's Last Reward, a visual novel of a game that combines the novel and puzzle/logic puzzles.  A sequel to 9 Hours, 9 Persons, 9 Doors, it builds on the universe created in the original game and fans of that will run into some surprising revelations.  However, if you're like me, then this is your first introduction to the games and let me tell you, you're in for a doozy.  The game is split between copious amounts of reading that's voice acted (unlike 999) and puzzle solving, where you are in a room and you have to figure out a way to escape it, usually by solving logic problems and puzzle solving.  Once in a while, you have to participate in yet a different type of game called The Ambidex Room.  At this point you (and your partner, if you are paired that way) must decide whether to ally or betray a person in a different Ambidex Room.  It's the standard prisoner dilemma: if you both ally, you gain two points; if one side betrays and the other allies, the betrayer gets three points and the ally-er loses two points; if both sides betray, nothing happens.  The goal is to gain nine points.  If you hit 0 points, you get "penalized," which isn't pleasant.So what do you do?  Trust that the person(s) in the next room are going to ally with you (the most logical choice since you both gain two points)?  Or do you fear that, regardless of what they say, they will choose betray?  The exit only opens once...do you really believe the other person has your interest at heart?It's this question that's at the heart of Virtue's Last Reward.  Surrounding that central theme is a myriad of questions involving science, human nature and other spoilerific questions that open up about as many questions.  To say that Virtue's Last Reward is surprisingly heady for a video game is an understatement.  Plot twists abound that make you question what's happening.  Each time you make a decision on whether to ally or betray and at other times in the story, you split off into a different story strand that will lead you to a different ending.  Ultimately there's 24 different endings; however, unlike most games you will probably see every single one.  A new feature in this game is the ability to swap between the different timelines at will and the way the game is structured, in order to solve the mysteries and understand everything that's happening, you will see every possible ending.  It's spectacular, especially the way this game mechanic ties into the story.As the game gets rolling, I found myself unable to quit playing.  I'm not usually a fan of portable game machines unless I'm out and about.  Chances are, if I'm home and playing games it'd be on my console or PC.  Zero Escape has changed this.  I have spent more time than I can count, perched on my couch or bed, playing this silly game.  It's a clich, but I truly do lose track of time when I'm in this world.  It is so involving and the puzzles are so tied into the story that I don't realize I've been playing for an hour or two.  To get through the game, you will probably spend upwards of 30 hours.  And that's "X"ing through the dialogue and not listening to the voice actors talk the entire time.  A nice addition, given the fact that you will see story portions again in order to choose a different path, you can hit "skip" and it will fast=-forward through the scenes you've seen before and stop when new dialogue is introduced.  It's an awesome addition and makes replaying areas drag less.Ultimately, Zero Escape: Virtue's Last Reward is easily one of my favorite games this year.  It's intelligent, the translation is top-notch and the English voice acting is pretty decent (purists can select the original Japanese track--a nice surprise).  The story kept me enthralled and the logic puzzles--while sometimes forcing me to resort to walkthroughs--never feel obtrusive.  If you own a PS Vita or a 3DS, this is truly a must own game.

Detention is what happens when a 90s-obsessed music video director gets high and gorges on Scream 4, Donnie Darko and Kevin Smith movies.  It begins with a high school girl lying in bed and breaking the fourth wall, espousing on her rules of existing as a high school hottie, with her rules being written on the screen a la Zombieland.  She is quickly (and thankfully) eviscerated by a surprising original and creepy-looking killer, modeled off of a fictitious horror show (a la Scream/Stab) called Cinderhella and its sequel.  The movie proper begins, this time with our lower-class, French-fry -in-bed-eating loser protagonist who also breaks the fourth wall (this happens a lot).  As Detention then introduces our unlikely protagonists who talk as if they wanted to be in a Kevin Smith film and dissect the horror movie they are in, all the while getting confused whether the murderer is replicating Cinderhella or Scream.  I think that's when they introduce the time-traveling stuffed bear.  I don't know.  I was on Ambien the first time I watched it.Why is it called Detention?  Well, about an hour into the film (approximately 30 minutes from the end), they end up in (Breakfast Club alert!) Saturday Detention during their prom because the principal (Dane Cook) believes that since they were near one of the people who was killed (who apparently has fly blood (The Fly) and lived for the first 13ish years of his life with his hand in a TV...I can't make this stuff up) one of them is obviously the killer so let's all get together for Detention instead of going to prom.  From there, time travel, body-swapping, end-of-the-world (Donnie Darko) shenanigans all come to play that I forgot I was watching a movie supposedly about a slasher-killer.Honestly, I don't really know what to say about Detention.  I did laugh periodically throughout and I appreciated some of what director Joseph Kahn was aiming for.  He takes shots at music video directors thinking they can be feature film directors (i.e., him) and the movie Torque (also by him) and continues the trend set up in Scream 4 in dissecting not only modern day horror but also the Twitter/Facebook/YouTube nature of pop culture today.  At one point, the Detentionees find footage of upcoming Cinderhella 3 and, much like the much superior opening to Scream 4, it is a movie inside a movie inside a movie, all wrapped around being in Saturday detention.  But when something takes a kitchen sink approach to filmmaking, it can either be absolutely enthralling and entertaining (see: American Horror Story) or needlessly exhausting (see: Detention).  I think it was around the moment of the mother/daughter body/time-swapping that my eyes glazed over.  Or it could have been the Ambien.

I approached Angelmaker with some reluctance.  When offered to review it, I almost passed.  I read Nick Harkaway's debut novel, The Gone-Away World...well, okay, I read about half of it.  That was a book that plodded along, contained some of the most verbose passages I've read this side of Victor Hugo and was too tangential in its story-telling to really keep me involved.  I eventually caved and chose Angelmaker because of the synopsis (which was exactly why I chose his debut).Basically, Angelmaker is about an antique clock fixer named Joe Spork.  His father was an infamous criminal nicknamed "Tommy Gun," but Joe turned his back on the mobster family history to live a quiet life.  One day, he activates an unusual mechanism for his client, Edie Banister, a retired international secret agent.  Long story short, the mechanism is an old doomsday machine that Joe has trigged and now is being chased by the British government and a dictator who also happens to be Banister's arch-nemesis.  Mix in a side story romance and other crazy shenanigans and you have Angelmaker.First a couple pluses: I actually finished this one.  And I found it to be pretty darn entertaining.  Much like Gone-Away World, Harkaway can writes scenarios that are both witfully entertaining and exciting.  But he can also get so bogged down in his own inventiveness and literary-mindedness that he rambles.  His story, again like his debut, flits around between time periods and characters that don't seem even remotely connected, before tying it all together in the end.  Inventive and fun, but needlessly padded.

Not exactly sure what to say about these dishes.  They came expertly wrapped for shipment and when I took them out, I was a bit amazed at the beauty of them.  They have a very modern and minimalistic design; I love the gentle curves of the plates and the way the bowls look.  The mugs' handles are very unique, too.  They look and feel very fancy and you can't go wrong with a traditional bone white color.  Also, very light but don't feel delicate.  These dishes make a great presentation and don't take up a lot of space.  Definitely recommend it, if you're looking for some nice modern china.

I had a previous Norelco Bodygroom razor that I absolutely loved for the most delicate areas.  So when I was offered a chance to review this one, I decided to give it a shot.  Depending on what you're using this for, you'll have better luck.  I don't think the razor is the best for certain parts of the body.  Using the attachments to cut specific lengths for trimming work, but sometimes I found it pulling instead of trimming.  When you take the trimmer parts off to use on...golf balls, for example, it tended to nick the oh-so-please-be-gentle parts.  It does come with an extender that you can use to shave your back with, which is nice.That said, I ended up going back to my previous model because, when it comes to golf balls, you want to have the closest, smoothest and, most importantly, least painful experience.

I absolutely love this device.  If you own an i-product and want full sounding speakers (and don't mind spending a bit for it), then definitely check this product out.  Setup is pretty easy, though kind of annoying in a needless way.  You have to download an app from the iOS store, plug your device into the machine (where it will also charge your device) and setup the wireless functions that way.  Once you're done with this step, you can delete the app since any Apple product on your network will work with the device.  Streaming to the UE Air Speaker is easy.  All you have to do is click the AirPlay button on your device and it streams to the speakers wonderfully.  It works with pretty much any audio app on the device.  Mainly, I use Spotify and have an instant playlist and music selection pumping out of the speakers.  Obviously, if you don't have an Apple device then look somewhere else.Now, I wasn't honestly expecting much from a sound perspective, even though the price is premium, but I was blown away.  Bass, in particular, sounds rich without vibrations in the speakers.  This thing pumps out awesome sound.  House-filling sound, actually.  I was very surprised.The nice thing about the UE Air Speaker is the minimalistic nature of it.  It basically has a power button and a volume control button.  With your iPhone/iPod, you don't really need anything else.  The charger base pops in/out to add to the minimalistic design.  The biggest problem, though, is that with the new Lightning connector, your new fangled iProduct might not work with it.  I was lucky to have this before I upgraded to an iPhone 5 but obviously now it won't plug into the base.  I don't have the new connector so I can't say how that works converting the Lightning connector to the old format.That's probably the biggest problem with this product, which is of no fault to Logitech.  Otherwise, it is absolutely fantastic and rich sounding.

Songbooks are usually a flip of the coin in terms of how good they are and what you are looking for.  Sometimes, you'll get books that incorporate the singing melody in the piano part, while also trying as best as possible to keep the background music going, to create a solo piano piece.  Others are simply the piano part, complete with spaces and other instrumental breaks for the other band members.  Others still try to make a complete piece that, while not including the vocal melody in the piano part, you can play from beginning to end.  This piano songbook tries to do the latter and, for the most part, it's one of the best piano books I've played for rock music.Honestly, Muse is probably one of the best bands to pick for a pianist, simply because most of the bombastic music incorporates pianos to some degree.  This songbook collects some of the better songs from a piano-playing perspective from every album up to Resistance.  There are some amazing songs here and most of them are incredibly fun to play.  This songbook incorporates the background music and leaves the vocal melody to the vocal line.  So if you're looking for a piano book that incorporates the vocal melody in with the piano part, look elsewhere.  The music is an accompaniment piece.  While this is sometimes a negative for me, since I just want to jam out to some songs as a complete piece, for the most part the background music here is so fascinating and fun to play that it doesn't matter.  Some songs contained here are absolutely fantastic to play on the piano.  The entire Exogenesis: Symphony is included and is quite simply the reason to buy the book.  It is written to the score, note-for-note keyboard transcriptions mixed with other instruments to be a complete symphonic piece you can play on the piano.  It also includes the vocal line, too.  But even without the vocal part being included in the piano melody, it still sounds and plays fantastic.  Ditto "United States of Eurasia (+ Collateral Damage)."  While you'll never play the vocal part, the background piano melody is fun and gets pretty complicated, with lots of arpeggios and octaves, with some odd and sometimes tricky rhythms for the bass notes.  It's a great song that builds wonderfully to the end (i.e. Eura-SIA! SIA! SIA!) and sounds fantastic.  And then, of course, the segue into "+ Collateral Damage," which is a condensed version of Chopin's Nocturne in E Flat Major and is a beautiful coda to a loud/bombastic song.  This is the song I'm currently learning and it's provided me hours of entertainment as I work through it.Other songs don't fare as well.  I was excited to have "Apocalypse Please" because of its bombastic opening.  But the piano part is literally that same bombastic chord structure for about half of the song.  Fun to play and bang out on the piano, but not when you're playing it, without change, for the first two/three pages.  It's a song that's better suited to have the piano as an accompaniment part, as opposed to a solo to play.  I'm sure a band that wanted to play the song would get more use out of this particular arrangement than the solo pianist.  This also goes for other songs, like "Feeling Good."  Fantastic song and if you plan on using the book as an accompaniment piece for a singer, it's great.  But as a piano solo it's not so fun simply because it repeats the same chord progression and notes for most of the song.  Again, note-for-not transcriptions and is exactly as Matt Bellamy plays it.Overall, The Muse Songbook does a great job of picking songs that sound great and feature the piano.  Everything from "Butterflies & Hurricanes" to the Exogenesis: Symphony is showcased.  It's not about their most popular songs or singles or anything (notice the lack of "Supermassive Black Hole," "Time is Running Out," "Knights of Cydonia," etc.), it's about songs that feature piano and could be turned into a complete song.  It's a fantastic songbook that truly features the awesome piano parts that go into creating a Muse song and really helps showcase just how rhythmic and complicated their music is.  I would definitely recommend this for any Muse pianist aficionado.  Just know that you aren't getting a book of piano solos, per se, and that the book is written note-for-note for a lot of it.  As such, it's definitely intermediate or higher.One of the best piano songbooks I've purchased, hands down.

When a book is compared to the hilarious and now classic Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy, you expect a lot.  And when I first began reading Year Zero, I thought, finally, a book would live up to its jacket comparisons.  Nick Carter (no relation to the Backstreet Boy) is a low-level entertainment lawyer who receives an unexpected visitation from two aliens, one dressed as a nun, the other as a mullah who think he is THE Nick Carter.  Apparently, everyone outside of Earth makes absolutely abysmal music.  And ever since "Year Zero," (i.e. 1977) when they discovered our music, they have been hopelessly (and erotically) addicted to the dulcet sounds.  Unfortunately for the rest of the cosmos, a little thing called musical piracy results in potentially bankrupting the entire universe.  The two aliens--Frampton and Carly, obvs--are hoping that the "famous" Nick Carter will be their one and only hope to clean up the mess because the rest of the cosmos has an easy solution to their problems: Destroy Earth.Year Zero was written by Rob Reid, an entrepeneur some music enthusiasts might know: the company he founded launched Rhapsody.  So his understanding of the music industry and the sometimes (oftentimes) silly laws and regulations surrounding copywrite law is top notch.  And when he stays in this territory, he's absolutely hilarious in skewering music execs and everyone in between.  In some ways, the book reminds me of Ready Player One in the way it namedrops musicians, bands and other musical tropes.  Unlike Ready Player One, once it strays from its known genre, it starts to fall apart.  Once cosmic reality TV shows and other obstacles are thrown in the way of our intrepid heroes, Year Zero starts to lose its pacing and focus.  And what started out as a strong and hilariously vicious satire of the music industry turns into a morass of pop culture that doesn't really find its footing.Ultimately, I didn't really enjoy the book.  But the humor in the beginning and its brilliant thumbing of the music industry provided enough smiles and laughter that I had to bump it up a bit in the score.  Entertaining but ultimately not very fulfilling.

Not really sure what to say about this device that isn't just shown in the star ratings.  This was easily plug and play and was up and running in a heartbeat.  I love that it doesn't require a secondary power source like some devices do.  Setting it up on my PC and tagging its folders for my network, I was able to easily and quickly stream videos and music from the HDD to my Roku/Apple TV devices.  Additionally, plugging it directly into my Roku player, I was able to easily access the videos from there and watch them.  So, really, this is a fantastic device that's easy to use, adds 500 GB of space and was so simple to start up.  Very much recommended.

Reviewing diet/fitness aids like Hydroxycut Hardcore Elite is very difficult.  As you no doubt see from the reviews already here, some people love it, some hate it and some are ambivalent about it.  The truth is that, until you actually try a product, you won't know how your body will react to it, whether it will work or whether side effects will be present.  Each person reviewing this item has had a pretty different experience.  I will give you what I've experienced so far.I'm not usually into the pill scene for dieting.  I've lost 50 lbs on my own, but have recently started hitting constant plateaus.  So when offered the chance to review this product, I decided to take the plunge.  I started it four days ago.  The instructions say to start with one pill, then on day two take two, then days three and beyond to take two pills twice a day.  I didn't do that. I started with one pill and I think that I will continue with that for the foreseeable future.  When I first took the pill, I stopped drinking coffee.  I had a ton of energy and felt vaguely warm all day.  I purposefully started the pill the day I had a doctor's appointment so I could check my blood pressure while on it, since I have bad blood pressure, take pills for it and am worried about how any medication will affect it.  My blood pressure was a little higher than it normally is, but it was still in the good realm so I felt pretty good.I noticed that I had more energy and was more focused than I have been, which is good.  A lot of people have commented about stomach issues.  I will say that while I don't feel nauseous, it has given me some issues that I'm going to watch and if they continue stop with the pill.  It's also supposed to be an appetite suppressant, but that hasn't  done anything for me.  I'm still hungry at normal times.  I will say, though, that I seem to get full quicker and am given a feeling of when to stop which is something that hasn't ever happened to me before.  The proof, though, is in the pudding, they say.  And I will say that over the last four days, I have lost about four pounds.  This has helped me break a plateau I've been plagued with for a while.

The basyx by HON is a very nice, easy to put together and relatively inexpensive chair.  My friend's 13 year old daughter put it together by herself.  The only thing that caused problems was that some of the screw heads were a little big.  I'm a bigger guy and the chair is incredibly sturdy and comfortable.  It has a higher-end feel than I was expecting for the price.  The casters went in easily and move around easily.  I was worried about the casters durability, but they seem very sturdy.  Overall a good chair for the price.

Ali and Ramazan is based on a true story of two orphan lovers, living on the streets.  One was a hustler, the other sniffed glue.  The story hit author Perihan Magden and stayed with her for many years.  Eventually, she sat down to write their very slim story, based solely on a couple newspaper articles.  What struck her was how careless and forgetful the article was of these two individuals.  I have a lot of respect for the author, a journalist and activist and I have a feeling her works read brilliantly in her native Turkish language; however, as much as I wanted to get swept up in Ali and Ramazan's tragic story, it failed to engage with me on any emotional level.Maybe it was a detachment to the cruelty and terribleness of their situation, but Magden piles on tragedy and pain by the truckload to the point that their story becomes so weighted down by tragedy that it verges on the cartoonish.  The beginning of the story, in which Ali and Ramazan meet at an orphanage and slowly and tentatively fall into love with each other is very touching and portends a good coming of age story, albeit a tragic one.  Once they get to the streets, though, and both fall into self-destructive patterns (i.e., hustling and glue-sniffing), I started to not believe their love for one another.  As translated by Ruth Whitehouse, the characters seem broadly written and don't contain as much character as I expected.  I never felt motivation in either of the character's struggles and conquests.  It just read like a downward spiral of stock characters.  I'm not sure whether it's something that was lost in translation or not, but it did not connect with me in a meaningful way.I wanted nothing more than to be swept up in this tragic story, but it just did not engage me.

Every once in awhile, artists/novelists/etc try to stretch themselves and try something different.  Christopher Moore has been slowly moving in this direction, first with his last book Fool and its comical take on King Lear and now with Sacre Bleu.  Sacre Bleu (or Sacred Blue) dives into the art world, spinning a tale that begins with the murder of Van Gogh and jumps from there to discuss his contemporaries, artists all.  One thread that holds it all together is a little man, the Colorman, who seems obsessed with the color blue and a female muse, of sorts, who inspires painters to paint.What follows is a murder mystery, of sorts, where Van Gogh's friends Lucien Lessard and bon vivant Henri Toulouse-Lautrec start to track what exactly happened.  Along the way, they learn about the mysterious Colorman and his female friend.  Christopher Moore is a good comedic writer and while I can appreciate the history context and the way he incorporated real life artists and gave them a spark of life, I did not find this novel as exciting or interesting as his earlier work.  Maybe if I were more involved in the art world, I could appreciate the story a bit more...but to be blunt, I just did not care.I mostly continued reading because Christopher Moore can turn a phrase and writes dialogue very well, even though it sometimes felt anachronistic in this novel.  Not one of his better novels.

I remember finding a bottle of caffeinated water once in the grocery store.  I bought it because I kept thinking that water with caffeine would be an awesome way of cutting out coffee in the morning.  Unfortunately, that water ended up tasting stale and not very good.  So I approached avitae with some skepticism; however, I can honestly say that it didn't taste bad or stale.  There was a little after taste that normal water doesn't have...granted, I'm kind of a stickler for water and seem to have a very sensitive taste for it.  But it gave me a nice little jolt (about the same as a cup of coffee) and it didn't taste bad.  If you're looking for caffeinated water, I'd easily recommend this.

Disclaimer: I love Guillermo del Toro. As such, I'm probably the target audience for this series of books.  As The Fall begins, we find New York City taken over by the vampiric virus from the first novel, The Strain.  And it is spreading.  Our hero Eph is leading a small band to stop the vampires.  Meanwhile, a war erupts between Old and New World vampires, with humans stuck in the middle.  The Strain spent a lot of time world building, particularly with the virus strain.  But The Fall gets going right away, with the struggle.It's an entertaining novel that reads very quickly.  I would have loved to see what would have happened had the original plan (a TV series that was CSI meets vampires) came to fruition.  But, regardless, what's here is just as entertaining as the first novel and made me excited to read the finale.  Very much recommended for fans of the first.
