I was incredibly skeptical of this device.  Plug it into your router, then into a power source and get wired internet?  Pff!  But it really is as simple as that.  It works wonderfully.  I will say that I didn't notice too much of a difference between that and my wireless connection, but unlike some people I don't really have issues with my wireless connectivity across my house.  For those who do, this is a great device that "just works."  I will also make the caveat that it will depend on how well your house is wired.  Bad wired connections can cause issues with the internet through this device. Otherwise, fantastic device.  Very much recommended.

I was incredibly skeptical of this device.  Plug it into your router, then into a power source and get wired internet?  Pff!  But it really is as simple as that.  It works wonderfully.  I will say that I didn't notice too much of a difference between that and my wireless connection, but unlike some people I don't really have issues with my wireless connectivity across my house.  For those who do, this is a great device that "just works."  I will also make the caveat that it will depend on how well your house is wired.  Bad wired connections can cause issues with the internet through this device. Otherwise, fantastic device.  Very much recommended.

First things first: if you don't have an HDMI port on your laptop/PC, move along.  You have to have a HDMI port for this device to work.  If you do, though, it works surprisingly well.  At first, I thought it would just transmit movies or whatever to my TV but it doesn't.  It transmits whatever is on your screen to the TV.  It looks fantastic and is an easy way to transmit to the big screen.  Plug and play and super easy.  Easily recommended.

I remember being disappointed when the first Raving Rabbids title came out.  Developed by one of my favorite game devlepers, Michel Ancel (Rayman, Beyond Good and Evil), it was a bunch of minigames centered around some diabolical yet adorable rabbit-looking creatures.  Unfortunately, the lack of multiplayer games and the quality of them made it a game that collected dust more than anything.  Now that we have the Kinect, this type of game seems perfect.  Alive & Kicking has 34 Quick Play games, 3 party games and some additional features.  The games are meant to be played mostly with 1-4 players, though the party games can have up to 16.The games run the gamut of smacking rabbids, avoiding projectiles or other obstacles, stomp on Rabbids, and basically just act silly.  With adults, this game can be fun at parties (especially when you introduce adult beverages and cameras to the mix) but the kids seem to enjoy it a lot more.  Entertaining.

As the "weird single bird-loving aunt", I couldn't resist buying this for my 10 month old niece. It's just a little bit large for her, but by the time the weather warms up here in Illinois, it should be a perfect fit - right on target with what you'd expect from a 12 month outfit.As a bird lover, my first thought was, "I don't know of any parrot with that coloring!" but it IS just a baby outfit, so I let that slide. My sister loved it. I was just at her house a couple nights ago, and I was actually a little startled to see the outfit in person. It was much brighter and more sparkly than it appeared in the product photos. It would be a great outfit for summer photos.

According to the Mayo Clinic's website, there is good evidence to support that CoQ-10 supplements are helpful to the heart and blood pressure. As a result, I passed my free sample along to a relative who would benefit from improvements in that area. Although it takes a while to see a difference with any supplement, what I do know is that Nutrissence products are made in the USA under GMP manufacturing standards.  There's been a lot of controversy lately over the fact that many supplement products in big box retailers don't actually contain much (if any) of what they say they contain, so it's always good to check for some reasonable assurance of quality standards.Although you're not going to see immediate results, there's plenty of evidence to suggest that taking a high-quality CoQ-10 supplement like this will improve your cardiovascular health.

I hate the way most sports bras give you a very unflattering uni-boob. I get that larger-chested women need to have them "strapped in" pretty well, but as a person with a perfectly nice but not enormous chest, I prefer to avoid that. I love the Beyond Yoga Lift and Support bras. They're cut in a way that's flattering but still very appropriate for athletic pursuits. Built-in padding is minimal, but sufficient to hide any pointy-ness. Although I usually prefer to wear them under a workout top, this is still a tasteful choice if you decide to go without a top over it. If you're really busty, you might have issues, though - especially if your activities include any kind of inverting.I will say that the color was a bit darker than in the picture. I like it either way, but if you're really particular about color, just be aware of that. I've attached a picture in hopes of showing it a little more accurately. It's also a lot softer than the other sports bras I own. If you're ever purchased Beyond Yoga pants,shorts, or capris, you'll notice quickly that this sports bra is made of the same kind of fabric.As far as sizing is concerned, I typically wear between a small and medium in tops and sports bras. Although I've found most Beyond Yoga things run a bit small, I found a size small to be perfect for me in the sports bras. I suspect that's because this is one thing where you actually want it to be fairly snug. In this case,the snugness makes it ideal for low to moderate impact activities. I'd recommend something a bit more intense if you're going to be running or jogging stairs.Overall, I'm very pleased, and I'll be buying more in other colors.

In my experience, Beyond Yoga bottoms seem to run about half a size smaller than brands like Athleta, Victoria's Secret, and Zella. These shorts were no exception,. Like some other people have mentioned, they do have a tendency to roll up if your hips are curvy. If you're more apple or banana than hourglass, you might not have that problem.Although I like these shorts, I tend to prefer them over a pair of contrasting color leggings. They're really short, and if you have much in the way of a butt (muscle or fat, either one), they get even shorter. They'd be great pole dancing shorts, if you're into pole fitness - lots of exposed skin for pole contact.I managed to get my pair on sale, and while I like them, I don't think I'd pay full price for them.

I've used headbands made of wider, stretchy fabric to hold my hair back when washing my face, and I've never had any problems with them slipping off my head. However, these just wouldn't stay put at all. Maybe my head is a weird shape - I'm perfectly willing to admit that's a possibility. I doubt it's a matter of hair type, since I have super thick hair. Unfortunately, these headbands are completely useless for me.On the bright side, they're very pretty and colorful. I would imagine that for some people, the rubber-y grip on the inside of the bands is plenty to keep them on their heads. No amount of adjusting would do it for me, though. If you've had no trouble with similar headbands in the past, you'll probably love these. On the other hand, if you're used to headbands slipping off and you're hoping these will fix the problem - you may not get the results you were hoping for.

For years, I've purchased the little jars of Wilton food coloring you find at big box general stores and craft stores. For years, I've found myself ever-so-slightly irritated at the process of getting out bit of food coloring on a toothpick or butter knife, then mixing it in, then realizing I didn't get enough, cleaning off my utensil and doing it again and again until the right color is reached. With this food coloring, that problem is no longer an issue. I love having food coloring in a squirt bottle instead of a jar. It may not be as easy to get the very last bit out of the bottle, but for convenience, it can't be beaten. You can also minimize that problem by storing the jars upside down in the original box.In terms of color, I couldn't be happier. It didn't take nearly as much coloring as I expected to achieve really vibrant, bright colors. I will say that if you're looking for primary colors, you might not be totally happy with the blue. It's definitely more of a sky blue than a regular blue. The rest of the colors are exactly what you'd probably expect, though. I've included a picture of some cookies with the blue (and red and green) so you can get an idea of what you're getting.Since I often bake at my parents' home, I'll be buying a second set of these for their house before the fall and winter baking season is upon us. I'm very glad to have found this food coloring.

I read this book a couple years ago, and it was a quick, happy little read. I didn't expect to be wildly impressed by the movie, but it turned out to be one of those rare cases where the movie is actually better than the book. Why? The book is short, and it doesn't go the best job of really capturing the experiences Hector has on the road. It doesn't capture the utterly boring, unsatisfying existence Hector was plodding through before his trip. It describes those things, just not as well as the film version.In the movie, you get wonderful acting, beautiful scenery, and widely varied pace from place to place. When Hector goes off on a patient in the beginning, you FEEL his frustration with the life he's leading. When he's living the high life in China, you really get a taste of the excitement and anticipation he would surely be feeling. When he finally lets loose and dances with his friends in Africa, you smile because you know he's a changed man.I'm not saying the book was bad at all, but this is one of those rare cases where the story is better told in film format, and all the right things came together to make it a good one.

Skippy Natural is my favorite peanut butter. I like that it doesn't have high fructose corn syrup like most mainstream peanut butters, but it DOES have sugar to make it sweet. I don't eat a lot of added sugar products, and nobody's going to convince me that a little in my peanut butter is such a terrible thing. Although the package says no-stir, there's a good chance you might have to stir once or twice if your jar was sitting for quite a while. Personally, I keep a few jars in my cabinet at all times and store them upside down. It seems to fix the oil at the top problem by the time I get around to using it. Stirring does fix the problem, but you have to stir really well and all the way down to the bottom if you don't want the top half to be much runnier than the bottom half.The only thing I don't like about this version of Skippy Natural is that it comes in a 40 ounce container. I needed some ASAP and this is what Amazon had in stock at the time, though, so I bought it. I don't like the way the knife handle gets all peanut butter-y when you get to the bottom of the jar. Otherwise, I'm very happy with this, and I'll continue to buy Skippy Natural. The only thing that would make me happier is if they got rid of the palm oil.

Have you ever seen a cute baking project on Pinterest and failed miserably in your recreation? Do you wish you could create cute, edible snacks for the people in your life? If so, this might be exactly what you're looking for.Although I love a good baking project, I don't always have countless hours to spend on them. Making multi-layered cakes with 5 different colors or frosting or fondant can be really time-consuming. Working with candy, on the other hand, is much faster. There's also a much greater margin for error, since most of the important pieces are pre-made.The one caution with this book is that you can't just open it up and expect to be able to make everything with a quick trip to the store. Most things are pretty easy to find, but there are some candies you might need to hunt for (or order online in advance). Some recipes do include a little bit of advance baking or prep work. Don't wait until the last minute, or you'll be very limited in which items you can make. It's not that any of them are super time-consuming, it's just a matter of availability at your store of choice.

I really didn't want to buy these traps. Unfortunately, after spending weeks attempting to catch and release all the moths in my apartment (and throwing out tons of bad food), I had to either get traps or settle for living with moths in my home. I have pet birds, and I suspect the moths came in with dove seed or spray millet.The hard thing about having birds and moths is that you can't use just any pest control method. Birds have extremely delicate respiratory systems and you can kill them or cause severe lung damage if you're not careful. Sprays are completely out of the question unless you relocate the birds for a week or more to let the place air out (and then wipe everything down for residue). These traps were labeled as bird safe and several other bird people mentioned that they worked well in their homes, so I bought them.I do want to note that I didn't put the traps NEAR the birds, though. They were all at least a room away, and I made sure the birds were closely monitored any time they were out of the cage. I have no idea whether the trap would be dangerous if they chewed on it (as parrots so often do with many things).I still feel bad about killing all those moths, but I have to admit the traps worked extremely well. I kept them out for about a month to get all the living moths plus any eggs that might hatch, and it wiped out the problem completely. Since then, I've developed a habit of freezing bird seed when I get it, then keeping it in an airtight container. The problem hasn't returned.

My sun conure and green cheek conure hate when I travel because it means they'll be staying in an unfamiliar place in smaller than usual cages. I make sure they have all their favorite toys and treats, but it's the Cozy Corner that makes it all work. Without their Cozy Corners, they're miserable and they don't sleep well. Once I put those in the cages, though, they simply cuddle up to the Cozy Corner and it calms them down instantly.I keep several sets of extra Cozy Corners around, both at home and when they're staying with my family or friends. Not only do I make sure they always have one in whatever cage they're using, but I also check them regularly for snags or holes. Birds can get stuck in loose strings or holes very easily, so it's important to make sure they're always using one that's perfectly intact.

My mother is a bit odd, and the home she shares with my father is full of doll parts and weird antiques. As a result, I knew I had to buy her these salt and pepper shakers the moment I saw them. Although they're not antiques, they definitely fit the theme in her house.The shakers were a bit larger than I expected, but they're still a great size for a normal kitchen or dining room table. The holes are neither too big nor too small, and they have no issues with the seals falling out and spilling the salt or pepper. The only downside is that my mom likes them so much she's afraid to use them. My dad has a history of dropping things, so she's afraid they'll be broken if they're out on the table for him to use regularly.

I've always been a little mystified by the whole "diamonds and gemstones" thing. I don't own any diamonds, and I really can't get excited about them. As a result, I decided to take some classes through GIA and figure out what all the fuss is about. I still don't care about wearing diamonds, but I've learned a lot and I now have a better appreciation of the artistry (not to mention, the investment potential once you look past retail jewelry).Renee Newman's diamond handbook is the best diamond reference book I've found. It has great color images, along with a ton of detailed, relatively current information. This goes way beyond the basic "4 C's" talk you'll get from most sources, and it will leave you feeling very confident when it comes to buying, selling, and discussing diamonds. It won't take the place of a good lab class where you learn to view them up close, but it's a fantastic supplement to any diamond course, and I'd recommend it to anyone with an interest in diamonds - whether you work in a jewelry store, sell them wholesale, or just enjoy trolling estate sales and junk shops for bargains.

I've been a fan of both bossa nova and Kenny G for as long as I can remember, so hearing about this album made me very happy. Kenny G's older recordings of Desafinado and The Girl from Ipanema have enjoyed prominent spots on my "Not That Kind of Brazilian" Spotify playlist for quite a while now, so I was anxious for this to finally be released.Brazilian Nights has all the sex appeal of traditional bossa nova without the "I could get stabbed in a Rio de Janeiro alley" edge. What do I mean by that? In short, it's a masterful take on the genre, but with the more smooth and refined sound you expect from Kenny G. Listen to some of the famous Stan Getz, Paul Desmond, or Cannonball Adderley recordings that inspired this album and you'll hear it. Where the others (especially Getz) have a breathier, almost rougher sound, Kenny G has a very distinctive and smooth tone. I love that it wasn't sacrificed for the sake of sounding like every other bossa nova recording.There's a lot of emotion in the songs on Brazilian Nights, and it doesn't leave you with exactly the same feelings you might get listening to the older recordings that made some of these songs famous. It's a surprisingly fresh take on the genre, while still being a great tribute. It might be my imagination, but when I listen to this album I hear notes of wistfulness and melancholy but also passion, hope, and even safety - the kind you'd feel in a perfect moment with a special significant other. As always with Kenny G albums, this would be another great playlist for "indoor activities".Piano accompaniment factors in heavily on quite a few of the songs, and it's especially good on bossa nova classic Corvocado and the originals April Rain and Brazilian Nights.I'm sure the stuffy jazz snobs will be out in full force to try to convince everyone that Brazilian Nights is objectively bad and that the jazz greats who inspired it are rolling over in their early graves. They don't sound like much fun to be around, though, and they certainly don't change the fact that I loved this album. If you like bossa nova and you don't hate Kenny G on principle, there's a good chance you'll love it, too.As a side note, the album also comes with some live tracks of classic Kenny G songs, which are fantastic. It's still nothing like actually seeing them performed live, but they're a nice alternative to the studio recordings.

I took some woodworking classes last fall so I could make some cool bowls and cutting boards for family members at Christmas. As a result, I needed some cutting board oil to treat the wood several times before giving the items as gifts. This did a great job, leaving the boards looking extremely nice (and my hands were pretty soft afterwards, too).Once I was done, I gave the rest to family so they'd have it on hand for future treatments. So far, everyone is pleased. Nobody wants to cut anything on the boards I made them, but I'm told the water beads up and rolls off nicely when the boards are being washed off after being used as serving boards.

I bought these for a friend's cats, and I honestly wasn't expecting much. I just knew I wanted to get something a little different that would fit in my suitcase since I was flying out there for a visit. I had no idea these toys would turn them into jumping, hissing, ecstatic monster cats. They were in love.Somehow, these toys gave them the ability to do perform masterful parkour feats using the living room furniture and walls. When they got tired, they carried the toys around in their mouths by the fuzzy part, eventually laying down to sleep with them. Even if they never touched them again after that first moment, it was absolutely worth it for the entertainment.

My family is not particularly religious, so we have a lot of fun with Christmas. This year, my sisters and I decided to celebrate "Bulgemas" by dressing up as Labyrinth characters. We had 3 female David Bowie's and 1 "babe with the power". I bought this set of pajamas for my niece since it was very similar to the pajamas worn in the movie.My sister (the mother) commented that she's actually gotten a lot of use out of the pajamas because they're really soft. They were great for Christmas, but it looks like she's going to be able to wear it for Valentine's Day, too. And of course, when she outgrows it, someone else is going to be delighted to receive these super-soft pajamas.

My little sister is a kindergarten teacher and she's a big fan of toys that break gender stereotypes. I purchased this train set for her children, and she was terribly excited to see both her son and daughter enjoying it (though the daughter mostly put it in her mouth).As the aunt, I was just glad to be able to purchase a reasonably priced, environmentally friendly, USA-made toy for my niece and nephew. It's great for open-ended play, too, so hopefully this means I'll have smarter, more creative nieces and nephews.

Confession time: I've seen Kenny G in concert 5 times now. I travel a lot and go to a lot of concerts, and Kenny G is one of my favorites to see in person. Some musicians just don't have the skills or personality to make their live show an improvement over the CD/mp3, but Kenny G absolutely does.On top of that, he plays with a band full of incredible musicians. In all seriousness, I would probably pay to see several of the other guys doing solo shows if I heard they were playing somewhere convenient. That's how good they are.Unfortunately,I can't head to a concert every time I want to get my Kenny G fix. I rack up enough frequent flier miles as it is. I wouldn't say this recording would ever take the place of the live shows, but it's still very good. It's also considerably cheaper than a live show, so that's a plus. The show featured here is a few years old now, and it does't include some of the really good newer material. Heart & Soul, for example, came out a couple years after this was recorded, and it's one of my favorites to see live. His new bossa nova album Brazilian Nights is coming out in a few days, so you won't find that on this 2008 DVD, either.Still, all the classics are here, along with a bit of the Rhythm and Romance album. I would recommend this for any Kenny G fan, but especially for those who haven't had the pleasure of attending a live show. The CDs and mp3s are wonderful, but the live shows are really special, and this gives you a taste of that.

I needed an extra black vest for a set of costumes, and this worked for that purpose - but only because we were taking photos from the front. There is NO back to this vest, so if you need an actual vest instead of just something that looks like a vest, you'd be better suited with something else.The vest is flimsy and covered in sequins as promised, and it does run a bit smaller than you might expect based on normal (inflated) American sizes. I wouldn't say it's total garbage, but this is definitely the sort of cheap thing you get for a costume or some other one-time use situation. It's not a quality piece of apparel at all.

I bought this thing as sort of a joke, but for it's intended purpose, it's really not bad!  And I've found myself using this more and more.  The joke was using a camera phone for a studio shoot.  But the darn thing works so well for light cameras I've kept it around.Now I did try a weight test and it does hold a full frame SLR with a  50mm lens.  But that was assuming everything was stationary and being rather ginger with the handling.  Lets face it, that's not the intended purpose of this ball head nor what it should be used for.  Argue with me if you like, but it's your money on the line when this thing fails and your expen$ive camera and lens drops like a rock.If you plan to use a phone or a point and shoot for videography this will (in conjunction with a decent tripod) give you a lot of options.  I mounted mine to a Manfrotto 055XPROB which required a 3/8" to 1/4" thread adaptor.  And surprisingly enough, they make a good combo.  Maybe a little mismatched visually but honestly quite versatile.  For a camera of a pound or less it yields a pretty positive lock.  And it's even notched so the ball can lay down 90 degrees to the horizon.  There's no way to accurately adjust where the notch will be when tightened but mine consistently faces the rear leg of my tripod.Really for something that works this well, it's quite inexpensive and worth owning.  Assuming you still shoot with light cameras.  Once again, DSLR users, seriously don't bother.

This really does seem to the best set of aluminum tripod legs for under $200.  I looked at a lot of different options and just kept coming back.  Sure there are better tripods out there, but prepare to take out a small loan to get one.I needed something to satisfy both my "standard" tripod needs as well as my desire to get down low, really low.  First I'm 6'1" and the XPROB suits me perfectly.  It's even tall enough for users up to 6'4".  And I'm sure users who need something shorter will feel right at home as well.  But I wanted something to let me get as low to the ground as possible.  The XPROB gets me there.  There are tons of video reviews out there but I'll summarize.  The legs once opened can be released to one of four positions.  (Notice I said "released" as opposed to "locked".  The 055XPROB does not lock the legs at any angle.  It's locks just keep them from spreading past a certain angle.)  The last position is nearly horizontal.  The center column can be easily manipulated to change from a vertical column to a horizontal "arm."  This gets the mount about 4" off the ground at the center line.  That's pretty darn low!As for the rest, the three telescopic leg sections are nice and solid once locked.  The column is the same.  The legs as they are opened have a degree of resistance which is nice.  Important to keep them from closing on you should you need to move the whole rig in a pinch.  In fact I must say everything about the XPROB just feels quality to me.  It's a hefty unit but that just speaks to me of build quality.  I realize there are many who dislike the weight of this tripod for travel of hiking.  And I agree that this could be concern if that's your intended usage.  But I don't plan to cross the Alps with mine.The column is tapped with a 3/8" standard thread mount.  The ball head argument is far more heated in my opinion than the legs.  I went ahead and shelled out the bucks for a Really Right Stuff head but that's another topic all together.  No matter what your choice of head, the 055XPROB is going to be an excellent foundation to build on.  As I said above, there are better options available but they can cost 3-5 times as much and beyond.  The final push that convinced me to buy was how many of these I kept seeing and the testimonials from the professionals using them.  Honestly, it seems Manfrotto really has cornered at least this portion of the market.  So if the weight of an aluminum tripod doesn't bother you and you need something versatile...look no further.

Moving into a new home?  Doing some electrical work?  Got high-end electronics?  Well you might want to check those outlets for proper polarity.You don't need to be an electrician to use one of these testers.  But you do need to understand a few things to know what your reading.  A three prong outlet found in every home in America "should" fed by three wires; a HOT wire, a Neutral wire, and (safety) Ground wire.  Even an experienced contractor can make mistakes and this can lead to problems if these are mixed.  The most serious of these is a potential fire.A little background:  Back when the first homes were being wired with electricity, about the only load in the house was lighting.  And light bulbs are dumb.  They don't care about polarity.  Many outlets were wired forwards and backwards and really nothing was seen as wrong about that.  However these days we have "always on" equipment with "soft" power buttons like most of the equipment in our home entertainment centers.  The switching circuitry DOES care about proper polarity.  I'm not saying it won't work if improperly wired, but damage can result.  Add to that, that reversing the wiring of a ground and another conductor can cause an overload do to heat that you many never notice since your TV and other devices seem to work fine.So basically, it's always a good idea to check an unknown outlet with one of these receptacle testers.  They will tell you if the line has just about any combo of reversed wiring through the usage of three led lights.  The "key" on the face of the unit will tell you how to interpret your results.  In general, two orange lights is what you're after.  Be aware however, there are at least two instances where this tester does not work.  First is in "two wire" systems.  Older homes may have outlets fed by only a HOT and a NEU and lacking a ground.  I've seen many of these that have been improperly "updated" with three prong outlets.  Plugging this into one of these will yield and "open ground" result.  However without a ground connection, the tester has no reference to test the polarity between hot and neutral.  In other words, in this (somewhat common) scenario, this tester cannot tell you the polarity of these types of outlets.  This would also be the case if you were to use one of these testers to test a two prong outlet in conjunction with a ground plug adaptor (two prong to three prong adaptor.)  Another problem is in installations with breaker boxes with isolated neutral and ground busses.  This tester cannot differentiate if the wiring of the ground and neutral has been reversed.  And potentially the ground conductor in the breaker box could be carrying the return current instead of the neutral conductor.  In most homes this won't be a concern as they only have one breaker panel and they are required by code to bond the neutral and ground buss bars together.  One more thing concerning NEU - ground reversal, again since it has no way to test this, it will not alert you if the neutral and ground wires on the outlet has been reversed.  Which leads me to this final point.  This is simply a "warning tool" or a "quick reference" device.  If you check an outlet and get anything short of "correct" on the indicator, you should delve into the issue further.  This can't always tell you the cause of your incorrect reading.  Only a voltmeter and proper training will.  If you lack either one of these, consult and electrician.

If you need to adapt a locking 120V 30A receptacle to a accommodate a 15 or 20 piece of equipment with a standard wall plug, this one really is about the best out there.  Now I'll admit there are cheaper alternatives, but when dealing with electrical equipment, I want something that's been genuinely UL listed.  Marinco is a trusted brand in my opinion.  This is part of their new EEL series.  Unlike some of their other EEL connectors, there is no special locking weather seal so this really is just a branding thing.  But the connections are tight and the build quality is solid.  Bottom line, if you want something you can trust to be left unattended without worry of failure under normal usage, this is the adaptor for you.

There really is no reason in my opinion to own anything else.  I realize you can nickel and dime yourself to death but something things really are worth the extra expen$e.  The 026 truly is the best as far as I'm concerned.I'm fairly new to photography and as I got ready to take the step into the larger world of off camera flash photography I took the time to properly research my equipment options.  Honestly this really is a no brainer.  The 5/8's inserts at either end yield nearly universal compatibility with mounting options which already get's the 026 to te head of the pack.  Obviously this is designed to be mounted atop a light stand but the included female adaptor lets the 026 to thread onto a 1/4" or 3/8" male threaded mount.  Not all alternatives include these adaptors.All locks are easy to manipulate and the whole rig is a solid bridge once tightened down.  The best of these is the main pivot lock.  Its the largest of the locks.  And once tightened down the handle can be "unlocked" and pointed to a more convenient angle then reengaged.  The rest of the tensioners are well designed and well placed.  The one thing I would change to improve this design is the "top lock" that normally holds your hot shoe mount.  A knob would've been preferable to the clamp style tensioner.  The rest is pretty standard throughout the industry.The bottom line is the Manfrotto 026 umbrella adaptor can be had for $30-35.  That's not going to break the bank if you compare it to the cost of a decent flash.  In fact at what a decent light costs, I really wouldn't trust anything else.  One more thing.  If you intend to mount a speedlight to this thing, do yourself a favor.  Buy a Stroboframe shoe mount adaptor.  These are the best.  The yield a positive lock on the hoe shoe foot.  And they also feature a cutaway that gives plenty of clearance for the contacts on the bottom of your flash (i.e. - keeping these from shorting to one another.)  There is one little caveat, the stroboframe has a small screw on the bottom that causes clearance issues.  The brass thread adaptor has to be set about 3/16" high in the holder to get proper clearance and a solid lock.

The 381 is one of those tools that fits the description "if this doesn't have it, you don't need it." In terms of what features you'd expect to find on a clamp meter, the 381 leaves little to be desired. The 381 is capable of voltage measurements to 1000V AC and DC with a 1000V CAT III and 600V CAT IV safety ratings. What's all this mean? CAT ratings are specific to a certain section of an electrical system. Meters rated to CAT 3 can work on most switch gear / breaker panels and systems down stream of them (outlets, appliances, hardwired equipment, ect..) CAT 4 is the highest level and adds service drops from the electric utility as well as underground installations. The accompanying voltage is the maximum safe working voltage on these parts of the system. I do not have the information on what the maximum transient voltage / surge voltage this meter is designed to handle happens to be.The 381 can measure voltage to 1KV on AC and DC systems, and of course has resistance measurements and includes a continuity buzzer. Now this does lack the diagnostic features of an electronics meter but that's to be expected. This is an industrial amp meter. The jaw clamp will take AC and DC current measurements to 999.9A in 0.1A increments. The iFlex clamp will take AC measurements to 2500A in whole numbers but will not take DC current measurements. Unlike other external clamps this uses a proprietary 3 pin connection to connect to the iFlex thus yielding accurate and appropriately quantified measurements. Now bear in mind clamp designs due to their nature of measuring magnetic fields inherently have a margin of error and this one if memory serves is between 2% and 5% depending on the range and frequency of power. Cabling should placed in the center of the jaws or the flex clamp to obtain best accuracy. Of course the meter can be "hung" on the cabling if accuracy is less of a concern and/or additional safety measures are needed. For those who have never used a clamp meter, measurements are taken by clamping onto an individual conductor in a circuit. The equipment ground conductor, the neutral conductor, and any additional hot conductors need be outside the jaws as these conductors will cancel out the readings taken. In other words placing a cord inside the jaws will yield a amperage reading of 0. The conductors need to be separated to obtain measurements. Hence the industrial nature of this meter and most clamp on meters.Note: I strongly discourage the homeowner tendency to split open an extension cord to obtain these measurements from a load with a traditional plug. For these types of measurements there are commercial plug-in adaptors available like the Amprobe ELS2A or the Extech 480172. In commercial / professional settings, typical measurements are taken off the loose conductors in j-boxes and the like. Again this is something I recommend extreme caution in practice and advise the inexperienced to avoid trying. Electricity is dangerous even if you know what you're doing and is deadly if you don't.Onto the real review...What I love - I mentioned above this clamp meter will take amperage measurements (in the clamp jaws) of both AC and DC systems. For my usage, the DC side can be quite indispensable and not all clamp meters work on DC installations. But then not all users need DC current measurement capability either. Next the 381 features a low pass filter to eliminate errors in voltage measurements due to harmonics in an AC system. Where this becomes apparent is when working on large non-linear loads such as VFDs or even large AC to DC converters. Unlike other meters such as the 87V, this feature is not switchable and instead is always enabled. However in electrical work this shouldn't pose a problem. It could limit the 381's usability in electronics diagnostics but again this is not an electronics meter. The next excellent feature is the "inrush" [current] measurement which I love. With this measurement the meter is placed on a hot conductor in the circuit. A load is then switched on and the 381 measures the peak amperage for the first few dozen cycles (for about 100ms I believe.) This gives a reading of the "inrush" or "startup" current which can be many times higher than the running current. This is one of features that sets the Fluke 370/380 series of clamp meters above the competition. The iFlex is of course another of these "cut above" features. The jaw clamp has an internal opening of .... The iFlex is much larger with a diameter of.... The iFlex can also be squeezed into compartments where traditional jaws may not fit or routed through and around other conductors if need be. There may be a penalty in accuracy but that's a small trade off for obtaining a measurement that otherwise couldn't be obtained. I love that the iFlex has its own setting on the main dial and that thanks to its 3 pin connector, gives a readout in amps and without any need for "multiples of this or that mathematics." On this meter, with the external probe, an amp is an amp and it's as simple as that. The last trick the 381 has up its sleeve is the remote display. The user can unlock the display and carry it to a better position up to 30 ft (or so the literature says.) I've had mine to about 20' with no issues. This meter uses some form of GSM wireless communication when undocked from the main body. When docked with the main body the display appears to use an IR window to receive signals I'm not sure if there is two-way communication or not. The display has three buttons on it including "hold", "min/max", and the backlight. Min/Max info could be handled onboard I suppose. But if I had to guess I'd say communication is bi-directional. I remember reading that "other displays can be synchronized" to the body but that only one display can be synced at a time. The question I have, to which I don't yet have an answer is whether two or more 381s can be used in wireless mode at the same time. I'm not sure if there would be interference or cross talk but it's not really something I need, just more of a curiosity. The other controls on the main body are the "zero" and "inrush" buttons as well as the mode selector dial. Back to the remote display, in addition to its wireless communication Fluke decided to give us one more handy feature. The back of the display has a magnet so this can be placed where its most easily viewed or to let the technician use the probes or to control the load being tested. Lastly I applaud Fluke for giving the consumer two things that should be standard equipment with all of their meters but aren't. The first is a soft side case for the meter and accessories. The second is a set of their genuine silicone rubber test leads. They include a pair of TL175 which have a twist lock safety shroud for the probe tips. Twist the end of the lead and the shroud extends or retracts. This is a safety feature for working on CATIII and CATIV installations. But for me the real safety feature is the silicone rubber leads themselves. In other meters I've purchased from Fluke, I've received their TL75s which are garbage in my opinion. Safety-wise they carry excellent ratings but the cheap plastic jackets over the wire, kink and get tangled. This can quickly become a safety concern if you have to fight a kink causing you to lose concentration on what you're working on. Flukes silicone rubber leads like the TL71, TL175, and the models in the TL220 series have no memory and even after months wrapped with a twist tie fall straight and free when unwound. Thumbs up Fluke!What I like -I like this meter's resolution. It yields a 0.1V to 600V resolution which is much better than other clamp meters that are only accurate to the volt then 600V to 1000V in wholes numbers. I won't go into accuracy & counts vs. resolution but can say that resolution does play a part in the inherent accuracy of a meter. That extra 1/10 scale means a lot to someone like me who is interested in obtaining the most accurate reading possible. Next I like the backlight. This isn't something found always on a clamp meter and its indispensable in my opinion. In my experience, electrical problems always seem to hide in poorly lit areas. The "zero" key is important as it lets the user zero a measurement even if the line has a small amount of current on it. It can also be used to zero prior to a reading to see change in current as opposed to total current flowing on a line. I like the "feel" of the 381. The dial is a tad stiff but is well placed and could be used one handed. The thumb "trigger" on the jaw clamp is well placed and easy to operate. The display is pretty large for this class of meter and is easy enough to read. The probe inserts are on the bottom which means the meter (with the iFlex attached) can fit into narrow spaces and is a bit less bulky. This is a bit of a trade off though as probes with 90 banana plugs (90% of probes out there) feel a bit awkward on the bottom of this meter.Room for improvement -There really isn't much not to like here but I'll list a few negative impressions in the spirit of being objective. First is the inherent flaw nearly all amp clamps suffer. The case. Unlike a traditional multimeter these almost never have a protective rubber boot/holster. Which means when gravity pulls your meter back to Earth (and usually, to concrete) the chance of damage to the casing and the internals is much greater. The 381 has an Achilles heel here as well. That lovely remote display will almost certainly go flying after impact and in the case of a face first impact will hit first as it sticks out about " from the main body. There's always a downside to a cool feature, and this is the 381's. Next is the lack of a Low-Z (aka a low impedance) voltage measurement. Being an industrial meter I feel this would've been a great feature to include for eliminating ghost voltages. You can buy an adaptor (Fluke's SV225) but I feel this is something that should come with this class of instrument to begin with. Finally is the "hold" feature. Fluke has their patented "touch hold" which operates by waiting for the probes to touch a circuit and records that (much the same as inrush feature works on this meter.) However Fluke gave us instead a "display hold" which once pressed the reading on the screen is frozen. Honestly I've seldom found display hold to be of much use. But in fairness touch hold may have been too complex to implement given it would have to talk two ways in real time with the remote display.In the box you get:-Fluke 381 meter w/ remote display-Fluke iFlex external flex clamp-A pair of TL175 silicone leads-A pair of AC175 over the probe alligator clips-A Fluke soft case for the meter and accessoriesFinal thoughts... The 381 is Fluke's current top of the line industrial clamp meter and reflects that with its ballpark $400-425 price tag. For those seriously looking at this meter I doubt I've told you anything you didn't already know. But for those just beginning their search for a clamp meter, this is a good example of what a top of the line model looks like. Is it over kill for a home owner meter? Probably. But it does have a set of unique features that make it attractive to professionals and hobbyists alike. All I can say is my need for an accurate AC and DC clamp meter lead me to this unit. The other features, especially the remote display I have found handy but weren't integral to my application either. Truthfully like all professional meters, it really is for you to decide whether it's worth it to you or not. Personally I would buy again, as I really like the 381. However I wouldn't rule out purchasing the 376 either. The 376 spec wise is nearly identical to the 381 except it lacks the remote display. All other features including AC/DC functionality, inrush current measurements, and iFlex attachments are still intact. And this meter clocks in around $80-100 cheaper. All in all I'm quite satisfied with the 381 and it's filled the hole in my instrumentation that only a clamp meter can satisfy. As such I give a glowing endorsement to any perspective users who have need of this feature set, find the functionality appealing, and aren't turned off by its price.

Yeah WOW!  The downside to screen protectors is the loss in brightness and image clarity.  "Glass" is different in that it's well...glass.  Meaning that it's much clearer than typical protectors.So this is supposedly a high strength impact resistant glass.  And after two hard spills (with a rubberized case mounted) I have really warmed up to this.  The texture feels the same as having no protector on.  The clarity and vibrancy is outstanding!  Colors and brightness don't suffer in the slightest.  It cleans easy and cleans well.  And lastly, after 6 months, not a single scratch!  I can honestly say I've never been so happy about a simple piece of glass!

I really like this sound bar.  It fills the room with quality sound.  The mid-range and highs are clear and compare favorably to my center channel off of another rooms home theater.  I used the "Sub Out" port to pair this with a spare 10" subwoofer I had and I must say the two do beautifully together considering the price.  There are a total of five inputs to allow for direct connections to A/V components if you wish.  Honestly the only complaint I have is the fact that using a digital input (Optical TOSLINK) from the TV causes the sound bar to go silent and start flashing sometimes if the channel is changed or the sound goes silent for a couple of seconds.  This doesn't happen on analog inputs so I'm a little baffled.  And I don't mind using analog connections though I'm sure some users may care.  But all in all, for the price, I think this bar is an excellent value,  and great addition to any room that isn't suited or intended as a home theater.

I'll be honest and admit I didn't research this all that much.  I just made the assumption that the stem was a 1/4" hex insert bit.  WRONG!  This is more similar to the drive design of a drill bit.  Makes sense since it's intended to be chucked in a drill.  However what if your jacks are a little recessed or your just feeling your age and you want more reach?  Guess your just outta luck...As for me, I'll be shopping for a 1/4" insert to socket adaptor and a 3/4" socket instead.

Just what it advertises.  This is a 24" downrod color matched for the current line of Hunter ceiling fans that use downrods.  Mine shipped with a 4" rod and this was a perfect replacement.  However with this length you will need to fish the wiring as it doesn't want to feed through inside of the conduit willingly.  Bottom line, it works as advertised.Note:  That whole 5 minute fan thing is joke.  It took me 5 minutes just to assemble the downrod!  But once assembled they work.  And even with the extra length, they don't wobble.

This is NOT an OEM cord!!!It looks like a cheap knock off. The fit is tight and it works as a micro usb charging cord should or at least it did...  However before that I'll tell you the markings are slightly different from those found on the OEM cord. Also the micro port is about an 1/8" longer than it should be. Really it just make the whole thing feel kinda cheap.Now two weeks after I received this.  It no longer works.  Waited 3 weeks for this Chinese piece if dung only to have it crap out on me in a matter of days.  FAIL!  Buy a real brand!  I'm going to buy the Media bridge which I should've done in the first place.

They look like the typical push-on alligator clips commonly shipped with DMMs from the major manufacturers like Fluke, Extech, and Ideal.  However these are poorly designed imitations.  The push on receptacles are completely different from other designs.  The common decent quality push on connectors are round (quazi-cone shaped) holes that are large enough to receive the test lead pin easily and without missing.  They get tighter at the tips to hold the test lead.  These are designed with a small round hole that is tight...  So small and tight in fact that you have to visually inspect the probe and attempt to insert the probe though this tiny hole.  And assuming you actually make it and insert the probe in this very tight receptacle...you end up stretching it and shortening it's usable life.  Honestly, don't waste your money.  Spend a little more and buy a name brand.

This is  a good quality strap.  I've bought a few of them in the past.  I've used them for battery box straps.  I've used them A LOT when backpacking.  Their great for lashing gear to your pack or for tightly bundling rolled gear together.  It uses a standard two piece side squeeze plastic clasp.  Lock it then pull on the tensioning strap.  Now your set for life.  This really couldn't get any easier.  Not much more to say about a length of nylon.

This is a great invention for those of using long heavy cable runs that require heavy gauge less flexible cables to maintain electrical integrity or for people who are trying to fit HDMI equipment in closed in spaces.  Either way this should be the solution for you.  The thing about digital signals is there's no "color loss" or "grainy ness" it's a digital signal and as such brightness, color space, even the audio is quantified as a coded algorithm.  So either the signal is readable or not.  So there will be no interference caused by this gadget.  Buy it with confidence.  It is a captured articulation.  That means it doesn't rotate 360 degrees on either axis but it's close,  It should allow you to position the device properly while routing the cable where its most natural.  Thanks Monster!

If a "Goodnight's" sleep is what your after then take a hard look at this.  I can tell you this traditional Japanese futon was exactly what I was looking for.  At just about 4" thick but while still having a firm padding this provides an excellent comfortable night's sleep.  I'm using mine on a twin sized camper bunk.  However this should be comfortable enough to sleep the traditional way which is to place it on the floor.  I would say however, Shiki Futons are meant to be used in conjunction with Tatami mats so sleeping on carpet or some other kind of padding would be recommended.  This futon doesn't conform the way a memory foam mattress will, but the firmness doesn't inherently create uncomfortable pressure points either.  As a whole I'm very impressed and would buy again.

These are great.  They fit into standard 14" x 14" RV vents and serve the same purpose as a draft guard on your door.  They have a soft cotton cover that covers the foam core.  The top side also features a heat reflective panel for use in reflecting sunlight in summer.  They're sized perfectly and fit my Forrest river's four ports just fine.  Now there always has to be a caveat...  There are two with these.  First if you have a shallow port they may stick out from the ceiling a bit.  Second, I have Ventline vents with knobs...these don't obstruct the plug going in.  However, other vent manufacturers use cranks which protrude down more than the knobs.  For a best fit, these cranks should be removed.  Other than that, these plugs do a great job of keeping the cold out.

This is a great tabletop/countertop mounting bracket for small and medium (up to 32") LCD TVs.  This bracket is a solid platform that gives plenty of confidence for putting a flat panel TV in your RV or travel trailer.  The mounting holes allow for several VESA patterns from 75mm x 75mm up to 200mm x 200mm and just about everything in between.  The vertical arm is a two piece unit that can be raised and lowered to accommodate fitting larger and smaller sets while fitting under overhead obstructions.  The maximum this bracket will likely fit is a 32" flat screen since the height of the TV will become a clearance issue from the TV centerline to the top of the triangular foot of the TV1-003H's base.  Simply put, the bottom of the TV will brush the base if it's too big for the bracket.The plate may be too big for smaller sets as depending on where they place the connections, ports for coax and HDMI may be obstructed by the mounting plate.  Unfortunately there is really nothing that can be done about this.  So measure your set from the center line of the VESA holes (dead center of the rear of the set) and make sure you have at least 8-1/2" x 8-1/2" of open area that cords don't access.The only other thing that users may not like is the small foot print of the bracket.  This has two downsides.  First is that if you intend to leave this installed while moving the coach the road vibration could cause stress on the countertop and pull loose over time.  OR cause flexing in the TV and transfer vibration into the TV causing damage.  The solution to this is to do as I have done and trill though the countertop and feed machine screws with washers attached on the bottom and use wing nuts on top to make this removable.  When it comes time to strike camp, remove the wing nuts and remove the TV and bracket as one piece, placing it somewhere safe for travel.  This brings me to the second downside.  There are four holes, the two in the front are easy enough to access, but the two in back may be a little more challenging.  That said, I'm only using two and it feels solid.Bottom line, what makes this a worth while investment over the stock base plate of an LCD if you just intend to move the TV when traveling?  First (at least for my setup using a 32" Vizio) the bracket sits about an inch lower than the stock plate which makes it fit in the trailer's "Desk" cubby and fills the hole nicely.  Second it IS bolted to the desktop which is nice when the trailer rocks as people are moving OR considering that an un-level trailer may add to the risk of the TV toppling.  This is a great solution by the MOR/ryde corp that lets us RV'ers further spoil ourselves by taking the latest and greatest in entertainment with us on our vacations.

The twist locking connector has become the industry standard over the last few years.  And for good reason.  The old style (through hole-pull out cord) had some real disadvantages.  Namely that there was big friggin' hole in the side of your camper.  Water, insects, small animals all had a way in.  Not a problem twist lockers.  But the problem that has been introduced is the idea that you have a fairly heavy cord pulling on it's own wiring and torqueing the coupler on the side of your camper...Enter the ParkPower Right Angle...  This is one of those "DUH" innovations that just makes you wonder why no one thought of it sooner.  With the cord's weight pulling straight down as opposed to jutting out and torqueing the plug the life of the cord should be much longer.  The cord itself is a genuine Marinco branded product with a 30A Hubble locking connector and threaded lock ring.  It's a weather proof 10ga cord and is designed as a drop in replacement for travel trailers and 5th wheel campers with 30A locking inlets.I do have one complaint.  My connection is a bit loose.  It's doesn't wiggle but at the same time it's not as firm to turn as the original was and as my 30A-15A pigtail is.  If the cord were bumped and turned AND the lock ring were improperly connected to the TT it could become disconnected.  However as long as the lock ring is installed this shouldn't happen.  And it's not going to come undone when it's in the vertical position, only when it's rotated about 30 degrees.  It does ship with a second lock ring for mating with the new style of Marinco inlets.  The locking ring has a notch which fits into a track and turns about an 1/8 of a turn making this a true twist on twist off setup.  I haven't changed the locking rings on mine yet though I do intend to.  I will update then.

Werner is one of the few names I'll trust my life to enough to step 20' off the ground on their products.  This is their rendition of the popular gorilla ladders.  I've had mine for about a year now and overall I'm very pleased with my purchase.  They say you can't buy one tool for every job...  This ladder proves and disproves that concept.One ladder to do it all.  Buy one ladder and you've got a Super Duty double step ladder safe enough for two grown men to stand on.  You've got a 26' extension ladder.  And lastly you have the flexibility of a stair ladder.  For the price there's no excuse for every American home owner not to have one in their garage.  But as I eluded to above, there are down sides.  Three that I've found anyway.  First) The weight...  When you standing on it, it's a brick house...solid as a rock...  When you're carrying it around, it's brick house...heavy as a boulder...  At nearly 70lbs this is not a typical aluminum step ladder.  Unfold it and use it as an extension that weight is compounded by the additional length.  It is a real chore to extend it and retract it.  Easiest way is to unfold it, extend what will be the top side, stand it vertical where you plan to work, and extend the bottom.  This is still not an easy feat and you need to be extra careful of your fingers.  With this much weight, it you let go it could chop them clean off.  Safest way is to fully extend it on the ground and walk the ladder up but this will require two people.  Second Issue) The J-hooks.  I had to send my first one back because one was damaged in shipping.  These are the Achilles heal of the MT series.  Be cautious not to hit them against anything as I fear the plastic housing that encases them will break.  Finally) returning to extension mode, since this is not a rigid beam construction setup found on modern extension ladders, there is a noticeable flex in the middle.  It's unnerving at first but I found after a time I got used to it.  Still the first time you pass that middle locking pivot, you say a little prayer that the guy on the line that day at Werner had his coffee that morning.Aside from the downsides listed above, there is nothing else not to like about this ladder.  The 26' version yields an excellent working height range as an A-frame.  And as an extension (while not the first ladder I would grab if given the choice) it has enough reach to get a grown man to the gutter level of just about any two story built on level ground.  As I said about, this is a must for all homeowners.  One final word of caution, this is an aluminum ladder and as such it will conduct electricity very well!  Don't perform electrical work from this ladder and stay clear of the power lines!

The new Marinco EEL series is amazing.  I love the new locking design!  This is even quicker and easier than their twist lock plug and lock ring.  The EEL uses the same Hubble 30A twist lock receptacle but with a "squeeze and turn" lock ring that thus far seems to be quite weather proof.  Then there is a "safety lock" that keeps the squeeze locking wings from being opened.  The power "on" indicator light is a nice feature to let you know the pigtail is receiving power.  The "flash light" in the center of the Hubble receptacle is a big gimmicky but doesn't bother me otherwise.This particular device is a 12" pigtail.  It's designed to be used in conjunction with a heavy duty outdoor extension cord to feed a 30A powered RV or boat with AC power from a household outlet.  This will let you run the camper's onboard battery charger, refrigerator, and other low wattage items while stored or in preparation for a trip.  The male plug is a 15A standard plug which is VERY TIGHT and is meant to be.  They don't want this falling out while plugged in.  Plugging this into an extension cord requires backing off the tensioning screw on the top of the male plug.  Firmly insert the plug into the female end of the extension cord.  Tighten the tensioning screw (but not the point where it begins to push the cord apart or starts to thread into extension cord.So why buy this?  It isn't that much cheaper than the real 30A locking cords...  Three reasons...  1) Unfortunately society has degraded to the extent that we have to worry about scrappers taking our cords to sell to recycling centers for pennies on the dollar.  Even if you loose this and your cord.  You still have you main cord for trips so your next vacation isn't ruined.  2) The ends of a 30A cord with a 30-15A adaptor tend to be large and bulky and often are too big to fit into outdoor weather proof outlet housings.  Lastly) given that this is a pigtail, you can tailor the length of 15A extension cord to your needs.  15' or 100' are equally doable.  Just make sure to use a heavy gauge cord (especially for long runs.)

I've used mine for about 5 years now and have no complaints.  I like them so much I took them with me when I bought my new travel trailer.  The lens contains a weather proof sealed circuit board which is custom fit to the series 59 lenses that ship with the LED upgrades.  Installation is a snap.  Remove the old cover, remove the old bulb.  Place the CB in the new cover, plug in the pigtail wire, push the cover onto the fixture.  DONE!  A small bead of silicone sealant (very small amount) is optional but I just take mine off every other season and clean them.Visibility is excellent at night and good during the day.  Each light fixture has two medium output LEDs that are visible and that's plenty to be seen.  Power consumption as you might imagine is nearly nothing.  This is great for mid sized tow vehicles without dedicated light circuits for trailer lighting.This is JUST the light cover and LED board.  The base must be already installed and prewired on the trailer.  These fit only Bargman series 59 bases.

I've used mine for about 5 years now and have no complaints.  I like them so much I took them with me when I bought my new travel trailer.  The lens contains a weather proof sealed circuit board which is custom fit to the series 59 lenses that ship with the LED upgrades.  Installation is a snap.  Remove the old cover, remove the old bulb.  Place the CB in the new cover, plug in the pigtail wire, push the cover onto the fixture.  DONE!  A small bead of silicone sealant (very small amount) is optional but I just take mine off every other season and clean them.Visibility is excellent at night and good during the day.  Each light fixture has two medium output LEDs that are visible and that's plenty to be seen.  Power consumption as you might imagine is nearly nothing.  This is great for mid sized tow vehicles without dedicated light circuits for trailer lighting.This is ONLY the lens cover and LED board.  The base must be preinstalled and prewired on the trailer.  This fits ONLY Bargman Series 59 bases.

Bright and cheerful Nanoha Takamachi is about to discover there's a much bigger universe out there.  Filled with magic and wonder, danger and evil, and people that need her help.  As an ordinary 3rd grader she doesn't yet know, but she has the making and potential of a top flight mage and will in short order be faced with saving the Earth and then ( even at this young age) teaching future mages combat and tactics.For now lets let her enjoy her breakfast.  She stands just about 6 inches tall.  She is painted on all surfaces.  The attention to detail is excellent and details like eyes are really well painted.  This figurine is made of durable ABS plastic but note this is not a toy.  It's made to be placed on a shelf and be left along.  If constantly handled, she will break, if left alone, she will proudly stand among your collection for many years.

This is a triple shield RG6 cable.  It's shielding and frequency range make it suitable for modern digital and high definition cable and satellite installations.  I bought this 100' cable to bury (in conduit) and run to a detached garage workshop.  For that purpose, it's worked great over the last year.  All stations tune and a crisp and clear.  There's no noise and the colors (on the analog portion) are great.  (Everything digital has to be tuned through a box when using cable or satellite.)  The connectors at either end are first rate and I have no complaints.  All in all...  Great cable!

Let's face it $10 is cheap for a bike light.  And I wasn't expecting miracles...  But this thing actually turned out to be a honest contender.  Construction feels "okay"  so far everything is tight, but we'll see how that holds up over time.  The beam can be adjusted from an all but useless square dot to a pretty bright white flood.  There are 3 mode settings which was a surprise to me, (bright, dim, and strobe.)  Dim gives enough light to navigate a path after dark at about 10mph, bright acts light a "high beam" if you twist the holder up just a bit, and gives me confidence to about 15mph.  That said this is still kicking out light more as a spot light than a "wash".  With it tipped just below parallel to the ground it gives the rider about 8 feet of light with at 10 feet out.  And illuminates the path with decreasing intensity for about 50 feet.  The strobe is good enough I'd trust it in traffic.  So far the only thing I wasn't impressed with was the mount.  The thumb screw wasn't long enough to reach and tighten around my bars.  Instead I used a machine screw to get it.  But this leaves you without a way to tighten it on the road unless you carry a tool kit.  Still unless your expecting a portable sun, this light should suit most riders without breaking the bank.

This is by far the best bike pump I've ever owned.  The ability to pump both traditional Schrader valves and Presta valves from one unit is worth its weight in gold.  The hose has a nice long reach.  The construction feels excellent.  Honestly, I have only one complaint.  I don't think the PSI gauge is accurate.  And whether it is or isn't, it doesn't automatically show a reading once connected to a tire.  I've pumped up my road tires for the last month and no two times have they ever felt the same on the road.  Pumped to 80psi up front and 85psi in back...  I've felt everything from rock hard riding to so squishy, it feels and looks half way flat.  That said, get an external gauge...  For all intent and purposes, this pump is an inexpensive way to air up before each ride.

This is a simple voltage averaging meter.  Perfect for sticking in a small kit or in a vehicle.  I carry mine in a messenger bag and use for AV diagnotics in PA equipment.  This simple meter in class III 300V & Class II 600V rated for AC and DC installations.  It's not suitable for large DB boards and heavy switch gear but for end user equipment or automotive daignostics this is a great tool to have on hand.  It's capable of AC and DC voltage measurement to 600V.  It has a bar graph on the bottom of the screen which is a rarity on cheaper meters and a terrific diagnostic tool.  In addition this meter has a continuity tester, a resistance measurement feild, and a 3V diode check.  It's a 4000 count auto ranging meter with selectable manual range override.Included in the kit is a detailed user manual and a nice folding "wallet case".  The one complaint I have is the perminantly affixed test leads.  These are small and flexible and well suited for general use applications.  But they also the Achilles heal of the meter as when (not if) they become damaged, they cannot be replaced.  That said, if you catch this on sale, it's cheap enough to replace assuming you get a few good years of service out of it.  Amprobe is a division of Fluke.  I've found most of their products to be quality built and this model is no exception.  Granted it has some limitations, but I'm reminded of the saying, the perfect tool is the one you have on hand when you need it.Update: 7-11-2015Note: The DM78C is the credit card size meter.  The DM73C is the pen model.  I have the 78C so my review pertains to that model.  After two years it's still going.  Though admittedly it sees light usage.  However I have noticed two issues.  The auto ranging tends to dance around with no source connected to the leads.  This doesn't seem to effect the measurement accuracy greatly but it is noticeable.  The other concern is the probes are aging ahead of the meter as I feared they would.  They never were as ridgid as a traditional DMM probe but now they'rd showing noticeable flex when pressure is applied accross the probe broadside near the finger stop.  With this I no longer believe my meter to be safe for potentially hazardous voltages (inclunding 120V testing.). Other than that it still functions which still makes it a practical meter for on the go electrical/electronic diagonotics or as a meter in an automotive tool kit.  I've docked it one star for the poor lead quality since they are board soldered and would require a fair bit of work to replace.  However don't let that dissuade you from purchasing if this is truely to be portable "tool kit" type meter for you.  Once I disassembled the meter I was all at once very impressed. I was struck at just how well put together the case was.  There are nearly full thickness blast shields on all sides of the case and even on the battery compartment door.  The planning and engineering that went in to these shields shows how well designed it really is in terms of safety.  I see now why it was able to be rated a CAT III device.  Should Amprobe ever update this meter I would like to see female banana jacks added on the bottom or sides.  Even if that adds a couple of mm of thickness to the casing.  Or a pair of silicone pigtails with female jacks so that traditional DMM leads could be used.

I recently converted my Fuji Nevada 1.0 mountain bike to a road bike.  After 13 miles, my hind end was feeling every inch.  This seat was just the answer.  I'm 230lbs and hoping biking brings that down a bit.  This seat is a winner in most every respect.  It's size is about 3-4" wider than "traditional stock saddles" which is a BIG differnce when your riding long distances.  There is also a stiff pair of rubber bound springs on the rear underside of the seat to obsorb some of the road vibration and bumps that the high pressure road tires do nothing insulate you from.  Then there is the gel padding in the seat itself.  Together these culminate in a much more enjoyble long distance riding experience.  Mounting can be done two ways.  It can mount to a standard "el cheapo" seat post.  If your old seat has the parallel bar style mount, the adaptor can be removed and the seat mounted directly to the clamp.  Once mounted, you may need to drop the seat hight slightly as this seat is almost certainly thicker than your stock saddle.

I had a triangle bag that had an angle too acute for my frame and too that I never consdiered that it would have to come off and on when I mounted it to my Thule hitch rack.  Then I discovered the Roswheel...  It's teathers in 3 places (2 on the top tube, 1 around the steaing column.)  This keeps it reasonably secure, though they could've given us a little less strap or a little more to strap to.  My Fuji Nevada has big main tubes and there's plenty of strap left.  Just a little tighter would be perfect.The window is a nice touch.  Though I am unable to use my screen through it, likely that is due to the type of screen protector I have.  There is plenty of space inside.  I can keep a wallet, small key ring, and a mini mag in addition to my phone.  I have a 4.3" Samsung Galaxy Nexus which squeezes in there with the standard Verizion kick-stand case.  Too much weight and this thing will drift to one side or another.  But for the cost, it's the best bag on the market.

I've got 26 miles on it and so far, I'm pleased.  I'm running this 700x32mm variant at the 80 psi max.  It runs well on paved paths.  At this point the tread that trims the center line is showing a little wear but that's to be expected.  As I'm running this as a front tire for my bike, I've got to say I love the way it handles corners.  It gives excellent confidence and sticks really well.  The center slick I'm sure is giving me the best I can hope for using a mountain bike as crusier in terms of speed.  Honeslty, there's nothing about it I feel that needs to be said against this tire.  Some will complain that its a wire bead, but that's not a concern for me.  All in all if you're looking for a capable preformer on paved roads this is worth serious consideration.UPDATE 9-26-2013:  An injury and a bit of laziness kept me off the roads as much as I would've preferred.  However with about 130 miles on them I've got to say, so far so good.  The tread is definitely showing defined wear.  But it's even and not effecting the handling at all.  This tire still corners very well and handles medium to high riding speeds with comfort and ease.  I really don't have any thing bad to report.  I'll continue to update as they age.

So many of us have too much free time these days.  We spend it re-designing the wheel.  Well if you're an electronics hobbiest, you'll need some main leads to piggy-back components together.  These double alligator leads do the trick.  This is a set of 10 - 14" double ended leads rated to 600V on 20AWG wire.  They have small jaw alligator clips pefect for fitting in tight spaces and even hitting individual components on bread board.  Not much more I can say about them other than they work and I like them.

So I have a 33' Keystone that tips the scales at 6800lbs empty.  Tongue weight was 780 dry.  So the 2000lb tongue jack sounds like it's more than enough.  However anyone who's ever used a weight distributing hitch eventaully puts 2 and 2 together and figures out that lifting up the back end of a full size pickup is A LOT of weight.  And then you remember that you never camp without gear and the pickup bed almost always has wood so that 2k lb rating all of a sudden seems just plain wimpy.  My tongue at last check was a hair heavy of 950 and the gear in the bed more than covers the slack.  After 4 seasons of abuse, the 2k lb'er finally cranked its last inch.  I knew that I wasn't going to be any nicer to my next one so I decided to search for something with some genuine capacity.  If your in the same boat as me then you've found your jack...Lift is the same as my stock model (if not, perhaps an inch shorter.)  The triple bolt pattern used has been around for at least 40 years so this should be a universal replacement for any 2-1/4" tongue jack.  The crank speed is a little slower but A LOT smoother and easier compaired to my original.  What this means in real world terms is that it actaully takes less time to lift the tongue since your not wearing yourself out.  The jack retracts nice and high for travel, clearance even with a jack foot shouldn'd be a problem.  It doesn't come with a foot, but they're availible for around $10 here on amazon.  All-in-all, price vs. performance, this one is a home run!

This is a really nice battery box for outdoor (tongue mounting) on travel trailers and RVs.  Its a perfect fit for common 24 series batteries (usually around 75ah).  I like it better than the one that shipped with my trailer since the vents on the cap are rain resistant.  My other had open air (mesh vents) that allowed water to pour into the box.  I ended up drilling drain holes in the four corners.  Honestly though, that should be standard practice for any box.  The lid has the typical bulges on one side to allow battery cables to come through without obstructing the lid.  It's held in place with an included nylon strap.  Not much more that I can say about a simple plastic box.Note: I bought on of these units for a hobby project I was working on.  It fits standard configuration (standard length) 7ah-22ah SLA batteries in the width of the box.

Even though the title said Amico, I recieved a SIBA brand.  I've not researched if they own SIBA or that was just what the seller sent.  In any case SIBA was what my Ideal 61-481 DMM had before, so I'm pleased to put one back in.  This is a 6.3mm x 32mm which is a style used by many mid-range multimeters.  It's a genuine HRC (High Rupture Capacity) ceramic fuse that unlike its cheaper glass brethren is less likely to shrapnel if it's hit with an extreme high energy jolt.  Now this is not exactly what came out of my meter, my Ideal shipped with a 1A fast blow for the mA range.  However I could only find this 500mA.  If you decide to go this route, understand that it is also a fast blow so even a short spike over 500mA will toast it.  Most of my mA readings are under a 100mA so that's fine with me.  Another thing to pay attention to is voltage ratings.  Barrel fuses can be rated from 60V on up.  Double check and make sure your buying one rated for 1000V.  Bottom line is, this fuse will serve my purposes without comprimising safety.Update: I beleive this is also the fuse that the Fluke 17B uses for its mA/uA over current protection.  In any case I've been using my Ideal's mA range with its fresh new fuse.  And at times I pushed the envelope.  The current spike over 500mA for a few fractions of a second at a couple of differnt points through the test and survived.  I must say that "forgiveness" is most welcome and I continue to sing praises about this replacement.

These are great little leads.  They are not some ebay crap made in someone garage.  They have full length, molded and sheilded banana plugs with solid (YES!  SOLID!) pins.  The other end is what I would consider a medium sized aligator clip.  It's roughly the same size as the slip-over-the-probe style aligator clips for DMMs.  The clips themselves ar simply the crimp on style found at most hardware stores but they feel solid.  The jacks are stamped with CE ratings and 10A current handing capability as well as CATIII 1000V.  The wire isulation itself is marked 2000V 18AWG standed.  I would've prefered 16ga but for this length 18 should be able to withstand what I'll run.  The wires themselves are pretty flexible.
