A little time consuming but not difficult. However, if you are not really computer savvy, you may have to get assistance.Summary - big, fast, large capacity and makes sharp, clear, color copy. Not really designed for photos (although it can do that) but very good for just about everything else. A little fussy to install on the network as described above.Recommended for volume printing users - if we had the ability to issue 1/2 stars - it would be a 4 1/2 star review.

The whole GoPro video thing is hot right now. Years ago, if track junkies like me wanted to video ourselves on the racetrack you had to pay a lot of money for pro gear or cobble together a college textbook-sized video tape camera onto a bracket inside your car. Yes, people did it but the first problem was vibration. The bumping on the track made watching these early videos a challenge. That all changed with digital video and miniaturization of the equipment. Several cameras with image stabilization hit the market and vastly improved action video but GoPro, with its sealed camera case, very good image quality and relatively low cost has captured the sports, personal action video market. It's become the gold standard.Enter cell phone cameras and smart phones. With their WiFi and network connectivity to social media, the handheld "selfie" was born. However, high-angle selfies were restricted to the length of the shooter's arm. Plus, if you wanted really quality video (for TV, public web sites, wedding video assignments, school projects, etc.,) you really had to use a better camera than your cell phone (although, that will certainly change as time goes on). So, bring on the GoPro! And, that's where the extension pole accessory came into being.With that as prologue, the GoPro camera system has a unique attachment method - not the usual tripod screw - so this pole has the right setup to allow the shooter to attach his or her camera and make videos or single shot images at nearly four feet over their head. Pretty cool. The swivel connection also gives the shooter the ability to change the shooting angle and there is a viewer clip-on attachment so you can watch what you re doing too.The pole extends easily with a twist on each section and the very comfortable rubber handle lets the shooter keep a firm grip on the very valuable GoPro camera. Plus, in extremes of heat and cold (it's cold now where I live so I can confirm the benefit) the handle is comfortable. Add in the adjustable wrist strap and you're good to go.The bottom line - if you have a GoPro, and shoot selfies or are looking to make high-angle shots, you will enjoy using this GoPro-only accessory. The only reason for 4 and not 5 stars - it's pricy. That's it.Recommended - if you have a GoPro.

I have been a Canon shooter since the EOS film days. They were and still are fast auto focusing systems for sports. I have also grown up in the digital world using Canon gear. I began with a 40D, progressed up through two 50Ds and, most recently, a 7D. They all performed well for magazine work and fine art printing. I was pretty satisfied with my kit but then I read the specs on the new mark II and that all changed.  A Modestly higher pixel count on the sensor wasn't the draw. The faster frame rate, in camera HDR, faster auto focus and better high ISO performance did it for me.I tested the camera at the big NYC camera show last fall and decided that this was the real deal. I purchased mine with the grip and it feels as professional as any camera I gave used in 40 years of shooting.Auto focus performance is fast and very accurate. Better, even than the 7D I traded in. That really surprised me since my "keeper" rate with the 7D body was over 90%. Also, everyone I know with a 7D shot -2/3 stop in bright sun because the camera blew out highlights. My camera was serviced annually by Canon under the CPS program so I know it was performing as designed. This camera doesn't seem to have that issue, delivering spot on exposures in bright light.I don't know why they went with compact flash and SD cards for storage but I like having 2 cards and can live with the SD decision.The thing I really like is the way the camera feels. The rubber skin is grippy and gives me confidence during fast shooting situations. It's a tiny bit lighter than the old model but it feels more rugged. Time will tell.And then, there is the burst mode! 10 frames per second brings new meaning to spray and pray!  And, the predictive AF can keep up. A definite plus for sports shooters.I'm not much of a video guy but the really cool camcorder like auto focusing works very well. A reason enough for a video klutz like me to love the camera.Finally, in camera HDR - simple and effective - will make me money! I have to shoot in terrible Iighting conditions (garages, car museums, etc.) and this feature will save time and help make more sales!Canon quality, great image performance and a near bargain price. Recommended!

The gold standard for action cameras these days in the GoPro line. While I was waiting for this camera to be delivered, I went to the huge camera show in NYC and sought out the Sony exhibit to get the low down on the AZ1VR/W. The vendor had a large screen TV with three windows. The first was a video shot with GoPro. The second was the identical video shot with the previous Sony camera and the third was a video shot with this, their latest camera. The differences were remarkable. The image stabilization, was much better on the new Sony than the other two. Also, the dynamic range on the new Sony camera and the overall sharpness / Image Quality (IQ) was clearly superior. Needless to say, I was excited to get my hands on the camera. The only thing to note is that the camera has a very wide angle lens. Anything close to the lens will get that fisheye distortion that on first look is cool but over time, can get boring. Again, you have to be close to the lens to see that level of distortion. You have been warned!First, the camera is small - really small. That makes placement in a car or on a bike or skateboard, etc., easy. Next, the splash-proof case is a great idea but when you add in the included waterproof case that allows real in the pool / lake / ocean use even better.The coolest feature is the wrist-watch-like video screen that gives you complete control over start, start and configuration. It can be worn in the wrist or on a tripod handle. However you do it, seeing what you're shooting helps ensure that your placement is going to deliver the scenes you want.Battery life is good but I recommend you buy spare batteries if you plan to use this camera for extended shooting. Also, you'll want a couple of spare micro-SD cards to ensure that you have enough storage to capture what you want to shoot.So, what's not to like? Essentially, the only problem I had was getting the camera to sync with the wrist monitor. And, I'm not the only person to note that. One of the other reviewers has written instructions on how to sync the two and I recommend you find it if you buy this product. It will save you a lot of frustration.Two stars for image quality. Two stars for ease of use (size, attachment methods, waterproof design) and one star for the external monitor / camera controller.Recommended if you need an action camera.

The Heinz company approaches ketchup production with a seriousness that I didn't expect. They don't buy tomatoes. The grow the tomatoes that go into this product, ensuring consistent quality and, more important, taste. If you have ever had another brand in a fast food place, you would immediately know that - this is NOT Heinz! It it the best? For me it is, but, of course, your taste may differ.The squeeze bottle is unique too. It sits upside down in our 'fridge so it flows easily. Another plus to our storage style is that the oil sits on top so you always get just ketchup and not oil and red stuff.Recommended

I was given a free copy of this book in return for an honest review.Glassford Girl: Part 3 takes us back to the adventures of time-jumper Emily Heart, a young girl that has been through a tumultuous existence, mainly due to her somewhat uncontrollable abilities to travel through time - a process that leaves her both physically and mentally exhausted. Shes been doing it since 1985 - 2 years or 30 years, depending how you look at it.What impressed me the most in this book is Falconers ability to tap into my imagination with words that seem to accurately describe a situation. For example, in the beginning of this Part 3 book, we see Emily coming back from a jump and ending up underwater - a scenario which the author describes step-by-step, including her respiratory system coming alive, lungs expanding, mouth engulfing water instead of air Even in challenging situations like when Emily was about to go head to head with Big Mike, Falconer managed to not only describe what was happening on the outside but also what Emily was feeling on the inside. And as a young woman, Emily was subject to a wide range of emotions that was perfectly captured, even her internal turmoils regarding following her own rules, especially Rule #7.Of course we see the return of our favorites, Derek Morgan, Jim Miller and even Junie, all of them with a part to play in Emilys life, mostly in a positive way. There was also Detective Alison, who was getting dangerously close to the truth. And we cant forget about the Orange ManOverall an amazing installment, leaving us with a spectacular twist at the end and FULL or burning questions just waiting to be answered in Part 4!

I was given a free copy of this book in return for an honest review.Not one to usually judge a book by its cover but Part 2 of the Time Jumper series (at the time of my reading) shows a VERY similar cover to Part 1, except for minor changes in the background and Emily Heart facing the other way. Might be confusing to some readers.On to the book itself; I am glad that the lack of variety of the cover art did NOT take away from the uniqueness of the second story, which was an excellent sequel to the first. Chapter 1 dives right into the action with our heroine Emily and the gallant Derek both handcuffed and taken in police custody. We see straight away that the attraction between these two were present and more prevalent than ever. We also see the ever-so-present pain and struggle that Emily faces, knowing that she can never settle down and lead a normal life with someone she loves, not even with some of her best friends. The biggest price of being a time jumper: 2 years to her is equal to decades to a normal person.This sequel is up to par - if not even better - with its action sequences with the first. The story progresses but also takes in a new direction with the appearance of a new character chasing after Emily, giving a different kind of sci-fi twist to the plot. The jumps still take a toll on Emilys mind and body, causing her physical pain in addition to the mental and emotional aspects.Jim continues to be an asset, Derek appears in a bigger role and Junie gets reunited with Emily - the positive aspects of the story definitely outweighs the negative, more depressing parts. Definitely worth a read!

I was given a free copy of this book in return for an honest review.Rogue, Book 2 of The Omega Group Series, deals with the concept of an Avengers-type of policing body.The story really began over a millennium and a half before the present day setting, with Ahiga and the rest of the Havasupai tribe and their conflict with the rival Yavapai tribe. From this setting I enjoyed the representation of the tribes and how they were described: brave, proud and willing to go to great lengths to protect their own. As a fan of ancient cultures in general, this was a big plus for me - and by the authors rendition of events relating to these tribes, I can see that the topic was well-researched and studied.Carter Mockta, present day blood member (but estranged) of the Havasupai tribe, and his purpose with the Omega Group along with Han and Jackie were soon introduced in the following chapters. Enroute to the Grand Canyon to investigate strange anomalies, we get a glimpse of a super soldier testing program that was being conducted there. However, before they could even get to their destination, we already see some major action in the book. I found this to be consistent throughout the chapters, never lacking in action or excitement. Definitely a great way to keep the story at a good pace.Carter is made out to be a spectacular character, relatable yet a true superhero. His uncomfortable reconciliation with his family and his past brought about a wide range of emotions, mainly due to his past relationship with Gina. Mirissa, whom we met in the first book Crossfire makes appearances in this book as well.Steeped in ancient culture, full of superhero-type of characters, intense conflict and characters to love and hate - Rogue was one breathtaking book to read!

I was given a free copy of this book in return for an honest review.Dacolias Dreamer of Dreams contains 4 short stories, each with a unique adventure. Unification is the first story and the longest one. It begins with a nice narration as to how Rymalone Weston Augustine found himself in a seemingly endless vortex. A good, old-fashioned good vs evil story. Traveling at the Speed of Love details the story of Joe Robeson and Ed Bloom, two astronauts on a mission to Mars, and their wives Felicia and Melanie watching them from the Control Center. Beautiful love story. The Expanding Earth centers on The Cromwell family and the curious case of why the trips they take seems to be taking longer and longer. Interestingly, the outcome was unique and deals with humans ability to be self-sufficient. The last story in this collection is called The Vision and relays the story of Bennys encounter with a mysterious angel and ends in what could very well be the future state of our planet.Dacolias definitely have a way with words, immensely appealing to the imagination and effectively tugging at the reader with his characters dilemmas, situations and complex emotions. It is a given that when you read one of his books - may it be novels or story collections - you expect to be taken along for an emotional rollercoaster ride. I always admire his vocabulary and the combination of words and phrases he uses to convey the lessons in his tales or even just to describe the back story or situation. The characters, although fictional, seem to accurately capture the essence of being human, hence readers can easily relate to at least one of the protagonists in this book. My personal favorite in this collection is the story Traveling at the Speed of Love as I am curious about the Mars One project and so I found it appealing :)

I was given a free copy of this book in return for an honest review.In The Fountain of Youth, Gilbert and Mannys adventure with Margaret was very cute and inspiring. It was heartwarming to read about the old folks at the retirement home who took a hold of their lives, in their own terms. Just because youre in there doesnt mean your life is over! In Reunion, Corinne was feeling the pressures of acting life and returned to her old neighborhood, seeking advice from her mentors. Marie and Tyler had a few things to say to help Corinne deal with her issues; advice that were well thought of and sounded realistic. I enjoyed their interaction, it showed that you can be family even if you are not blood related. Oblivion was of a unique experiment-type plot. It relates the story of the young and ambitious Stuart, who devised an experiment to live in isolation by the Salton Sea for a year. Interesting outcome. Footprints in the Grass relates the story of an unlikely friendship, between Lester Federman (aka Mr. Fanatic, obsessed with his prized lawn) and Hilary, a little girl, so innocent and full of life. They each taught the other valuable lessons in life; a very heartwarming story. And finally, The Island of Him shows an intense story of how a life can seemingly be pointless when suffering from a disease.Dacolias has a very consistent way with words, almost like a magical touch, telling the stories as if a narrator was reading them. This narrative style, along with his way with descriptions greatly contribute towards making the plots interesting. I believe these tales contained in Sculptor of Stories are some of his best work yet. The introduction to the stories were pretty substantial, giving the reader a complete look at the background before the action began. The endings felt complete and provides sufficient closure to the stories.

I was given a free copy of this book in return for an honest review.For someone who was supposed to be the center of the attention, the star of the media, the biggest celebrity of her day, Jono was not a happy person. Her boyfriend Troy, a wannabe in the Hollywood insider circle is a controlling, demanding person who bathed himself in the limelight under which Jono is constantly a part of. A leech. Maxwell, her manager, on the other hand is someone who genuinely cares for Jono and her well-being. Understandably, he hates Troys guts but he is supportive of Jono and her decisions. He takes care of her and stood by her side through the good times and the bad. He is smart and knows the industry very well - a great companion to Jono.During a traumatic event that could very well have ended Jonos life, she unknowingly crossed paths with a beautiful hero name MikeI think Mikes personal story was touching, a sad past that understandably impacted his current views and way of life. I liked how his relationship with Jono progressed, degressed and then redeveloped. I especially liked the descriptions of the settings; for example, the house in Hawaii where the party in the beginning was thrown appeared vividly before my eyes, simply from Jones description of it. The characters were written well; realistic, relatable, some of whom I HATED and others who I couldnt help but love.I have read Jones other novels (Long Trip Home and Rose) and even though the stories were all different and dealt with diverse situations, the ability to tell the story with flow and ease were present in all 3 books.

I was given a free copy of this book in return for an honest review.Weve all been there at some point, where were not really completely unfortunate but cant help but feel that something was missing And then we get thrown to experience the greatest adventure of our lives!Long Trip Home is a unique story, different from any that I have read before. We get a glimpse in the beginning of Troys life - one that was pretty much ordinary: a loving husband to a wife (April) and dedicated father to two children (Maggie and Justin), son-in-law to his boss Frank. However, all of these were catapulted out of proportion one day, in the middle of a country steeped in conflict, while stranded, waiting for their flight - when Isabelle walked into his life. On a side note - as a frequent flyer, I feel Troys pain when it takes you 36+ hours on the way home from distant lands. Anyway back to Izy - someone who is in a completely different path yet captivating and stubborn, knows-what-she-wants type of woman! A forbidden friendship - one that had to be kept a secret, essentially leading Troy to live a somewhat double lifeI love Dutch Jones style of writing; it kept me engaged as I read the novel in between chores and pretty much whatever free time I could get. The characters were appealing and likeable, no matter how different they are from each other. The pace moved fast enough for me, where you are thrown right into the middle of conflict and action.Enjoyed it very much!

Review I was given a free copy of this book in return for an honest review.The story started off in beautiful Greece, with Polybios Nicomidis nervously reporting to his first day on the job, at a place that was both menacing and exciting at the same time. We get a glimpse of the people working in the Ebola Division as well the ones working with Poly in the Rabies Division - the Communicable Diseases Investigators. Interesting characters; weird but interesting.We see glimpses foreshadowed by Neighbours Reports, adding to the suspense of the story. Who is this girl? What experiments??Then we read about Emma.Shes a girl with a passion for - biology. Making her parents proud at first. Observing things under a microscope, even her own blood, leading to a an obsession - and a tragic situation.Their paths crossed when Poly and co-worker Zoe were sent to Emmas town Kilkis, off Thessaloniki, to investigate a rabies incident...I can say that I enjoyed the story very well. It is of a unique structure, the pace was just right and the suspense was spectacular. It was easy to imagine this story as a movie, with the authors style changing, alternating the chapters with narration, interviews from various neighbors, teachers and family members, even video transcript style. The plot was superb; even though there are hundreds of this type of stories in movies and books, this one had a particularly unique characteristic. The characters were realistic actually, easy to remember, possessing quirks that you see in everyday people in everyday life.A short read but a great one!

I was given a free copy of this book in return for an honest review.A gripping beginning, even for those readers who may not have read the previous Athina books. Estes accurately spells it out for you: this young woman in the introduction is not your typical young lady in the castle tower at all - she was in fact, a modern man, a construction worker named Jim Sanders, native of New York CIty.And Jim, now Athina, is in deep trouble. Accused of treason - a crime that carries a death sentence, but as shown in the last book, reduced to life imprisonment in her case. Jim needs to ensure his survival and in order to get this done, he needs to find out the truth behind it all: did the real Athina really plot against the King?I cant help but laugh when Athina gets uncomfortable whenever men like Lord Handel Blue get all up and personal in her private space. But wait! He proposes a way out of the tower imprisonment if Athina were to conceive his child! This situation just led to trouble, specifically to a more physical fight, the outcome not being good for both Lord Handel and Athina.Anyway Estes takes us through Athinas trial - actually it wasnt much of a trial at all! Unbeknownst to her until the trial, there had already been an agreement regarding her guilt and it wasnt a trial but rather a proceeding where she was expected to publicly admit her guilt. But since she said no as any innocent person would, the prosecutor was forced to relay the whole story of the charges against her before the court, including their evidenceA messy ending, with painful deaths and destruction, feelings of extreme sorrow with bouts of happiness. So much love - so much tragedy - and its not over yet ;) Genuinely looking forward to what is next in store for Athina, as herself and Wendall face some extraordinary new challenges.

I was given a free copy of this book in return for an honest review.There is always something uniquely magical about Dacolias stories.In the first few chapters of What We All Have, we get a glimpse of the suffering that a young man named Tony is going through: the pains, the aches, his healths decline. Since the onslaught of his condition, he had felt that this new unwanted companion (his disease) has rapidly influenced his belief that he is truly apart from the world and that the world wants no part of him. He shows anger and frustration at those who seemingly have it all but yet let everything go to waste - maybe even at his old self, back when he was happy and illness-free. This hate brought about a feeling of depression that pushes him further into seclusion from the rest of humanity.It is a very sad and miserable life. I can understand the power of Dacolias descriptions of what this man is going through - anyone who has been around someone with deteriorating health can unfortunately understand this scenario all too well.We also meet Lake, a once-privileged member of the elite society, complete with her fancy cars and multiple luxury dwellings, along with an aloof attitude towards those who were not of the same social standing. Until the passing of her grandmother, who saw it fit to leave her fortune to charity - and nothing to Lake. To add insult to injury so to speak - a month later, she got sick as well, sending her social status and wealthy friends out the window and she became one of the unprivileged ones that she once despised.Tony and Lake crossed paths, a brief yet strange first encounter but one that neither of them could forget. So began a new bond between them, one that was tied together with misfortune. It was interesting to see how it panned out, because they each already face multiple challenges plus you add love on top and it becomes a challenge in itself. I overall enjoyed the story, it was an interesting take but one that carries a slew of lessons for the reader.

I found "Heads Off" to be a witty and interesting police procedural crime novel. The protagonist Lisa is very relatable; little characteristics such as her constant struggle to lose weight and to succeed in a predominantly "man's" profession makes her appealing to most female readers. The way her thoughts are portrayed regarding the different men in her life was very well done and really shows the audience what she thinks through the author's use of witty descriptions.Aside from the story being a solid mystery, I also enjoyed the pictures in between the chapters as they helped with my imagination. Overall a well-written plot rounded off with interesting characters and good brain teaser.

Ordered this case the same day I pre-ordered my Galaxy Note 4 and it arrived the same day! Perfect fit, feels sturdy and very solid. I like how it fits my new baby, it doesn't make it look bulky like other armour cases. It was very easy to install, both the rubber and plastic components work together to keep my phone in place.The sound doesn't get affected by the case as was my experience with my old Note 3 and it's case. I'm glad I ordered it ahead of time though because they didn't have any "tough-looking" cases at T-Mobile, other than an Otterbox which I find too bulky for my small hands.

Having previously read a few of Ray Dacolias books (including Guardians at the Gate and most recently, The Tragedy of Woman,) I knew to expect a thrilling and complex plot along with a gradual slowly-but-surely form of character development. This book is a good break for the usual full-length novel as it is a collections of several yarns; a big plus for me as I am a big fan of short stories.I definitely enjoyed The Lauren Tree, an interesting take on the subject of lying and lies in general. Out of the three Animal Stories I enjoyed the very last one the most, mainly due to Lindsays actions regarding the protection against the mistreatment of animals but also because of how her husband Seth and herself lived among the wild animals later on. I definitely loved the twist in that story and how it ended!Although Fat City, Steel Maiden, The Epiphany of Pain and The Vanishing Point are all decent honourable mentions, out of all of the stories though I feel that Ten Chances was the one that spoke to me the most because it deals with a topic that affects a lot of people, both young and old. The story outlines Ikes ten chances, and it vividly describes an unfortunate pattern that emerges when people are given too many chances until there was none left to give, leaving behind a trail of destruction and more than one broken soul.In its entirety, this anthology is a great reflection of Dacolias talents and storytelling abilities. If you are new to his work this is the perfect place to start as you can see the depth that he is capable of and the potential of his other works!
I love using 1channel and icefilms on my box. They are the best addons.

This face moisturizer has been the most amazing find for me! I have fair, sensitive skin with freckles and my skin is so sensitive and picky about the lotions I use on it, but this moisturizer has been perfect from day one!  After 2 weeks I could not believe the difference in my skin. Although its expensive I bought the full sizes. My skin has not looked this good in years. It is well worth the money.

This season where Christmas falls right after Halloween and Thanksgiving is definitely the perfect time to take a look at this book.We can see how Rocko the bat, a Halloween decoration that is annually placed in a prime position that made observing Gray and Kates family as well as the other events during Halloween very easy. He observed the kids get dressed up and leave for trick or treating. He could see the kids at the door in their costumes such as dressing up as ghosts, skeletons or like himself - a bat. It was obvious that he enjoyed it when the kids are happy (like when they get candy). This year though, Rocko got to see what happens during the year because they had forgotten to put him away!I found the book very much ideal for kids. Aside from the consistent and clever illustrations, the storyline itself is easy to follow, even for little ones. They can follow along with Rocko and learn about the Holidays and would definitely put them in a Halloween, Thanksgiving and Christmas kind of moods. It is relatable for kids to read about Rockos observations with regards to the routines the family go through, like thanking Someone before Thanksgiving dinner as well as the putting up of trees and other Christmas decorations. The Christmas story itself was also very well worded, in language that little kids will understand and learn from.Through Rocko, children will have a better idea about the Holidays, especially about Christmas as well as the power of prayer!

An incredible help to those of us that are sometimes too busy to cook food at peak hours and at the same time trying to maintain eating healthy. I used to feed my family take-out when I come home from work - but now I have access to tasty recipes that I can put in the slow cooker before I leave!But the reason that I appreciate this book so much is because one of the kids is in the autism spectrum and we had been advised by therapists to try converting into a gluten-free diet for her, which had been previously difficult to do without sacrificing flavour and budget. Now armed with recipes like Herbed Meatballs, Creamy Chicken Curry and our new family favourite, Layered Cheesy Chicken Casserole, I feel relieved that I can feed them quality meals, no matter how busy I am.

Foreshadowed by the title, there was a sympathetic tone set for Oscine throughout the story, as life dealt her with one bad card after another, but yet she was portrayed as a positive, compassionate individual. Beginning with a horrible childhood, she was faced with challenges that no person should have to go through, but unfortunately it does happen. Its a story that was sad to read because the main characters spirit gets attacked as she continues her journey in search of both love and happiness.As she grew up, her interactions with persons of the opposite sex, coupled by her desire for finding the man that would rescue her proved to be a toxic mixture that would lead her to early marriage including the shock of her new duties and responsibilities as a new mother. There is a part of the book that described exactly how Heath felt about his wife; when he saw that she is 100% faithful to him and that she will never leave him because of the baby then he stopped complimenting her, stopped giving her gifts and started to become suspicious of her. That is unfortunately too familiar as we hear about those situations in real life quite often.Throughout the novel we see Oscines innermost thoughts of both hoping for better circumstances and life but also the amount of torment she feels inside. Even when her own boys abuse her at their fathers cynical command, she still thought the better of them all. I couldnt help but feel a whole of anger for all the suffering that Oscine endured and even though I felt pity for her, I wish she would just get up and leave her situation and never come back! And the tortured love between her and Abraham turned to be yet another good thing that turned incredibly tragic.Eli on the other - a completely different story! We see his past before he became Abrahams best friend. I am glad the author ended with him though because if the story just stopped with Book 1 then the reader would be left off on an extremely sad tone.Overall a long read, a complex plot but overall an enjoyable, complicated novel!

We found out recently that my partner is suffering from chronic gastritis and we had to change our households diet. We still have much to learn about it but this book provided some excellent recipes that we tried, including our new favorite - chicken with kale! Pair that up with berry salad and red lentil and spinach soup plus a fruity yogurt dessert - definitely makes the transition easier.

SATED is the last book of the romantic, coming of age story that started with Wantin and followed by Unrequited. In this series we follow Talia Jacobs as she journeys from childhood into womanhood, including all the challenges and heartaches she experienced and up to now as she finally finds herself ready to accept the love that she has been looking for - to a man that she has a history with since they were children and to whom she is drawn to like a moth to a flame.Aside from her primary love story centred around Bodhi, we hear of another example of triumphant love - through the story of sweet old Mabel (and her now deceased husband of 42 years, Walter), whom Talia met at a random coffee shop. Her love story seem to have a positive effect on Talia and the feelings of love for Bodhi that shes been experiencing.I found this book in line with the other two with regards to sensuality, being full of emotion, astounding when it came to the portrayal of each of the characters thoughts and feelings, easy to relate to as it covered not only familiar human interactions but also places that are familiar to world travellers or even avid book readers. The little touch of supernatural towards the end seemed fitting and somewhat expected. The ending itself was a satisfying conclusion and I believe that it gave the readers exactly what they are looking for in terms with the closure of Talias journey.

As I thought about my lifestyle and in an effort to be healthy, I considered being a vegetarian. I found this book on Amazon and decided to try out some of the recipes  with AMAZING results! My personal favorites were the Spicy Green Beans with Quinoa and the Cheese-stuffed Bell Peppers with Salad and Spaghetti.The instructions were clear and easy to follow, and the introduction at the beginning of the book provides great information for those of us who are not informed well or are simply not sure about what being a vegetarian is all about. It even discusses the different types of vegetarians and it breaks down the differences between the vegetarian food pyramid and the Harvard Healthy Eating pyramid!

I originally posted my verified purchase review of this book on Amazon.ca, but since it doesn't show up here, I decided to post it here as well.The story starts in the late 1600s and it was easy to be fond of Alpheus, and to feel bad for him from the beginning when he is plagued with problems including being robbed by the nomads. Eventually he was buried deep - until 1996!This book has a nice mixture of different genres - humour, action, mystery, suspense. The author uses superb description and I enjoyed the easy to read/understand style of writing.Not your typical vampire novel at all!

It is inspiring how the author gave the reason behind how he came to start off with nothing: Hurricane Katrina. Like many affected by that tragedy, he had lost everything. But that didnt stop his drive for success, as this book shows.It provides a clear guideline  call it a blueprint if you will  about how to start with absolutely nothing and end up in the top. Along with basic principles and lessons, it shows you how to utilize the untapped portion of your mind. The detailed views of what to do if you find yourself in a having nothing situation applies to pretty much any field.As you read through the pages, you can see the point that the author is trying to make: if you have goals and desires, you should not have to worry about money to achieve simply by showcasing the well know principle of paying it forward.The best part about is it the concept that makes the point to make sure that the information is almost completely free, in order to benefit everyone who wishes to be successful.

The Paleo diet - aka caveman diet, Stone-age diet- centres mainly of fish, grass-fed pasture raised meats, eggs, vegetables, fruit, fungi, roots, and nuts, and excludes grains, legumes, dairy products, potatoes, refined salt, refined sugar, and processed oils.This book contains the most delicious recipes that aligns perfectly with the paleo lifestyle. It is usually hard for me to pick out breakfast items that would go well with the diet but it's solved now thanks to this book!They are easy to follow, quick to prepare, delicious and very convenient.

Reading many positive reviews about Total Car Diagnostics and their products, I though I'd give TOAD a try. Expecting to get the same old under-promised, over-hyped experience, as is true with many of these OBD diagnostic scantools I got from eBay. Not so with these guys. Turned out to be a stellar exceptional product that worked on our 2001 Holden, 2004 Ford & 2008 BMW X5. Instantly showed their condition and faults. Saved us at least $2000 in repairs. My initial support ticket took 2 days to get answered. Next one took under 24 hours. So be prepared to wait. I'm sure they're dealing with many support requests.Install: Quick, smooth and easy, thanks to provided step-by-step instructions on their site.Software friendliness: Overwhelming at first. 1 hour of playing with it, got it! Be prepared for initial learning curve.Cost: 10/10. Compared to what I've seen on the market, TOAD's functions match, if not excel professional $10,000 scanners easily.

I originally posted the verified version of this review on Amazon.ca but since that don't show up here I decided to post it here as well.Networking  to interact with people to exchange information and/or develop contacts  can be an intimidating task for some people to accomplish.  As this book brings out, there are those among us who have been shy all their lives or just have problems connecting with other people.I am exactly like that.I gave this book a read simply because I am shy (always have been!) but in order to advance my career goals I needed a way to get over it so I can successfully network. I found Chapter 4 How Do You Overcome Shyness very useful. I never looked at it that way before  that shyness is only a negative thought about myself that I can replace with a positive thought.The book has a personal touch to it, because the author cites his own experiences. The advice contained therein are not only solid, but also as I personally found out, effective.I definitely recommend this book to all but particular to those who retreat into their shell when it comes to meeting people.
I received a copy of this book for Christmas and I immediately read it of course! Great info that made me want to book an around the world ticket right then and there.

Although I bought this book on Amazon Canada and posted my review there, I felt like I should post it here as well so that everyone can see it.I love the author's enthusiasm with regards to saving a ton of money thru the use of coupons  - it is contagious! After I read the book I was more than excited to follow what I learned. The explanations regarding the different ways you can save money and/or receive free groceries are detailed and offer a step-by-step instruction. The real life experiences provided are also encouraging to try out these "tried and tested" methods.One thing I will definitely try is writing to companies and provide them with my own consumer feedback. The book helps us with this too because it outlines the most effective way of doing it!

If you, like myself, think that you have seen it all when it comes to steamy romance books then prepare yourself to be surprised. This isnt like those other billionaire books  in fact the author even makes fun of them! Introducing a heroine who is shrewd, resourceful but with a heart.There were a few twists and turns in the saga that caught me by surprise, including one in particular that I have never seen before in a book of this kind.  You will also read about a certain low point in the heroines life, and up until then you will really notice the dark direction that the story was taken. But after that, everything changes  when she begins to find herself and eventually, the man of her dreams.The ending turned out to be romantic, which I certainly didnt expect. It is scandalous, smart, funny  but best of all, SIZZLING HOT!

This was a fantastic read! The book was well-written and fast-paced. You always wanted to know what was going to happen next. And there were some surprising twists and turns. Belateche is great at keeping you involved with his characters. You feel like youre there with them, sharing the adventure!

These trainers are an alternative to conventional orthodontics for cases of mild to moderate malocclusion, sometimes even cases of severe malocclusion can be corrected, such as expansion of the upper dental arch, maxillary protrusion, and jaw deep overbite. You can find amazing before/after photos by searching on alignment trainer Dessa Dental. They have been used successfully in Europe and elsewhere for more than a decade, but so far have not been approved by the American Association of Orthodontists. In my opinion the reason is obvious: the profits coming from conventional orthodontics and the frequent trips to the dentist's office, compared to an inexpensive device that is at least as effective and can be applied at home with far fewer trips to the office and little danger of side effects, such as carries. American orthodontists and dentists cannot now dispense these devices to patients, but they do use them for their own family members. In fact, it's a bit of a wild west out there because these devices are not regulated in the US or Asia, so you will see knock-offs and proprietary elaborations at much higher costs.First off, the blue size is meant for children whose adult teeth are in or coming in, ages about 8 to 16. There is a smaller size for younger children that is applied for the correction of myofunctional habits and tooth eruption guidance, and a larger more rigid size for adults. That's it, and there are no custom fittings such as with Invisalign or even bite guards.The device is intended to be inserted at night or during the day when convenient. It works by guiding the force of the tongue and the lips, each of which can and does exert more than ten times the force needed to move children's teeth. It discourages, but does not prevent, mouth breathing, which is a cause of malocclusion because then the tongue does not press properly against the upper teeth. Like conventional orthodontic devices, it is uncomfortable and requires some getting used to, but that's usually not a deal killer, and note that it is not a choking hazard. Results will require many months of use, just like conventional orthodontics, depending on how far teeth have to be moved, but results will be evident at three to six months. Children can continue to use the device even after their teeth are aligned, until they have outgrown the blue size. A dentist can evaluate progress at regular exam/cleaning visits, but few dentists are familiar with alignment trainers, so expect some skepticism.The alignment trainer should be cleaned just like a night guard. Some kids will need help with that, but otherwise these devices appear to be totally safe. BTW, I'm just a parent, with no connection to any manufacturer or distributor, but with a cool dentist whom I trust.

My high hopes were for naught. The book is poorly organized: the Level 1 questions are so basic that, if you need help with them, you need a basic math education, not a narrowly focused prep guide. The Level 5 questions are more advanced than are likely to appear on an ACT, and are a waste of time to study and learn. Plus, some of the questions are misleading, and some of the answers are wrong.For example: Problem 115 asks what the is the sum of the *three* distinct regions of the plane that can be divided up using three lines. The explanation shows three drawings which result in 4, 6, and 7 regions (so the "correct" sum is 17), but the question is misstated. But there are, in fact, 4 different ways of dividing up the plane with three lines (not shown: all lines passing through one point), so the answer explanation is screwy.Another example: Question 118 expects you to know that an angle inscribed in a circle is half the degree measure of the arc it intercepts; but that's far more difficult than anything on the ACT.The author suggests you memorize the quadratic formula. Good advice, but when it is required on the ACT it is given in the question.Another bad example: A question asks for the solution when x=5 of (x^2 - 5)/(x -3) times the number of horizontal and/or vertical intercepts of that function. In the answer, the author says that the function has a vertical intercept on x=3 and no horizontal intercept. Who would know that? The correct solution is to know that hyperbolas are the only conics with asymptotes and they always have two asymptotes and 0, 1, or 2 can be vertical or horizontal. The answer choices are 10, 9, 8, 7, 6, so the only answer possible is 10.The only good information is on using a calculator to plug and test answers, but the author suggests a TI-85, which is way overkill for the ACT and a distraction for most students. A more basic Casio fx-260, well understood, would be a far better choice.The best ACT math book is Ultimate Guide to ACT Math by Corn, but if you are going to get only one general guide, the math section of the essential ACT Prep Black Book by Barrett is far better than this "Red Book." You also will need the real "red book," Peterson's The Real ACT Prep Guide. This "red book" will waste time and confuse most students.

This end mill arrived reasonably quickly, but there was a considerable amount of rust on it. There was no protective coating, as you would expect with a quality tool; not even any oil. A microscopic examination showed that the cutting edges had not been polished and were noticeably rough. I'm sure it will cut, so I'll use it for rough cutting, but it is meerly cheap, not a bargain. I don't expect much life out of it either, because the rough edges will soon wear.

Tool is burly and handy, in the sense that it feels right in the hand. Wail away on it to dig out most nails. However, it works poorly on small finishing nails. The V-shaped slots end too wide. For small brads and finishing nails, and even small staples, the Estwing puller works better.

It's just a basic mill clamp set, and 58 pieces, actually, but it is reasonably well-made and the price is right. It arrived from MIS Tool Supply in amateurish but more than adequate packaging, and showed up a week before I expected it.The parts holding setup is a metal bracket with a molded plastic insert. It works. The clamp parts seem like ordinary steel, with a black oxide finish and a little oil. They're sorta rough, but reasonable.The 7/16" T-slot nuts did fit the slots on my venerable Maximat V10P, but the base of the T-slot nuts didn't. They were a few mils too wide and a few too thick. Several minutes with a bench grinder fixed that. The ground surfaces are not precision and are non-load bearing, so hand grinding is appropriate. The ground surfaces don't even show in fixtures of in the holder rack.There is no country of origin stated anywhere I can see. No "CHINA," for example. If not China and maybe not India, where then? Kinda makes you say, "Hmmmmm."

Head and shoulders above the competition - in terms of design and functionality.First, it will cut flush to the blade teeth. Surprisingly, not all hacksaws will, and if you need that capability and don't have it, you'll curse your saw. Secondly, the main grip is rubber-covered and fits large hands, or hands wearing gloves, quite nicely. The small, end grip is also quite easy to grasp and is also rubberized. Together, they let you tackle tough jobs with both hands; a steel bar, for example. The tension adjustment mechanism works with fingertip ease, but can put a lot of tension on the blade; it is nicely protected by a plastic cover to prevent snagging on your clothes or nearby wires.I was initially dubious about the utility of the additional functions, but very soon after I got the saw, I realized that a job I was working on would be a lot easier using one of them. Soon another application came up, and I had the blade I needed right in the saw, so I guess I shouldn't be so skeptical. I even reversed the blade once so the saw cut toward itself, and the whole business was east to manage.The only possible complaint might be that the thing is somewhat heavy. To me, that's an advantage, because it seems not to skitter around when starting tough cuts. With a double handed grip, this saw gets right to business.

What I got was a flex putty knife with a hardwood handle. I expected mediocre quality, but I was pleasantly surprised. It was exactly what the job required, tapered thickness blade and all. A multi-purpose tool indeed. You can find similar putty knives with plastic handles and a metal endcap, but for most every job, I prefer the feel of wood. And you can always find things cheaper than Prime items, which seem to have the shipping cost buried in the price. Up to you to decide what a trip to the store is worth to you.Actually, this putty knife changed my whole view of Tekton tools. I always thought of them as just-get-by quality. But I thought about all the various Tekton tools I have accumulated over the years, and now I'd say they are a great value. I'd still use Snap-On in a production environment (if I weren't covering the cost), but Tekton is fine around the home shop, and I can't remember ever breaking one or having it fail to do its job.BTW, the most commonly used tool is fingernails.

I checked this set against metric shop standards and couldn't find any problems. The fit and finish were perfect, as far as I could tell. The whole design is a bit clunky, but it is completely serviceable. So why knock off about $100?But I'm not complaining. I was lucky to get a set while they were selling them cheap.

An excellent tool for someone who understands when and how to use it (see YouTube for skin stapler videos), who isn't squeamish, and who understands sterile technique. It's not a cure-all for wound closure, but for basic, non-facial lacerations it lets you do the same thing an ER doc would do, only faster and cheaper. It's easy enough that you can do your own woulds if you can somehow close and slightly evert the edges. And grimace.Note that the version I received was the 35R. That means 35 staples of the small size: 5.4 mm x 3.6 mm. The most commonly used size is the W: 7.0 mm x 4.0 mm.

The pros are that it looks smart and seems to be well-made.What killed it for me was threefold:*The cellphone holder is too small for my Galaxy S5, and probably an S4*The section for the phone, cards, pens, and other stuff only opens at the top, so you really can't see what's in the dark down there, especially if something falls to the bottom*The case doesn't open to lie flat to make airport security faster and easier with a laptopI also noted that the handles don't connect together in some way, you have to grab both of them them carefully. And the pocket that's supposed to go over a roll-around handle is suitable only for paper items that you don't care about wrinkling or creasing; it won't fit standard-sized documents.If these aren't issues for you, you may like it.

Layout Essentials: 100 Design Principals for Using Grids doesn't actually deliver design principals, they're just platitudes. Here are some examples: Avoid crowding, Avoid overcrowding, Design with ample margins, Pack it in. What the book does deliver is a well-chosen selection of excellent page layouts, most based on applications of grid principals, though a few make you scratch your head. (There is an illustrated compendium of grid layout terms on the first pages.) The author even applies the same principal to the layout and comments of the pages that illustrate the particular principal chosen, so the book design itself is excellent and quite clever.What the author does not deliver is solutions to today's designers' main challenge: keeping a consistent look and grid design over printed pages, computer screens, and personal device displays. The book is focused almost entirely on printed pages or posters.Nevertheless, the examples shown are brilliant and inspirational and the author's comments well-taken. Also of note is that many of the designers of the featured examples are women; nice to see a stereotype broken. All in all, the book is well-worth its cost.

I have no idea why Anova dropped their price to $200, but my advice is to get one before they come to their senses. This is a great immersion heater, and it is exceptionally well designed. It inspired me to write a short review.It isn't obvious from the photos, but the display isn't Photoshopped, it's actually a color, back-lit, graphical, LCD touch screen. There's a startup screen where you can set C or F display and select the timer mode (yes, it has a timer): to either beep or shut down when the time runs down to zero. The timer can be set for up to 99 hours, but if no time is set the unit will run until the water evaporates below the two low-water sensors. In use, the display shows set temp, measured temp, and time remaining on the timer, with a Stop option. Temp can be set to 0.1 degree and Anova claims 0.01 degree stability, but that would be hard to measure. You can touch the display while it's running to show several simplified screens with heater and pump icons.The heater is a full 1000 W (limited by household current supply), and the unit has a burly but intelligently short removable/replaceable IEC line cord. The stainless steel cover over the heater, sensors, and pump easily twists off for ready access to the insides for cleaning; that's very handy when one of your pouches leaks and everything gets covered with duck fat or one of your onsen tamago cracks and you have egg white pumped throughout your circulator. In the long run you can also easily clean off mineral deposits. You can scrub off the inside parts with a soapy vegetable brush and put the cover and pump cover in the dish washer. The pump cover screws onto the main cover and you can unscrew it a bit to trim the direction of the outflow if you need to, although the bayonet attachment of the main cover by itself allows four different flow directions. The pump flow is robust, rated at 12 liters per minute. Although the tank capacity is rated at 6 gallons, I'd guess that to run that big a tank at a high temperature you'd want an insulated tank (this is pretty easy to set up: just use two nesting plastic tubs and a lid). The clamp wants a tank at least 7 inches deep, but the unit stands stably on its base without the clamp and doesn't use its bottom for water intake like other units, so there's a lot of flexibility in setting it up in tanks as shallow as 3 inches.A few fine points and then I'll look at the competition. There is a physical mains power switch, but it's out of sight, positioned like a trigger behind and below the display head. The instruction booklet talks about sending the unit in for repair, so it looks like repair rather than replacement is possible. And the startup screen also allows entering a calibration mode, though it isn't advised. I checked my unit with a precision lab thermometer readable to 0.1 degree C, and it was spot on as far as I could tell. The unit also seems to have a thermostatically controlled fan in the control head that operates independently of the pump motor--a nice touch.Now about the competition: The least expensive Polyscience Sous Vide Professional immersion heaters are rated for household use. The Discovery model costs $300 and has a 750 W heater. The Creative unit costs $400 but has a 1100 W heater and a timer, although there are but two numerical displays so one flashes between set temp and time. Both units have a pump capacity of 6 liters per minute and 0.07 degree stability. Amazon reviewers report that these Chinese-made units cannot be repaired. The Anova unit actually compares favorably to the Polyscience Chef model, which costs $800 but like the others requires screwdriver disassembly for good access to the inner parts for cleaning.I'm an electronics engineer and product designer, and I was really impressed with the design of the Anova immersion circulator. Even the packaging was well-designed, so the out-of-box experience was excellent. I have only a small quibble: the setup screen could easily provide a few more options, such as beeps when the unit reaches its set temp and an option for the timer to start counting down after the unit reaches its set temp, and the timer options don't need to be mutually exclusive. Seems like it could be done with a simple firmware change since everything else is there. Nevertheless: 5 solid stars.

It is always amusing when creationists turn to science to justify belief; inevitably they are untrained in the areas they call upon and they readily resort to quote mining  and selective misunderstanding. This book is a fine example of that tendency. Philosophers will find the philosophical component as risible as I find the Discovery Institute science, but I'll leave that to them and comment on what is presented as science, which is so notably lame.The underlying premise is "Science can't explain the Cambrian explosion to my satisfaction (even though I'm not a biologist), so it can only have been due to supernatural Intelligent Design." Any scientist knows that Darwin's lack of certainty is simply the way science works. Only religion is free of doubt.But let's have a look at what science knows about the Cambrian explosion. First, was it really an "explosion?" It got that name back in the day because the fossils of first animals were initially discovered in a relatively narrow range of geological time. Since then, many more fossils have been discovered of earlier hard-bodied animals and even of soft-bodied animals--but the name has stuck. Meyer thinks this all happened too fast, but that's because he doesn't understand molecular phylogenetics. Meyer can't account for what he thinks is the too-rapid evolution of hard-bodied morphology except by invoking divine intervention. He seems ignorant of the way evolution works: it builds new traits and new phyla, not de novo, but from mutations in or doubling of genetic building blocks that already exist. By the time of the Cambrian, hard-bodied animals had existed for tens of millions of years (in the Ediacaran). And the basic genes employed in Cambrian animals had existed for more tens of millions prior. In fact, some of these genes are well-conserved and are still with us today.By the Cambrian, not only did hard-bodied animals exist, but macrophagy had long evolved. Deuterosomes and proteasomes had split, and not just Echinodermata but also protochordata were well established (and again, the genetic building blocks for these characteristics preceded them by tens of millions of years). Bilateralians had appeared. Parasitism had long before pushed sexual reproduction into multicellular animals. Scientists are increasingly able to pin down the timing of this diversification due to advances in genome sequencing and understanding of the molecular clock. Fossils are not required. So, sure, in the first third of the Cambrian the number of phyla went up somewhat and the number of classes about doubled over twenty million years, but that shouldn't cause scientists (or creationists) to go nuts. Compare it to the mammalian "explosion" that followed the KT extinction, keeping in mind that invertebrates reproduce, and therefore evolve, an order of magnitude faster than mammals. But that radiation wasn't called an explosion, so Meyer doesn't find it mysteriously inexplicable.Also consider the other factors at play in the early Cambrian, including abiotic factors. The Earth was emerging from a period called "Slushball Earth," which meant that water retained in snow and ice was released, the regolith was eroded, and sea levels rose to cover coastal areas. That increased the amount of phosphorous and calcium (by a factor of three) in seawater, making it available for biomineralization and for the first time the evolution of hard tissue predators and prey and the rapid evolution of their arms race and participation in complex food webs in new marine ecosystems.Oceans rising onto eroded regolith (mud) meant a substantial increase in littoral habitat and the appearance of burrowing and other benthic animals to take advantage of it, further adding to biodiversity and increasing animal morphological diversity.So the potential causes of the rapid diversification of animal types in the early Cambrian are many, and doubtless they interacted. But just because real scientists have yet to agree upon the proportional contribution of each of the many possible influences, or their relative timing, does not mean anyone should throw up their hands and conclude that a single cause must therefor be responsible: an intelligent designer. Meyer seems happily oblivious to all this real science stuff so he can only drag out the old god-of-the-gaps argument and dress it up a bit, perfectly illustrating the Dunning-Kruger effect. This book makes no contribution to our scientific understanding of evolutionary processes in the early Cambrian period. For that you'll need actual science.

The product that I received failed. It may have worked at first, though the plug was sloppy and unreliable, but apparently it soon failed to charge the battery while reporting that it was charged. I took the camera back to COSTCO and they exchanged it. But it was the dead battery at fault, not the camera. Later, the charger gave off that old familiar smell of hot electronics and it melted the side of its plastic case. The charger was dead.I'm an electronics engineer, so naturally I took the charger apart to see what had gone wrong. I found what you'd expect for inexpensive consumer electronics: nothing fancy, but nothing terribly slipshod either. A voltage regulator chip had failed and overheated, maybe because its heat sink wasn't large enough? Maybe I just got a lemon. The charger has a CE mark but no UL, and the printed voltage specification doesn't make sense, so I don't think an engineer was involved in drawing up the label.I asked Amazon for a refund before I realized that the charger was weeks out of warranty. The seller contacted me and offered a refund or exchange. I picked refund and they complied without asking me to return the charger. That was more than fair; I would have sent it back so they could have a look.I'm not sure I can recommend the charger, based on my experience, but I can definitely recommend the seller. I replaced it with another brand because I didn't want to be without a charger while the replacement was being processed, but otherwise I'd probably buy it again. The price is good and the vendor inspires confidence.

This order is actually 5 identical bags. Each contains a larger and a smaller pry tool. They are made of hard plastic but no doubt they will soon be damaged. Better them than your cell phone. Better these than a metal knife blade for sure.

I use these on USB thumb drives to make it easier to find the one I'm looking for. Mu daughter uses one as a leash on her small camera. Don't know why more cell phones don't have small eyelet holes for leashes like these. If it isn't clear from the picture, there is a sliding thingy that can cinch up the large, soft loop to make it less likely to slide off your wrist or whatever. I yanked on them pretty hard and had no failures. Nice.

I wanted to like this book, because I believe in rigorous mathematics. Unfortunately, it's pretty uninviting.I have no doubt that it thoroughly and rigorously covers its topic (plane geometry), but, sadly, it's too rigorous for modern high school students. And it's pretty dry. The few pages on trig are far too few and too terse; there's no picture of sin/cos waves that will certainly lie in the future for students who tackle science or engineering. I'll refer to it while I teach, but I'm afraid that it would turn off most students. If this were the textbook, students would be dropping like flies.Seriously, the depth of this book is excessive for what a contemporary high school student needs to learn about plane geometry or about constructing clever proofs. It might be fine for a future math major, but it might also discourage potential future math majors.I didn't find any answers to the exercises, which not only requires that a teacher work them out (and many aren't trivial, to say the least), but it doesn't show what elegant methods the author might have had in mind when he posed the problems. Often the solution (particularly of proofs) is as educational as the lead-up text. And worked examples are the best way to teach, IMHO. There are too few in Kiselev.

These things work reasonably well and they are convenient in first aid kits. They're unbreakable and they can't read too high (unless you leave them in your black car in the summer). They are single-use disposable, so there is no possibility of germ transfer. Their battery never goes dead. And they are bite-proof and don't require poking something in an ear.I started using them to end all discussions with our pediatrician, who always hems and hasw when you tell her what thermometer you used. Their practice uses these (or the equivalent 3M TempaDOTs), so that ends the discussion. For me, these are easier to read than the TempaDOTs.

This thing fits my Sero 7 Pro perfectly. The cutouts for the rear camera, speakers, front camera and light sensor, the buttons, and the sockets all align very well. It's the best Sero 7 case I have seen, and I've seen several.The case is made from dark brown leatherette with nicely finished edges and flawless white saddle stitching. It has a nice manly look, or it could go with a Coach purse. My daughter wanted a pale blue case, so she looked elsewhere. Inside there are slots for two microSD cards, three credit cards, and some notes or receipts. There's a wide elastic strap to keep things attached to your left hand with the case opened, and a small strap on the back for a pen. There are magnetic closures and, in addition, another elastic strap for positive closure. There is provision to stand the tablet at an angle in landscape mode.All in all, a fine case with great features at a great price.The seller has been contacting buyers in case they accidentally shipped a case for the Sero 7 LT, which says good things about their service. I didn't have that problem.BTW: any case that has magnetic closures, as they all seem to have, will drive the magnetic compass in your tablet crazy, so check YouTube for re-calibration ballet instructions.

This fan has a lot of cool features and they all seem to work well -- plus, it's only a few dollars more than "reversible" fans that must be physically reversed (lame!). The remote is powerful enough to reach at least 40 feet or bounce off a wall. But here is one of the caveats: the buttons are all the same shape, so you'll be a bit challenged to use the remote in the dark, even with the obvious LEDs on the fan unit's face.Don't fret about reviews that say it's hard to mount. The clips that hold the side slats will snap into place when you drop it down into whatever slot it will rest. No big deal; at worst you can have someone else pull a book out from under the unit as you spread the sides and let drop into place. There are two expander plates for wider windows and plenty of foam provided to fill gaps; I didn't need any.I got mine in 2013 so maybe the location of the thermostat issue has been resolved; I just set mine low and ignore it, changing the direction of flow to get the effect I want. It seems the thermostat shows the temp of the air passing through the unit, slightly favoring outside temp. Mine never sees direct sun. You can work out in your head what temp you'd want to set if the air is moving in or out (or both).The fans move air well; I seldom use any but the lowest speed. And they are fairly quiet, too. But there's the caveat: the blade guards are far apart, so flies and mosquitoes might be able to enter your room, though my flies haven't figured that out yet. And the fan doesn't easily disassemble for cleaning. We'll see how that goes, but it's no worse than a box floor fan except that half of the blade guards are outside the room. An update months later: no flies or mosquitoes have come in; maybe the ones in my neighborhood are fan-challenged. Let's hope.After using it for months, I've raised my rating by one star, because it works so well in my application and it has cut down on my use of the small window AC that it sits on top of.

I posted this about the Transcend 32 GB SDHC card that was getting trashed in reviews by Canon owners. It also applies to the Sony card (read down), and readers may find it helpful in evaluating SD cards in general.The 1-star threads on the Transcend are like watching a committee of blind men describing an elephant. Unsurprisingly, no one has the complete picture, but a lot of Canon owners think these cards are bogus. SD card technology is very complex, the Class system is often misunderstood, and there is a long history of compromised cards appearing on eBay -- or even from reputable dealers who have been hoodwinked. Kingston cards are most often faked (or taken from the midnight production run); that's because Kingston has about a third of the flash card market and doesn't forge their own chips, but any manufacturer can be spoofed. It doesn't pay to buy cheap cards on eBay or less reputable sources.An SD card contains a controller chip and flash memory chips, even the microSD versions. Realize that SD means Secure Digital, and that security comes from crypto managed by the controller (MMC cards didn't have that bloat, but Hollywood DRM requirements made sure they faded). The controller can be pretty powerful: the Samsung SD controller is a 32-bit ARM TDMI chip with 128 k of code space -- that's cell phone power. It handles I/O and fading (when the card slowly wears out its NAND sites after about 100,000 hits so writing is randomly distributed and kept track of), the factory self-test, and a host of other functions, but it can also be programmed to report a false storage capacity. Sometimes the firmware on the controller or its crypto or something else on certain cards leads to problems with certain hardware, as it has, for example, with the Samsung Galaxy III and maybe the Canon cameras. Usually the card is found to confirm to SDcard dot Org specifications and the hardware is to blame, but you never know.To test the actual capacity of your card, use H2testw, which is free. It writes the full amount of data to the card and then reads it back (this nukes whatever was on the card). This can take more than an hour with a 32 GB card but it tells you if the card indeed holds 32 GB or if it has problems. H2testw also gives you read and write speed numbers, but it's unclear whether the numbers are for random read/write, or sequential read/write or a mix. Sequential write is what photographers and videographers most care about.Sometimes a Class 6 card might appear to test faster than a Class 10 card, when using computer read/write tests or even in a camera that wasn't designed with higher capacity cards in mind. That's because such cards use smaller block sizes (there's no cache on an SD card). Explaining the significance of this is getting too far into the weeds for an Amazon review, and modern devices and their firmware should not have that limitation.To test random and sequential read/write speed, use CrystalDiskMark, also free. Run the full suite; it won't take long. CrystalDiskMark requires that the card be formatted, and the most reliable way to do that is to use the free tool from sdcard dot org. A 32 GB card will may report 39.9 GB before formatting and 29.8 GB after; don't worry, you haven't been ripped off.Unfortunately, there's no easy way to read the manufacturer's ID off the SD card, even in Linux, to determine who actually made the card, because you have to have the card connected directly to a motherboard; an SD-to-USB adapter won't work because it doesn't pass through disk data, and that's what's in nearly all computers. But what do you care, so long as the card's as big and fast as claimed?Now, what about the Transcend 32 GB SDHC C10 card? Here are full test results from CrystalDiskMark:Transcend 32 GB SDHC C10-----------------------------------------------------------------------CrystalDiskMark 3.0.2 (C) 2007-2013 hiyohiyoCrystal Dew World : [...]-----------------------------------------------------------------------* MB/s = 1,000,000 byte/s [SATA/300 = 300,000,000 byte/s]Sequential Read : 19.953 MB/sSequential Write : 13.786 MB/sRandom Read 512KB : 19.618 MB/sRandom Write 512KB : 13.827 MB/sRandom Read 4KB (QD=1) : 3.003 MB/s [ 733.2 IOPS]Random Write 4KB (QD=1) : 1.414 MB/s [ 345.1 IOPS]Random Read 4KB (QD=32) : 3.491 MB/s [ 852.3 IOPS]Random Write 4KB (QD=32) : 1.842 MB/s [ 449.8 IOPS]Test : 50 MB [F: 0.0% (0.0/29.3 GB)] (x5)Date : 2013/05/12 18:19:47So you can see that the sequential write speed, what matters to a photographer or videographer, is over 13 MB/s, more than 30% above the C10 spec. The other speeds aren't too shabby, either. There's no way that this card is too slow for a contemporary camera, still or video, that is functioning and designed properly.Also on Amazon for a very attractive price is a Sony 32 MB SD card. Here are the full CrystalDiskMark test results for it:Sony 32 GB SDHS USH-ISequential Read : 19.998 MB/sSequential Write : 14.115 MB/sRandom Read 512KB : 19.772 MB/sRandom Write 512KB : 13.173 MB/sRandom Read 4KB (QD=1) : 3.682 MB/s [ 899.0 IOPS]Random Write 4KB (QD=1) : 2.302 MB/s [ 561.9 IOPS]Random Read 4KB (QD=32) : 4.517 MB/s [ 1102.8 IOPS]Random Write 4KB (QD=32) : 2.323 MB/s [ 567.0 IOPS]So the Sony is slightly faster, 40% over spec, on its sequential write. H2testw also reported full capacity and no errors for this card, so they are both top notch (The Sony doesn't come with a little case and the case for the Transcend case is about twice as big as it needs to be and so won't fit in the little pockets in a modern camera bag. Big deals.)Just for reference, here are the results for a contemporary USB thumb drive:SanDisk Ultra 32 GB USB thumb driveSequential Read : 22.508 MB/sSequential Write : 7.985 MB/sRandom Read 512KB : 22.365 MB/sRandom Write 512KB : 1.767 MB/sRandom Read 4KB (QD=1) : 3.719 MB/s [ 908.1 IOPS]Random Write 4KB (QD=1) : 0.520 MB/s [ 126.9 IOPS]Random Read 4KB (QD=32) : 3.871 MB/s [ 945.0 IOPS]Random Write 4KB (QD=32) : 0.482 MB/s [ 117.7 IOPS]As you can see, this USB drive is faster than the SD cards for reading, such as for playing music, running software, or looking up data, which shows that it is nicely optimized for its intended functions.As an aside, anyone who thinks they have lost data on an SD card can recover pictures using the free tool at z-a-recovery or recover everything(!) with the free PhotoRec tools.So, if people want to whine about these SD cards in their particular cameras, they should run these simple, free tests and reach their own conclusions about whether the cards are "too slow." The cards test above spec objectively. And they both work flawlessly on my still (not Canon) and video cameras. I think they have gotten a bad rap on Amazon from people who don't have the full picture, so to speak.I've also posted this as a review on the Transcend 32 GB page. I hope you found it informative.
