I originally wrote this review on the Barrons SAT Vocabulary Flash Cards, but it's really a review that I hope anyone looking to build their vocabulary might find useful, so I thought I'd copy it here. It covers the American Heritage books and other resources...The Barrons flash cards fall far from what they could, or should, be. The good part is that they are flash cards. I prefer cards to books because they are easy to carry, easy to select the words you have mastered and set those aside to work on the others, and easy to randomize. The size is right and the paper weight is adequate to hold up until the cards have been learned.But the main content is poor. The selection of words seems weak, but I can't be sure. You may discard a hundred right away, but then you'll still have 400. The syllabications and pronunciations are often non-standard. For example, Barrons breaks "articulate" as ahr TI kye let (The I should be marked short and the e's should be the upside-down e schwa symbol that indicates a minimally stressed vowel; capitalization indicates the stressed syllable.). The American Heritage Dictionary, which I consider to be the best, treats "articulate" as ar*tic'*u*late, ar-tik'-ye-lit, where the i's are marked short and the e is the schwa. This poor treatment goes on and on so much that it becomes annoying and unhelpful. So does the frequent use of the schwa; you end up mumbling the words instead of pronouncing them articulately. Barrons seems to use the pronunciation style and symbols of American Heritage Dictionary (called AHD), but not quite.The definitions are where Barrons really falls short. The definitions are often too terse, sometimes just synonyms and not always good ones; different meanings are separated by semicolons, but sometimes different uses of words, as, say, noun and adjective, are not mentioned at all. Sometimes not all of a word's several meanings are given. The definitions are the sort that a high school student might memorize without really understanding how the word is best used, because they fail to convey nuance that true understanding of the word requires. The example sentences often seem as though inelegantly written by a high school student -- the word just stuck in some sentence with no enrichment of its meaning or usage. And the synonyms are weak. In one case I noticed, "rant" is given as a synonym of "tirade," but "tirade" is not given as a synonym of "rant" but "storm" is.My recommendations for really learning new words include the "100 Words Every High School Graduate Should Know," and "100 More ..." By American Heritage Dictionary. The words are well-chosen and include a few technical or scientific words. They give syllabications that seem more standard, followed by the AHD pronunciation guide, so you can really see how to pronounce the words correctly and overcome schwa uncertainty. Following that is a fuller description of the words' usage, such as "noun," or "transitive verb." If the plural is tricky, it is listed next. Then an elegant meaning or meanings, which are numbered if they are significantly different. Then the word is used in a sentence, often from a notable person. The etymology is often given, which I find makes words more memorable and their definitions more nuanced, so you can use them with confidence. And for most words, related words are listed along with their part of speech.I also recommend Grammar Girl's "101 Words Every High School Graduate Needs to Know." Her definitions are really great; they are high on nuance and often blend in etymology, so you really understand the subtitles of a word's usage. Her word selection comes up with elegant words, but which are a little more down-to-earth. Her example sentences are often lengthy, from notables, and amusing. Fogarty really delivers a rich understanding of what each word means, and her writing, as always, is a pleasure to read. But there is no pronunciation or syllabication guide, and, surprisingly, all the words are capitalized.The problem with these books is they aren't as well-suited to drill as are flash cards, and the words are permanently alphabetized. You could, I suppose, insert a piece of paper at random, and lower it to reveal the word but not its definition; that would sorta make the books into flash cards. For that amount of work you'd come away with a much better understanding of the words you should have mastered before entering college.There are other ways to learn new words on line, for free. FreeRice and SparkNotes prompt SAT words with multiple choice synonyms and vocabulary dot com has many lists, including AHD's high school 100, as does esldesk. Vocabulary dot com will track your progress and learn what words you know and should know. Quizlet has lots of virtual flash cards, though the definitions are unvetted. You can even find AHD's several lists of words on the Houghton Mifflin web site and then look them up in their online dictionary. But nothing beats a fistful of the real thing. Houghton Mifflin, are you listening? Turn your American Heritage books into flash cards -- please!

OK, it's a cheap medicine cabinet. But it's not as bad as the reviews indicate. So long as the assembly was done correctly, it does the job and it looks OK. It goes in a standard=size wall opening, and it really should be installed in a recess. Be gentle when you mount it. It's plastic, but that means it's rustproof and easily cleaned.The reviewer who mentioned that the paint came off the trim should have known that he was looking at a protective plastic film intended to be removed after installation. The mirror frame is chrome-looking stainless steel and its unobtrusive -- no more so than an edge bevel. I buffed the edging with a Scotchbrite pad to make it look like brushed stainless to better match the brushed nickel elsewhere in my bathroom and it looks fine.And by the way, Home Depot has the same medicine cabinet for $25, so go have a look.

These cards fall far from what they could, or should, be. The good part is that they are flash cards. I prefer cards to books because they are easy to carry, easy to select the words you have mastered and set those aside to work on the others, and easy to randomize. The size is right and the paper weight is adequate to hold up until the cards have been learned.But the main content is poor. The selection of words seems weak, but I can't be sure. You may discard a hundred right away, but then you'll still have 400. The syllabications and pronunciations are often  non-standard. For example, Barrons breaks "articulate" as ahr TI kye let (The I should be marked short and the e's should be the upside-down e schwa symbol that indicates a minimally stressed vowel; capitalization indicates the stressed syllable.). The example sentences often seem as though inelegantly written by a high school student -- the word just stuck in some sentence with no enrichment of its meaning or usage. And the synonyms are weak. Then an elegant meaning or meanings, which are numbered if they are significantly different. Then the word is used in a sentence, often from a notable person. Fogarty really delivers a rich understanding of what each word means, and her writing, as always, is a pleasure to read. This might be a fine book for a mathematician who likes algebra textbooks, but it will be daunting for students. It is mostly proof-type lessons with few examples and little step-by-step pedagogy. There are few word problems; in fact, there are few problems overall. Pretty dry stuff. If you're looking for challenging algebra with a high standard of instruction, I'd recommend the books from Art of Problem Solving. They have a reasonable number of problems that increase in difficulty. Plus they have free online lessons that match the books' progress.

The features and price are fine -- and nice big numbers you can see from a distance. But there are two issues. The small one is that the numerals are not nearly as bright in the dark as the hands and neither stay visible in the wee small hours of the morning after having been charged up by room lights. But the BIG one is that this little clock makes a really loud sound. Its TIC - TOC can be heard in a typical room, but in a quiet bedroom it is really loud. If you want to keep it nearby and are a light sleeper look elsewhere.Did I mention it is REALLY LOUD?!!

Metric, as it should be.This hanging weight set works fine for physics experiments.Its weights are: 50 g (the hanger), 9 x 20 g, 10 g, and 2 x 5 g. Each weight is stamped with its value.What's not to like.

Agave syrup is essentially 100% fructose and is therefore the most toxic sweetener of all. Fructose leads to non-alcoholic fatty liver disease, and all the rest that we have learned about high fructose sweeteners. From corn or cactus, fructose is fructose, and it's all bad.

The Benzethonium chloride antiseptic in StaphAseptic is the modern, preferred ingredient, the same that is used in operating rooms in preference to povidone iodine. It works on bacteria, viri, and fungi, and it is non-alergenic, compared to drug store antibacterials. StaphAseptic also contains Lidocaine, a pain killer. Unfortunately, it also contains tea tree oil, so it has a pronounced smell. It's claimed to be a gel, but it's more like a salve or grease.The problem with StaphAseptic is that it comes in 2 oz tubes, far too much for a backpacking or biking first aid kit. These single-use, trial packs are a great solution; plenty for field first aid. The problem with them is their high cost, especially after shipping costs, but I just shrugged it off and figured they would be used in emergencies only, and I'll use the tube version for normal use.

I'm comparing these to the similar Chicago Cutlery scissors that cost about ten bucks. These are better for my large hands, with larger openings, and the handles have grippy co-molded interiors that feel nice. Their hinge has adjustable tension, rather than being fixed. They are made of thicker metal (.115 inch compared to .092), and their toothed grippers are stamped to make them align rather than remain offset as the downmarket CC scissors are. In their favor, the Chicago Cutlery scissors have slight serrations on one blade and a notch that makes cutting things like rose stems much easier; the Faberware scissors have plain blades that are a bit beefier. Both scissors are fine, but overall the Farberware 4-in-1 Ultimate Shears just have a better fit and feel and are worth the higher cost for something I use every day.

Not great, but not too expensive either. I prefer the Farberware 4-in-1 Ultimate Shears, but they cost more and my wife misplaced mine. I bought these then found the others, so I can compare. These are less ergonomic, particularly for my large hands, and they are made of a noticeably thinner metal. On the positive side, they stay sharp and they have a notch that facilitates cutting things like rose stems.

I used to think that Rusczyk's *Algebra* was the best math text I had ever read. That was until *Prealgebra* came out last summer. Wow! It's brilliant!*Algebra* was written just right for a (very sharp) high school mind. *Prealgebra* is perfectly dialed in to the (better be very sharp) middle school mind. The book is very challenging. It teaches with the most scientifically-proven effective technique there is: worked examples. There's almost nothing else. No photos, no cartoons, no distractions of any kind (cognitive load theory explains that these reduce learning). Just very straightforward working through of examples and a few bullet points. There are actually very few problems, and certainly not page after page of work sheets. And the problems themselves (most are word problems) are mind stretching. Then you move on.I doubt if this book could be a text for a middle school class; the teaching would be too challenging (you definitely want to get the Solutions Manual, if only to see how the authors solve the problems). But for a kid who finds math boring, this will present all the challenge and engagement you could ask for. I suspect that it will take more than a school year to go through it, because it is so thorough. I use it with a small group of PG tweens (IQ > 145) and it is perfect for them after finishing Singapore Math 6A/B. They find it challenging and rewarding, insightful, engaging, and doesn't talk down to them. They know it's hard, but it's fun hard, and it's never boring.I should mention: there are free step-by-step videos on the Art of Problem Solving dot com web site where Rusczyk teaches each point. You can go back and replay parts, stop the video, etc. I don't use them, because I find interacting with each of my students personally and addressing their issues individually works better. (My daughter snidely remarked on one: "He's doing it the hard way.") But I can certainly see how a parent would be happy to turn their math whiz over to the master himself. Find him on YouTube too.This book will build a solid foundation for discrete math and combinatorics, sadly lacking in math education these days. I have but a single criticism: many times a problem could be solved using a pair of simultaneous linear equations but instead a more convoluted method is suggested. I suppose there's a reason for that. I'll have to ask Rusczyk the next time I see him -- after thanking him profusely for this fantastic text.

This resistor assortment is a great offering -- except for one big thing: they are actually 1% resistors. This means that they are 5-band resistors (color bands, indicating their value). That means that the third band is always black (0) and the fourth band is one color less than you'd expect in the usual third band, and the 5th band (tolerance) is black instead of gold so it isn't readily apparent which end is which, and that means they are MUCH harder to read than customary 4-band resistors. It makes them a real PITA to read, even if you're familiar with the color code. You'll hate 'em. I hate 'em.Joe, if you are listening, here's my suggestion: First, eliminate the useless 0-ohm resistors (jumpers); wire works well enough for that. I suspect you're just padding your offering.Second, supply quality 5% (4-band) resistors, such as R-Ohm. Good production processes mean that quality carbon film 5% resistors actually run about 2% or better. There's no reason to use 1% unless you need tin oxide resistors for low noise in sensitive circuits. And I suspect these ain't tin oxide (but if they are you should say so). If a source of 5% carbon film resistors doesn't actually run 2%, then you should expect other problems as well, such as poor bonding of end caps, poor plating of the steel leads, and poor scoring of the carbon film and thus random hot spot failures.Finally, you can't simply measure resistors with a VOM. You need an instrument, such as a bridge, to test resistors, and you need some statistics to really determine how many resistors you must measure and what the resulting tolerance actually is, based on your measurements. Simply providing 1% resistors is a lame solution to quality control problems and poorly serves your customers.

I bought this drive to replace another that failed. I back up my wife's system using xxclone, a free application that clones an entire disk, warts and all. You can either clone disk A to disk B then run off B while keeping A as a backup, or run off A and keep B as a backup until you clone again. The clone disk is a complete, bootable replacement for the original disk (except that Windows could possibly and unhelpfully complain. In my experience, changing only the disk but not the disk ID, a feature of xxclone, is tolerated by Windows XP Pro.) I would think that Microsoft could now send out an update to XP systems that would allow easy clone backup of XP systems, seeing as how they have since gone through Vista (with great pain) and 7, but they seem to want to perpetuate the pain of backing up an entire hard drive in case it fails totally -- which seems to be the common mode. They want you to re-install every app and every update -- not customer friendly at all.Sure, the disk is old school, and so is my wife's computer, but it functions well enough for email and occasional word processing. Still, there are things on her computer that would be a pain to lose. Solution: clone the disk to another IDE disk using xxclone every few months.Having used Linux/Ubuntu on other systems, I'll never buy another Microsoft or Apple system again; most people would never notice the difference except for the lack of headaches and cost. But for now, it's great to have available a quality hard drive to back up a legacy computer -- at least until the motherboard fails.
These work just fine for sharing seeds saved from gardening. Just fold over the ends and staple them; what's not to like?

This hood fits the 18-200 mm lens better than the Nikon HB-35 original and it might even be a bit sturdier. Strangely, the little dots are located so that you line them up with the dot on the lens before you rotate the hood into position, whereas on the Nikon they line up after the hood clicks into place. I'd compare them to confirm this, but of course I no longer have the Nikon hood. Anyhow, I like the JJC approach better, and I sure like the price better.

This is a bit strange. The product comes in an envelope with no case, no instructions, no batteries -- nothing but a bubble wrap sleeve. On the other hand, the unit itself appears to be well made, with some decent screw machine components, rubber-covered barrel, and sturdy clip helpfully labeled *Laser Pointer*. The sparkly thingy on the end is useless to me, but it protects the laser output port from getting dusty. The beam itself seems well-colliminated and indeed about 5 mW with fresh AAA batteries, about what you'd want for pointing out stars and planets but not unnecessarily lethal. And the price is right.
This stuff works very well, better than enzymatic cleaners. It's easy to use, too. The moisture drops are so - so, but it's the cleaners that get the job done.

This stopwatch probably uses the same microchip that most of the others use, as its functions seem to be identical. In other words, some functions like the alarm are so obscure that they are likely seldom used (I haven't figured out how to shut off the hourly beep that I somehow turned on). But the main functions are what you'd want. The display is large enough to be visible without readers, and the push buttons have a nice, firm, positive feel. Not bad.The case is screwed together and has a serpentine rubber gasket. What about the push buttons, you might ask, wouldn't they leak? They appear to have tiny, little O-rings around them. So the whole thing might actually be water resistant.Improvements? The case is a little small for me, and I'd like to see more colors available, so when you have several around your neck it would be easier to find the one you need.I'd give it 4.5 stars if I could, but 5 is close enough. And it arrived surprisingly fast.

You want a high-nitrogen fertilizer to encourage the growth of foliage as plants are developing, and for growing plants that are only foliage such as herbs and leafy vegetables. But when blossoms appear and fruit sets, you want to switch to a low-nitrogen fertilizer to shift growth from leaves to fruit. You should keep on delivering water soluble trace minerals. This fertilizer is what you need in a low-nitrogen fertilizer and it contains trace minerals, too. Just don't over-do it. And I'm speaking of growing garden vegetables and fruit trees, in case there's any confusion. This is the lowest cost water soluble, low nitrogen fertilizer I have found, but I think it's over-priced based on its raw materials. What are ya gonna do?

It's the right size and it will stick where it needs to, but the mirror has poor optical quality, so only the center of the view is usefully free of distortion. I'm not talking the expected spherical distortion, I'm referring to additional distortion that whacks out the image around the edges where it doesn't seem like it needs to if a better mold were used to make the mirror. I'd lower the stars if the price were higher, but I guess I'll keep using it. I wonder if there isn't a similar product with a better mirror?

But it ain't cheap.I've more than paid for it, however, by making repairs that couldn't be made except by extraordinary means. Like fixing narrow structural cracks in fine furniture. Like sticking an endpiece on an ABS gutter system while high in the air. Like sticking the head on a chronically loosening mallet. The list goes on. The four different viscosities and the spray or brush activator seem to cover all the bases. Makes me hunt around for new projects.

Turns out this thing has all the features I was looking for: C/F done with an easy switch, timer, over-temp alarm, and long pointy probe. So far it works great and it allows me to measure the temp of things I'm cooking so easily that I do it more often. I've even used it to sous vide in my rice cooker, although that takes full-time monitoring with a finger on the cooker's "warm" switch.And it seems to be accurate: I checked it against three lab thermometers and a narrow-range lab reference mercury thermometer. Turns out one of my lab thermometers needed recalibrating, but the others and the Polder were within a C degree.

This book comes off as a write up of Google searches. It contains lots of interesting factiods, to be sure, and on the whole is worth the price, but it's neither a chemistry course nor a cooking course nor -- what you'd hope for -- a braiding of the two.It's not a biochem course, not even a lightweight one, as it doesn't build from first principals -- it just throws out whatever chemistry facts happen to pop up, some times at a basic level and sometimes at a very deep level -- too deep, I'd think, for most cooks. Neither is it a cooking/baking course (it mixes both), as again it doesn't build up an understanding from basic principals. So you get a chemistry fact, sometimes paired with a curious fact about cooking or baking. Then off to the next fact. Fortunately, it has a table of contents and a good index, so at least you can find the tidbits you might be looking for. Many times they are interesting, but not always.My degrees are in chemistry and I consider myself reasonable well read when it comes to gastronomy, so I enjoyed the book and read it completely. But I think if I were someone expecting to be lead through an understanding of basic food chemistry and simultaneously basic cooking/baking I would have been confused and disappointed. You'd come away with some facts, but I don't think you'd come away with an understanding of the chemistry of cooking or baking, and I don't think you'd become a better cook (or chemist).

I've been looking for a case for a netbook, but up to now they were either meant for a much larger laptop or they were too small to carry the accessories (AC adapter, wireless mouse, DVD drive, a few cables and USB drives). This one does the trick. It's not too big, as packing all the accessories in takes some effort, but they do fit. It's well-padded and seems well-made. Plus my daughter loves the colors.Recommended.

I'm a fan of Dr. Dawkins, but this book is a sorry mish-mash. It strikes me that he (or more likely someone else) wrote it by covering Post-It notes with his favorite invectives against religion, and then printing out various Google searches, and then pasting it all together and calling it a book. It has no structure, it has no development, it has no plot to be sure. Just a laundry list of silly beliefs and lame counters of weak "reality." More like reality TV. He never really explains "how we know what we know." It just comes off as "my claims are better than their claims."There's no new insight here (no insight at all, actually), just a thinly veiled attack on foolish things that believers believe. I agree with Dawkins' scathing opinions of religiosity, but I would have expected more from him than he delivered with this book. It doesn't belong in anyone's collection, believer or non-believer, but with Xmas approaching, my copy will soon belong in someone else's collection.

I've used Dexter knives since I was s short order cook in college, a very long time ago. They are great. They stay sharp, can be dumped in a powerful commercial dish washer, and they are light weight, so they are easy to use for long periods. I can't imagine using a heavy, cast "chef's" knife. Plus, in normal use a cook's knife gets sharpened so often that they only last a few months. Knives must be affordable, and this one is. The blade is nice and wide, too, so you can use it as a spatula rather than reaching for another tool. The fact that they are NSF-rated means that they can be sanitized in a dishwasher, whereas those wooden handled "chef's" knives have too many places for bacteria to hide, so they aren't NSF approved. The grip is easy to hold with wet or oily hands, and makes it easy to control the knife.Forget the Henkle, etc, skinny, heavy, impressive looking "chef's" knives and get the real deal.

I'd like to write a helpful review about the drivers disc, the nice tech support response, or the ease of editing the parameters to get it to function. But I can't.I plugged this unit into a Linux box (Ubuntu 11.04), powered up, and It Just Works (TM); no driver loading, no setup settings, none of that. Well, it works pretty good, too. Before, I was using a spendy Belkin USB wireless adapter on a short extender cable and saw two wireless networks. With the TP-Link on its included 5-foot cable I saw 7 networks, including a fire station over a mile away. My box's network icon now shows only two bars where the Belkin often reported three, so I'm guessing the Belkin had a high opinion of itself, whereas the TP-Link reported that it could handle more. But the number of signals tells the true story.Highly recommended.

Tried it on a Linux box and it appeared to be dead. Tried it on a Windows XP box and it didn't light it's LED but Windows did think it had a weird USB device installed but it still didn't work.A Belkin wireless USB adapter was plugged in to both boxes and It Just Worked (TM).This one's going back.

This unit is well-priced and has a good feature set. It switches easily from F to C, shows High, current Hold, and Lowest temps, has a weak LED back light of the readout, and shuts off automatically after a several seconds.No general purpose IR thermometer will be highly accurate, as they depend on the emissivity of the surface they are measuring. This is easy to see if you take a heat reservoir, such as a bucket of water, and measure a black patch on it vs a white patch, vs the actual temp of the water from a real thermometer. IR thermometers are calibrated to read a "typical" surface, whatever that is. Your skin, which is much cooler than your internal temp, would be a silly test, as would be a black body source, which aren't common in the real world. My La Crosse IR-101 is calibrated for a surface emissivity of .95 (a dark, non-reflective surface) and compensates for room temperature. It typically reads a few degrees low compared to a dial-type surface thermometer. No big deal.What I don't like is that it runs on four button cells, but you can find them on Amazon for less than $.25

I weighed this guy with a Mettler analytical balance, accurate to a milligram, and it weighed 100.000 grams. I think that's 10x better than it needs to be. Cheap, too.Mine wasn't scratched or corroded and didn't appear to have been touched by anything other than gloved Chinese hands.

Well, the answer is a bigger scale. But if you can deal with the 4x4 dimensions of this little guy, it's great, especially considering the price.Out of the box, I put a 100.000 g calibration weight on it and it gave me 100.0 g. Confidence building. It runs on two AAA batteries, not coin cell$. The automatic shutoff seems to be after a minute of no weight change, so tapping the weight appears to reset the shutoff timer.There are a few things to think about: definitely be sure to remove the two hidden pieces of cardboard under the stainless weighing platform and the plastic interrupter in the battery compartment (Doh!). Although it comes calibrated in firmware, should you ever need to recalibrate it, you'll need 1 kg and 2 kg calibration weights (!); don't lose the instruction "manual." It has a small illuminated readout, but no easy way to hold a reading that may be occluded by whatever is sitting on top of it -- like a big box, or even a little box. Just use a cheap plastic cup (tared) to raise larger objects. It has six little bumps on its underside that count for feet, so you need to use it on a fairly flat surface.Other than those points -- highly recommended.

Every family should have some packets of Oral Rehydration Salts around, for when diarrhea eventually hits. Pedialyte and store knockoffs have too low sodium and too high osmolarity, and kids hate the taste. Unfortunately, the World Health Organization ORS packets offered on Amazon are not the newer low-osmolarity formula, which has been around for over ten years. The CeraLyte 70, 50 g packets do have the right formula; they use maltodextrine in the form of rice syrup to deliver more calories without raising the osmolarity, and they're flavored. Problem is they cost North of $4.50 per liter packet, whereas all around the world you can buy WHO ORS packets for less than $.50 and it's easy to make your own with readily available items like Morton Lite salt and dextrose bought on Amazon.

My recommendation for avoiding louse infestations is simple: collect everything you need to deal with one. It has worked for me without exception. Other parents who are unprepared seem always to get infestations; not we. But seriously, when my kid's friends have gotten lice I've used the comb to search for lice and found that the comb works better than the plastic versions insofar as going through fine hair with conditioning is concerned. So far: no lice, but no parent should expect that to persist.

Don't let your young artist use similar colors. The caps and bodies are not numbered, so if you try to put them back together you're essentially doing a color-blindness test. The cap colors only approximate the delivered colors. The tips are conical, about 3/16 inch diameter at the base. I hope they are indeed washable, and from human skin as well as fabric. I put all this to my young artist, who responded: "Who cares!"

The Reading and Writing Sourcebook series is really excellent. The authors understand how to attract the learning mind. They offer many entry points into the skills of reading and writing, even providing lines alongside the reading text and encouraging students to write notes or draw pictures. Even to write or draw in the text! The colorful illustrations are part of the lessons. In each lesson (of 16, say) there is a well-chosen excerpt to read and think about. There are exercises to get the student ready for the writing challenge, and there's a vocabulary building exercise. Then there's a short writing prompt eventually touching on all types of writing, including poetry.These books would be perfect for home schooling or to put some substance in the lameness that passes for learning to read and write in most schools. Students can work through the lessons on their own; there's no need to teach. These books turned my daughter from a reluctant writer to a confident, expressive writer who looks forward to the next lesson. I have recommended these books to other parents and teachers to universal acclaim. I'm mystified as to why they are not better known or available from Amazon. When you can find one at a reseller for $5, grab it!

They offer many entry points into the skills of reading and writing, even providing lines alongside the reading text and encouraging students to write notes or draw pictures. I had one of these for many years until the handle connection failed -- small hands at work, methinks. But it worked so well that, after looking over all the others, I decided simply to replace it. What can you say about a cheese grater (a lot, judging by the other reviews)? It's dishwasher safe. It grates fine and coarse (I've seldom used the slicer), which is what you need for hard and softer cheeses. It comes in a weird, purplish shade of white. It's only slightly overpriced. It gets, almost, to the last little bit of cheese (which I retrieve by turning the handle backwards and then pitch to the dog). If you tip it, you can fill its cup with grated fromage and then artfully dump it on your guests' spaghetti. It's Energy Star rated. It's doubtless made in a Chinese factory on the upper slopes.

This is an excellent text for teaching problem solving, in my opinion the main reason to learn and enjoy mathematics. It seems to me that it goes beyond "school" mathematics, though it fits well with Singapore Math, and could help set kids up for math competitions, such as Math Kangaroo and MOEMS. The book offers a methodological approach to solving problem of many kinds rather than computational skills. The best way to teach complex material is by way of worked examples, and that's how this book goes at it -- very successfully. And fortunately for us teachers, the answers to challenge problems are in the back.
