I became so engrossed in their stories, which is a testament to how solidly crafted the characters were.  In their quest to find answers to their most troubling questions, Julianna and Wyatt occasionally cross paths, but not in a way that seems too contrived. The conclusion isnt tidy, but it is certainly intriguing and satisfying, with both characters coming to terms with their tragic histories.I received a complimentary copy of this book via TLC Blog Tours.

Faber has written an unusual, thought-provoking, and wholly original novel.  Missionary Peter is sent to the planet Oasis to minister to the native population. A mysterious corporation has created a settlement on Oasis and it takes a rare individual to endure the isolated environment there. The strange new world Peter encounters is mesmerizing; barren and desolate yet wondrous and beautiful.  The book isn't straight science fiction nor overtly theological, but incorporates elements of both.  Peter struggles with his mission, conflicted about the wife he left behind and the alien race he serves.Despite the challenges of living among the extraterrestrials on another planet, Peter learns more about human nature than he ever did ministering on Earth.  His experiences are haunting and surreal, the atmosphere is incredibly written.  I was mildly disappointed that there seemed to be unresolved issues and unanswered questions, but that just added to the overall mystery of Oasis.I received a complimentary copy of this book from the Publisher.

I got this book for my husband for Christmas, as we are both huge Simpsons nerds.  I read the whole thing cover to cover in just a couple of hours and found myself laughing out loud and some of my favorite quotes.  The book focuses on the chronological history of Homer and the Simpsons family (like a scrapbook), but what I found most interesting was how Groening incorporated the more obscure episodes from their past (90s grunge scene).  There are several flashback episodes that are presented (Lisas fist word, Homers dream job), and it all flows together seamlessly.  With beautiful illustrations and a fun layout, this is a must-have for any Simpsons fan.

I was excited by the idea of ONan writing about a quintessential American author, but I was disappointed that he chose the most unexciting and depressing period of Fitzgeralds life.  With Zelda shut away in an asylum and their Jazz-age days behind them, Scott is trying to renew his career in Hollywood.  He attempts writing for movies, only to get taken off projects and denied credit.  Broke and boring, Scott begins an affair with gossip columnist Sheilah and his existence centers around schmoozing studio executives for his next job and staying sober.  He occasionally shuttles back east to reunite with Zelda and their daughter, which only reminds him of how depressing his life has become.  Besides working sporadically and fighting with Sheilah after drunken relapses, he hobnobs with stars like Humphrey Bogart.  Theres plenty of name-dropping and extolling the Hollywood scene, but when war breaks out in Europe, those things become trivial.While it was a well-written depiction of Fitzgeralds final years, it just wasnt a captivating novel.  Witnessing Scotts decline was somewhat tedious.  I would have rather read more about the literary scene (although Hemingway does make a cameo) than Hollywood in the late 30s.

This book is not for everyone for several reasons.  First, it is very stylized, with a stream of conscious narrative.  And that becomes even more cumbersome when it is from the perspective of chimpanzees.  Plus dialogue is not distinguished by quotes.  Second, it deals with animal testing, and the cruelty that the chimpanzees endure may be disturbing to some readers.  Finally, theres the basic understanding that chimpanzees are wild animals and that keeping them as pets is dangerous.  The inherent violence that is a consequence of keeping chimps in a domestic environment is presented in a brutal way.Judy and Walt are childless, and figure that adopting a chimp is the next best thing to being parents.  But as Looee gets older and larger, the inevitable happens when his animal instincts take over and he attacks humans.  He spends the next 14 years in a research facility, being tested, injected, sedated, and kept in a cage.  Eventually he is introduced to a population of other chimps and he had to learn to interact with unfamiliar animals.  Its a unique perspective as it attempts to demonstrate the social structure of chimp society.  I was disappointed that I didnt get to know more about Judy and Walts lives after their world was shattered.  I really wanted to know how the people attacked recovered from their grave injuries and how they learned to adjust to life after Looee.  It is not an easy book to read because of the style and the subject, but I must say that it is original.

Delving into the mind of a serial killer always makes for a fun read.  But this book went in a totally different direction than I initially thought.  What started as a gruesome portrayal of dismemberment and caged victims turned into a dark comedy when Mr. Murderer falls in love.  The meticulous, merciless deviant seems detached from reality and emotion until he meets Rachel.  When he is smitten, he is careless, and that won't fly when the police come asking questions.  He tries desperately to curb his bloodlust, but one of his victims is causing trouble for him and his sloppiness is causing suspicion.  The conclusion was bizarre and intense, and the ending was left to the reader's imagination.  Will he be found out or will he get away with it?  As much as I wanted to know the answer to the question, the ambiguity of his fate was very well done.

I went into this thinking that Doughty would expose all things sordid and gory about the death industry.  While there were plenty of anecdotes illustrating the grim realities of cremation and body disposal (I wouldnt recommend reading the chapter about dead babies during dinner), it wasnt quite as in-your-face as I anticipated.  I give the girl props  to immerse herself in the business of dying as a profession takes gumption.  Her morbid curiosity of death and the macabre comes off as purposeful, if quirky.  Her humor isnt knee-slapping hilarious, but Doughty is clever and witty.  This book is really her own crusade to alleviate the stigma surrounding death and to advocate alternative practices in the funeral industry.  The standards we have come to believe as normal in the 20th century arent necessarily a requirement.  It was definitely an insightful and compelling perspective that engages the reader to consider their mortality.

I was completely enamored with this book  Until the final pages.  The conclusion completely threw me.  It wasnt bad by any means, but I didnt expect Picoult to venture into M. Night Shyamalan territory.  The supernatural element took the entire plot and flipped it on its head.  You have to suspend disbelief, because although the mystery presented in the preceding pages came together, the psychic connections were a little too convenient.Back to the book.  The mystery centers around an elephant sanctuary and a tragedy that occurred there ten years ago.  Picoult succeeds with the elephant narrative where she fell short in Lone Wolf.  The most engaging aspect of the novel was learning about what intelligent creatures elephants are.  I enjoyed the quirky characters: a 13 year old girl whos too smart for her own good, a psychic whose gifts have abandoned her, and a dead beat alcoholic P.I.  The unlikely trio team up to discover what really happened at the elephant sanctuary a decade before.  What they discover about the incident and themselves is devastating.  I dont know whether Picoult fans will appreciate the direction she went here, but it was certainly creative and unexpected.

I initially began reading this book sequentially but found myself skipping around to read topics that were of particular interest to me: the JFK assassination, the Lindbergh baby, Hiroshima and Nagasaki.  There were other subjects I completely skipped over.  I didn't really care if Rachel Jackson was a bigamist or whether Daniel Boone was a traitor.  But I must say I did enjoy what I read and was intrigued by a few topics I previously knew nothing about (Amelia Earhart, Salem Witch Trials, Cortez and the Aztec, Iran-contra) .  I liked that each subject was relatively brief (4-8 pages) and delving into an individual story wasn't too time consuming.  I read snippets here and there over the course of a couple weeks and, though I'm not an American History buff by any means, found I learned a good deal about the nation's secrets.

Once again, Gabriel Allon is recruited to rectify the unfathomable crimes of The Holocaust.  This time, its personal.  Not only has his dear friend and fellow agent been targeted by an assassin, the culprit also appears to be his mothers own tormenter, a ruthless Nazi whom she encountered during the Death March.  But proving the identity of the war criminal wont be easy as the paper trail is so misleading.  It is Gabriels mothers testimony that is the driving force of this novel (be warned, its incredibly heartbreaking).  Though I wasnt quite as captivated by this book as others in the series, I did appreciate how it revealed another level of Gabriels tortured soul and tragic past.

This novel is the perfect example of why Im a McEwan fan.  He delivers shock factor like no other author.  It started a bit slow, but once I got about 25 pages in and the perfunctory cold war rhetoric was out of the way the plot picked up.  I really liked the main character, Leonard, who initially comes off as timid, yet proper.  He is very aware of his Englishness, especially when hes around his American colleagues, but once he meets Maria, she brings out some confidence in him.  As he begins his first love affair, he is also participating in a secret operation to tunnel into the Russian sector of Berlin and tap into the communist communication lines.It is the last third of the book that had me completely captivated.  Without giving too much away, I will say that Leonard and Maria get themselves into quite a situation and the way they deal with it is quite shocking.  Then Leonard goes a little crazy and every time he made a decision contrary to his initial plan, I wanted to shout into the book, Seriously Leonard?!  What are you thinking?!  McEwan creates the most absurd circumstance and allows his characters to do the most insane things and its ever so much fun.  I think The Innocent is one of my favorites in McEwans repertoire and Im a little bit sad that now Ive officially read everything hes published.  Then again, Im glad I save the best for last.

This set of sheets is pretty impressive, since it tells us upfront that it is 200 thread count--which on shopping channels implies old time feed sack quality.  Think again. These are soft and smooth, with a mild sateen finish, generously sized with deep hems. I will use these, and like another reviewer, not hesitate to order more for myself or gifts. The graphite color is a pale gray like a silver car, nowhere near the color of a pencil point--suitable as any neutral. They washed nicely and dried quickly, and brought to mind the great percale of my youth.

As one who considers the volume, "Consider the ForK" one of my all-time favorite books, I expected to be intrigued by this book, but even I was wonderfully surprised. While it has 470 pages, the writing style is concise, and the black and white illustrations add a great deal, and it is packed with all kinds of information that can be accessed. There are two tables of contents:  one by chapter and the other by recipe, not to mention an index, so a cook or reader can find what is needed. The contributors include our friends from America's Test Kitchen, which ranks high on this household's choices on Prime Video on Demand, besides the usual PBS. The book can be enjoyed either straight through, or dipped into by surprise or specific topic. The print size is not tiny and is black-on-white, so it can be enjoyed by those with older eyes. It is heavy enough that it lies pretty flat when open on the lap or table.

This a very fragile toy. One needs a very thin phillips screwdriver to get the car out of the packaging. It requires 2 AAA batteries and 2 AA batteries to hopefully work. The instructions are in very small print. After carefully  going through all these processes, including installing the antenna and aligning the wheels, the car did not run with either sets of good batteries. This is not the answer to anyone's gift list.

Having this book fall into my hands during the broadcast of "Home Fires" (reflections on WWII England) probably enhanced my enjoyment, but it would be a pleasure whatever the season. Every family deserves an interpreter of chronicles as gifted and astute as Ian Buruma, but few are so blessed. His editing of his grandparents' correspondence is deft, and the research and personal experiences he uses to enrich his material are touching. I felt I became acquainted with the whole circle, and appreciate his sharing them. I was swept into the picture with his first chapter which described the wonderful Christmas celebrations of his youth, about two decades after the trauma of World War II. Then, getting the backstory from 1915 is remarkable. There are twists and turns enough for anybody, from the poignantly gripping (cherishing refugee children) to the determinedly proper (consuming mayonnaise misserved instead of custard). This is biography, memoir, and letters at their best.

These fit true to size, and the flexible fit does allow for some mild expansion. They produce no panty line. At the present price for four pair, they are a tremendous value. They would be purchased again, which is a true recommendation.

The target readership for this book is middle graders, and it is right on point. There is enough of a supernatural element to appeal without any dark overtones, in spite of a locale next to a cemetery. The characters are challenged with sorrow, physical handicaps, economic woes and the cares of us all, but these are surmountable. Children of any age--not to mention the rest of us--are feeling their way to find their place in their circles, both family and community, and this story deals with that issue realistically, and ultimately with triumph. The people are likable:  the good guys are good guys, and the bad buys are not deviant. I do not hesitate to offer this book to anybody who reads well enough to either read it for oneself, or as a readaloud, down to age eight.

I am a real fan of Lamaze toys for baby, so was thrilled to be offered this one to evaluate.This one is targeted for 9 months plus, so its purpose is not so much 'cuddly with engaging noise and texture' as 'interactive and visually grabbing'. It is the size of two softballs, and they are hard (because they contain the electronics) but not heavy. Of the appendages, the feet do nothing, and one paw does nothing. The triple ears and one paw contain activating buttons, and the tummy lights up. (I wish the tummy could be turned on to glow as a night light  for about ten minutes, but that is not an option.) It talks in four languages, and to opt for one language, the electronics in the body must be dealt with. One left ears play 12 seconds of cheerful music, and one right ear play 12 seconds of sleepy music. This one is only surface washable, because of its electronic component, but by nine months plus a child will not have to chew everything in his/her explorations, so it should stay clean enough. I would consider it is as engaging as a busy box or board book, but it will probably not be a prime 'lovey'. This is a real beginning toy.If your little one has had a Lamaze toy at a younger age, this one makes a familiar transition to more complicated playthings.

This is my fourth set of tongs, and I do not barbecue. I use them for other kitchen chores, and to reach things all over the house. Two sets are shorter than this, and one is the same size. This is a premium tool because it has silicone tips that are nearly filled with metal reinforcement, so they  hold tightly, and they have silicone strips right where one instinctively holds them to use. The best part is a hanging loop at the end--something lacking on my other three sets. This is the size I use to get stuff out of the washer and dryer, besides other long reach places.

A good can opener can be hard to find--either they twist too hard, gather gunk, refuse to give up the can and lid without drizzling, etc. I have been using a Kitchenaid can opener for years, but was ready for a new model because I think it may be getting dull. I even ordered another model well reviewed and sent it back because it was too hard to turn. Along comes THIS RED MODEL:  It takes up exactly the same space as the old one, even though it looks flatter. The new one is not shiny--metal is matte, and so is the plastic handle cover. The handle is hard, no silicone give to it. It nicely opens a can with an ordinary amount of turning pressure. My hands are old but not crippled, and I can turn it fine (not like the reject I sent back). The bonus feature is the magnet on the tip. There is a tag attached to explain how to use it, and it works great. When the can is open, unfasten the jaws and use the tip of the opener to lift off the can lid without having to touch the lid or fish it out of the contents. Some reviews mention getting duds that did not list long. This does have a one year warranty that should cover that. It is mentioned on the card the opener is ziptied to. NICE!

This would get rate five stars, except it comes without a ribbon or string to hang it on the tree. That seems a bit skimpy for a so-called "keepsake" quality ornament, that would likely be presented for a true fan of Star Trek.

I live in rural America and spent six years in a mobile home, besides teaching at all levels in public schools. The segment depicted in this book, while present in the 1990s, is not typical of life in the USA--even in these economically challenging times. The group at a dance is described as sorting itself out by "genes, marriages, or restraining orders". While those are legitimate guidelines, most people are not quite as depraved, hapless, and sordid as the ones gathered in these pages. I picked this book to read and review because it purported to be lighthearted. I read it all, and the change never came. At the end of the year, (SPOILER ALERT) the good guy became the first grave in a new cemetery and the other folks continued in their ruts--both in terms of trenches and deer behavior. Small town America deserves better.

As a long-time packer of lunches, this item is a great addition to the reusable collection. It is sturdy, being made of slightly thicker material than most lunch containers. There are no seams to catch drips or scraps. It microwaves nicely, and it fits comfortably in a lunch bag, having a 4 inch diameter and 4.5 inch height. It is not huge, but it is enough of two  things for lunch, be it soup and crackers, soup and salad, casserole and salad, or something and dessert. It just works.

This construction is substantial. At the top of the page it says 29x17. No. The base is a 29 inch square, and the whole thing does weigh right at 50 pounds. The parts are sturdy. It took two of us about half hour to assemble it, balancing, turning, sorting pieces, etc. The instructions, which are pictures only, no words, do say assemble all towers, then attach to each other, and finally screw to base. That balancing is tricky. We did get it together, dabbed the different platforms with catnip crumbs, and let Sir Picky at it. He weights about 16 pounds, and just does fit it. The whole thing takes up the space of an occasional chair, so be prepared.

This pair of gloves just does fit the man of the house, who wears extra large in winter and work gloves. They are heat resistant to the point that wrestling a turkey is easily doable on a charcoal grill. The reason for four stars is the One Size Fits All aspect. If they came in average and extra large, we would have opted for extra large, and they would clearly be an overall superior product.

This is the kind of book that puts flesh on the bones of history. The book was written with love by Noel Streatfeild about her father's family nanny, but the love that shines through--as it should--is the devotion of Emily Buckwell to her nurslings. It begins in the 1870s, and its perspective is strictly that of Emily, whose life's work is to provide her instinctive 'cuddles' to her charges. From the day and night nurseries, it is surprising how much drama comes into the tale, in spite of Emily's efforts to keep everything stable, serene, not 'overexcited'.I don't consider it a 'spoiler' to say that with careful reading outside the book, I figured out that Noel Streatfeild is Victoria, second daughter of the eldest son. I found it a page-turner, and being a fan of Downton Abbey does help.

THIS REVIEW IS FOR THE PERSONAL SIZE  MODEL THAT RUNS ON A WATER BOTTLE. Small is the operative word, but it works like its bigger brothers. The footprint is 4 inches by 5 inches. It immediately starts spewing cool vapor from its turnable spout, when it is turned on, and adjusts easily from no-vapor to lots. Instead of having any kind of tank, you use a typical personal-size water bottle. For my test, I used a bottle of Niagara-brand water which has a half-depth cap and flimsy sides. The short neck was no problem--just pushed it on the adapter, got a perfect seal, upended the bottle, turned it own, and away it worked.While a personal water bottle will not run forever, I like knowing the exact age of the opened bottle of water in the little machine. This helps keep 'old' water from being present to possibly grow any kind of mold. (My mother sickened once years ago with that situation.)The little device is very quiet--about like an electric clock.  I am sitting about six feet away, and I can definitely tell it is changing the air. It will be perfect near a bed or chair, where one family needs some extra humidification without turning the whole house into the tropics. There is no reason to use a new bottle of bought water, either, every time. One can easily refill an empty bottle with filtered water from the fridge door, or distilled water from a larger jug, or just plain tap.

THIS IS A NEW, IMPROVED VERSION OF BROWN SUGAR KEEPER FROM PREPWORKS, and it is EVER NICER than the two I already own. This one is latched in dark grey (instead of red), and the inset seal is even tighter than the previous version, but it still easy enough to open, even for my medicare-eligible hands. Note that the terra cotta disk is to be soaked in water, to add the moisture to keep the sugar soft. It does hold a two-pound bag of sugar, and these stack perfectly, if you get multiples to store other baking items--and I want them all!.

Another winner, and a visit with old friends. If one has read the other books in the series, this one moves the tale along through life in every satisfying way. Like others, I was inspired to go back and reread earlier volumes.

These are priced all over the map, both here at Amazon and in local stores. Totally disregarding price, but considering the quality and palatability of  the dog cookie as both a treat and breath freshener, it is a winner. It is  size that is suitable for any dog above six pounds. In spite of it smelling like eucalyptus straight from the package, my four come running for it. It is too hard for me to break with my hands, but they have no trouble gnawing it away in about ten minutes per biscuit. The 22.9 ounce amount of biscuits will just about fill a quart jar, to give an idea of how much is in a bag.

These were an immediate hit with four different kinds of dogs between twelve and twenty-five pounds. To get enough, I broke one for the two least ones to share. It smells like dog food, but is not strongly cloying. As a chew, it lasted about thirty minutes, and they loved every second. It has a strange triple-boomerang shape that is easy to chew on both sides of the dog's mouth, that seemed to work well.

If one is living where the local water has issues, and is not blessed with filtered water from the refrigerator, then this is a premium pitcher for home use. It holds eleven cups, which is just shy of three quarts--larger than lots of filter pitchers. What really makes this a winner is the shape of the pitcher. It is tall, but narrow, so it will fit on the door of most refrigerators. The handle is comfortable and generously sized, so the center of gravity makes it easy to use the pitcher, even for a child of about seven. The instructions say wash before using, and you will because it comes smelling like new toys, but that dissipates with the washing. The loose cover to pour in the water has a learning curve to keep it from falling into the body, but it is a quick lesson, and not to be taken as a discouragement.

This is so heavy, it will be most useful if the party is in your own home, but it deserves five stars, anyway. It comes with 20 various recipes that look appetizing, and using it with your own recipes presents no problem, as long as the batch will fit in 1.5 quarts. It is perfectly glazed cast iron--I could find no specks or bubble in the model sent to me. The base is also sturdy, and cooks at low, medium, and high. The tea-light stand is also stable. I do not perceive any safety issues, except someone touching the heated base, and that is true of any heated appliance--and there is a small warning note printed on it. Being cast iron, one can also use it on the stovetop or in the oven, if one has the strength to move it. Notice there are handles to grip it with potholders. The color is vivid, and it will serve as a cookie jar very nicely, when not cooking.

I opted to read this book because it purported to contain humor and imagination, plotted with fantasy. I read hard and kept waiting for the humor to come forth--did not happen. The supporting characters were grouchy and rude, and the main character was rather frantic, even though I kept trying to like her. The best character was an imaginary monster, cleverly named 'Monster', no less. The strongest part of the 375 page book was the last 20%, but getting there was contrived and dreary. I do not see this book as reaching its intended audience, to my disappointment.

The kibble is the smallest I have seen in dry cat food--the size of an 81 grain 'baby' aspirin, and this is no disadvantage. Our cat took to it immediately and has suffered no change-over ill-effects. I wish the bag was resealable, or zippable, but it is a good heavy foil that will be air-tight, folded over and clipped. The ingredient list is superb.

The space required is 18 inches by 36 inches, and must be within three feet of a power source (outlet or power strip) because it runs on a black thing with a wire, like a recharger. Assembly was fairly intuitive, due to the picture on the box. The included instructions were extremely small print in grayscale on thin paper--to the point of calling for a magnifying glass. Included with the kit is one foam piece (postcard size) that fits into the cover for the waste which is said to be odor controlling for 30 days. It does not smell itself and I do not see how it will add anything. Also included are two thin (think grocery sack) bags 6x14x6 to use one at a time to line the waste receptacle. We are not told where to buy more, however, I think we can substitute a piece of wax paper, typing paper, or a trimmed grocery bag to ease emptying the dish. The waste pan is attached to the whole thing, so one cannot just pick it loose, dump it, and pop it back. It does have to be attached, too, because of how the rake flips the lid to deposit the waste. There is a fill line on the littler box, and not very much litter is required to work. There is no litter waste, because the rake only moves waste clumps--the litter stays neatly behind. The amount of waste that can be stored in the tray is about the same as fits into the Omega Paw drawer we are used to using.As mentioned, we have been using the Omega Paw for a year, so our cat is used to having a covered box. The instructions with the Healthy Home do outline a plan for transitioning. We just replaced the Omega Paw with the new system, which has no cover, and watched to see what happened. The rake timer can be set to rake at 1 hour, 4 hours, or 8 hours. We set it for 8 hours, since we only have the one cat. The cat looked longingly at his old box (empty of litter and facing the wall), and did use the new box, and has continued to do so, with no complaints (and he would complain if he wanted to--cats do make opinions known). The box sits there neatly raked, and the only way to know it is used is by flipping the waste lid and peeking inside.I cannot say how long the motor will last, of course, but it really does offer a clean open box all the time, and an easy enough way to dispose of the clumps (be sure to use clumping litter). I will keep the Omega Paw to return to, if this one quits. This system is pricey, but it does stay neat and will not need to be tended to any more often than once a week, if need be. Our former box got rolled about every other day.

This toy has a good deal going for it. Of course, it runs on batteries--4 AA, and it comes with short-life, non-alkaline is place, so it can be used right out of the box. The instructions were well-hidden, but necessary, under the sub-floor of the packaging. They explain that it comes turned up to its maximum sensitivity, so it detects everything--even the nails under the carpet in the floor.  Once you adjust the sensor down a bit, the fun begins. It really does sense metal, so stuff can be hidden under a rug or blanket for indoor explorations. Where it really shines is in a sandbox, because things can be hidden and retrieved. The white scoop is perforated in the bottom, so the sand can be sifted through, to leave the find in the bucket. It rolls freely and is light. I would suggest this for ages four to seven, at least. This does not duplicate any other toy I have seen, and has a good deal of creative play value. The packaging is bigger, but it will fit in a shoebox.

This beautiful and comprehensive not-just-coffee book is loaded with both information and charm. It is the size (9x8x1.5) of a family cookbook with color pictures and readable print. The pages are not slick. The book is full of informative and fun data, including anecdotes germane to helping one remember what is read. The arrangement through the seasons is thoughtful. I will be reading this with a highlighter, to mark things that catch my eye, even with a lifetime of experience of managing a home. Homemaking is the job where we never learn it all. In spite of all the stuff on the internet, it is still a pleasure to have something in the lap or on the tabletop to think about and act upon.

The highpoint of any reading season for me is another Phil Gulley book, whether his wicked satirical fiction or spiritual insights. This is another winner, with visits and revisits with old acquaintances, friends and enemies, and a few new folks in the congregation. A nonstop read.

I really like this interchangeable teether-age puzzle, which has three vividly colorful animals. There are some surface colors that are applied to the base color, and I was concerned that these colors might gnaw off by a teether. I did not gnaw it myself, and my testing child has not had it long enough to get it off--but I did claw and scrape at it with a nail file and scissors blades, and I can say the color spots did not mar or budge. My evaluation of four stars instead of five is due to the size.  If the scale were about 3/4 as large as what they are, they would be easier for the intended age child to handle, whether chewing or interchanging. After they come apart, they do go back together, but it takes a bit of oomph to get the parts seated, which may be beyond the dexterity of the youngest players, but they will grow into it. These just sit--there is no loop to attach the pieces to anything to keep them off the floor or getting away from the play area, either. They are certainly washable in a dishwasher.

As it appears, this basket is totally waterproof and sturdily sewn. There are eight pockets around the outside that would hold a water bottle each, for reference. The inside space is about like a lunch box.  It is perfect to bring a little organization to any spot in the living space:  not only shower, but laundry space, beside a chair or bed, odd tools under the sink or in a vehicle, toys to go to daycare, etc. It is all web, so no water is going to collect anywhere---unlike the ice cream buckets we took to the showers when I was in college in the late 1960s. This would also make a thoughtful gift for someone in a nursing or assisted living facility, too.

These razors are my personal multi-bladed gold standard for personal use. Some others may be "as good", but most are not, at any price point. Not only are they effective without nicking or scraping tender skin, but the shades of color make it easy to know whose is whose in a multiuser household or dorm situation, but which is the "newest", if one is the single person household. Getting 8 in a pack is also handy.

I thought I had read all of Ms. Aldrich's books years ago, but this one had slipped through the cracks--and it is well worth getting second-hand from the United Kingdom, if necessary. This one was written "contemporary" in the 1920's, unlike some of her others that are pioneer stories. However, the dynamics of families do not change, and this one is spot-on, whomever of the group is the main character, chapter by chapter. Whether it is a small-town bazaar, a school program, separate family vacations, or a "New Broom in Town", the scenarios are both familiar and with twists that are thoroughly entertaining. Another reviewer mentioned it as a family read-a-loud, and it would be as good as Rebecca Caudill's Fairchild Family, and Laura Ingalls Wilder--high praise, indeed.

I was unfamiliar with this writer, but decided to take a chance--and the reading pleasure is mine. I am sorry to come to his writings this late, but that is okay. Succinct, tongue-in-cheek, from the heart--it is plain to see why he was awarded the Thurber prize, among others. I thank his editors for bringing this together and making it available for a growing audience.

As the owner of multiple dogs and one cat, we work hard to keep ahead of parasites. Some years, and seasons within years are harder than others, and some strains of parasites are more tenacious, too. That said, this brand comes at a very good price point. I have had success with it, rotating it with other brands if I felt one or the other was beginning to lose the battle. I will buy it again, especially for winter months.
This razor compares well with the 5-blade models of other brands. The handle is smooth, so might be slippery, but not a danger or a reason to avoid.

This was consumed both black and with cream and sugar by various testers. All commented on the pleasant scent. The flavor was good, without the slight bitterness that is often present with K-Cup beverages.

I, too, have read other books by Homer Hickam. I think this is every bit as engaging as his earlier offerings in different ways. The plot of this one is the way family stories are not told in one session, but are revealed layer by layer over the course of our lives by several narrators for different reasons--and we are just lucky if we ever really get to the ending. At the beginning of Chapter 23, Mr. Hickam writes, "Elsie had always felt her life was life a jigsaw puzzle with no picture on the box to show her how the puzzle pieces should fit together." Most of us can identify with those sentiments. This book of eleven sections is touching, funny, and convoluted. It reminds me of Southern novels I read growing up, which are not easy to find anymore--but refreshing when they turn up. If the movie, "Secondhand Lions" struck a cord with you, this novel is likely to do the same. Albert did not live in vain.

These treats are the size of a Jolly Rancher. They are not dusty, but were consumable by two dogs with older teeth. All four dogs in my test group ate two readily, and came back looking for more. The three primary ingredients are barley, molasses, and rice. The home base for the company is Massachusetts, with no mention where the treats are manufactured. the secondary language on the label is French. They are in a reclosible box and sealed in a plastic bag that is not zip-closed. The odor is not too strong, with the slightest hint of the molasses, and holding them does not leave a scent on hands, like bacon flavor treats does. I will look for these to treat my group.

While I was shopping hard for a sturdy, heavy-duty chair at a reasonable price, this one seemed too good to be true.  There are also some reviews with caveats. Well, I have had the chair for a month and have waited to review, expecting something unpleasant to happen. Nothing unpleasant has developed. The chair is bigger than most, and so is the delivery box--also heavier. In spite of that, I assembled it myself to the point of setting the seat onto the base (I am more than somewhat infirm, too.) While it is large, it is not so huge that it looks outside in its space. A complaint of previous chairs with my weight is that the pneumatics give out and the seat collapses so near the floor I became stranded. This will not happen here, because it is high enough to use comfortably and arise at its lowest point. The seat is truly 25 inches wide, and that is what I wanted. The arms are unpadded, but look okay. The seat is comfortable enough, and not so thick it trips me as I sit down--a personal scenario true with thicker, puffier models. For a heavy-duty chair, the price is phenomenal, even paying some extra shipping fees that some suppliers add.

This is an extremely effective spot cleaner (and I have used at least a dozen kinds over the pet owning years). The first spot tested (urine) came up so fast, it disappeared before I could mark it for reference. The second test area was on berber at the edge of a study door mat, where grime tends to gather and linger. We spritzed, let stand, watched the streak lighten, grubbed over it with a towel, and left a clean area that matched the rest of the carpet with the grime on a towel. Note that there was no bleaching effect, where sometimes a 'cleaner' spot is left--the spots just disappeared. Minimal scent, but pleasant. Enough said.

Having read several of Antonia Fraser's books of history, I jumped at the opportunity to read this, to review. As the title says, she and her mother were avid noters, correspondents,  and diarists, with memories like traps, and she has chronicled the 20th century from her always age-appropriate perspective. The whole book is readable, down-to-earth, and tongue-in-cheek, besides. Especially touching is the chapter about her coming to faith and formally embracing the Catholic faith during her early teens at school in Ascot. She tells her tale from her viewpoint (with a memoir she should), but like her historical writings, she is careful to be as unbiased as possible and shed light that has come forth in later years that was not knowable at the time of occurrence. That is the beauty of living a long life--we get to see the ending for some stories. If a reader has enjoyed her other books, this one is a personal triumph. As a footnote, this was the first time I had heard that Oxford was not Hitler's target because he expected to possess it. Creepy, creepy, and not the only example of things I learned reading this one like mad.

This game is a winner for the targeted audience (4+) It comes in a sturdy, slick, cardboard box that is just at 11x11x2. It should hold up better than cheap uncoated boxed that smack of flimsy. The contents  are bright and attractive, and plastic coated, so they can easily be wiped clean, if need be. There is a warning about choking hazard for 3 and under, but the apple/balls are really pretty good sized, at over an inch in diameter. The game can be played by two to four people. The pieces are easy to set up, and can be done by a 4 year old. The rules are minimal and not frustrating. The minimum moves to complete a game is five for each player, so the games will not last too long--we can play again, and maybe win the next time, etc.Learning to behave appropriately while game-playing is an important developmental landmark--Kindergarten progress reports have "Plays well with others" for a reason. We cooperate, share, win and lose gracefully, take turns, encourage, and clean up after ourselves. This game promotes all these positive skills for the beginners among us, but would be fun for fourth graders to play during recess, too. (As a teacher for all this age-range, I know.)Finally, it will not bore the mind out of the parent, grandparent, caregiver, or older sibling playing, so we can stand to play just one more round. That may be the best part, since the whole exercise of game playing--in addition to the traits listed above--is interacting with each other and learning together.

This new cleaning configuration has all positive attributes. The cord is longer than the usual length on stick-type floor vacs and steamers. The storage footprint is upright and about 6 x 12 inches on the floor, so it will tuck into a pantry, corner, or behind a door. It REALLY DOES VACUUM AND STEAM CLEAN THE FLOOR IN ONE STEP. The steam feature does take about 90 seconds to heat, instead of the 30 in the instructions, but that is okay. The vacuum is powerful, in our case picking up bread crumbs, baking dust, pet hair and cat litter in a kitchen and utility room. There were six ounces of water left after completing the job. The vacuum cup was easily emptied, with lots of pet hair on the filter, which is easy to pop off, I am very arthritic, and use an office chair to navigate my kitchen. This appliance can be used by me, working from my chair.

This bottle of cleaner uses one or two caps of cleaner per fillup of rug-cleaning machine, depending on your judgment as to dirtiness. Using the two caps mixture, it will make about 20 gallons of cleaner, which would be at least three to four large rooms of carpet--certainly as much as I would want to do at one time with a rental machine. For testing purposes, I used a Bissell home machine and was pleased with the results. The scent is very mild and non-chemical, as these cleaners go. The instructions say to shake the bottle to mix the ingredients, which make it look milky-like soda and water.

This rates in the top three hand/body creams I am used, and it is really nice for cuticles. I have diabetic legs, and it is good for retaining moisture there, too. The scent is very mildly herbal--mild enough not to compete with cologne or some other product that one would rather be the primary note. It also keeps skin hydrated for longer than most products--no constant reaching to apply several times a day.

If there is an aspect of our lives where  we may tend to get a bit carried away, the holidays are probably it. These zippy narratives from the author's life beginning with her childhood and extending through her children's celebrations at her hands "tell it like it is." The sad thing is, the holidays in the United States are so overdone that exaggerated satire reads like scenes from our own trips down memory lans and the local discount store. I loved it all--I myself tend to have a bit too many nativity scenes, like her mother. As a reader who spent my early adulthood reading Peg Bracken, and my middle years with Erma Bombeck--not to mention Mark Twain's "Innocents Abroad"--this book is pure fun, and the absolute best early Christmas present, to set the mood for another holiday season.

I wish this came in a smaller quantity--this can will make 153 loaves of bread. However, it is well worth the investment. This is the conditioner that gives the texture, clearly visible as soon as I lift the lid of the bread machine, and keeps the loaf fresh until it is gone. Do not be fooled into getting the one pound bag of stuff from the fruit-sounding company. It does not work, and this one does. The little spice bottle stuff works, but does not go very far and is pricier. Honeyville delivers, all four pounds of it. l put a cup-size container on the shelf, and stored the can in the back corner of the refrigerator.

Sturdy is the operative word. This cover is put together just like one wants and expects. There are no corners cut. The drawstrings are clasped by good quality slides of a size to be easily grippible. The color is neutral gray with a hint of green, so it is unobtrusive. The canvas surface is backed by slick plastic, so its weatherproofness is beyond doubt. The size is generous, by the specified measurement. This is far above using a lawn/leaf bag a a cover, or a piece of usually-blue tarp  When your garden goes off-season, these covers make sure the outdoor furnishings are well-protected.

UPDATE: This evening as I was preparing to cook a meatloaf in the cooker, I was wishing for a RACK to lift the loaf above the drippings that were going to seep from the loaf. Unmentioned in the promos is the presence of a nice rack. The steamer basket bottom can be unswiveled from the side rings to produce a perfect rack raised on one inch legs to do exactly what I want. This machine gets better all the time. I have used it enough now to be able to mentally adjust recipes from conventional to using the multi-cooker. 10/8/2015I love this thing already. It is a versatile dream, having all these cooking functions and a nonstick pan to hold the contents with bright white measurements up the inside. It has a handle. The chimes are hearable, but soft enough not to disturb a household. What I have made, out of the 35 item cookbook comes out very tasty.Now for the suggestions: The lid needs to open a few degrees wider to get the pan out of the machine, straight up, when it is holding liquid. There need to be some guidelines on how to convert my own recipes to preparation in the cooker. There are no suggestions included, and 35 recipes will not go very far.  I have found some good ones at the KitchenAid multicooker site, and the FagorAmerica site, not to mention the ones on Pinterest. But for this money, Phillips should meet me need, instead of having to go to the competition.Do note that all the instructions and the cookbook are in English, French, and Spanish--separate but equal.For learning curve comparisons, it is about as easy to use as the bread machine I got last year, which quickly became my favorite thing. This promises to rank alongside.

I had never had the plain bulk-type rice from Zatarain's before, but had used their flavored boxes when that seemed like an appropriate side dish with some meal. When Vine offered me a pound to sample, I though, "Sure". Well, what a pleasant surprise! It really is a cut above the other guys' similar products. We all have some favorites that we select, in spite of a possible difference in price or ease of getting it home. This just became another of those groceries that are worth seeking out and buying online, if necessary.

Our cat was unfortunately found to have a tumorous cancer which was removed through surgery.  A few weeks after surgery while looking at ways to prevent the tumor from growing back or at least slow its progress I read about ES Clear having positive results on cats with cancer and decided to give it a try.  The first issue I had with this product was the amount you have to give the animal.  Our cat was 15 lbs and very difficult to get any type of liquid medication into her mouth let alone the huge amount of this product that would need to be given per day if following instructions correctly for a cat of her weight.  I put a few drops worth in the dropper to start with to see if that would have any effect and it did-a negative one.The first day I gave her this product the cat started throwing up an hour or so later.  I barely got a drop in her mouth due to her fighting off the liquid and most of it spilling on the floor1  She threw up so many times over the course of the day that eventually nothing but blood was coming out and lots of it.  She was 14 years old and had never thrown up blood in her life prior to this day.  I took her to the vet and they found nothing wrong and just said she must have an upset stomach, so I stopped giving ES Clear to her for a few days and there were no further issues.  The second time I gave her ES Clear the same thing happened constant vomiting to the point where she was throwing up blood all over the house.  At this point the ES Clear got dumped down the sink.  She lived for about 6 months with the tumor afterwards and never again threw up blood or had a vomiting spree again.Also on both occasions I gave her this product she developed large welts on her body.  The first time she had one on her side that I found while petting her the second time she developed one on her head near the ear that was visible.  Both welts lasted around a week and then went away.  Like the vomiting this only happened after giving this product out of her entire life.Was she allergic to something in ES Clear that caused the vomiting?  Is this product toxic..will the same happen to your cat?  I don't know the answer all I can say is our cat lived over 4,000 days and there were only 2 where she threw up blood and grew welts, both of those times it was after taking this product.  There were no other changes to her diet or anything else-this product caused the issue.  I regret ever purchasing this or giving it to our cat.  If you are looking at this product it is probably because you are hoping for some miracle cure to cancer in your animal like I was and unfortunately this is not it.

Was a bit confused from all the different sizes but this is perfect fit for my Olympus Pen E-P5 body.  Made out of the typical neoprene material which is good for preventing scratches but probably not very effective against a drop onto a hard surface.  Works well to carry a spare body in a backpack when outdoors or on the plane when traveling.

Bought this for a Bar Rescue fan and decided to read it since it arrived well before Christmas when I am going to give it to them.  Overall the book may have some useful advice if you work specifically in a bar or restaurant but even then the advice given is highly questionable.  If you have watched an episode of Bar Rescue you already know everything that is stated in this book and have no reason to waste money on it.If one thing is certain after reading this book Jon Taffer thinks he is a god and is absolutely in love with himself.  The entire book is bragging about his accomplishments primarily using examples from the show Bar Rescue.  The following quote from page 211 gives an idea of what you will read on every page about how much Taffer loves himself As a professional consultant, someone who has owned a lot of businesses, and president of the largest bar and nightclub trade show in the country."  If you think Jon Taffer is the most fantastic human being to ever walk on this earth this book will definitely reinforce your thinking.  Its like he is in a job interview with you and reiterating his accomplishments from his resume over and over again.Bars that have failed after being rescued by Taffer are blamed as the problem he accepts no type of responsibility in any failures throughout the book.  Anyone with an internet connection can look up the reality of what happens after an episode of Bar Rescue has been filmed.  Some bars have been sued because Taffer failed to get necessary permits, others have failed because the window dressing he provides cant save a bar that is in a horrible location, read up on it if you have been believing the great success that is reported on each episode at the end.Jon Taffer loves to speak about his scientific approach to the industry but this book is as far from science as possible.  Almost every page includes some type of reference to a survey with specific numbers but nowhere does it say who conducted that survey, where those numbers came from, or provide any type of references at the end for anyone interested to do further research.  Examples of what I am talking about appear below:Page 53 - "Increasing guest frequency by just one visit a month increases revenue up to 12 percent."Page 141 "Chains that landed in the top 25 percent..."Says who?  Where did this information come from?  Did Jon Taffer make it up or was there an actual published survey/research saying this?  You walk away from this book not knowing the answer because it isnt provided in any way whatsoever.  Science provides references, without them this information is completely useless and anyone believing it is a fool.Another thing you can read from the book is that Taffer must have financial ties to many businesses such as TGI Fridays which is mentioned so many times it is ridiculous.  The whole book reads like an advertisement for a few chain restaurants and bars.It is a very quick read, takes maybe an hour or two so if you are able to find it in a library check it out but I would not spend money on this if you are actually looking to open a bar or turn around a failing one.

This is the same mrror they sell at the local auto parts stores for about 3x the price.  If you are seeking a telescopic mirror this is a cheap and perfectly usable option.  I use it for working on the cars and to reflect the sun beam around the yard for the pet cat to chase after, works great for both purposes.  Usually with these things the hinge will loosen over time but at the price it really doesn't matter to me I can get another one for less than the cost of lunch.

I was incredibly dissappointed when shopping for a 2014 Trailer Park Boys calendar to find that there was not one available. I am very happy that there is a 2015 calendar available, my wall has been missing the boys for a year!  If you like the show you should have this calendar.

Purchased this to mirror my Seagate 5TB 3.5" desktop external hard drive which has about 1 TB of data on it.  There were two concerns I had when deciding whether to get this drive or not and both were unwarranted.  One thing I was worried about was cooling capabilities since this has no type of fan or way to keep cool, but this drive stays cooler than any other external hard drive I have owned.  If I am transferring things from my Seagate drive to this or vice versa the Seagate drive heats up to a toasty 95 degF while the Silicon Power never goes above 80 degF.  I've had the Silicon Power drive connected at work for 8+ hours a day for the past week and it has never gotten hot yet.  Another worry I had was that the USB cable in the product photo looks ridiculously short (it is) but when it arrived I found out the drive comes with another USB cable that is about 3 feet long as well.  The short USB stays in the notch on the side of the drive for times when you don't want to carry around the longer cable.  Small size, waterproof, dropproof, stays cool, and works with no issues so far I have no complaints.

I have numerous mice, rats, shrews, or whatever in my backyard of various sizes that leave trails of poop spaced about every inch every night in the windowsills.  They are like little poop machines and I am tired of cleaning it up daily.  I wanted to catch them alive and relocate them elsewhere so I looked into a live trap.  I bought this model because on the Havahart website (and here on Amazon) this trap is listed as supposedly perfect for rats, mice, shrews, etc and since I have no idea which species of these animals is in my backyard..I figured this would be a good catch all trap.My overall issue with this trap is it it WAY too small to catch the species it claims to catch.  Unless the mouse you are trying to catch is a newbord baby or species that grows to less than 2 inches in adult length it is not going to get caught in this trap.  I have attached a photo of one of the mice, rats, whatever it is in my backyard next to the trap and it is clearly longer than the trap.  What happens is they enter the trap and take the bait and when the trap starts to close it just hits them in their back and they walk right out with the trap closing behind them.  Even if by some stroke of luck one went all the way in and the trap managed to close it would be an inhumane and tortuous night spent in this trap.  A creature in this trap would be unable to turn around, move, or defend itself in any way leaving them vulnerable all night. In the hours between when I go to sleep and check the trap in the morning a group of fire ants or mosquitos could kill the poor victim stuck in this trap.  At the minimum a night spent in this trap would be incredibly uncomfortable for whatever is trapped inside.The description of this item from Havahart needs to be revised to state that it can only be used for incredibly small species and rats, chipmunks, mice, etc definitely should not be listed.
Excellent song.  I don't even listen to country music but I can listen to this song all day long and never get tired of it.

I am a barefoot runner who only wears shoes when absolutely required for running (too hot or too cold to run barefoot).  I bought the Sockwa X8 since the specs looked good and I truly wanted to like this shoe but unfortunately it is an absolute disappointment.ConsSizing - The sizing chart Sockwa provides on its website makes absolutely no sense.  My feet measure 9-3/4 inches which according to their website chart makes me a size 9.  The size 9 arrived in a white cloth sack and was smaller than my foot so I exchanged for a 10.  The size 10 arrived in a box with a size chart printed on the side that clearly showed my foot as a size 11, which is the size I eventually got after a second exchange.  If you are looking at the size chart on their website order 2 sizes larger than whatever it shows you the size chart on the Sockwa boxes and the size chart on the Sockwa website are as different as day and night.  I wear a size 9 dress shoe and size 11 Sockwa.Ground Feel  Doesnt exist in this shoe.  The sole is thin but I would not be able to tell the difference between concrete, grass, or anything else underfoot if you were to blindfold me with this shoe on.Inner sole - The inner sole of the shoe is ridiculously slippery and your foot moves back and forth with each stride which caused numerous blisters on the bottom of my feet when wearing these.  Running barefoot on concrete I get no blisters but with these shoes on I had a minimum of 4 blisters on the bottom of each foot due to the slippery insides.  The back of the shoe also rubs my feet the wrong way and gave me a blister there.  I tried wearing socks but then it was so slippery inside that I couldnt even walk, let alone run.  The inner sole of the shoe needs to be redesigned to not be so slippery.Outer sole  The outer sole bend and squishes together inward with each stride and caused me to trip on numerous occasions.Height  They are a little too high for my liking and would be better an inch or so shorter around the ankle area.Upper material  These shoes are hot and retain sweat like a sponge.  Each shoe weighed a full ounce more after my runs due to this issue.  The upper material is absolute thin garbage.  After less than 20 miles running with this shoe on I got tripped by the outer sole for the thousandth time and my toes on my left foot came straight through the upper material.  See the attached photo the hole is nowhere near the end of my toes when standing still the shoes just bend over on themselves so much while running they are unwearable.  My nails were trimmed a day before this happened that was not the issue, the upper is just so thin and cheaply made it is a joke.  The upper of this shoe is basically the same thickness as a pair of womens leg pantyhose.ProsWeight  They are light, my size 11s are 3.3 ounces each.  That is the only good thing I can say about these.Overall opinionIf you want to waste money on a cheaply made piece of garbage that will fall apart in less than 20 miles of use by all means purchase this shoe.  For the rest of you out there who want something worth their money do not even consider purchasing these.

I've been using this camera body for about 6 months now and overall am satisfied but there are big reliability issues in my opinion.  I switched to Micro 4/3 after years of using Panasonic compact travel zoom point and shoot cameras (ZS/TZ series) previously so will be reviewing from that perspective.  As point and shoot manufacturers have continually engaged in a game to see who can offer the most megapixels the amount of noise in the newer point and shoot camera images forced me to switch formats.ProsImage quality is excellent compared to the new point and shoot cameras and on par with DSLR's.  The images taken by the E-P5 are very sharp and can be cropped without losing quality.  The Auto and Scene modes work well for those who want point and shoot functionality and not worry about adjusting ISO, aperture, shutter speed, etc.  Excellent image quality is the main reason I have chosen to stick with this camera.The tilting LCD screen is excellent and I find myself wondering how I was ever able to use a camera that did not have one.  It is an incredible help when taking images at odd heights or in harsh lighting.Menus and controls are incredibly detailed and customizable.  It takes time to get used to the menus to know where to find things but almost everything can be customized if you know where to look.Image stabilization in the camera body works well and I can get great shots handheld with all lenses except the 75-300 at the 300 end where I have to either use a tripod or stabilize against a nearby object.The all metal camera body stands up to the elements well.  I have bumped mine into countless tree branches in the woods and dropped them a couple of times onto grass and don't even have a scratch on either body.  I would definitely appreciate a water and dust proof body like the OM-D model but the OM-D is just too big.I have not used a viewfinder for years and always use the LCD screen on cameras to take shots.  I have incredibly light sensitive eyes and always wear sunglasses in daytime hours so could not look through a viewfinder even if this camera body had one.  The lack of a viewfinder means less weight and bulk and is a positive thing to me.Burst mode is impressively fast and I've used it to take around 90 shots consecutively of an animal on the move using a class 10 memory card with no waiting for buffering.ConsReliability.  I purchased my first E-P5 body in May and within a month had to send it in for repairs because it began shutting itself off immediately when power was turned on.  When I got it back from repairs in less than a month's time it broke again and would not recognize any lens that was attached.  This happened while I was on vacation on an island and I had to use my old point and shoot that I had luckily packed for all photos.  While it was getting fixed the second time I purchased a second E-P5 body as a backup in case of another failure at a critical time and within the first two months of owning that body it also had to go in for repairs because it had the self shut off problem experienced with the first body.  It is due to this horrible reliability so far with two bodies that I cannot give this item more than 3 stars.  If I was going somewhere where a camera was critical (hiking for example) I would have to carry two bodies because I cannot trust this camera to work when needed.  I will revise my review in time if reliability gets better but for now my opinion is this model is unreliable and if it breaks again I will probably give up and get a different brand.Size/ergonomics - Yes this camera is smaller than a DSLR but it is still quite large and heavy.  My Panasonic compact point and shoot camera packs a equivalent focal length of 24-720mm and weighs about 12 ounces including the carrying case.  The Pen E-P5 body alone weighs around a pound.  If you toss in a minimum of three lenses to try to match the functionality my compact camera has (12mm prime, 14-150, and 75-300 for instance) you are now carrying close to 5 pounds of camera equipment and cases.  Over the course of a 20 mile day hike with thousands of feet in elevation gained and lost 4 extra pounds of weight on your back is incredibly significant.  Size wise it is a large camera body compared to a point and shoot and required me to try all types of larger cases for carrying.  Ergonomically the camera fits well in the hand and all controls are easy to reach but I really dislike the eyelets on the sides of the body which dig into my hands.The interval shooting mode is limited to 99 shots.  There is no reason for this limitation that I can think of other than to cause annoyance to the consumer.  Aftermarket timers are available but they are also limited to 399 shots.  There are point and shoot cameras available that can take 999 interval shots and this camera should offer at least that many.The on camera flash is weak and if you try to use it with any of the longer lenses (14-150, 12-40 PRO, etc) you will see a significant shadow in each shot from the lens.  An external flash is mandatory for most indoor or night shooting.The battery door is flimsy and does not fits loosely compared to the rest of the body the battery door is junk.iAuto mode always takes photos in "Enhanced" color mode which produces some very fake and unrealistic colors in many situations.  I would love to have the ability to default this to "Normal" or "Vivid" color mode instead.I geotag my photos and have to synchronize my camera time to my GPS to do so.  It is hard to do with the Pen E-P5 because you cannot adjust or see the seconds.  For instance, it shows the time as 12:00 but is that with 0 seconds, 10, 30, I have no idea?  Because of this it is impossible to synchronize camera to GPS with complete accuracy.  Would appreciate the ability to set the seconds in the future.Not a con of this camera specifically but of the Micro 4/3 format as a whole is telephoto lens limitations.  The longest Micro 4/3 lenses currently available are a 600mm equivalent.  This means that my tiny point and shoot with a 30x optical zoom (720mm equivalent) has more reach than a Micro 4/3 with the longest available lens attached has.  At some point it would be nice to see some longer telephoto lenses developed.UPDATE 2/1/15 - I'm bumping this up to 4 stars based on my recent use in Costa Rica.  I had both of my Pen E-P5 camera bodies out in rain and high humidity constantly.  Both got soaked numerous times with raindrops but performed flawlessly.  This is not meant to be a waterproof camera body but it handled water with no failures or breaks.

Since switching to Micro 4/3 format I have been trying different carrying cases constantly to find something minimal that allows quick access.  Most of the small cases out there are way too large for me.  The best thing I have found so far is the Capture Camera Clip Pro.  I mount this on my Camelbak shoulder strap and can carry a Pen E-P5 with lens (usually the 14-150) attached easily and always have the camera in reach.  It is incredibly easy to get the camera in and out of the clip if you can get yourself dressed each day you should be able to figure this out.  It really is just as easy as the promotional videos make it appear, I dont know why there are so many complaints about it being difficult online.  You push a button to unlock and slide to remove a camera from the clip and simply slide it on to reattachthats it.  The clip holds the camera in place very securely I have tripped, scrambled, climbed, and bumped into various things getting through the thick woods in my area with this attached and never had a failure.  Most importantly you can mount this wherever you want-shoulder strap, hip strap, belt, hat, its up to you.  This was the key reason I went with this over other devices on the market that require being attached to a belt.There are three issues I have with this device.The included attachment screws are too short to fit this clip onto anything thicker than about .  My backpack shoulder straps are way too thick for this and even my older backpack with worn out padding is too thick.  To fix this get two NO 10-32 x 1 long all thread rods/studs.  I ordered a pack of 25 aluminum studs online for less than the Peak Design sells their set of 2 (part number CB-8L), if you want to get ripped off buy it from Peak Design.The PRO model weighs almost 5 ounces and is a bit heavy for what it is I would prefer it to be made out of something lighter.  The regular model is probably lighter but only the Pro model was available with the Micro mount so thats what I ordered.Even though the Micro mount is smaller than the other mounts and meant for use with point and shoot or Micro 4/3 cameras it is still too big and gets in the way of tilting LCD screens.  The Pen E-P5 screen hits the mount when tilting which blocks the full range of motion-have attached a photo showing this.

Excellent, for those wondering this is the original mix of the songs not the remix album that was released a few years after the original.  Better sound quality than the original release and way cheaper than people are trying to sell the original album for.  This is a classic southern album from Kool Daddy Fresh.

I have been a user of 100% whey for over a decade since back in the days when this cost less than $25 for a 5 lb container and had no issues till recently.  For the past few years I have bought the Cake Batter flavor exclusively and use it twice a day.  Recently I bought two 5 lb containers and both had issues-the tasted horrible, mixed to the thickness consistency of a Dairy Queen Blizzard, smelled wrong, and gave me horrible diarrhea afterwards.  As i've said in 10+ years of use I know what the stuff is supposed to taste and smell like and that it shouldn't mix together at the consistency of sludge.  I emailed ON and told them about the two bad containers and they sent me back a 50 or so question email to fill out so they could investigate the lot numbers.  They told me how serious they took the matter and would get back to me within a couple weeks but that was it I got no further replies for over a month even after asking again.After giving up on the hope that ON would stand by their own product I contacted the retailer I bought it from and they sent me replacements with a prepaid shipping label to send back the bad two.  In other words the retailer did a fantastic job of fixing ON's horrible protein at their own expense.  I will never buy another ON product again due to their inability to stand by their products and replace them when they are causing sickness to their customers.  If you are looking for a laxative then this is a terrific product for you otherwise avoid it.  Maybe you will get a good container maybe not but i'm not risking my health again with this company.

This book is fantastic and points out exactly the problems in the area where I live.  At first I was hesitant to order this book because it is not a recent publication but when reading the first couple pages it was mentioning my everyday problems of traffic, lack of community, etc.  The city I have lived in for 30+ years has turned into a horrible place to be as more and more development has occurred and the reasons why are explained very precisely in this book.  This book is not recently published but it is very up to date on problems and unfortunately not much has changed for the better since it was published.  There are many pages devoted to solutions and not just a discussion of problems which is great compared to other books on related subjects.  If you are tired of development that requires owning an automobile, increased traffic, lack of mass transit, and endless suburbia definitely pick up a copy of this book you wont regret it.

I purchased this to monitor an animal that had surgery and would be recovering and wearing an e-collar for around a month.  The plan was to use this monitor to be able to work in my home office and be able to help the animal out when necessary without hovering over the animal all day staring at it.  For my purposes this monitor worked perfectly but I would NOT recommend this monitor to a parent watching a child due to the bright LED light on the screen which cannot be turned off or dimmed.ProsThe screen is large enough to see the subject being monitored from multiple feet away.  I placed it on my desk next to a computer monitor and it worked well.  The screen size is much better than some of the other competitors out there with tiny flip phone looking screens.Battery life is excellent I only charged this a couple times while owning it and using it for numerous hours each day.  Not sure of the exact battery life but it lasts long enough unplugged to go multiple days without charging.I never had to do anything to connect the wireless between the camera and screen all I did was plug in the camera and turn on the screen no additional steps needed.  I had no connectivity issues in my house or interference.The two way speaking works well it allowed me to yell at the animal whenever her e-collar was finally removed and she kept trying to scratch her healing surgery area to get her to stop.ConsWhen the lighting in the room with the camera is dark but not dark enough to switch the cameras IR light on (cloudy days, closed blinds, etc) the viewing screen is not visible from directly in front.  I found that I had to look at it downwards or else all I could see was a black screen regardless of how much I turned up the brightness.If you use the screen outdoors it is not visible while wearing polarized sunglasses it completely disappears.The LED light around the controls is very bright and there is no way to turn it off.  It flashes different colors whenever sound is picked up and I couldnt imagine trying to sleep in a room with this bright light on.  I only needed to use the monitor during daytime hours and even then the light becomes annoying after a while.  This light would be a fantastic feature for hard of hearing parents where the flashing LED would be an indicator that the child is making noise.  Levana needs to give the user the option of turning this light off for this to be a viable monitor.  Unless you can sleep soundly in a room with a bright flashing disco light on I would not recommend this monitor simply because of this LED light.As with all baby monitors I know of there is a slight delay between what you see on the screen and what is actually happening of probably 1-2 seconds.  Not sure if there are any monitors out there that can stream instantly from camera to screen yet.

This is an excellent and well written history of the LH7 ranch but also a depressing one.  Depressing because unfortunately I live and work near where the ranch was and hate to say for those who cannot drive by that the LH7 ranch is gone.  The ranch houses, etc were bulldozed and the site is currently being developed into a massive sprawling apartment complex.  The Heritage Society and historical marker did nothing to protect this historical site as was hoped for in the Epilogue of this book.  The Marks family descendants sold out their family history to developers for profit.This is a very interesting read and there is a lot more history to this ranch than I would have imagined prior to reading the book.  It is hard to imagine the wide open space that was here only a short time ago when looking at the suburbia that exists in the area today.  This is an excellent read for anyone interested in the history of the Katy and West Houston areas.

I bought this for a cat who had a tumor removed from her head between the eye and ear and currently has staples along the surgery site.  I was hoping this would be a good alternative to the vet supplied soft plastic type collar she is wearing.  Unfortunately the Comfy Cone is poorly designed and cannot be used for any animal with any stitches, staples, or exposed areas on their heads which was not clear from any of the other reviews or information on their website.  The issue is that the neck size is adjustable using Velcro that is built onto the cone.  In my case the cone would have to be adjusted to the second of three Velcro straps as it is too small on the third one.  This leaves an exposed Velcro strip on the INSIDE of the cone where the cats head is which could  rub, irritate, and possibly cause significant issues to the staples and exposed flesh on her head.  There is a cover provided for one Velcro strip on the outside of the cone which will not rub on anything but there was no thought put into providing a cover for the strip on the inside where the animals head is?Weight wise the collar is heavy (3 ounces) compared to the vet supplied collar I have (0.5 ounces) and could be problematic for smaller animals.  The material is also very stiff and unlike the vet supplied collar which bends a bit when the cat needs to eat or drink I don't know how an animal would even be able to do either with this collar on.  I had thought it was comfy like a pillow but its not its more like hard cardboard all around your pets head.If your animal is wearing the collar to prevent them from reaching their licking or scratching their heads do not buy this product because unless you are lucky and it fits perfectly with all three Velcro strips you will be left with exposed strips on the inside of the collar.

I own several Fenix flashlights and have always been impressed by their weight to brightness ratio so when looking for a new bicycle light buying a Fenix was my first choice to replace my Princeton Corona bicycle light.  To say the BC30 is bright is a severe understatement.  On turbo mode (1200 lumens) this light is brighter than my trucks headlights with the brights on going down the road and brighter than any spotlight I have ever owned.  The beam is a wide flood type pattern and when riding down a trail at night does an excellent job of lighting all of the surroundings.  I've used it a few times now and pretty much keep it on the lower modes which are more than bright enough.  The light has remained cool to the touch in 80-90degF weather during my use and have not had any of the shut off problems mentioned in the other review even when on for over 2 hours continuously.If you are purchasing the light for the 1800 lumen burst it can only be activated while you hold in the button on the remote pressure switch it is not a constant mode.  At first I thought it only worked in certain modes then figured out the issue is the remote switch connection to the light.  You have to press in until you hear it click into place otherwise it may look like its connected and work a time or two but it wiggles loose when you start riding.The only gripe I have with this light is the release knob for changing batteries.  My best description is it's like a paperclip bent into a U shape that you have to turn and there is  spring pressure resisting against it when you are inserting batteries.  It is poorly designed and not easy to do.  If you have large hands or grip issues there is a good chance you will not even be able to operate this stupid little thing without pliers.
