I have used this tent about 10 times now and overall it is ok but not great.  My main reason for purchasing this tent was that my $25 Ozark Trail tent accumulated too much condensation during the night and the airflow vents on the top of this tent were supposed to prevent that.  Unfortunately during all nights except the one I spent in Death Valley this tent accumulated a ridiculous amount of condensation under the rainfly.  So much condensation is accumulated that it is impossible to even exit the tent without getting drenched either from brushing up against it or from the puddles of it dripping to the ground.  I camped with my brother last week with me using the Kelty and him using the Ozark Trail and the Ozark Trail had no condensation accumulated in the morning while the Kelty was completely soaked so it is in fact worse than a $25 tent.The tent is very easy and quick to pitch although I had to replace the included stakes which bent during the first use.  The advertising for this tent talks about it being color coded but I have no idea what portion supposedly is since all the poles are orange and no color coding is present.  The floor of the tent is so thin it is see through and purchasing the available footprint is a requirement in my opinion, the footprint is color coded to the tent at least.  There is more headroom in this tent than many other models which helps when getting dressed in the morning.  If you are car camping and dont need something light my recommendation is get something cheaper because there is nothing about this Kelty that is special and it is too heavy for backpacking.

I bought the large size to use for some near car and near house camping where it would not have to be carried more than a few feet.  Overall I find it more comfortable than the Exped Synmat I previously had but not too a good choice for side sleepers.  The problem is that when the pad is fully inflated it is very uncomfortable unless you sleep on your back.  To make it comfortable for side sleeping I had to let out a considerable amount of air.  Once the air was let out I could find a comfortable position on my side and distribute my weight evenly while awake but the slightest movement resulted in my hip bone hitting the ground while sleeping and waking up sore in that area.  The pad is made out of too thin of a material with no noticeable type of insulation to prevent the hip bone from hitting the ground.  The Exped I had previously had some insulation within the pad and prevented the bone from hitting the ground. The material is also very noisy when touched or if you roll over.

I bought this cd for a cousin who is a fan of Counting Cars somewhat as a joke but the numerous positive reviews here had me wondering if this could actually possibly sound good.  Ive given the cd a listen and think that The Count Danny should stick to working on cars.  I will give credit where it is due-the band is actually very good and they have the potential to do very well if someone else were singing.  The weak point on this album is Dannys bad singing voice and poor lyrics.  Dannys voice just is not made for singing he hits none of the notes correct he sings just like he talks on the show.For the questionable lyrics look no further than the chorus on the song Save a Little Something For Me  which goes I wish there were more than 24 hours in a day but there's not and i'm sorry but I wouldn't have it any other way"  What in the world is that even supposed to mean?  He wishes there were more hours but there arent and he is happy about it and wouldn't change it.what?Some of the songs are Rock & Roll where others are more Blues like such as the one mentioned above but none are worth listening to.  I will continue to watch Counting Cars because it is a great show but wont be buying any more of his cds.  I don't possibly think this would have gotten any 5 star reviews if not for the television show.

First off I agree with other reviewers that this should have just been supplied with the 14-42mm EZ lens for free.  Second, there is absolutely nothing about it that makes it cost over $30 since it likely costs pennies to manufacture.  Moving past that, it is a great thing to have and saves me the trouble of popping off the lens cap to take a picture and keep track of where I put it.  Im using this on the Pen E-P5 and all I do is turn the camera on, the lens extends, and the cap slides open just like with point and shoot cameras.  I wish this type of cap was available for the other micro 4/3 lenses.  Rating it 4 stars because while it works as it should the cost and fact it should have been free keep it from being perfect.

Eneloops have long been the best rechargeable AA batteries out there and I have dozens of them.  When I ordered these I got worried becauase the name on the package changed from Sanyo to Panasonic and I was not sure if they changed them for the worse.  When they arrived they looked the same except for the Panasonic name so I put them in the Maha/Powerex charger on break-in to test the capacity.  Out of the 8-pack the lowest capacity was 2001mah and the highest 2036mah so I have no complaints.  The name on the box changed but they work just like the Sanyos, will buy again.

Years ago I gave up on screen protectors when the only option were the horrible Invisishields which dried with bubbles all over and were a mess to put on.  When I bought my E-P5 though it was quite expensive and I decided to give this protector a try and luckily this item is easy to put on.  There is no water needed during installation and thus, no air bubbles.  Basically you just clean off the screen with the included cloth and sticky sheet then just peel the protector like a sticker and put it on.  I unfortunately didn't clean off a couple specs of dust so they show but the protector is not noticeable with the camera on or off.  Two protectors are included so if you mess up you can try again.  One warning though there are no English language instructions included and you have to go online to view an instructional video.

I have a couple pairs of snake proof boots that are supposedly waterproof but somehow manage to leak in a little water if I am walking around in water for an extended period of time.  This boot dryer does an excellent job of drying them out without having them bake in the backyard sun all day.  I was seeking a dryer with a built in timer and this was the cheapest option I could find and overall am happy with it.My main complaint about this dryer is that all four vents have to be on at the same time and I would appreciate the ability to turn them on independently or in pairs of two.  I only have two feet and do not need four vents on at the same time.  I live in Houston and it is close to 100 degrees all summer long so I am forced to use the non-heated option on this dryer or else I would have the two unused vents pumping hot air out and making the room even hotter.  If you plan on using the heated option you need to also realize that the heating element smells and must be plugged in the garage or somewhere you don't have to deal with the stink.

This has become my default lens that is always left on the E-P5 paired with the auto lens cap.  It is an extremely small lens that allows me to carry the camera with lens attached in the smallest camera bag possible and snap photos quickly.  My main subjects of photography are reptiles and amphibians and I need a zoom lens because depending on the species (venomous or non-venomous in particular) I will be different distances away.  This lens also works excellent for landscape photographs.  Carrying numerous prime lenses (17mm, 25mm, etc) is not something I have any interest in doing and there is no need when this lens works so well and does the job of two or three of the prime lenses alone.  Photos come out excellent, sharp, in focus, and in most cases better than handheld photos I take with the 60mm f/2.8 macro lens.  I feel as if many people have missed the point of Micro 4/3 to carry around less gear.  This lens is for those of us who want a small, practical lens and the ability to carry around the camera without having to lug around a purse full of prime lenses.

Overall this is a lens I dont particularly like but will use for now because there is not much else on the market for 300mm Micro 4/3 lenses.  My main issue is that the lens is enormous and looks ridiculous when zoomed to 300mm and placed on my E-P5.  This lens causes the camera to become very front heavy and must be used on a tripod if you want to take shake free pictures.  I have tried changing shutter speeds and various settings on the camera such as the shutter lag time but 300mm (600mm with crop sensor) hand-held shots with this lens are blurry 99% of the time.  The problem is this lens is just too large for a smaller Micro 4/3 camera, something larger like the OM-D it might be perform better.  I have used many compact point and shoot cameras with 24X optical zoom (600mm) or greater hand-held and they all performed better than this lens at delivering a blur free image.When using a tripod photos taken using this lens come out in focus with nice color but somewhat slow focusing time.  I am waiting to see what the price and size of the Olympus 300mm prime will be when it is released and hopefully it will be a viable option to switch to.

I saw this in the book reviews section in the back of Herpetological Review a couple months ago and ignored it at first because I thought it was a field guide to Taiwan snakes.  After reading the reviews here though it became clear that this was a book filled with tales of herping similar to other classics like Snakes and Snake Hunting, etc.I have taken many trips to Asian countries and done a lot of herping there but never even considered Taiwan as a destination.  From reading the tales in Hans book though Taiwan is an excellent place to photograph snakes and has a large number of herpers also practicing the hobby.  This book is essentially a field journal of Hans herping adventures filled with natural history notes and photographs of the various species.  The stories throughout the book are entertaining and kept my attention.  I also appreciated the chapter on the pangolin at the end of the book as they have always interested me.  One tip I took from the book was road cruising in a jeep with the doors removed to cut down on the amount of time it takes to get out of the vehicle (also would prevent locking the keys inside) and will try that next time Im herping in Nevada.My only grudge against the book is that the author stresses how he did snake presentations at schools and constantly tried to educate people but at the same time filled his book with misinformation.  The aggressiveness of many snakes and results of their bites are greatly exaggerated in this book in numerous placessome examples of what Im talking about appear below.Page 63 - Referring to Elaphe carinata "in the wild it strikes readily and bites without hesitation"Page 216 - Referring to Sinonatrix percarinata suriki "if you've ever tangled with an American Nerodia, you're probably casting a knowing glance at your scars right now".Page 229-230 "Bats have an impressive number of needle teeth, and also carry enough crazy diseases to keep an entire virologist congress giddy with excitement"The quote from page 216 is particularly ridiculous because as someone who has bitten by countless Nerodia over the years and knows others who have there is not one scar on my body from them.  Nerodia bites result in nothing more than a small scratch or puncture that will heal within a few days with no trace of the bite left behind.  Thorny plants in the woods are more dangerous to the skin than a Nerodia bite.  These types of exaggerations will cause non-herpers who could potentially read this book to become even more scared of snakes.Altogether it is a good book to read if you are a herper and wanting to read some tales of herping in Taiwan.  Im knocking a star off because of the exaggerations mentioned above.

I had the size MW Synmat but sold it after a few nights because it was too uncomfortable for me side sleeping.  When inflated this pad is essentially the same as sleeping on one of the pool lounge floats due to the raised dome shaped channels running its length.  I found that the only way to get reasonably comfortable on this sleeping pad was to have a minimal amount of air in it but that also led to my hips touching the ground while side sleeping which hurts on hard surfaces.  If you have too much air in the pad it is way too hard and uncomfortable.  The pad inflates and deflates properly with the built in air pump and fits back in the carry sack with ease.  If you are considering buying this take a couple dollars and buy a pool lounge float and try sleeping on that first to determine whether you are going to like this type of design, personally Im going to get a pad with a flat surface next time.

A couple months ago I spent time backcountry camping in Death Valley and realized just how bright the night sky was there compared to other areas Ive visited over the years.  I had seen this book mentioned in a magazine recently and decided to order a copy after my hiking trip.  The book is very interesting and highlights all kinds of issues I had never thought about related to our overuse of lighting at night.  Things discussed in the book include health effects related to artificial lighting, historical writings before artificial lighting was invented, various lighting advances over the years, etc.  I had never known there were groups that actively work with businesses, parks, communities, cities, etc to correct light pollution until reading this book.  I also never knew there were whole cities and communities designated as dark sky areas who have passed laws and restrictions on types of lighting allowed.  I am unfortunately surrounded by neighbors who have security lighting in the front and back of their homes turned on all night every night and there are references to articles proving security lighting to be a fallacy in this book.  The notes section at the end of the book has many good references and other books to read if you are interested in more information.The book is packed with information but at times it is hard to follow where quotations from other books end and where the text for this book begins.  For instance, the author will quote some lines from a historical book on night walks and then set out to physically walk the same places and I got lost many times trying to figure out whether a sentence was a quote or not.  I was also confused on the purpose of the discussion on the word melancholy that appears between pages 166-169 which seems to have nothing to do with the rest of the book.Overall, it is a good read but at times a confusing one.

I found this to be an excellent read and actually learned a lot of things that I had thought to be true were absolutely wrong.  Take for instance the Coriolis effect, I had been convinced that toilets flush and sinks drain in a different direction in Australia but thanks to this book now I know how that MYTH came into existence.  There are plenty of other facts like this throughout the book which I will not spoil.  Chances are pretty good that you will learn something new from reading this book.

This is a great book for learning the history of our national parks and the people who helped them become a reality.  As other reviewers have mentioned this is not a photography book of park pictures or a detailed guide to any of the parks, so do not buy it if that is what you are seeking.  The purpose of the book is to explain in detail the story of people like John Muir and Teddy Roosevelts involvement in the creation of Americas national park system.  The pictures are primarily of the people being described although there are many nice pictures of the parks and plenty of historic ones.  There are plenty of people in the book that I had never heard of prior to reading it who played pivotal roles in the creation of our park system.  Size wise the book is large and heavy and not comfortable to sit down and read it on your lap it is more something to place on a table and read.  Altogether, its a great book if you are interested in learning more about how Americas national park system came to be in existence.

I bought this game hoping that it would improve my memory and concentration and overall I find it more annoying than helpful.  The Dr. Kawashama character who appears as a talking head is the primary issue I have with the game.  The premise of the game is that you spend 5 minutes of training a day but that 5 minutes is actually around 15-20 due to all the stupid talking you must endure from the Dr (holding down the stylus to fast forward helps some but not much) .  First, when you turn on the game each day you must endure a brain training tip almost every time.  When you choose Devilish Training and open one of the games you must sit around and hear how you did last time and between each level you must hear the same speech every time you scored greater than 85% going down a level blah blah blah.  After playing the game for 3 months I get the point already and dont need to hear this between each level!  If you play with the volume on and do something wrong the Dr. will start making stupid comments at that point as well like oh you almost got it or something similar.  While playing any game you must look at the Dr.s huge head in the background the entire time, it is just so annoying.Moving beyond the Dr.s annoyance to the actual game I find that this version doesnt do much better than any of the past Brain Ages when it comes to recognition of what you are writing or saying.  If you write a lowercase g, p, or q while doing Word Attack the game does not recognize it 99% of the time.  I once spent over 2 minutes just getting it to recognize an absolutely perfectly written p.  While doing number games like Calculations x 20 half the time it does not recognize the numbers you are writingyou might write a 1 and it somehow picks it up as 24 or something similarly ridiculous.  Devilish Pairs I find to be incredibly inconsistent in that one time you may have multiple pairs next to each other and after that none are even nearby.  This causes the problem of allowing you to move up a level and think you are getting better when in actuality you may never advance again when the pairs are not close by.Altogether, there should be an option to turn the Dr. off and not hear his speeches or see the head in the background of each game the annoyance factor is the primary issue with the game.

I bought this book because I spend the majority of my free time researching and photographing reptiles and pick up pretty much any book that has to do with alligators.  The instant I looked at the photograph of the shirtless author on the cover I had a feeling this book was going to be entertaining because it is nothing like the typical author photo you would expect on a book jacket.  This book is without a doubt the most entertaining thing I have read in a long time and I actually enjoyed it more for the authors stories and style of writing then the actual crocodilian research.  The overall premise of the book is to explain the travels and people involved with the authors research done while writing his thesis on crocodilian communication.  The way he travels and the descriptions are in most cases both ridiculous and amusing at the same time to anyone who travels in a typical fashion.  I cant even imagine travelling some of the ways he did and would never do many of these things myself.  There are perfect descriptions for many things in this book that I have also observed such as some photographers seeming to base their egos on whose camera lens is the longest.  Descriptions of bribes and cultures around the world are laughable but true and I especially liked the authors mention of a foreign official not accepting a bribe in his passport once as witnessing a miracle.For those interested in reading the actual thesis that was written by Vladimir you can find it on his website in PDF format for free (the website address is mentioned on the inner book jacket).  There are also PDF versions of various research papers he has published in scientific journals along with English translations of some of his earlier books.  I actually learned a lot about alligators I never knew before reading his research papers regarding hunting strategies and communication.  I highly recommend this book both to people interested in reptiles and people just looking for a hilarious story.

Overall when this camera works correctly it is a remarkable piece of equipment.  My childhood was filmed using enormous VHS recording camcorders, followed by the VHS-C, and Mini DV all of which took horrible quality videos compared to something as tiny as the GoPro it is truly a huge technological wonder.  I use this camera primarily in 1080/60P narrow mode and do not like any of the wide angle fisheye looking modes.  Video quality is excellent for the size and when used in correct situations.  The GoPro is made for action and use in places where you would not risk using another camcorder in my opinion.  I would never mount my Panasonic HD camcorder underneath my car or take it underwater for instance but I do it with the GoPro rather frequently.  The underwater housing works well both underwater and to protect the camera from rocks and things when driving down the road.  One thing I wish they would offer on the next model is the ability to take the highest MP photos without it having to be the stupid wide angle mode.My reason for a negative review is that this camera consistently gives me corrupt videos.  Before you type me a smart comment saying the issue is my memory card and that I am an idiot read on.  I am well aware of the counterfeit memory cards causing problems that is not my issue.  I have multiple Sandisk Extreme Micro SD cards that I use with this camcorder which have all been purchased from reputable retailers and all pass testing with both H2testw and Flash Drive Tester with no errors whatsoever on read or write.  All of the memory cards work flawlessly in other devices I own as well.  Every time I use them in the GoPro however I get at least one corrupt video usually within the first 60 minutes of videos.  The videos transfer to the computer as mp4 they just have no thumbnail image and they are not playable.  I have tried transferring them using Adobe Premiere Elements 10, GoPro Studio, and simple dragging and dropping off the memory card onto the computer they are corrupt either way.  My GoPro has never been knocked off or stopped recording due to damage or battery life running out.  There is no message on the GoPro after recording saying it is fixing the video.  I have contacted GoPro support about the problem since the camcorder is less than 3 months old but they are useless.  All they will tell me is that the problem has to be the memory card and will not take the camcorder back or exchange it I have been going back and forth with them for a while now it is like talking to a wall.  At some point if I get a properly working camera I will revise my review but as of now due to the loss of numerous videos with no solution in sight this is not trustworthy enough of a device to recommend to anybody.  Luckily I use this device for somewhat unimportant things and have not lost anything critical.

Checked this one out from the library because I am incredibly bored at work and looking to switch careers so reading anything I can get my hands on for free regarding career moves.  It is an entertaining read the authors stories are engaging and I finished the book quickly.  Overall however there is nothing really gained from reading this book other than the entertainment value of the read.  The points being explained in the various chapters are things that anyone with common sense should already know like not quitting a job until you have something better already lined up.  The vast majority of the book seems to be trying to drive traffic to the authors blog since it is mentioned on just about every page.  Perhaps some people will read this because they are fans of his blog but personally I had never heard of the author or the blog before reading this book.  If you are looking to switch careers and become a full time blogger or want to read an entertaining book then definitely read this, if you are looking for insightful information on career changes though this book is not of much value.

I have been a Nintendo handheld user since the first Game Boy came out and am now an adult in his early 30s.  Previous to the 3DS XL I was using the DS Lite which is about as close to perfect as I could ask the weight was right, size was good, bright screen, matte finish on the inside, and comfortable to play for hours.  The 3DS XL on the other hand is terrible.  I put off purchase of this device for a long time but eventually all the new games I wanted to play or download required the 3DS platform.  Here is my summary of this device after owning it for 6 months now:ConsWeight  The 3DS XL is too heavy, it is uncomfortable to hold for more than a couple minutes.  The top screen seems to be top heavy and it constantly feels like the whole thing is pulling down backwards.Ergonomics  The buttons are placed horribly and the device does not feel good while in your hand.  I find the joystick control to be absolutely useless for the games I play (New Super Mario Bros series and other downloaded NES or SNES side scrollers primarily).  The arrow keypad is placed in an uncomfortable area and if the joystick were eliminated it would be a better device.  I see a lot of reviewers complaining that they wanted a second joystick control but that serves no purpose for me  When I play games like Brain Age I have a hard time writing on the screen and come nowhere close to records I set on the DS Lite.Screen size  The screen is large but at the end of the day it is too large for any non 3DS games.  When I try to play Solitaire in Club House Games the cards are so pixelated they are almost illegible.  Old NES or SNES games downloaded through the eshop look terrible.  This device appeals to the bigger is better crowd who carry around cell phones the size of a tablet and think that the largest thing is automatically the best.Screen wobble  The top screen wobbles too much.  I have tried to eliminate this by placing a rubber foot between the two screens like various videos online show but they constantly fall off and the screen wobbles again until I can replace them.3D  My eyes cannot tolerate even the minutest level of 3D.  I have the 3D effect turned completely off, meaning the one thing that made this device different from the DS is pointless.ProThe 3DS XL has one positive thing going for it which is the matte black finish surrounding the inside screens.  I would love to buy the regular 3DS if they offered it with a matte black inside screen.  I do not understand why computer monitor manufacturers and Nintendo think that having shiny light reflective material surrounding a screen makes sense.Summary  I wish Nintendo would have made games such as New Super Mario Bros 2 playable on the DS Lite so that I would not have had to upgrade to the 3DS XL.  Alternatively, make a 3DS Lite or offer the 3DS with matte black inside screens for those of us who do not enjoy having light reflected in our eyes the whole time we play.  I'll give it 2 stars because those of us who played the original Game Boy can attest to how much better this is than that at least.

I bought this to use with the WG-3 GPS camera.  I knew that the battery could not be changed and accepted that fact before purchase so giving a poor review based on other problems I found out afterwards.The first problem with this item is that the range is extremely limited.  It only works up to I would say less than 10 feet away and has to be pointed directly at the sensor on the camera with nothing in between, if you point it 6 inches away from the sensor it does not work.  If you were planning to use this remote to take a portrait of your family for instance this remote does not work because you would have to be holding it pointed directly at the camera in the picture and could not trigger the shutter with the remote behind someones back or in your pocket.The second problem is that the remote cannot turn the camera on or off, which i'd assumed one of the two buttons did.  I was hoping to use this to take night time photos of the sky while camping without having to leave the tent but since the remote cannot turn the camera on that isn't going to happen.Due to the limitations above I have found this remote to be completely useless.  This remote will not do anything for you other than allow you to trigger the shutter when the camera is already turned on and you are standing within arms length with the remote pointed directly at the sensor on the camera.  If you are looking to take night landscape pictures with no camera shake or portraits use the self timer or an interval shooting mode and save the money you were thinking of spending on this.

I searched around for a long time online for a good camping pillow for a side sleeper and came up with the large version of this as the winner. It made sense to purchase since i've used an Exped Synmat sleeping pad for over a year which I like.  Recently tried it for the first time camping in Death Valley and wow did I hate this pillow.  The slanted design where one side is higher than the other just kills it for me.  Regardless of which end I tried laying on and different air pressures there was just no comfort with this pillow.  It felt like trying to sleep on a wrongly inflated balloon.  I really wish I had tried this out before my trip because I ended up sleeping on one of the headrests pulled out of the rental car when it became obvious after 3 hours trying with this air pillow that I would never get to sleep on it.  If you are intent on getting an air pillow you would be better off buying a seat for an inflatable boat for about half the price of this pillow.

Recently used the Zip on a 10 day trip and it works excellent.  The Zip gets 2 cups of water boiling in around 2 minutes and it is small and easy to carry around.  I used a piezo igniter to light each time and had no issues whatsoever.  The Zip is designed to boil water and it does it perfectly.

I have owned two pairs of this shoe in the original version 1 so figured this would be an easy purchase since those two fit me fine for years now.  I went to a New Balance store to try these on and my version 1 size was way too small so I ended up buying a wide version of these to get the same fit.  I tried them on in the store with normal socks on and figured since I usually wear them sockless that the reason they felt weird was due to the socks.  When I got home and tried them sockless I realized the problem is actually the arch area is different from the version1 shoe.  The version 2 arch on the inside of the foot is much higher, basically the sole of the shoe comes halfway up your foot.  I returned these because the hard arch is just completely uncomfortable and a poor redesign.

I have been a user of the Panasonic superzoom models for years now an all of them have been excellent.  Currently I am on my third ZS15 due to breaking the previous two because I do not treat them nicely.  The image quality is second to none in this product category.  My main uses for the camera are wildlife/nature photography and landscape photography while hiking.  I carry this camera typically in a small Pearstone bag and use the chest strap on a Camelbak to hold the camera bag via the belt clip.  I will never own a DSLR because I hike as light as possible and do not have the patience or room to haul around multiple lenses anywhere.  Why bother when I can have this camera hanging by my chest and take excellent pictures?  As a tip use the "Vivid" color mode for any of the Panasonic superzoom cameras it produces the highest quality images and sharp colors while the normal mode is somewhat bland.If you own a Panasonic superzoom camera sooner or later you are going to get dust/dirt behind the lens on the CCD sensor.  My recommendation to you is to search on Youtube and you will find a very well done instructional video on how to clean that sensor.  Prior to going on a trip or somewhere important make sure to clean the sensor in advance so that all your pictures are not ruined by that tiny piece of dirt. On a previous Panasonic model I sent the camera back to Panasonic repairs to clean the sensor for me and it took them over 2 months both times, while it takes me less than 5 minutes after learning how do not waste your time with their warranty service for the CCD sensor cleaning.

Just about all the negative reviews for this product are related to the streaming features which I could absolutely not care less about and will not review because I have never used them.  If you are looking for a blu-ray player and not a media streaming device this product works excellent.  Blu-ray discs load quickly and all have played for me without a glitch, DVDs work great too.  I was also just about pulling my hair out over finding a way to play HD videos off my camcorder in full quality on the TV and share them without compression and this player finally solved that problem for me.  I am able to take the MP4 files directly off my camcorder at 1080P/60 fps and burn them as a data blu-ray disc and the Sony plays them perfectly!  I do not have to edit the files at all in any movie editing software an no encoding is necessary to burn MP4 files as a data disc giving me incredible time savings.  Prior to this, I had bought multiple "media players" to try playing MP4 files and all of them failed miserably but this player is excellent

I've been using this as my primary flashlight now for over 2 years and absolutely love it.  I have since purchased multiple other Fenix flashlights and other than occassionally having to adjust the tightness of the tail cap have had no issues.  This flashlight is incredibly light and brighter than many of the spotlights I used to have to carry around at night looking for reptiles and amphibians.  I have dropped this countless times, put it under water, and generally given it a beating most products couldn't survive.  Fenix makes incredible lights.

This is the book to get if you are planning a trip to Costa Rica and doing some Herp photography.  Costa Rica is an excellent country to locate Reptiles and Amphibians and you can find them just about everywhere.  Savages book is without question the most detailed at identifying and learning about these species.  One issue I have found after a trip to Costa Rica is that the taxonomic names for species in Costa Rica are a mess.  Most taxonomic names have changed since the publication of this book and most seem to have changed multiple times, it is a bit ridiculous.  Plan to look up the current taxonomic names for any species you photograph while in Costa Rica because the name in this book is probably no longer correct.As a tip when you photograph amphibians in Costa Rica if you want to identify them you will need to get both pictures of the animal above, below, and the feet if you plan to identify them.  A lot of the frogs are almost identical with the only difference being something on the bottom of their feet or whether a certain toe is webbed.  For this reason, I ended up with a lot of pictures that just had to label as unknown frog.As a second tip this book is heavy at just under 7 lbs and you probably will not want to lug it with you to Costa Rica.  There is a company named Rainforest Publications that makes small pamphlets for identification of different creatures (Frogs, Snakes, insects, etc) which are laminated and you can carry those in the field with you while in Costa Rica much easier than this book.  You can buy those guides before your trip and save some money, but they are sold pretty much everywhere in the country if you forget including the airport.

I've been using this chair for probably over a year now when working at home and overall it works but I don't really like the material of the seat.  The mesh like material irritates my legs when wearing shorts and I with I had gotten either leather or some type of plastic instead.  The back portion, armrests, and adjustability are all good.  If you wear pants this chair will probably be fine for you but the material is a little annoying if wearing shorts.

This is an excellent book for learning how to properly pronounce words in Spanish.  Having how it sounds next to the words is much better than trying to read a word on the page and figure out how it sounds.  I initially checked this out from the library but bought a copy because I liked it so much.  My only problem is I wish it were longer and had more words.

I have been a subscriber to Reptiles Magazine for years now and love it.  Although I do not have any reptile pets I find the articles informative and love reptiles.  If you like this let me recommend to you to subscribe to Herp Nation and become a member of SSAR to get Herpetelogical Revew and Journal of Herpetology.

I am planning a trip to Death Valley and bought this book to get some ideas on where to go other than the well known destinations.  This book is packed with off the beaten path hikes and every single hike has a tremendous amount of background information on the specific area.  The author has obviously done a lot of research on Death Valley and there is probably more information in this book than you would ever even want to know.  Hikes are detailed enough to know that the author has done them, knows the terrain, and has spent a considerable amount of time in Death Valley.  If there is anything that would improve this book I wouldn't mind GPS waypoints for some of the hikes but as it is this book is excellent.Update 4/24/14 - I finally took my first trip to Death Valley this month and this book I will say again is excellent.  There are many mines that you would never know are there without this book like those around the Racetrack and Ubehebe Peak.  I am already planning my next trip because I loved it and realized after reading the book again afterwards that I missed things that were right under my nose and should have read certain pages better.  As a bonus I noticed when reviewing my pictures that I took the exact same picture that is on the books cover in Fall Canyon without knowing it.

I was looking for a very thin insole to use in some slip-on dress shoes that needed a new insole.  I bought a pair of the Pedag 172 and a pair of the Pedag 102 and honestly can't tell the difference between the two when wearing them, if you are trying to choose between the two models just choose the cheaper one.

I really like this nail clipper set  it comes with both large and small clippers, plus a bonus emery board and a handy little travel case. The quality of the clippers is great  thicker metal with smooth movement so I don't feel like I'm going to accidentally break the clippers. I have a husband and four sons who have been using these clippers and no one has popped them apart yet, as has happened with lower quality nail clippers when the boys try to trim thicker nails. The blades on both clippers are extremely sharp  they trim fingernails and toenails quickly and cleanly without bending or splitting them. With the included carrying case, this is a great nail grooming set to keep in your purse (or briefcase, or gym bag, or wherever).I received this product at a discount in exchange for my honest review; all opinions are my own.

Even after reading the product description, I was surprised at the size of these storage bags. They really are enormous! I've never used vacuum storage bags before, so I did have a teensy bit of a learning curve, i.e., I overstuffed the bag the first time I used it. But even packed to the brim, I was happy with the results. I took a huge pile of my son's outgrown clothes and packed them into one of the bags. Since I'm expecting a baby boy in October, I'm saving these outfits to hand down to the new baby, but they won't be needed for a couple of years. The clothes overfilled an 18 gallon storage tote, but all fit into the bag (which is where the "overstuffed bag" comes in). I closed the top of the bag (kind of like a double-sealed Ziploc bag), removed the cap from the vacuum hole, and sucked the air out  it compressed the bag down to about half of the original size. I've since discovered that I can get better results by not stuffing the bags so full, but I'm more worried about keeping the clothing safe from moisture and spiders as they sit in our basement than I am about sucking them flat, so I left that first bag as it was. The seal is really tight (I made sure to screw the cap back on as tightly as I could), and no air has gotten back into the bag since I vacuum sealed it. (I'm going with the theory that if air can't get in, neither can dust or spiders). I do kind of wish that the bags had handles somewhere, as the size makes them sort of awkward and heavy to tote around (especially if you're seven months pregnant), but other than that I'm very pleased with these bags. Now I need about twenty more to store all of our blankets, my older boys' outgrown clothes, my own clothes that I'm hoping to fit back into someday, etc. and so forth!I received this product in exchange for my honest review; all opinions are my own.

I'd never used a crystal nail file before purchasing this one, but now that I've tried it, I'll never go back to the cheap emery boards again. When I first opened the package, I really wasn't sure how well this would file rough edges off my nails, since the file feels almost smooth to the touch instead of rough or sandpapery. But it actually works SO much better than any other type of nail file I've ever tried. I have medium length fingernails and it drives me nuts to have rough edges on them that snag and catch on things. With other types of files, you have to be careful with the direction you're filing, otherwise you'll just create more rough edges. With this one, I just glide it over my fingernails in any direction and it shapes them perfectly and leaves perfectly smooth edges.Obviously I can't speak as to whether or not this file will truly last a lifetime, since I've only had it for four weeks, but so far so good! If you've used cardboard files, you know that you can see the lines of wear on them pretty quickly as you use them and rub the grit off. Since this one is made of hardened glass, the grit doesn't wear down and you can't accidentally bend it either. I would assume you could break or shatter it if you tried, but this one comes with a protective case that I keep it inside. The case itself is just thin, lightweight plastic, nothing fancy, but it serves the purpose of keeping the file from possibly getting broken if you keep it in the bottom of your purse like I do.I received this product at a discount in exchange for my honest review; all opinions are my own.

I ordered this watch as a gift for my 19-year-old son, and couldn't be more pleased with it. It's a much "classier" watch than what he's worn before, more suitable for an adult than the plastic or faux-leather styles he's worn in the past. I love the natural patterns in the wood and the carved details. On the back of the watch face, all the information (such as the Bewell logo) is actually carved right into the wood. The wood is very, very smooth, with no rough edges that might catch on your skin or clothing. It's also listed as water resistant (although not waterproof), which is a must-have when gifting a watch to a young adult.This is a larger watch (about two inches diameter across the face of it), so while it looks a little oversized on my scrawny little girly wrist (pictured), it's a good size for a man's watch. Despite that, it's incredibly lightweight. The band itself is adjustable up to about 8.5 inches around (in comparison, my wrist is 7 inches). The description states that you can easily make the band smaller by removing joints from the strap  I haven't tried to do this myself yet, but it looks like it would be relatively simple to do. The clasp on the watch is unique  one end fits to the other like a puzzle piece, with magnets in both ends to hold them together.The packaging of this watch is also quite nice, ready for gifting. The watch wraps around a cushioned velvety pillow inside of a sturdy black cardboard box; the lid of the box has a plastic "viewing window" that displays the watch inside. And the cardboard box comes inside of a clear plastic box for extra protection.This is a very attractive watch, and I would love to get one of the more feminine styles for myself now that I've seen the beauty and craftsmanship of this particular design!I received this product at a discount in exchange for my honest review; all opinions are my own.

This is a great assortment of decorative butterflies in various sizes. The body of each butterfly is molded plastic, and the wings are a sort of medium weight glossy paper. I checked and you *can* tear the wings, but not easily  I had to actually try to start a tear on one of them. The colors are bright and vibrant, and the wing patterns vary so you're not stuck with a bunch of boring identical butterflies.The butterflies arrived separated by color into two clear envelopes; in addition to a small magnet on each butterfly, each package contained a sheet of 12 round double-sided sticky circles. The magnets aren't super strong  plenty strong enough to hold the lightweight butterflies to your fridge or other surface, but probably not enough to use them to hold up anything other than the weight of the butterfly itself. The sticky tabs, on the other hand, are super sticky  I tried to move one of the butterflies after sticking it to a wall that has a flat paint on it, and the butterfly came off the sticky tab before the sticky tab came off the wall. I was able to remove the tab without damaging the paint, but it took a little bit of effort and might possibly damage some kinds of paint. You could, of course, use your own mounting tabs instead of the included ones if you wanted to make sure you could remove the butterflies without damaging the surface underneath, though. I did find that the included tabs didn't stick very well to a textured wall painted with some sort of glossy, slippery paint, but NOTHING sticks to the walls in that room.Overall I found these to be a really cute and easy way to add some color and fun to the walls (and refrigerator). At two dozen butterflies for the listed price, this is well worth the purchase.I received this product at a discount in exchange for my honest review; all opinions are my own.

I've always been a little bit of a hippie at heart, so tie-dye bell bottoms are perfect for me. And these pants are incredibly soft and comfy in addition to being a fun style. They're stretchy without feeling tight or restrictive. They actually fit similarly to leggings with the amount of stretch to the fabric, but the wide flare on the bottom keeps them from looking like leggings. I'm 5'10 and found the length of the size large pants to be perfect (which means that shorter girls might have to hem them a bit). I'm also seven months pregnant, but the material (95% rayon and 5% spandex in the pair I ordered) is stretchy enough that it goes around my tummy without binding or feeling tight or uncomfortable.The material is also extremely lightweight, so these pants are comfortable even on a warm summer day (although they'd be too thin for cold weather without something underneath them). They can become slightly sheer when stretched, but only in bright light (and if someone's looking specifically). Quality-wise, I'm very pleased  despite the light, stretchy fabric, I don't feel like the material is "fragile" or like it will snag or tear if I catch them on something. The stitching is nice and tight, no loose threads or gaps.I received this product at a discount in exchange for my honest review; all opinions are my own.

Living in an older house with my husband and our four kids, I believe that there's no such thing as too many (or enough!) carbon monoxide detectors. And this one comes with everything you need, including two AA batteries so you can put it to work right away. Also included are two screws and two anchors for hanging it up. There's a circular mounting plate that you attach to the wall with those two screws, and then the batteries are installed into an open compartment on the back of the CO detector (that section rests against the mounting plate, and the detector itself is held in place with tabs on the mounting plate, making battery installation and changes very quick and easy).The front of the detector has three lights  power, alarm, and fault  and a display screen, plus a test/hush button and a "peak level" button. As long as everything's okay, the green power button gives a quick blink a couple of times a minute so you know it's working. When you press the "peak level" button it lets you know the highest detected level of carbon monoxide since the last reset. In the event of dangerous CO levels, the red alarm light would blink plus the audible alarm would go off. "Danger" levels start at 30ppm, and how fast the alarm goes off is determined by how much CO it detects  if it detects as low as the 30ppm for 120 minutes, you'll get an alarm; higher levels would set off the alarm much faster. For example, 300ppm would trigger the alarm after just 3 minutes.It's recommended that you have at least one CO detector on each level of your house; in a perfect world, one in each individual bedroom.  And I definitely recommend this particular CO detector, in particular because of the peak level feature.I received this product at a discount in exchange for my honest review; all opinions are my own.

I was really looking forward to trying this product out  my husband and I like to do a lot of outdoor activities, and I thought this would be a good way to keep our phones charged up while we're out and about. Sadly, I could not get this charger to work for the life of me. So far I've only tried it with my phone (a Samsung Galaxy S6), but even sitting in direct sunlight, my phone never charges. I tried leaving the charger sitting outside (at the recommended 45 degree angle) on a bright sunny day for several hours, and still nothing  I don't even get the charging symbol on my phone. It's like plugging my phone into a charging cable that's not plugged into anything at all. I am going to have my husband give it a try this weekend and see if he has any better luck; if so, I'll update my review to reflect his experience.On the plus side (if I could actually get it to work): Since this solar charger comes with suction cups and carabiners (four of each), there are multiple options for places to put it (like attached to a backpack or suction-cupped to a vehicle windshield). A short micro USB cable is also included. The back of the charger has a zippered mesh pocket to hold everything it comes with  I can even fit my phone (a Galaxy S6 in an Otterbox Defender case) in the pocket and zip it closed. The charger itself is really lightweight (under half a pound) so it doesn't weigh you down if you have it attached to your backpack.But again, as I can't get it to work at all, for the time being at least I have to rate this a single star.I received this product in exchange for my honest review; all opinions are my own.

5:29 MinsThis was my first time ever setting up and using a dash cam, and I found it quite easy to do. It's basically plug-n-play, although I did have to track down an SD card, as that's not included with the camera. It comes with both a sticky-tape dash mount and a suction cup attachment, so you have your choice of where to put it. I used the suction cup, which has a locking feature that makes it very secure - I didn't even wash the windshield or get the suction cup wet before mounting, and it still stayed stuck to the window even when driving over cobblestones. The camera lens swivels back and forth with a little ridged dial on the side, and the display, while small, is quite clear. Also included are an extra-long USB cord and a cigarette lighter adapter, so you don't have *have* to have the camera fully charged before you take it out for a test ride.Once you turn the camera on, the interface is really intuitive. There are four buttons below the display - in rest mode, the first one contains all the menu options, the second one takes you to a folder of saved images/videos, the third one takes a still shot, and the fourth one starts the camera recording. There are a lot of features, options, and settings to play with in the menu screen,  everything from the standard date/time set and stamp to adjusting the white balance, color, exposure, ISO, etc. In record mode, the first button is "SOS" which will lock protect the section of video it's currently on (so that the looping doesn't overwrite the file). The second button turns the microphone off or on, the third button zooms in and out, and the fourth button stops the recording.When trying to review the dash cam footage on my computer, I couldn't get my computer to "see" the camera, but I just popped out the SD card and accessed the files that way. The recording is smooth and the video resolution is really good - if I were ever involved in an incident and needed to use the camera footage it would be completely possible to do so, as I could clearly read street signs and license plate numbers when playing back the recording. My only wish is that it would automatically save the recording in the event of an accident instead of someone needing to hold down the SOS button to save the file - but overall, for the price and quality of the video recordings, I'm definitely a fan of this camera.I received this product at a discount in exchange for my honest review; all opinions are my own.

2:45 MinsMy two-year-old son LOVES this train set! He's a big fan of trains in general, but a little too young (and destructive) for a standard train set. This beginner train and tracks is perfect for a train-obsessed toddler. This set comes with 12 pieces of track, four little ramp-thingies to support the raised sections of track, a battery-powered train, and some stickers (which I chose to leave off, since my son would just peel them off and stick them to the wall anyway).There are no instructions included, but you really don't need any - even with "help" from my little guy, it took under five minutes to set the track up and have the train making laps. (Using the picture on the box as a guide to which pieces of track go where is the key). The pieces each have tabs to connect them to the next section, although they don't "lock" in place, and the ramps serve a dual purpose of both supporting the raised sections of track and holding those pieces of track together. The train takes two AA batteries, and the battery compartment is secured with a screw. (Note: there's no gasket inside the battery door to hold the screw in place once you've loosened it, so be sure you don't drop that teensy little screw when installing the batteries!) The train has a simple on/off switch, but sadly no volume control. Oh well, the owner of this particular train is the youngest of four boys, so it's not like my house was calm and peaceful to start with! Once you turn the train on, it makes some impressively loud train sounds, the light on the front flashes, and the wheels spin to pull it around the track. It stays on the track perfectly, even around the curves and up and down the hills - until your toddler derails it. It can be a little bit tricky to get the wheels lined up with the edges of the track, so mom or dad will probably have to be in charge of putting the train to rights every time your little engineer takes it off-roading.All in all, I'd definitely recommend this beginner train set for any kiddo who's fascinated by trains - my son even set the iPad aside to play with this train set, so you know it's a winner!I received this product in exchange for my honest review; all opinions are my own.

I'm 5'10 and currently 6 months pregnant, and this shirt in a size XL fits perfectly. (I usually wear a large, but went up a size given my current "expanded" state). The drape of the panels on the bottom of the shirt are very flattering, and while it's still obvious that I'm expecting while wearing this shirt, I believe it'll do a lovely job of camouflaging my post-partum tummy in a few months. The bottom of the shirt hits me at hip length (though it should be mentioned that I have a shorter torso for my height).The material is very lightweight and breathable (97% rayon and 3% spandex) so it's comfortable to wear even on a warm sunny day. It does appear rather sheer at first glance (before you put it on), but happily it's not see through once it's on. I did wear a camisole underneath the shirt just in case, but even outside in direct light you can't see the camisole through the material of the shirt. It's labeled hand wash and line dry. You're also not supposed to iron it, but it doesn't seem to wrinkle (and I don't iron anyway). The material has a bit of stretch to it (the neckline does not, however), which makes for a very comfortable fit. The scoop neck is cut low enough to be flattering, but not so low as to be considered revealing. The quality of the shirt is top notch  well-stitched, no loose threads, no weird gaps or folds.I received this product at a discount in exchange for my honest review; all opinions are my own.

This is a great set of gel pens, with colors and styles for just about any art project.  I started using gel pens when I developed an interest in adult coloring books  they're more vibrant than colored pencils, and easier to use than even fine tip markers. They also don't bleed through like markers do.This set comes with TWO packages (identical) of 48 pens each; each package has four trays of pens in it, so they're somewhat sorted by style (standard, neon, swirl, glitter, metallic, and milky). Since you get two identical sets, it's ideal for either keeping one for yourself and gifting the other set to your favorite artist, or having backups for when your favorite colors eventually run dry. Personally, I have two teenage artists in residence, so two sets of pens means they both get a set of their own.Most of the pens worked right out of the box with no scribbling required to get them going, although a couple of them did take a couple of scribbles to get the ink flowing. The tips vary in size between 0.6 and 1.0 mm (depending on the pen style), and all of the pens in the package that I opened write cleanly and smoothly with bright, vibrant colors. Both the caps and the ends reflect the color of the pen so it's easy to find exactly the shade you're looking for. While I purchased these as gifts for my artistic teens, I'll probably be buying another set for my own personal use, since they work better than the brand I've been using.I received this product at a discount in exchange for my honest review; all opinions are my own.

I'm really impressed with these baby proofing locks  they're super for areas that are more difficult to childproof! I have four children, including a very curious and clever toddler, and another baby on the way, and I also have an old house with hard-to-childproof "features." For example, our kitchen sink is an old-fashioned porcelain cabinet unit, with metal doors in the cabinet portion. So I can't secure the cabinet under the sink (where most people, including me, like to store cleaning supplies) with standard cabinet locks  that are designed to screw into wooden cabinets. These cabinets also don't have handles that I can loop a childproofing latch through. I was seriously considering supergluing a hasp to the cabinet and padlocking it shut, and then I discovered these locks and decided to give them a chance first.I followed the directions on the back of the package and couldn't be happier with the final results. You can adjust the straps to the length you need by trimming the end. Once you have it set to the length you need (I left it as the length it came for my under-the-sink cabinet), you lock the black tab in place  I found it easier to tug up on the end of the strap to slide the tab into the locked position. The 3M foam adhesive tape sticks very securely  the packaging recommends giving the adhesive 24 hours to fully cure, but I was able to tug on the cabinet doors just a few minutes later and the adhesive didn't budge. Once you have it all installed, you just slide the tab on the other side open to release the lock, and push it down onto the base to re-lock it. And ta-da, no more worries about the baby drinking the dish soap!The package came with six of these nifty little locks, and there's no shortage of places they'll come in handy  locking the oven door, locking the refrigerator, locking the toilet lid I'm even planning on using one on the door between my toddler's bedroom and the bathroom as a back-up to the doorknob cover. These locks are terrific, and even if you have wooden cabinets, these ones are MUCH faster and easier to install than other child safety locks/latches I've installed before. I haven't tried to remove them yet (and won't be for several years), but apparently they're also easy to remove when you no longer need them just by heating the area where the tabs are attached with a hair dryer for a few minutes.I received this product at a discount in exchange for my honest review; all opinions are my own.

This is a great product, especially for the price. I've definitely seen lower-quality toys for much higher prices. My favorite feature is that you can easily control the speed on a "sliding scale" depending on how much power you want. The vibration speed is controlled by a ridged band at the very end of the battery cap, you just twist it to turn the speed up or down. It provides a surprisingly good range of power (from very low to relatively high) with just two AA batteries. I've not tested the waterproofing, but it does have a thin rubber gasket when you twist off the end to put the batteries in.I received this product at a discount in exchange for my honest review; all opinions are my own.

This is a great set of frequently-used essential oils  if you're just starting out using essential oils and aren't sure which ones will be most helpful for you, or if you want to keep a set of oils in a different area of your house, this is an ideal collection. It would also make a great gift for anyone who uses or is interested in essential oils, and the packaging the set comes in (a very sturdy, thick cardboard box with attractive graphics that's sealed upon arrival) adds to the "gift giving" attractiveness.Calily uses dark amber glass bottles with a screw-top plastic lid that's sealed upon arrival. I've purchased other oils where I could tell what was in the delivery before I even opened it because the scent "leaked" from the packaging; with these bottles, you can't smell anything until you actually open the bottle. Once opened, the caps screw back on nice and tight, with no leaks (of oil or scent) even if you store them on their sides. The bottles also have built-in droppers that are easy to use to dispense just the right amount from. Each bottle is clearly labeled with the type of oil inside.The oils themselves seem to be high quality, with lovely scents. My favorite is the lavender  lavender oil is what started my interest in essential oils, as I have a child with autism and his therapist used lavender oil as an amazingly effective calming technique when he would start to get overwhelmed. I'm also a big fan of the peppermint and sweet orange  a few drops of each in a diffuser helps energize you, which is something I'm in desperate need of! And the tea tree oil is great as a disinfectant and to help treat acne. A couple of the varieties in this collection are ones that I haven't used before, so I'm quite excited to expand my knowledge of essential oils and learn about the uses of the less familiar varieties.I received this product free in exchange for my honest review; all opinions are my own.

I have several portable power banks, and I have several external speakers. But this is the first product I heard of that combines both of those in one item. The PowerSource MusicStick comes with an instruction booklet, a USB cable, a cable with 5 interchangeable connectors (mini USB, micro USB, 8-pin/Apple lightning, 30-pin/MacBook, and what I have tentatively identified as a Nokia charger), and a handy carrying pouch. In terms of size, it's not very heavy (just over 6 ounces), but it's a little larger than a "pocket sized" power bank  you *could* carry it in your pocket, but not securely (and probably not at all if your pants have the typical stupid "girl pockets"  i.e. half the size of normal people pockets). The MusicStick is only 1.5 inches diameter but it's 5.5 inches long.The end of the speaker swivels (lift and twist) to allow access to the ports, which is a pretty nifty design. To charge it up, you open the end to expose the USB port and use a USB cable to plug it in to another USB port, like on an electrical adapter or on your computer. (This is a little bit different from most power banks, as there's no available micro USB port for charging  it's USB to USB only). When all the lights on the LED status bar are lit, it's fully charged. The audio jack is built right into the cap part of the MusicStick.The power bank portion of the MusicStick features 5200mAh battery capacity with a single 1A port and an output of 600mAh. My phone, a Galaxy S6, has a 2550mAh battery, so I could charge my phone from dead to 100% twice without having to recharge the MusicStick. It doesn't charge up my phone as quickly as other (larger and heavier) power banks I have due to the 1A port (instead of 2.1A) - according to my status bar, it would take approximately 38 minutes to fully charge my phone when the battery is at 82%, which is fine if you want to recharge the battery while you're sleeping or while your device is in your backpack or whatnot. And it'll at least slow the drain on your battery if you're using your phone (or other device) while it's plugged into the power bank. It works like any other portable charger to charge your device  plug one end of a USB cable into the charger, and the other end into your device. The interchangeable cable that comes with the MusicStick comes in very handy here, since you can swap out the tip to fit whatever device it is that you want to charge.As a speaker, it should first be noted that this is NOT a Bluetooth speaker  you have to plug it directly into your device's audio jack. The biggest negative, as other reviewers have mentioned, is that the audio jack won't fit if your phone has a thicker case (like an Otterbox) on it. Since my phone cost more than my monthly mortgage payment it pretty much never leaves its Otterbox, so I'll be sticking with Bluetooth speakers for it, but if your phone is naked or in a thin case you shouldn't have a problem. Basically, you need to be able to press the end of the MusicStick right up to the edge of your device where the audio port is. I have a small, inexpensive MP4 player for my kids that doesn't have a case, and the speaker works great with that. (I wonder if there might not be a way to add a short retractable cord onto the end of the audio jack, so that it might be pulled out slightly from the cap of the MusicStick, with the cord retracting back into the endpiece when not in use?) The sound quality is quite good and gets very loud. You need to turn up the volume on your device to get the speaker to kick in, but once it's going you can turn the volume back down if you want to and it'll keep playing.Another nice thing about the PowerSource MusicStick - I'm always on the lookout for products that will make great gifts  products that are not only useful, but also come nicely packaged, and this fits the bill for that. Overall, the PowerSource MusicStick is both convenient and cost-effective  it's less expensive (and much more convenient) than buying a portable charger and an external speaker separately. (I've seen similar power banks alone, without the speaker function, sell for more than this product). It would be great for either personal use or as a gift for someone who'd enjoy the convenience of having a power bank and speaker in one small package.I received this product at a discount in exchange for my honest review; all opinions are my own.

This hammock works great to contain my son's stuffed toys. Stuffed animals take up a lot of space in the toy box, so it's really helpful to have an alternative storage solution for all of his squishy friends. I really appreciate that this toy hammock comes with three hooks and three wall anchors, so it's ready to hang up as soon as it arrives. Installation is really fast and easy  mark the three drill spots, drill the holes, tap in the anchors, screw in the hooks, and attach the hammock. The edges of the hammock are super stretchy elastic, which is a feature I haven't seen in a toy hammock before. (The other one we have has canvas edges with no stretch to them). The elastic edging is actually really convenient, as it makes the hammock more versatile in terms of how much stuff you can put in it. As you add toys, the elastic stretches to accommodate the influx.The package insert includes installation instructions on the back for how to position it to prevent it from sagging and from toys falling out of it. The instructions recommend that the side hooks be installed 3.8 feet from the corner (minimum listed in the product description is 31 inches). As it turns out, my son's bedroom doesn't have a single corner that has 3.8 feet of space available on both sides due to doors/windows/closet. Therefore the picture I'm adding to my review is what the hammock looks like if you only go out just over a couple of feet from the corner. It's still perfectly functional, just not as secure at holding toys as it would be if I were able to install it per the instructions. I could still add plenty more stuffed animals to it as-is, though. We're in the process of setting up a downstairs playroom, though, and we'll be moving the toy hammock to that room  and installing it per instructions - once it's ready.I received this product at a discount in exchange for my honest review; all opinions are my own.

I love this two-pack of swaddling blankets - I'm expecting a baby boy in October, and we're setting up an "ocean" theme for the nursery, and these are a perfect addition! Besides the adorable patterns, these blankets are made of 100% muslin cotton, which I discovered with my toddler is the absolute best type of fabric for swaddling babies. This type of fabric feels "delicate" and is very lightweight and breathable, but also strong and durable  and can be machine washed and dried.I was also impressed with the packaging  you can't fully appreciate how high-quality the box that the blankets arrive in looks just from the product images. My first thought when I opened the package was that they'd make a great baby shower gift  the blankets are incredibly useful and adorable, but the packaging really sets it up to be a great gift. I actually plan to get another set to gift to my sister-in-law who's also expecting.The size of these blankets is great  at 47x47 inches (or just shy of four feet square), they're much larger than typical receiving blankets. The larger size makes it much easier to swaddle a baby (AND they have visual step-by-step swaddling instructions on the back of the box!) The combination of size and the lightweight material also makes them ideal to use as a nursing cover or car seat cover  or even as a light summertime blanket for an older child. My two year old is fascinated with the patterns on these blankets so he's currently using them  and this type of fabric gets softer the more it's washed, so they'll be extra-comfy by the time the baby gets here.I received this product at a discount in exchange for my honest review; all opinions are my own.

This is a very handy little water resistant (not waterproof!) Bluetooth speaker. With four music-loving kids (including two teenage boys) I'm always looking for creative wireless speakers to use around the house, both indoors and out. We've actually been using this speaker as an outdoor speaker instead of in the shower, because of one of the kids forgets and leaves it on the porch, it's not going to be ruined if it gets a little bit of rain or morning dew on it. (It's also pretty sturdy if a kid drops it, which is nice).This speaker from Perfect Life Ideas comes with mini USB and 3.5mm audio cables; the ports are located under a water resistant plug on the bottom of the speaker. It works as both a Bluetooth speaker and as an FM radio (you toggle between the two using the "Source" button in the center, and the indicator light changes color to indicate what source is active  blue for Bluetooth and green for radio). You can also answer your phone (and end the call) with this speaker.The buttons are pretty self-explanatory. To advance or go back one track (or go one spot back or forth in radio mode), you short press the buttons on either side of the source button; a long press with increase or decrease the volume. The top button will pause and play your music when short pressed, a long press will either redial the last number you called when in Bluetooth mode, or scan through radio stations if you hold it down (approximately three seconds  short press it when you find a station you like).There are also three different "where to put it" options with this speaker  you can hang it using the hook on the top, you can stick it using the suction cup on the back, or you can just put it on a flat surface  there are little rubber treads on the bottom to help it not slide around. We hang ours from one of the planter hooks on the front porch, but the kids have also stuck it to a window and the suction cup works very well. The Bluetooth range is quite good, especially in an open space (with no walls to disrupt the signal). The battery life is also impressive, it can go all afternoon and into the evening without needing a recharge.There are a couple of small things I noticed that kept me from leaving a five star review (at least at the current price point) - the volume level doesn't go incredibly loud, which is fine for us since we live in a residential area and this actually prevents my kids from annoying the neighbors with their music too badly, but if you're looking for a super loud speaker, this isn't it. The sound quality is also okay, but not terrific. It would also be helpful if there were a little display to show what radio station you're on when in radio mode  as is, you sort of have to guess until you get to a station you're familiar with, so it can be tricky to find a specific station.I received this product free in exchange for my honest review; all opinions are my own.

0:48 MinsThis is the third brand of diffuser I've purchased, and I have to say that I LOVE this one - it's definitely my favorite of the bunch. The design, the LED light band, the "babbling brook" sound, but especially just how well it works to diffuse the essential oils inside. (And really, isn't the ability to diffuse EOs the most important function of a diffuser?)The RiverRock diffuser is a bit larger than I envisioned it being - that's not a bad thing, just an observation. The larger size is actually good, because that means it holds more water than I'd expected and therefore will run for a longer period of time. It measures roughly 7x4.5x3 inches - although I've never seen an ostrich egg in person, that's the word that comes to mind in terms of size and shape.This diffuser comes with the diffuser itself, an instruction booklet, a power cord, and a small plastic measuring cup for adding the water. The measuring cup is a nice added touch, and one that I haven't seen included with other diffusers I've purchased. Operation is pretty self-explanatory, especially if you've used diffusers before. Lift the lid, add water, add a few drops of essential oils, replace lid, and turn it on. There's no power button with this diffuser; what you get is a sticker that says "Press Down Firmly Here" and that single spot controls all the functions. One push turns the RiverRock diffuser on with the LED light band cycling through the colors; a second push will stop the color cycling so it stays on one color; a third push turns off the LED light, and a fourth push turns the diffuser completely off. Once you're familiar with where to press, the instructional sticker easily peels right off.When in operation, this diffuser does an amazing job of diffusing essential oils. Its "reach" is a lot better than the other diffusers I own, with a stronger scent too. The cycling lights are very pretty - not too bright, but bright enough to clearly see the different colors as they cycle even with an overhead light on. And I adore the sound this diffuser makes, which is different than the typical diffuser sound. It really does sound just like water babbling over a stone-filled creek - a very quiet sound, but perfect for relaxing and falling asleep to. For that reason, this diffuser will be getting the "place of honor" on my bedside table. Being able to stop the LED light band on a particular color (like the soothing blue shade) or turn the lights off entirely also makes this an ideal bedtime diffuser.I received this product at a discount in exchange for my honest review; all opinions are my own.

There are few sounds more annoying than that of a single fly buzzing around an otherwise quiet room. Or the whine of a mosquito nearby as you're trying to go to sleep. I hate using a fly swatter because of the gross mess it leaves on whatever surface you swatted the bug against, and I'm pregnant so using any sort of chemically based bug killer is out.Now, I'm normally a pretty non-violent person, but I have to admit that I do get a sense of satisfaction about zapping a bug that's been stalking me. It makes a very loud "zapping" sound when it makes contact with a bug (just like if you have one of those hanging light style of bug zapper). The Electrocutioner is about the size and shape of a toddler-sized tennis racket, but definitely NOT for toddlers to play with. It takes two AA batteries (not included) that fit into the handle. The battery cover is the sliding type and doesn't require a screwdriver to open (another good reason to keep it away from kids, in case you needed another reason beyond "it'll zap you if you aren't careful"). I have NOT tested out the effects of the swatter personally (by touching the metal grid while it's activated), but from what other reviewers have posted (and from its effect on the bugs I've zapped with it), it packs quite a punch. I recommend that you keep this product stored in a safe place, where small children (or teenagers, for that matter) can't access it. I actually store it with the batteries out for safety reasons; it only takes a few seconds to pop them back into the handle.In addition to indoor bugs, I've also found this very effective for outdoor use  I like to sit on my front porch with a cup of coffee in the mornings, but the horseflies like to try to hang out with me.
