Because it only took me about 20 pages to be overcome by the physical need (NEED, I say) for pastrami. Real pastrami.This book will do it to you. Goodness, how I love it.NEW:All of that still stands, but this is really a lot more than just an ode to delis. It is also a wonderful history of delicatessens and their place in both Jewish and the larger culture. Sax makes some very serious and real connections between the state of the deli and it place in Jewish life and culture. As a goyem, I can only comment from outside, but having cooked at Fox Deli in Indianapolis for several years in the early 1980s, I was privileged to see the place of a great deli )okay, pretty good) deli in a neighborhood and a community. I learned a lot and picked up some great jokes, too. One of the things I learned was an ongoing and continuing love of kosher and kosher-style deli foods. (Here in Chicago, Manny's is what I imagine heaven is imagined to be for people who believe in heaven.)But I also became aware of how a deli can be a meeting place, unofficial cultural center and melting pot. Sax takes that and turns it into a tribute and elegy here. So while just looking at the cover does make me hungry, there is a lot more here than a travelogue and dining guide. Very much recommended.

In the seemingly ever-growing horror-mystery genre, this is a good one in the Silence of the Lambsish sub-genre. The premise is intriguing and the characters develop nicely over the course of this first collected volume. Not as gripping as, say, Bedlam, but not far from it.Only complaint is the rather ham-fisted imagery that routinely pops up in the transitions. After the first grisly murder scene cut to a close up of a ridiculously blood steak on someone's plate, that sort of thing gets a little old. Those of us over 14 get it.Small quibble, though, and overall an entertaining introduction that certainly creates anticipation for Vol. 2. Looking forward to it.

This is a wonderful reboot, a fascinating origin story, and an admirably original new hero. Others here has done a nice job of thumbnailing the story, so I will only add that as an old guy, who had been away from comics for a long time before slowly climbing back into them over the past couple of years, I found this remarkably touching.There is a warmth and joy here that is missing from much, if not most, of the superhero genre. The artwork works in concert with the text and dialog to form an organic whole that is uplifting, as well as engaging and entertaining. It's obvious to the point of cliche that there is still a dearth of interesting female comic character, but Ms. Marvel, as well as the recent reboot of Captain Marvel, is showing that this need not continue to be the case. Long may this young girl grow and bloom.

An interesting and mostly successful one-shot merging of Batman and A Christmas Carol.The art is lush and gorgeous. There is definitely a feel of an old Victorian Christmas card feel here, with some Victorian Gothic mixed in. A few of the interiors come dangerously close to Thomas Kincade territory, but manage not to fall over that cliff. All in all, lovely and lovingly-drawn and inked book. Todd Klein's lettering is outstanding, adding atmosphere while still being clear and readable.The story is, as a whole, surprisingly effective as an attempt to address the often overly grim Dark Knight mood. This doesn't bother following a specific continuity, but as a one-shot, that's no big deal, and probably a strength. It gives the story more of a individual feel that let's it exist on it's own plane. My only quibble, but it is the reason for docking a star from "love it" to "like it", is that in establishing the need for BM's enlightenment, Bermejo pulls him a little too far into the amoral vigilante role. Endangering the innocent child, as it plays out, is just a step or two too far. This doesn't bother me to the extent it seems to bother some other reviewers, but perhaps I take my comics and superheroes slightly less seriously.Still, as a whole, this is an engrossing and interesting take and with a new holiday season coming up, this is nice volume to find under one's tree or next to one's menorah.

Not a full-scale biography of this often-forgotten baseball great, but rather this is a vivid and fascinating thumbnail that illuminates his place in his times and cultural background. While hardly the first Jewish player in the major leagues, Greenberg was the first Jewish STAR in the major leagues, and as such, found himself in a unique and often uncomfortable place as both a very visible target for anti-Semites, and a repository of Jewish pride and ambition.Greenberg, by nature a modest and good-natured man, as well as a non-practicing Jew, faced this dual challenge with a shockingly admirable combination of grace and good humor, only on rare occasions showing any outward stress or anger. In fact, the portrait here is that of a gentle, if fiercely competitive man, reluctantly accepting the mantle of "credit to his race" by simply being a good man who worked hard at his craft.Kurlansky, who is of course the author of a great number of wonderfully readable books on a number of interesting topics, does a good job of showing how and why Greenberg was so important to so many people in his particular place and time. Highly recommended for baseball and cultural history readers.

I love reference books. They are the best for nightstand and bathroom reading. A good, solid reference on a subject you are interested in a wise investment in time and money.This new edition of a long-time classic is, as the past editions have been, a sheet delight. Like the old potato chip commercial put it, you can't eat just one entry. You will find yourself staying up later than you intended (or taking a lot longer to get ready for the day, etc.), but pfft. Who cares when a writer like Thomson is keeping you reading? He has not lost any of his edge, strong opinion, or ability to make you laugh out loud. If you agree with his take, you nod your head at his wit and incisive writing. If you disagree with him, all the better. It's still enlightening and more often than not, a hoot. Not just everybody is listed here, of course, but then, not just everybody deserves to be.Turn on the side lamp, adjust the pillow, and expect to be tired in the morning.

Nama here provides a great service to comics and pop culture fans with this thoughtful and concise look at black superheroes in mainstream comics publishing. Focusing almost exclusively on Marvel and DC heroes, he looks at not simply how those characters were portrayed and their evolutions (where such occurred), but also, and more importantly, how they reflected their times and how they were often perceived by readers, in particular black readers. He also follows those characters (where such did so) into television and movie representations.While he may miss a character here and there, this is pleasantly inclusive and, frankly, introduced me to a few characters I was previously unaware of, and his comments and conclusions are generally well laid out. There are a few awkward turns of phrase here and there, but overall this is well-written and the academic jargon is at a minimum. The book is quite accessible to the average interested reader. Recommended.

My girls are both ostensibly beyond the age-range for Peppa and her family, but them so I am. This doesn't matter. Peppa Pig is so charming, so delightful warm and breezy that it is hard for me to imagine much of anybody at any age not being won over after a couple of episodes. The secret, to me, is that gentle and friendly as they are, they are completely devoid of mawkishness and sugary sentiment.The humor is often sly, though never of the this-is-for-the-grown-ups-and-the-kids-won't-get-it variety. If you spend any time around little kids, you know good and well that there is a lot of overlapping sense of humor and Peppa does a nice job of this while never coming within miles of snark, sarcasm or mean spirit. Peppa and her family are, quite simply, wonderful.

Just finished the final three volumes in this series this weekend and these stars apply not only to this volume, but to the entire series. This is, however, a wonderful finish and may well be the best of the lot.While all six volumes can stand alone, they are all loosely interconnected and part of the same seedy underbelly of the same series. This one stands out, not only for its magnificent James Cain-like story, but also because of the introduction of some visual counterpoints to the usual (greatly atmospheric), claustrophobic permanent twilight artwork. The flashback interludes are both textually and stylistically funny in a darkly ironic way.All in all, count this as a recommendation for the whole series, if you like. This is top-flight graphic storytelling and taken individually or together, a masterpiece of modern noir.

Follow the advice of the other five star reviews on here. Lots of summaries and such here already, so just this:This is a chilling, mortifying read that will linger on in your mind and psyche. A masterpiece of unease.

Have not yet seen the movie, but confess that trailers for it are what made me aware of this. I like it, but cannot say that I love it. It certainly has a fascinating premise, but this is a case of the pace being a little too fast for its own good. The characters have promise, but none are developed very far and the transitions are, in places, so abrupt that a couple of time I thought I must have turned to pages at once and skipped one only to turn back and, no, it just shot ahead.I am curious, and liked this enough, that I want to check out Vol.2 once it hits TP. I think there is great potential here, but as it is, much as I like many elements here, I am slightly less than satisfied and hope that Vol. 2 will fill in some back-story and / or flesh out some characters.

I guess I'll split the difference here, star-wise. I really wanted to like this and have liked Azzarello on other books, but this just didn't do it for me. Some pretty interesting side characters are treated pretty shabbily here (not so much in the sense of how the Joker treats them, but rather how the author does). The book looks good as a whole and Mr. J is pretty effectively creepy throughout, but the story seems overly bombastic and off-track to me.I get the concept, and have no issue with that, and, in fact, really like the idea of this being told from the viewpoint of a henchman. Just not the execution. Would like to see what, say, Ed Brubaker would do with a similar conceit.

Pure and simple, this is a really fun comic series and story arc. The humor is genuinely funny, the action big and dumb and fun, and the interplay between Herc and Amadeus Cho is witty and touching. If this were a summer movie, I'd say two big thumbs up. Since it is a seemingly out of print comic TP, I'll just give it four stars as pure, unadulterated fun. Make some popcorn and enjoy.

Like others have stated here, there is, as a whole, so little on the Walker Brothers available, that even as I write this I am quibbling with myself over adding the fifth star. There is a whole lot to like here - I'm just not quite able to love. Anti-kudos first:Though it settles down over the course of the book, Reynold's writing style over the first few chapters borders on annoying at times, with what occasionally feel like pretentious flights of verbal fancy that fall short of their presumed target. As Nigel Tufnel once said, "There's a fine line between clever and stupid". Reynolds come close to that line a time or two too often in the early going.The other annoyance in the early going is the excessive quotation of Kim Fowley, a dubious source at best and once with no real connection to the band that I could discern beyond "he was around." His quotes are wise-ass, dismissive, and seemingly beside any point that I could see.Okay - now, then. This is also a very interesting and fairly deep look into the career and work of the Walkers, together and apart, up through the recording and release of Nite Flights, their final work together. While their solo work in this period is covered with equal depth, it ends there and makes only very passing references to Scott's pretty significant work thereafter. That's okay. That's not in scope, but for readers interested in his later solo work, we will want to look elsewhere.Not really a biography (the members' personal lives are treated very superficially), this is a very good dive into the songs, records, performances and recording. It sheds a great deal of light into the circumstances around the records and how, when and why they got made. For those of us who are Yanks, it is eye-opening to see just how massive their success in England really was. Here in the US, they were a British group that had a couple of big hits. In the UK they were major stars with a popularity that rivaled, and for a brief time, surpassed that of the Beatles.In all, this is a valuable book to have on the Walkers and I am certainly glad to have it. I do certainly recommend it. I just don't quite love it.Side note, for those so inclined: This is a beautifully put together book. The soft covers are high quality stock, brushed and handsome. The pages themselves are heavy stock and, though it doesn't say, I suspect they are acid-free as well. The saddle-stitching is first rate, using actual cloth thread. Compared to US mass market trade paperbacks, this is like a cathedral. I wish there were more photos (especially since several are referenced in the text, but do not appear in the book), but those here are quality reproduction with solid printing. Maybe I love this after all...

This is simply an exercise in comics fun. The Herc - Amadeus partnership is both silly and kind of touching. The storyline and dialog are entertaining as all get out, and the artwork suits the larger and goofier than life spirit here perfectly. This is a series for those times when all you want out of your comic is sheer entertainment. It is no small talent to deliver that, but Incredible Herc does. Vol. 2 also recommended.

Ed Brubaker has become one of my favorite comics authors in the past year or so and while I am steadily going through his back catalog, I am delighted to have picked up this new TP and get in at the beginning of the arc. This is first rate spy / espionage stuff and Brubaker, while perfectly wonderful with the superheros, really excels with crime and mystery. The canvas here is wider than, say, Criminal, but EB seems right at home. The story moves along at a rapid clip, the character of Velvet is engaging and the plot, while labyrinthine, is manageable. And very entertaining.The art, as a whole, is very strong and creates a nice, dead-of-night / sinister shadows mood for the dead-of-night / sinister doings. My only complaint, and a small one, is that some of the secondary characters are hard to distinguish visually. Of course, the fact that are all spies and therefore all trying to blend into the passing scenery sort of asks for that, but still, from page to page it can be disorienting as the story shifts in time and location, but all the spies look like the same guy.Not to nit pick, though. This is an intriguing start to a new series that I look forward to following as catch up on the others.

Great fun, for those of us old enough to have been around during these years especially. Was introduced to Kiss by a slightly older buddy around the time of Hotter Than Hell, and for a couple of years they were like a secret treasure. My first concert was Uriah Heep and Kiss in August of 1974. Pretty amazing for a 13 year old.Almost gave it five starts, but can't quite because of thinking about how much more fun this would have been if not an "authorized" book with Gene and Paul listed as co-authors. As it is, Peter and Ace both pretty much disappear around page 200 and only have brief quotes very here and there after that. And despite the appearance of candor, knowing how Simmons protects the brand, one has to simply imagine what got edited, cut, or left out altogether. Such is life. For Kiss fans from way back (and maybe others looking for a glimpse into the early days), this is still great, good fun: entertaining and a very quick read. And, I admit it, it made me pull out the first three albums again for the first time in years.

I confess, I was surprised to the point of near shock by how much I enjoyed this. As an offshoot of the WWH main story line, this is really an Amadeus Cho story more than either the Hulk or Hercules. As such, there is a lot more plot, character development, pathos and humor than in a sadly typical "Hulk Smash" story, which most of the other offshoots I've read are. As a result, this is much more in line with the feel of the WWH story in general. As a result, I am now looking forward to checking out the post-WWH Incredible Herc story arcs. Cho is a fun and very interesting character and it's nice to see a "hero" who glorifies intelligence and thinking.Seems to be out of print, but currently there are a number of reasonably priced new and used copies available here, and quite possibly your local comic shop, as well.

Have never used Elixir strings before, but likely will again. I like these quite a lot, actually. Cannot say yet, as others have here, that they are longer lasting than other strings - I simply haven't had them (and therefore haven't been playing them) long enough, but as someone who rarely changes strings unless they break or otherwise wear down, that would be a plus for me.I can say, though, that I like the tone and range on these, particularly the shimmering, clear highs. They give an overall very full sound that is welcome to someone like myself, who tends to play solo and likes a full-bodied sound underneath the vocal. They are also quite easy on the finger tips. Only complaint (for the moment) is that the feel is a touch waxy to me and, honestly, I like to hear finger slide, and these cut back on that some. I realize that for many this will be a good thing.Overall, so far, so very good. Will likely buy these in the future.

I loved Harlan Ellison when I was a kid and I genuinely appreciate that he brought a sense of wonder along with a jaundiced eye to my literary development. Some of his stories still rank among my personal favorites. Somewhere in my mid-20's I stopped reading him and moved along to other writers, other topics, other things.A couple of years ago I picked him up again to see what I thought 30 years later. Some good stuff here and there, but frankly, I found much of his work (including some that I loved back when) to be simplistic, kind of petulant, occasionally pretentious, and just not what I wanted to read anymore.Still, I picked up 7 Against Chaos. This is not particularly petulant or pretentious, but it is a mess. And not a particularly interesting one. The characters are lucky if they get two dimensions, the story is disjointed space opera, the artwork stagey and wooden. Lot's of 1950's sounding techno-gobbledygook-gook.Two stars because I just don't like it. Not enough here to make me hate it. Don't get me wrong on this point: I love graphic novels and comics. The format here is not the problem. I would hazard a guess that if the author of this were not "Harlan Ellison", DC would not have published it and it would have been another of HE's seemingly endless line of Edgeworks publications.While reading it, I developed a couple of alternate theories to go along with its alternate history:1. Artist Paul Chadwick sent Ellison the finished art and Ellison put in the text and "dialog" after the fact, trying to find a story to hang explain the pictures.2. Ellison decided to write a retro "gee whiz" space adventure and and wanted to finish before he went to bed that night.3. Ellison decided to write a parody of a "gee-whiz" space adventure, but lost interest after signing the contract, so had to furnish SOMETHING.4. Ellison wrote a synopsis of a "gee-whiz" space adventure and the artist mistook it for the full script, shrugged and made do.In any case, I found this dull, tiresome and, worst, coming from Ellison, uninteresting. Really, this isn't very good.

As should be fairly clear from the title (and if you are at all familiar with Marcus), this is not a linear history. There is no first-there-was-this-which-wasw-followed-by-that in this history of rock 'n' roll. Which is a good thing. There are plenty of those out there and a quick search here will lead you right to them. What we have here is an impressionistic snapshot of what rock 'n' roll is, can be and could be.Marcus' look at rock 'n' roll (not "rock") is, par for his course, thoughtful, thought-provoking, a teeny bit pretentious here and there, learned, intellectual and witty all over the place. Marcus chooses songs that, for him, express what rock 'n' roll is, and what it means, and uses them as a launching pad to look at how the music and has changed and how it has changed us; how it expresses and reflects the desires, fears, excesses, joys and howls of the women and men who made it, as well as those of us who listen to it and, it a real extent, live it.But this is not a ponderous book, by any means. We ponder, sure - the book is liable to prompt many self-reflections and barroom arguments among those of us who love and feel this music (that it's NOT for everybody is a given) - but it is in many ways a light and breezy read, even when it is discussing some (pardon the word) heavy stuff. While bits and pieces of this will be obscure to some of us (I was unfamiliar with a couple of folks referenced and will be hunting them up 'cause they sound interesting), the songs themselves are songs that most all rock 'n' roll people will have at least a nodding familiarity with. Some of the versions of these, not always so much, but then that gives me something to go hunt up and listen to. (As Marcus points out, thanks to youtube, virtually everything he references is readily available, if not necessarily in the the finest of formats for listening.)The one exception here is "Guitar Drag", which I had never heard of. It is the recording / soundtrack for an art piece / experiment that Marcus describes in detail, along with comments from the artist and Marcus' placement of the piece in much broader social, and artistic, context. I cannot say that I am in any great hurry to go hear it, but I AM glad that I know of it and read Marcus' essay on it.I am also glad to have read the rest of these essays. Which is, for me, really what they are: a mosaic of interconnected essays creating a larger image. Not all of it works for me (for example, I think the Beatles' Motown covers were almost all horrible - not a major point overall, but of interest to one of the essays here), but it DOES all make me think about this music I love very, very much, and that is a gift. (As is the Etta James - Beyonce chapter, which in a select three paragraphs within it says everything I think about modern pop vocal styling [and more].)Not for everyone, but then rock 'n' roll never claimed, or wanted, to be.

Fits as expected, which is to say that it is a bit large for my 6 year-old. That's fine - she can wear it an extra year. The shirt is well made and not one of those every-more prevalent tissue-paper grade T shirts roaming the earth. The graphics are clear and bold and so far hold up fine in the wash. Would buy from these folks again.

Seems to be well-made. It is very cute and the youngest daughter loves it. The sound is the genuine "Perry" sound (accept no substitutes!) which, no matter how we try, none of us can make correctly ourselves.
...loves it. Good quality shirt (not one of those paper-thin things many places have now), bright, clean graphic. Good Joker shirt for a younger kid - Jokery, but not too disturbing.

Four and a half, actually, but I suppose I ultimately "liked" more than "loved," but I like it a lot.From Brubaker, it is more noir than Lovecraft (and it is a little too easy - lazy? - to equate all ancient tentacled things with HPL, but there you go). Lots of thumbnails and summaries here already, so you don't need mine. Suffice to say that Brubaker has a great way with hard-boiled crime and the art here matches it very, very nicely.If any of the above sounds interesting, then you'll likely like this a lot.

Captain Marvel is becoming a must-read for me. In Carol Danvers, Marvel (in both senses) has created a vibrant, interesting character. DeConnick is doing a bang-up job making her complex and relatable, while remaining heroic. The Avengers story here is big, splashy fun, with Thor and Spider Woman playing the major supporting roles. Lots of action and lots of humor.But the biggest treat here is the inclusion of Captain Marvel 17, which features a good enough dollop of action, but is instead a smaller, more intimate story that shows off DeConnick's deft touch with characterization. Recommended.

I have been reading about polar explorations for over 20 years now and come to this very well versed in Shackleton and the Endurance expedition. I'm not sure what I expected from this, but I am increasingly enamored of :01 as a publishing house and thought that, at the least, this would be fun. (I have not yet read Bertozzi's previous book on the Lewis and Clark expedition.)I confess to being amazed here. Not so much by the art work, though the minimalist b&w suits the story very well, nor so much by the breadth and scope - this is very to the point; there is very little background or biography of any of the principals, including Sir Ernest. No, what amazes me is Bertozzi's ability to humanize the expedition, to turn these historical figures into people, and to do so with the simplest of touches.Rather than spend a great deal of space and ink on the "heroic" nature of the ordeal, he focuses on the personal and the mundane. Rather than paint in larger than life strokes, he presents us with a series of miniatures that illuminate these men and what their lives on the ice were like. Example: rather than provide a "tour" of the Endurance and provide "specs", Bertozzi uses an escaped sled dog's romp through the under-decks and a cutaway of the ship. We get the same information and sense of scale, but in a novel way that lets us relate to these men AS men. In this case, annoyed men trying to corral a runaway dog. It is touches like this that make this thin graphic work a valuable addition to polar literature.These touches do not in any way diminish the ordeal that Shackleton and his men went through. On the contrary, it rather ennobles them. They quickly become real to us. Not is a particular, biographical way, but in a personal-in-the-universal way. I am really very impressed with the achievement here.Certainly, anyone looking for the depth, details and inner workings of the expedition will find this wanting and will be better served by something like Huntford's terrific biography of Shackleton, or one of the many  available volumes recounting the plight of the Endurance and its crew. But this is a fine and true portrait that deserves attention not just from graphic fans, but anyone interested in the universal, human story as well.

Like a lot of people, I am really looking forward to a day when we can stop referring to important parts of American history as "Black" history and simply recognize that it is all "American" history. And while I'm not holding my breath, I hope that day is soon so that a book as wonderful as The Harlem Hellfighters will be read by a wide and all-inclusive audience. The book is wonderful fictionalization of an important event and people that is generally relegated to an afterthought or footnote. In that sense alone, this is an important work.That being said, and out of the way, it is also a terrific work of historical fiction where the words and pictures work together to create a seamless and moving whole.I have never previously read any of Brooks' work, though it has been recommended to my from time to time, but if this is any indication, I will likely be reading more in the future. This story is well-paced, involving - wrenching in many places - and his main characters live and breathe and never fall into  stock ciphers or cardboard cutouts.Which is also a reflection of the art here. The action sequences are suitably chaotic without ever becoming confusing, and the quieter moments are illuminating, as well. The details are telling and apt (a well-placed wink plays an important part in a character's development, for example) and the grim mood never becomes morose or bathetic.I am very glad that I read a review of this (in a different forum) that pointed me to this worthy book. I hope that this review, as well as the other fine and more detailed reviews here, pique others to pick this up and be transported into an important chapter of American history. Highly recommended.

Not a lot to add to the other reviews here except to say that I really enjoyed the focus on the Gordons in this terrific story arc. The increased gore level, normally not at all my cup of tea, didn't bother me so much since it was couched in a very human story that allowed the Commissioner and Barb to have some significant story time. The continued growth of Dick as BM is fun to read, too.The stylized art helped keep it from feeling exploitive, as well. Lots of other reviews go into more detail, so I'll not bother or bore, but I did enjoy this one quite a lot.

Maybe this would have made a better novella or short story, but this is the first time I've been disappointed with a Shirley Jackson novel.This feels like an early, dry run for my personal, hands-down, Jackson favorite, We Have Always Lived In the Castle: fading aristocratic family slowly goes mad in isolated mansion while the locals gawk and scratch their heads. Unfortunately, this is missing all of WHALC's incredible satire, dry wit and absurdist lunacy which, added to the genuinely creepy sense of foreboding, creates such a powerful, wrenching reading experience.Instead, here, we have a sort-of Importance of Being Ernest in a (very) private lunatic asylum.Basically we have an insulated group of crazy people wittily insulting one another while waiting for the world to end. And part of the problem is that they start off crazy and simply stay that way. The characters are all cardboard cutouts and they spend the length of the novel hurling dialog at each other that starts off wittily enough but after 20 or 30 pages begins to feel like Monty Python's Oscar Wilde sketch. That no one is particularly sympathetic is not really a problem - a lot of good novels have characters with few, if any, redeeming characters. The problem is that these characters have no depth to them.And then they go on and on for a couple of hundred pages.This is, of course, readable, because even mediocre Jackson is well written.Again, this might well have worked as a short story or novella. It might have worked if the characters were fleshed out beyond the placards they carry around (Hi. I'm the Rogue / Hi. I'm the spoiled, self-centered gold-digger, etc.). It might have worked if we were able to see these characters slowly (or even quickly) go mad. But instead they start that way and never develop over 200+ pages in which little happens except for the dulling of the witty dialog.If you are new to the magnificence that is Shirley Jackson's writing, this is not the place to start. This is for Jackson completists, after you've read all the great stuff.

I really like this new, rebooted All Star Western series. Bringing Jonah Hex to 1870s-era Gotham was a great idea and as the series unfolds, they are keeping it interesting and entertaining. The Hex - Arkham pairing was great fun, and Hex as fish-out-of-water in the "big city" presents a lot a fodder for its continued success. I recommend you start with Vol. 1, if you are new to this, but if you have already enjoyed 1 & 2 and want to see about 3, then here you go: You'll want this one, too.Docked 1/2 start for the absurdly silly-assed costumes all of the female characters are put into. I mean, jeez, really? Some of your readers are not slobbery little boys (or their overgrown counterparts).

As a kid and younger man, I always had a major gripe with the Who: namely Roger Daltry, who I found one of the most annoying singers of all time. Heck, he wasn't even the SECOND best singer in the Who.On the other hand, I've loved Wilko Johnson from the moment I laid ears on him.Therefore, I was a little hesitant to pick this up, especially as this is almost exclusively Wilko / Feelgood covers. I already have these songs in great versions. But I listened to a couple of tracks online and, well, here I am.Either I've mellowed on him, Daltry has gotten a lot better, or some combination, but he does a great service to these songs. Part of it is the naturally aging of his voice. It is tougher and yet more expressive here than in the old days, and is very well suited to the greatest-bar-band-around vibe here.Of course, Wilko Johnson has a lifetime of being in greatest-bar-bands-around, so he is right at home. So is the rest of the group here backing up these two old pros.And while it is true that I, and maybe you, already have great versions of these songs, and that as a result there is something essentially nonessential about this record, who cares? You don't have THESE versions and they are pretty great, too, and part of that greatness is the relaxed feel here.These are old guys who have been around pretty much every block there is to go around and they swing here with confidence and comfortable swagger. Johnson may still stutter-stammer his way around the stage and, for all I know, Daltry may still swing the mic around in big circles, but all youthful bluster, bravado and general frantic is gone. Now, those things fueled some damn great music in their day, that day is past for these guys. Nothing to prove, they do what they do, and love doing, with skill and passion. I'm happy to get out of their way, sit back, and have a wonderful time listening to them be who they are now.

For those of us of a certain age, this movie brings back a lot of memories. But there is more to it.This is the story of Terri Hooley and his Good Vibrations record shop in Belfast, which became the home of Northern Ireland's punk scene in the late 1970's, as well as the first record label for many of its bands. While, being a Yank and having  never set foot in Ireland, North or Republic (as yet, still hoping), I remember the bands and the music.Of course, if it were only for the nostalgia, then the CBGB's movie might have been good. Thankfully, what we have here is a wonderful story with engaging (and often maddening) characters, marvelous performances and direction and editing that capture the anarchic sense of both fun and danger that great rock n roll can inspire. Set down plop in the middle of the Troubles, fun and danger are both constant presences here, along with a look at the way that music can build bridges in the damnedest of places.I don't know enough of the actual, historical particulars to know how faithful this story is to real life, but then again, I don't care. The movie works as a movie and I suspect that the veracity is pretty close. I was also pleased with the way the filmmakers refused to tack on, or weave in, a happy ending, letting the climax be bittersweet the way life usually is. Hooley is presented warts and all, and if the character behaves badly in some (important) parts of his life, in others he shows a quiet nobility.The soundtrack is terrific and primarily features the bands the movie portrays (Rudi, the Outcasts, the magnificent Undertones' magnificent Teenage Kicks - still one of the greatest singles in r n r history).You don't have to have been there, nor do you have to be the right age, to find this a wonderfully moving, witty and in many ways joyous film. Go to it.

By now, if you are a reader of mainstream sports books, you probably have an opinion on John Feinstein. Mine is positive. I like his books, those I have read.And here is no different - Feinstein is a pro - he knows how to pace a book. He knows how to weave a number of stories together to create a big, nuanced picture. And he does so here, following a dozen or so ballplayers, managers and even an umpire through a year of AAA baseball, for the uninitiated, one step below the major leagues. But here is where the title really misleads.it is hard to imagine that there is much of an uninitiated audience for a book on AAA baseball and, as a result, most everybody reading this is likely to know most, if not nearly ALL of these names. The reason is that Feinstein isn't really looking at life in the minor leagues, plural, he is focused on AAA. And not only that, his focus is even more narrow - he is looking at players who are, for various reasons, caught in the revolving doors between the majors and minors. Anyone beyond the very casual fan certainly know the names of Scott Podsednick, Nate McClouth, Brett Tomko, Scott Elarton, Sam Fuld, and Brooks Conrad. They likely also know the names of Dan Johnson, Zach Duke, et al, that also play parts here. Sure, there are some names that would require a bit more specialized knowledge, but, really now. These guys would pretty much have to leave the world of baseball entirely to find a place where nobody knows their names. Don't know if the issue lies with Feinstein or Doubleday, but...Of course, the name doesn't really determine the quality and that is first rate. Feinstein has a terrific topic - what it is like to ping-pong between the Show and the not-so-show. The players here find themselves in AAA for various reasons: getting a little too old, having been injured a little too often, being not quite consistent enough, finding themselves one step lower on the totem pole than the newest phenom, the newest high-priced free agent, so on and so forth. For whatever reason, these men find themselves chasing their chance, or their next chance, or their last chance. Feinstein gives them plenty of room to breathe and tell their own stories and they are a sharp, fairly articulate lot. And they are representative of lots of other guys who are out there working their behinds off while being not quite young / healthy / consistent / good enough to make, or stay, in the major leagues.He follows his sources throughout the 2012 season as they come, go, come back again. A number of players make it up, for at least a little while, but nearly always end up sent back down. Only a couple stick and find themselves playing ball in September, and beyond. In the Epilogue, he gives updates on the players entering Spring Training 2013.And that is the reason for four, rather than five stars. Again, whether due to Feinstein or Doubleday, this books is coming out as Spring Training 2014 is coming to a close. Couldn't we have an epilogue that catches us up with them at the END of the 2013 season rather than the beginning? I can Google them, check Baseball Reference, etc., but it would be nice to know where they ended up in the follow ups, not just where they started. This may seem (and BE) a small point for most readers, and it doesn't really change the feel or thrust of the book - it IS a very good, interesting read and you cannot help but pull for these men as they continue to pursue their dreams to the end. But it would be nice to know how much closer they came in the last year.Certainly recommended. But with this one reservation.

As long as standardized testing is still a major scourge on the land, there will still be an audience for this book. This is good news for Farley's financial outlook, but kind of sad for the rest of us. No offense, Mr. Farley.The story here is equal parts sad, funny and scary as Farley relates a lot of behind the scenes stories of how are children are tested, evaluated, ranked and filed. Oh, and their teachers, too. And their schools. If you are anywhere near the fence on standardized testing, you ought to have a look here at how these tests are created, administered and graded.

Actually, that may sound like damning with faint praise, depending upon your view, but this is the first volume in a very strong Bruce Jones - authored story arc that smartly puts more focus on Banner and less on Hulk SMASH.I'm going to say my bit here, since this is the start, and not go into reviewing each volume individually. The story line throughout the series does meander a bit, and a couple of the volumes (esp. Vol. 5) are more or less self-contained and only tangentially connected to the overall story, but in all cases, this arc is interesting and entertaining as Banner flees from competing shadowy and powerful (and clearly darned-well funded) organizations that may or may not have government sanction. It gets pretty silly if you think too awfully hard about it, but is a great deal of fun while you're immersed. A number of old Hulk foes show up here and there throughout and there are shifting alliances as we go along.But despite the occasional "wait a minute, what?" moment, this is a terrific arc and explores Banner's life on the run in greater detail than is normally the case.It looks like all of these are out of print now, which is a shame, but for now they all seem to be available from various marketplace vendors, in some cases pretty cheaply. If you are a Hulk / Banner fan, this might just be right up your alley. And the truth is out there, probably, somewhere...

While I think I would change the subtitle, there is not much else I would want to be different about this gripping and fascinating look at the enigma that is Pete Rose. Not so much a biography, but rather more of an extended biographical essay, Kennedy's book takes a long look at the many things Pete Rose is and the many things that shaped him, in his life and in ours.Live most any baseball fan of my age (early 50s), Pete Rose has always been a major figure around the game. Growing up in Indianapolis, it was impossible not to be faced with him everyday during the season, and many during the off season. The Indianapolis Indians were the Reds' Triple A affiliate for most of the 1960s and 1970s, an being only a couple hours drive from Cincy, Indianapolis was big time Big Red country. Consequently, I hated the Reds, though I loved being taken to games at Crosely  Field, and later Riverfront. And during those years, no matter how great anybody else on the team was - and they had some great players - the Reds WERE Pete Rose. And so I hated Pete Rose, though I also kinda loved him. Even early on, I could tell that Rose was the kind of guy you hated unless he was on your team, then you adored him.And here, in this book, that plays itself out in large. There is much in Pete Rose to adore. There is much in Pete Rose to abhor. And that is the enigma. The only dilemma I can see, really is being torn over whether or not he belongs back in baseball and eligible for the Hall of Fame. And I confess, I am torn there. But in a sense, that is only a small part of both Rose and this book. This is a fascinating portrait of the man: gregarious and secretive; painfully honest and a proven bald-faced liar; a loyal, true-blue best buddy and a man who ignores his siblings and some of his children.This is a well-written, well-researched and very enjoyable read. I have not previously read any of Kennedy's other books, but I likely will now.I will go so far as to the clich that you don't have to be a baseball fan to find this book gripping and the man fascinating and infuriating. Of course, I AM a baseball fan and so Pete Rose and the one dilemma and the larger enigma do mean something to me that they probably don't to most people. So I will also pull back just enough to say that if you are eagerly awaiting opening day (about 2 1/2 weeks away as I write this), then you are likely to find much to intrigue and interest you here. And if you are of a mind to delve into a uniquely American tragi-comedy of a life, you likely will, too.

I enjoyed this a great deal. It is a lovely and evocative novel of love, commitment, obsession, divided loyalty, dreams, the lure of the river and mermaids. It is moving and wistful and really quite beautiful.As with the best graphic novels, it is impossible to separate the art and the, um, words. Here the two blend seamlessly to create a moody and somber work of mystery and revelation. It is a fantasy, to be sure, but very much an work of adult emotion. Many of the reviews here provide a thumbnail of the plot and setting and so I see no need to rehash. Quite simply: this is a terrific novel and a work of art worth exploring. A journey worth taking one's time on, like a steamboat on the river.

In the interest of full disclosures, I attended my first Pacers' game in 1969 and I followed last night's horrible Pacers loss online. So yeah, I'm a Pacers fan.Further, my mother worked for Bob and Nancy Leonard for a few years in the late 1970s and early '80s. I met Bob on a couple of occasions.So along with those, one last caveat: This book would have to be awful for me not to like it. And if that were the case, I simply wouldn't post about it. But here I am.I am partisan, but Boom Baby is a lot of fun. It is curiously formatted, with co-author Lew Freedman introducing each chapter with a thumbnail and then Bob reminiscing about the same time period in what seem to be more - or - less is own words. One does get the sense that his-own words have been cleaned up a bit for grammatical purposes and edited to make it a bit more family-friendly (hard to imagine that there weren't some tray expletives littered here and there in the original transcripts), but the voice is clearly Bob Leonard and if you have listened to more than a couple of Pacers' broadcasts over the years you can pretty much hear him saying it.And what you hear him saying is an informal story of his life and, for the past 50 years, the story of the Indiana Pacers.Of course, Slick did some living before he came to Indianapolis, and you'll hear about all of that, too. His childhood, his glory years playing ball at IU and then his all-too brief professional career (derailed by injuries). And all that is great.The meat of the book, though, is his life and career(s) with the Pacers. This is not a detailed history, of course, that we are still waiting on, but this will satisfy most Pacer fans with stories of the great ABA teams and the struggles of the early NBA teams. And Bob would know about both, better than anybody else.But as much as anything, this is a couple hundred pages in the company of an interesting, good-natured and pretty humble man who just happens to also be a basketball Hall of Famer - finally, at long last. And well deserved.I won't go so far as to suggest that this is the amiable memoir of a great national treasure, but he at the least a great REGIONAL treasure. If you are interested enough to be reading reviews of this book, then you will certainly enjoy the book itself.

Hawkman has had a tough time of it in the past 40 years or so - constantly having his story altered, his name changed, his true love taken away, then brought back with no memory of him, lots of bad writing too often eclipsing the good writing (too often ignored). Seems like the least I could do is pay tribute with this JLA Hawkman logo shirt. Well-made, well-fitting and stylish (within its limits, of course). Carter Hall or Kotar-Hol, either way, I'll testify.

Frankly, this may be more Superman - The Movie than most of us really need, considering the price and all the fun extra stuff that comes on these four discs, this is likely the one you'll want to go for.Picked this up recently and wanted to show my daughters (6 and 8), so I watched it again solo to make sure I wasn't forgetting something that was inappropriate for said ages. There isn't. And they both loved it when I showed it to them.And so did I. It had been a long time and I had forgotten just how good this movie is. Some of the effects are a little dated (though not nearly as much as you'd think going in) and the odd wardrobe decision is now brow-raising, but the story, the acting and the sheer fun and enthusiasm are first rate. In fact, I recommend this very much to those who get a little bogged down by the current need for heroes to be anguished and tortured souls. Not that there's anything wrong with that, but, damn, its fun to see a superhero revel in being one.The story, cast and direction are first rate. This is a classic and this set is a good way to revel in it yourself.

Well, like most of the superhero storybooks aimed at young kids and primary readers, the prose here is pretty leaden and, um, inelegant. Kinda dry.However, it is still useful, and I give it the four stars, because it is a decent primer of Marvel hero origin stories. One of the hindrances to those entering, or wanting to enter, comic fandom is the bewildering world of up to 60 plus years of backstory so many characters carry around with them. While some kids can and will jump right in and start swimming, others reasonably want to know, "Well, why does he...?", or "How come they...?", or How did she...?" For most of the major Marvel characters, this book gives you/them a quick story to explain why Bruce Banner gets big and mean and why Thor cares about us mere mortals when he could be relaxing on Asgard being fed grapes (or their equivalent).The art is nothing special, call it adequate. But if you have, or are, a young 'un looking to jump into the world of tights, capes and conflicted, if noble, ideals, this isn't a bad place to get the lay of the land.

"Today the people of North Korea are among the most desperately poor, hungry, and economically deprived on Earth.""The story continues. Economic collapse remain, famine haunts the land, and missiles still get lobbed into the Sea of Japan."Despite the occasional red-flagged story and "can-you-believe-these-Kims" internet meme, many, if not most of us, here in the US are pretty ignorant of the reality of North Korea. This is in part because almost nobody really has a good view of what goes on there (including those who are IN there). It is also because, sad, crazy and bewildering as it looks when we DO look, as a whole, we don't look often. This new volume gives us a chance to look a little more closely and thoughtfully, should we decide to.Caveats first:Minor: I read this in proofs, but even for a galley, there are an awful lot of typos and related issues. I will assume these will get fixed for the trade edition.Less minor: There is a great deal of repetition here that bogged down my reading.This is exacerbated by the overall construction of the book, with the author addressing topics individually through time, then circling back in time to address the next topic. While this does not hinder the individual chapters and subchapters within his topics, it does make it difficult to keep the timelines straight when reflecting from topic (say, economic developments) to topic (say, military developments). This has the effect of making the book seem evening more repetitious than it might otherwise be.Those aside, this is a strong, big-picture look at North Korea from Kim I's rise through the present day - or at least a close to it as we are likely to get considering the subject. While other recent books have looked at personal-level portraits of the DPRK and how individuals, mostly refugees and defectors, have presented their stories, this volume looks at the nation's place in the world, how it got here and where it may go. None of it is pretty.It is, in fact, both breathtaking and heartbreaking to see, even if the view is necessarily occluded, how a people can be so relentlessly abused by those who publically bellow about how they are creating a paradise. It's hard to gauge whether or not anyone at all actually believes it.But at some point, North Korea must be reckoned with. That it has not yet become a disaster outside its borders is hard to fathom, but what can be done to keep it from becoming one (at seemingly any moment) is even harder to imagine. That said, despite a few flaws, as above, French gives us a good place to jump in and see where things seem to stand. And from there we can begin to think about what the outside world may be able to do going forward. To do nothing is increasingly not an option.

This is on the short list for my favorite books of all time. Ingenious, sly, witty and laugh-out-loud funny every single time you read it. And the kids love it, too. And they learned some new vocabulary words.Gorey, in a nutshell, at his most sublime and wonderful.

Here in Chicago this book has taken quite a beating over the years since its publication. How dare anyone question the divinity that was / is Walter Payton? I can only imagine the hostility that will greet the first in-depth biography of Mike Ditka...And Payton really was something of a deity on the field - no denying. As football heroes go, he was about as football-heroish as you can get around here (or much of anyplace else, I suppose). A lot of fans reverently mumble a "hallowed be thy name" and that's that. But that also does a disservice, in many ways, to the real man who lived inside that hero. And Payton was a real man.To present the man in his complexity, with his not-always admirable behavior, is a service to life in general. One doesn't want to make too much of a person who's claim to fame is the ability to play a sport very, very well, but if you DO want to look at a man or woman who excelled at such things, then really look at them. And this book does.The Payton who emerges here is no less remarkable as an athlete, and his shortcomings and foibles do not render him any less admirable in his strengths and positives. This is an absorbing read about an interesting, flawed man. For those interested in his life and career, it provides three dimensions, not just the two you saw on the field. And part of that third dimension was pretty admirable, too; just not all of it.

It is hard to find fresh gooseberries here in Chicago and so one must learn to make do with canned much of the time. That being the case, in my experience, these are the canned gooseberries to make do with. Like all canned fruit, these are not as firm as you would like and they cannot create quite the same bite on the tongue, but they are flavorful and quite useful in baking. That will certainly do when I cannot get fresh.

For those of us for whom Wilco Johnson is an essential piece of Dr. Feelgood, well, this is IT. This is pretty much everything you need, outside of a copy of the documentary. Classic, amazing working-class Brit R&R / R&B, and nearly every track is a winner.I was about to type that this is also a great buy for those interested in the roots of the punk / new wave movements, but then thought that makes this sound like a historical document. While I suppose it is, in a sense, it is much more than that. This music is every bit as vital, powerful, fun and invigorating today as it was 35 years ago. It is timeless and it is great.
This is soft and comfortable, but not very absorbent nor quite large enough for my husband (6' 2" tall, 36" waist). Don't plan on using it as a towel.

You know how when you make a cocktail you have to get out a bunch of different supplies, hoping they're all clean? Not anymore. This shaker does it all. It reams the citrus (reamer is made of sturdy silicone), the lid is a jigger (1 oz and 2 oz labeled) and it's got a built in strainer and pourer. The stainless steel shaker is a large 24 oz and fits the hand nicely. This shaker looks gimmicky, but it works while taking up less space than all of the different components would take if you stored them separately. (My problem with gimmicky kitchen tools is that they take up so much space.)

This totally works to keep my brown sugar from clumping into a rock hard mass. This very sturdy container is BPA free and air tight. It has a clay disc that you soak in water and put into the lid to keep just the right amount of moisture in the box. Wonderful!
Even though the first ingredient is salmon, this cat food seems to have a lot of fillers. Unfortunately, my cat won't touch it, so it doesn't work for us.

This is very soft, comfortable and absorbent. The velcro holds tight -- it will not slip off. One size fits most. The body wrap has a loop so it can hang on a hook. Hair wrap works nicely, though could be just a bit thicker for my hair, but I appreciate how light it is.

I've got two kids in college and another who's now preparing for the SAT. We have always found the Kaplan books to be helpful. Kids will learn what's on the test, strategies for taking the test (how and when to guess, etc), reminders about shortcuts, and review of important concepts. The books assume that they learned the material in school and that this is a refresher/reminder. The practice tests (in the book and online) are helpful.This book is helpful because the SAT is changing and we didn't know what to expect for 2016.

Pros:Very strong and soft. Definitely premium toilet paper comparable to the best national brands.I love getting 96 rolls delivered to my front door. There are five people in my house and toilet paper is something we definitely don't want to run out of. When I buy toilet paper, it takes up half the cart at the grocery store. I love the front door delivery!Cons:The rolls are on the smallish size (typical roll size). I like bigger rolls so we don't have to change them as often. If that's important to you, this may not be the best choice.

This was fun at first and stretches the mind a bit, but it requires a lot of time for scoring each round and we got tired of that. The game is sturdily made and is probably best for certain types of people when they're in the mood for spatial contemplation.

This stuff is great looking cat food and I'm convinced that it's healthy and high quality. Unfortunately, my cat, who loves wet food, is not impressed. She won't touch the salmon at all, though she loves fresh salmon and loves other brands of salmon cat food. She isn't crazy about the other flavors, either, but she will eat them is nothing else shows up in her bowl. She much prefers Fancy Feast, so I'm going back to that.

The switch was very easy to setup, I just plugged it in in place of my old switch and all the statically and dynamically configured computers on the network were immediately available with the correct IPv4 and IPv6 addresses.The administration panel is full of features and works well. The download speed for large files is unmatched. I tested NFS file transfers that my old switch struggled to keep up with but this switch kept a constant 100+MB/s download. So it hit near 1gbps - even with NFS limitations.
I'm very pleased with these lovely earrings. They're very well made, solid and sturdy, but light on my ears. They're packed in a nice gift box. These would make a great gift.

My husband got this for his office which is small enough that when you go, everyone knows. This was becoming a problem, but Poo-Pourri solved it. Now, everyone is happy and nobody is being teased for dropping a "creamy behemoth" in the bowl.

These are my go-to stakes when my neighborhood has a vampire outbreak. They are exactly the right size and shape, the weight feels balanced in my hand, and I love the rough texture which allows me to retain my grip even when they're covered in gore. I also love that they come in packs of 12. Two packs usually do it for each outbreak, assuming that I've got a couple of vampire-hunting friends to help me. The price is reasonable, allowing me to simply discard the stake (burning is recommended) rather than try to clean it up for next time.

This flies well and is fun to play with.Here are some problems:This product is much much smaller than it appears here on the Amazon page.It's flimsy and cheaply made.Instructions are in Arabic (I think). Not English. So, we haven't figured out how to do tricks yet.Some of the items I was supposed to get in the box weren't there, such as the charging cord, thank you very much.Conclusion: Worthless.

This is a really beautiful large men's watch. I got it for my son who's 6'4" tall and likes to wear a wristwatch. The one he was wearing before looked too small on him. This is quite heavy and sturdy. I love the dark face and the gold highlights.There are some features: time zones, stop watch, date, but the best feature is just that it's lovely.

I'm very pleased with this. I own several, but this is my favorite because of the size and shape. It can easily be slipped into a pocket or purse, which is much better than the more boxy types I own. It will charge up my Samsung Galaxy phone one time. There's a short cord that has a USB on one end and micro on the other so that the same cord can be used to charge the power pack (by wall outlet or computer) and then reversed to charge the phone. It does not come with the part that connects to the wall socket, but you already have one of those.I also think this is a great price.

The sound on these is very good and they cancel out noise well. My husband can hear his music above the sound of the lawnmower. However, they are uncomfortable for him. They dig into the ear canal. Also, in case it matters to you, they can't be worn while lying down because the back presses against the pillow (or whatever you're laying on) and pop the earbuds out of your ear. These have limited value for us and do not seem like they're worth the price.

My two daughters (13, 10) have been playing with this every day for a week. They're having a lot of fun with it. The kit is very basic but it's a good starter kit. There's an instruction booklet, quite a bit of glycerin soap, measuring spoons (cheap plastic), molds (cheap plastic), and some cute gift boxes for gifting the soaps.I was pleased with the amount of soap offered and the recipes and instructions. I also like the quality of the soap my kids have made for me. Many of the molds, however, are too small. I think we'll be visiting a hobby shop soon for better molds, or finding something around the house that works better. Any ingredients you need will be found at a hobby shop, so it's easy to replenish supplies.The advantage of buying this set is that it's an inexpensive way to see if your child enjoys soap-making. Then you can move on to something more elaborate. My daughter and I have signed up for a local soap making class.This would also make a great gift for a child who hasn't yet tried soap making.

These are nice large thick fluffy towels. They're not the most luxurious I've ever encountered, but they're on the higher end. You wouldn't be embarrassed to have these in your guest bathroom. (I tend to give our better towels to guests.)So far they've washed well and haven't faded. I will update this review if there are any problems.

Net Nanny does not close open internet connections. How is supposed to help you regulate time on the internet? It only blocks new connections. Not good enough. Net Nanny would not refund our money even though it doesn't do what it said it would do.

Net Nanny does not close open internet connections. How is supposed to help you regulate time on the internet? It only blocks new connections. Not good enough. Net Nanny would not refund our money even though it doesn't do what it said it would do.

Net Nanny does not close open internet connections. How is supposed to help you regulate time on the internet? It only blocks new connections. Not good enough. Net Nanny would not refund our money even though it doesn't do what it said it would do.

The sleeping bag is quite comfy and large enough to fit a 6' tall person with a few inches to spare. It is very warm, despite being relatively light. The only significant downside is that it is somewhat large - normal size for a sleeping bag but not an ideal choice for backpacking. It would have received 5 stars if it were a few inches smaller in diameter.It's well constructed with a nice double-sided zipper and a hood that cinches or can be used as a pillow. It's tight against the wind. The stuff sack is just a nylon sack.
This is a very nice basic men's shaver that's perfect as a starter for my teenaged son. It's simple and easy to clean and does a good job. No frills, fairly priced. Recommended.

So far we love this machine. It's a large heavy nearly commercial quality espresso maker. It took several trials to get things right, but the manual is very helpful and gives detailed instructions and tips. For example, explaining exactly the amount of pressure to use to tamp down the coffee grounds so that the water flows through them evenly. It explains the necessity for this and many more specific behaviors. There are a lot of factors that go into a good cup of espresso or cappuccino and it takes some time to learn how to get it right.The machine is loud. It sort of sounds like a Nazgul screaming, or Dementors sucking out someone's soul, but that's fine. I now associate that sound with the imminent arrival of a delicious cappuccino rather than my imminent death.It's a little difficult to wash some of the parts because the steam milk splatters. Just be sure to wipe it up right away before it dries up.My family of five has been drinking lattes and cappuccinos, and making them for friends, daily since we got this. If we have any trouble with the machine, I'll update this post. If it's been a while, feel free to leave a comment if you're wondering whether it's still working. I'll reply. I know that the reliability has been an issue with this machine, according to other reviewers.

This FlexBrew system has lots of nice features that are missing from my previous K-cup maker (which was much more expensive). First of all, it can do both K-cups and ground coffee, which I LOVE. It's a lot cheaper to use ground coffee than the K-cups, and I already have the coffee beans, which means I don't have to buy something special for this machine.Another feature is that it makes a larger cup of coffee (more oz) than my expensive Keurig brewer. THat one didn't even fill up a normal sized coffee mug when it was on the highest setting. I hated that.I love that this one has a removable platform so that I can put my tall travel mug there. Awesome.The reservoir is nice and large.Here are a couple more differences to note:The Keurig is ready to make a cup at any time, unless the water is low. It keeps a constantly hot reservoir so that a cup can be made immediately as long as the machine is kept on. This machine has no such option (or at least it doesn't make it clear if it does). It takes a few minutes for it to heat up, but you can walk away as long as your cup can fit all of the liquid.- On that note, this machine's options are significantly less clear than the Keurig's. It's harder to operate and clearly not as well thought out as the Keurig's interaction. I had trouble getting the programmed oz settings to work as expected (multiple cups nearly overflowed) and I think it's due to fact that each setting can be programmed. I haven't been able to find a way to reset the programming on it, either.That being said, the Keurig 2.0 has no way to use ground coffee so I've replaced it with this machine.

I love this so far. I'm using it to scare off raccoons from our back porch. We feed a stray cat on the porch and every night the raccoons arrive and eat all the food and sometimes even carry the bowls away. They make a huge mess on the porch. So, I put this motion-detecting light out there, right next to the food. haha. Now, when the raccoons arrive, the light turns on and off they run. hahahaha!So, yeah, it freaked the cat out at first, too, but after only a day she adjusted and will come eat the food even though the light is on. Good kitty. Raccoons still stay away. Good raccoons.The LED light takes 4 D cell batteries and doesn't require wires. I just set it right next to the food, but you can mount it to a wall or wherever. It swivels and adjusts so you can aim the light wherever you want. It's hard enough to adjust that it stays where you want it. It's not going to swivel away from where you aim it.Also, the light doesn't come on during the day because it's photosensitive.It's fairly bright, but it isn't going to light up 20 people at your midnight barbecue by itself.

So far I love this steam mop. It was very easy to assemble (my 13 year old daughter did it). Once you put the water in and turn it on, it heats up extremely fast and is easy to use. It does a large room without needing to be refilled. There's a brush on the back for scrubbing, if needed. It comes with two washable pads so that you can change the pad out after it gets dirty. My tile floor was clean after using the mop.Attachments allow you to scrub grout or non-floor items.Only negative so far: If you turn the mop off and back on, it is ready to go immediately, but if you unplug the mop and plug it in again somewhere else, it requires a few moments to be ready again.Added bonus: my cat loves the long box that the mop comes in. She thinks it's a great hiding place.I have had several of these types of mops that broke after a while. If that happens to this one, I'll edit this review.

I just love the idea of being able to stand up these cooking utensils because I hate laying utensils on the counter and I don't want to use a spoon rest because that's something else that has to be washed and take up counter space. I love these utensils for that reason. I also like that they're solid, sturdy, heavy, and great quality. My only complaint is that the stand makes them a little awkward for the drawer I keep them in. They take up twice as much space as a utensil normally would. I guess you can't have everything, though. It's ironic that the very thing I love about these is also the thing I hate. I guess that's MY problem.

This does control the frizzies in my wavy frizz-prone hair. Use only a tiny amount, though, as it can be greasy if you use too much. It smells nice and my hair feels softer after using it. I have another product that I like a little better: Citrseal. By reading reviews, it seems to me that everybody's hair is different and what might work for one person might not work for another. I'd suggest trying both this product, though. It's a very good one.

After years of searching, I have finally found the best beef base and chicken base products. Both the beef and chicken base have meat as the first ingredient. They are rich, intense, and taste exactly like the should. There is NO MSG!

This little feeder is such a great idea. It's wonderful for my office window. I can watch the birds while working at my desk. The cat loves it, too.It's small, so you'll have to fill it often, but I guess if it was any bigger, the weight of the feeder and the seed would be too much for suction cups...

Head & Shoulders has been my preferred shampoo for many years. It works well on my dry scalp, cleans my hair nicely, and leaves it feeling full. This new version has a very light pleasant citrus scent. It's thick and rich and does exactly what I expect H&S to do. I like this new scent quite well. I also like the large bottle that's flat on top so I can store it upside down when it gets low.

I received this as a Vine product for review. I have a problem with it because the instructions don't tell me how to hook it up with my particular system. There are the wrong number of wires. I will attempt to find the information online so I can properly review this product. I'll edit this review when I do that. It is due, however, so I needed to turn something in.

This product is 2% salicylic acid which, according to experts, is the best thing to use. I like that it has a nice citrus smell (doesn't smell like an acne product -- gosh, I hate the smell of Clearasil). This also does not bleach any fabric that might touch your face such as towels and sheets, unlike benzoil peroxide products.
TASTES LIKE CHICKEN!Seriously, it tastes like chicken. Best chicken based product I've ever tried, and I've tried many.

My family has played SET for years -- it's a great game that's easy to learn, fun to play, and versatile. My favorite aspect of the game is that we have a large range of ages in the family and everyone can easily learn and understand the game and find it challenging. Usually a game that's challenging enough for an adult will be too hard for the youngest child (and vice versa). But SET works for everyone.We've played the card game for years. This dice game is a nice twist. I love that the diced are solid and indestructible. Also, it's harder to lose the pieces than with a card game. There are also a couple of new games based off the original that work better with dice than they would with cards (because of the shape). You could make up new games, too. I also appreciate that the box is as small as it can be. So many games are in boxes that don't need to be so big. They just take up too much space on the shelves.

Time for the SAT again. Ugh.This is my third child taking the SAT. The first two did very well and got into the college they wanted to attend. I think the most important thing, assuming they've had a decent education up to this point, is to practice, practice, practice.This book, like many others of its type, will definitely help. I like the fact that it's a paper book and I can observe my son studying it. I like that it has practice tests and even online tests that can be graded online so kids can get feedback about their performance. The book contains explanations for the answers, too.I like the structure of the book and that it has chapters such as "How to Avoid SAT Math Traps" where it gives sample questions and what you're likely to do wrong. It also has tips from kids who scored perfect scores. Example: "Memorizing special right triangles is definitely worth the effort. They come up frequently in geometry problems, so don't waste time working out all the sides and angles for every question."Besides the information in the book, there is a CD with tutorials and links to a lot of online help. There is so much in this book that it will go a long way toward SAT prep. I doubt that anything else will be needed.

Head & Shoulders has been my preferred shampoo for many years. It works well on my dry scalp, cleans my hair nicely, and leaves it feeling full. I love that they're now giving us different scents. This one is supposedly "manly" but I'm a woman and I'm using it on my hair. So far it has not caused me to sprout hair on my chin, nor have I snatched the remote out of my spouse's hands... yet. This shampoo is thick and rich and does exactly what I expect H&S to do. I also like that the bottle is flat on top so I can store it upside down when it gets low.

Head & Shoulders has been my preferred shampoo for many years. It works well on my dry scalp, cleans my hair nicely, and leaves it feeling full. This new version has a very light pleasant coconut scent (not fake and strong like suntan oils). It's thick and rich and does exactly what I expect H&S to do. I like this new scent quite well. I also like the large bottle that's flat on top so I can store it upside down when it gets low.
